This stylistic choice felt more akin to a children's movie than the gritty dystopian atmosphere I had come to expect from the series.The narrative's conclusion felt ambiguous and somewhat unsatisfying, leaving several questions unanswered. Additionally, I found it challenging to establish a deep connection with the characters, which impacted my overall engagement with the story.In summary, while 'The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes' showcased some interesting concepts, it diverged significantly from the tone of its predecessors. This departure resulted in a film that, to me, felt average and slightly disappointing. Despite my love for the series, if given the choice again, I might hesitate to watch this installment. It's a film that might intrigue fans curious about a different take on the Hunger Games universe, but it may not resonate with those seeking the intensity and drama of the original trilogy.

title: Character motivations and actions are nonsensical
text: If the hunger games was all about fascist myth making and how people just come to accept it as the new way of life, why would the protagonist be less angry 10 years into the new order than 75 years? When injustice is a new, people are supposed to be more angry, less accepting of it. Katniss was appropriately angry and defiant, whereas Lucy Gray was immediately giddy (i guess we are meant to interpret it as hippie freespirit i-love-all-peoples charm), and flirting with an agent of the state that has literally reaped her into an arena to kill her. Think of how much it would take to justify why a Jewish girl might even consider thinking of an SS soldier in a romantic light, and how little this story did to that end. The trust and romance between two characters from opposing sides of a fascist occupation has to OVERCOME that very tall barrier to earn any Rebel's trust. However even though the fact that Snow is doing it for personal gain was established, it was kind of ignored to continue this bizzare unearned romance.I am also okay with the premise that not every person in a fascist system is born evil, and showing the descent of a regular citizen into this kind of evil. However, living and participating every day in a fascist state has to impact your soul that ends up showing in small ways, casual dehuminisation of the Panem citizens, growing paranoia as the bombs start, disdain for the rebels etc. Which other characters in the academy and Grandma Snow does. But exceptionally, Snow was shown to be upstanding and moral throughout the movie except in the end with a abrupt descent into betraying his friend, all the while romancing a Panem citizen outside the district borders. It was so forced, and why?? We already knew that Snow would become evil, so why not show us how it happened in a believable manner (maybe show that his time as a peacekeeper interacting with D12 citizens allowed him to dehumanize them or something..), instead of rushing it as a "twist" at the very end of a very long movie? Every story in THG was a self contained plot that will be developed upon it, but this one felt like a botched incomplete story to that is built as a premise for sequels to the prequel.

title: A good origin story
text: While I didn't read the book, and origin stories aren't typically my thing, this movie managed to strike a chord with me, largely thanks to the heartfelt performances of Tom Blyth and Rachel Zegler as Coriolanus Snow and Lucy Gray Baird. Blyth nailed the portrayal of a young Snow, adding layers to the character, while Zegler's was rapturous as Baird.Despite the commendable performances, the storyline lacked the depth needed for a more fulfilling experience. As a result, while I appreciate the leads for making the movie memorizing, I can't shake the feeling that the overall story could have been more robust. Hence, my rating stands at a 7.

title: This gave me those Game of Thrones vibes - the good ones
text: Went into this without having read the book, so this isn't your "But the book is always better" review.Was genuinely surprised by how well this movie turned out to be, albeit with a few pacing issues here and there.It has got your good ol Hunger Games in there which take up about a third of the movie with the around bit being the actually interesting part. How Coriolanus Snow became who he is with a lot of politics, intrigues and lore surrounding Panam. Made for an amazing and very enjoyable ~3hr watch.Although you could really feel that they did rush the plot in the movie, there's too much to tell the viewer in this movie format. A (mini) series might have been the better choice.

title: Where the original trilogy failed, TBOSAS succeeds
text: As a fan of all four books, I felt that the original trilogy missed the mark at many moments and overall could not deliver all of the things that truly made the books great.This movie however, succeeded.Although much of the movie is condensed due to time constraints, I felt that this adaptation still preserved every important beat of the story and the tone of almost every scene. At the TBOSAS core, it is a story about Coriolanus' view of humanity and him ultimately coming to the conclusion, as is the point of the games, that humans are inherently evil and the world is cruel. In a cruel world with malevolent beings filling it, why not be the man in charge? Why not be cruel right back to the world and kill and starve others? This story shows Coriolanus get to this state of mind, however misguided his cognitive journey may be. It is the story of a man losing any semblance of morals he had and losing his own humanity in order to become the powerful villain of the main trilogy. 100% worth the watch (even if you did not read the book).

title: This is somehow less likeable
text: The tributes pictured to be willingly killing each other without any meaningful explanation. Even the lead character Lucy could just let a sick girl drinking a poisonous water without doing anything even though the arena was clear, in my opinion at least.We are supposed to have something to hold on to when watching this, and I don't supposed it could be those mentors, who could just stand still seeing everyone killed each other as a career without no remorse.I remembered the passion watching Hunger Games came from Katniss' spirit of fighting, and also her compassion. Even at the most desperate moments, she still tried to find a way to save the one next to her. I think that's what make the horrible games could light a bit of hope.But in this movie, it just became meaningless. I don't think the singing at the end of the game could turn us to be more sympathetic. I don't know whether the games itself were designed to be more underrated in this franchise, but the characters themselves didn't exactly try to make us root for them.And also the sequence somehow didn't make sense, how could one fall in love easily with someone who just watched her fighting over her life the whole time? Not to mention to be a watching material by the whole nation.. At least there should be a little grudge or hate emotion at first, but no... Lucy and Snow seemed not to be able to keep their eyes off of each other from the very beginning.At least for me, it just made the story less natural, it seemed to be forced to fit the purpose of Snow and the plot just made it become less likeable from the start. It was supposed to be a heroic fight (games), instead we were served with typical teenage romance.

title: Can someone explain to me why Snow and Lucy Gray turn on each other and why Snow turns to extreme evil all of sudden?
text: That's the whole point of this prequel, Snow's transition to embodiment of Lawful Evil, isn't it? 'The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes' should have been a series rather than a 150-minute movie. Francis Lawrence has so many things to tell and maintains the pace of the story, but at the last minute starting from 'Part 3: The Peacekeeper', he crams all those and develops so hastily that I am short of breath just by watching. What's with all the sudden change of emotions from all characters and rushed progress of plot? It loses all coherence and logic along the way.Ironically, this film makes me realize that Jennifer Lawrence, Josh Hutcherson, and Donald Sutherland trio is the best you can ask for. Lawrence and Hutcherson were about the same age and had similar duration of acting experience as Zegler and Blyth when they started the first movie of the Hunger Games franchise. They were brilliant and passionate afresh. Zegler's performance is especially disappointing.However, just like any other Hunger Games, the film offers exciting and spirited adventure, drama, and energy. The plot development for Part 1 & 2 is not bad.

title: Snow was the only redeeming factor of this film
text: Was this a worthy prequel? No. How many times did I check the time throughout? Around 20. Unbelievably slow and boring. Lack of chemistry between 'Lucy Gray' and Snow, was genuinely quite confusing watching their relationship. Why did Snow turn evil? Actually unsure. So many plot holes. The hunger games were extremely hard to watch, so gory and unnecessary. Could not stand Lucy Gray as a character, she weirdly kept breaking into song. NO comedic relief whatsoever. All characters were poorly developed, and for the most part unlikeable. Costume design felt really poorly executed, all of the costumes for the 'poor' felt very inaccurate, looked like they had gone to a fancy dress shop and asked for Aladdin clothing. Also why was Lucy Gray playing what looked like a very expensive guitar. Extremely inconsistent as some parts felt modern and some felt extremely old- fashioned. The 3 parts to the movie were poorly split and it honestly was so long for really nothing much to happen, was very choppy. Only good part was Snow being extremely hot.

title: High expectations and not disappointed
text: First off- the initially mixed reviews on this shock me. I am admittedly a large fan of the first four movies, which is why I was equally as excited and scared to see this film. It did not disappoint. Excellent plot throughout, and it did an amazing job translating the book into a movie. If there was anything negative to say it would be I wanted a little more backstory, but I still thought every character was great and well acted. From start to finish it doesn't have any weak moments, and each scene feels like it has a purpose. This installment connects well with the other four movies, and honestly I just hope we might get a another at some point in the future.

title: "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" is a film that shows promise but delivers inconsistently.
text: "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" sparked a buzz of excitement among fans when it hit screens in 2023. Directed by Francis Lawrence, this prequel takes us back to the grim universe of Panem, zeroing in on the early days and transformation of the infamous villain, Coriolanus Snow.The star-studded cast is without a doubt the film's shining glory. Viola Davis, as the fearsome game-maker Dr. Gaul, and Peter Dinklage, as the tired and corrupt Dean Highbottom, deliver performances that are both gripping and nuanced. Despite some off-screen drama, Rachel Zegler shines through with undeniable talent in her role as Lucy Gray Baird, the tribute from District 12.However, the film isn't without its flaws. The pacing is all over the place; the movie tends to drag on at times with lengthy dialogues and expositions that disrupt the flow, making it less engaging. The film also struggles to deliver clear thematic elements. The exploration of power, privilege, and moral decay gets lost in the expansive plot and a large roster of characters, leaving audiences with a jumbled mix of messages.Fans of the "The Hunger Games" series will find parts of the prequel enjoyable, especially the trip back to the well-loved world of Panem. But, it does raise questions about whether this deep dive into backstory was needed. The movie starts with a strong premise of showcasing the rise of a great villain but loses steam as it progresses, watering down the impact of Snow's transformation.While the plot is solid and could stand alone, the narrative stumbles in its attempt to meet its lofty goals. The screenplay also occasionally lets the film down. Some attempts to capture the depth and grandeur of the original material fall short, leading to scenes that feel forced and, unfortunately, that undermine the overall impact of the film.In short, "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" is a film that shows promise but delivers inconsistently. Despite some stellar performances and a compelling story, it's let down by its pacing, muddled themes, and a screenplay that doesn't always hit the mark.

title: IT WAS SO GOOD OMG
text: The hunger games is movie series that I am obsessed with. I thought that movie was gonna unnecessary but now My perspective on the entire movie series has changed. Especially the last scene gave me goosebumps. It was a masterpiece like other movies. I think the movie deserves at least 8. If you don't like it, I think it's because of the "original is always better" perception. Of course, the first movies were better for me, but this movie was a good ending to the series. And now I think that snow is not pure evil. I wish they hadn't made him look so disgusting in the previous movies. Of course, the girl in the lead role was not a Katniss Everdeen :) I'm gonna miss this movie so much.

title: Quite good prequel despite some slowness
text: First of all, the acting is really successful and they play their characters very well. In addition there are beautiful settings throughout the film as well as costumes which sometimes fit perfectly with the nature and character of the characters, in particular the different looks of Lucy Gray Baird correspond well to her rebellious and extroverted nature.However, the warrior spirit of Katniss, absent in the film due to the time jump, creates a void in the film. Indeed, despite her rebellious aspect, for me, the character of Lucy failed to match Katniss.On the other hand, there are moments in the film that I find a little long, particularly during Lucy's different songs. These moments reminded me of a bit of a musical... I think there are too many songs during the film.Then, I find that there is too big a "temporal gap" with regard to the costumes between the film and the main saga (with Jennifer Lawrence) which is seen in particular in the different looks (clothes, hairstyle and makeup) citizens of the capitol. I know that the gap between the two is still big (64 years) but in the film (The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes) the citizens of the capitol have looks that are more in the theme of the 60s so that in the main saga they have very extravagant and futuristic looks.However, we do find the premises of the futuristic technology of the main saga in the film, particularly with the first parachutes via the sponsorship system during the Hunger Games.Overall it's a pretty good prequel to understanding the history behind the Hunger Games saga and one of its main antagonists : President Snow.

title: This certainly does not catch fire.
text: It's been some years since the franchise have us Mockingjay Part 2, my interest peaked at Catching Fire, but slowly diminished as it went on, I thought this looked recent from that trailer, for me though this was a bit of a damp squib, it wasn't bad, it just didn't hold my attention, a film I just couldn't get into.I had a feeling the film would struggle without Jennifer Lawrence, and it really did, I had no issues with Rachel Zegler's acting, indeed I thought the was rather good, but I couldn't attach to hers, or any of the characters, I just found them all a little anonymous, and almost impossible to empathise with.A mixed bag in terms of production, I thought some of the visuals were great, some terrific special effects, but all of that music, it just wasn't for me, I didn't quite see the appeal.Do yourself a favour, go and see Saltburn instead, an infinitely better film, I did thr double, that captivated me, this one sent me to sleep.5/10.

title: A Fascinating View into Panem's Past
text: This movie is a very entertaining character study into Coriolanus Snow's descent into becoming the sociopathic future president of Panem as well as a glimpse into what the Hunger Games were long before they became the spectacle that Katniss and Peeta encounter the 74th and 75th Hunger Games. The arena for the 10th Hunger Games is much smaller and not near as scenic which in a way makes the violence more raw, and the typical game is over within hours instead of several days. We see that they are working out kinks and trying new things (even adding some things based on Snow's suggestions).Tom Blyth does a great job playing Coriolanus Snow, a morally ambiguous but cunning character that we often empathize with while at the same time, we don't completely trust. Is it because we already know that he'll become President Snow, Katniss Everdeen's enemy, in the future? Possibly. We're rooting for Snow to help his tribute, Lucy Gray Baird, but Snow continually crosses moral lines, and yet he completely justifies to himself and others *why* he crossed those lines. Blyth is great at conveying Snow's scheming with his facial features while still keeping the audience guessing as to his underlying motives. Does he genuinely care about Lucy Gray? Is he putting on an act to get her to trust him so she'll follow his advice on performing for the viewers, to further advance Snow's opportunities?Rachel Zegler has a beautiful voice and is well-cast as Lucy Gray Baird, the "songbird" that captures both Panem and our hearts with her singing, including a mesmerizing rendition of "The Hanging Tree." While we're rooting for the "odds to be ever in her favor, " we don't get as much background on Lucy Gray as we did on Katniss Everdeen in the original movies, so we never quite form the same connection with her which is a shame.Viola Davis is fantastic as the evil, creepy, scheming Dr. Volumina Gaul. She steals every scene that she's in, and we love to hate her. Her voice alone is haunting, and her outlandish costumes and makeup combine to make her one of the most memorable villains we've seen in some time.While Peter Dinklage is a great actor, we don't connect to his character Dean Casca Highbottom much. Perhaps it's because we're rooting for Snow's success in helping Lucy Gray, and Highbottom gets in the way.Snow's cousin Tigris, played by Hunter Schafer, is the person that Snow is closest to in the world, and she is a moral touchstone for Snow. Watching her subtle changes in her reaction to Snow as the story progresses was interesting.Jason Schwartzman as "Lucky" Flickerman provides some much needed comic relief as a weatherman, magician, and first host of the Hunger Games. He's not near as smooth in the role as his descendant Caesar Flickerman will become, which is a source of much of the humor.While we don't connect to these characters to the same degree as we do to Katniss, Peeta, and others in the original Hunger Games trilogy, it is an entertaining movie well worth watching. There is plenty of action (much of it violent of course, as this *is* the Hunger Games), the music is great, and it's fascinating to step into Panem's past.

title: Such a waste of a great opportunity
text: This was so much worse than the book. Not only did they take all the depth out of the characters and their relationships, they also made many changes that simply didn't make sense and only made the story less emotional, less disturbing, less complicated, less morally grey and just plain worse.It was truly very disappointing to see how little remained of Snow's compelling and complex character arc. Instead, he literally had no personality here and they took everything away that made him interesting. I genuinely understood why Snow did the things he did in the book or why he thought the way he thought, and even found myself sincerely rooting for him, but none of that was the case here. I simply didn't care about him here or about this story in general. I might even say I was a little bored. Such a waste of a great book.

title: Bad Movie
text:
Rating: 4.7
Overall, a poorly executed movie as the direction and writing fail to build Snow up to be a bad guy to the point that they have to force this by the time the movie ends (making the first two acts of the movie feel pointless), but the movie is entertaining in the second act because they convey The Hunger Games well.Pretty Bad Direction (The direction on a macroscale is good as the director uses the large sets, VFX, and cinematography to help paint these grand scenes in both the capital and the arena of The Hunger Games (while at the same time showing its grime and dark side), the direction of The Hunger Games was good and kept the movie engaging in the middle part; the direction on a microscale was bad as the interpersonal scenes did not feel fluid at all and were not well executed; the direction of actors was bad as none of of the performances felt like they were elevated by direction; storytelling was poor as there doesn't feel like a sense of where the movie is going as builds to one thing and drastically disposes of it in favor of a something else), Decent Acting (Pretty Good from Tom Blyth (Shows some range of emotion and shows both the good and the bad side of Snow decently well), Pretty Bad from Rachel Zegler (Her accent kept on slipping and she kinda feels out of place with the rest of the cast (and the chemistry between her and Blyth is not the best); her musical moments (while forced) were carried out well as she shows off how good of a singer she is), Pretty Good from Peter Dinklage (Really just feels like he is playing many of the characters he has played in the past (the drunk character who has a lot to say) so he kinda just goes on his own), Good from Jason Schwartzman (The best performance of the movie as he plays the comedic relief character well), Pretty Bad from Hunter Schafer (Very emotionless and doesn't have any emotion with Blyth), Decent from Josh Andrés Rivera (Has moments where he shines and some moments where it feels like he's overacting), Decent from Viola Davis (Not really her best performance as it is a lot of overacting (but it doesn't feel like it is a bad performance, just not the best direction)), Decent from the rest of the cast (Hard to comment as most of the cast is child actors who feel like they weren't given the best direction)), Bad Story (The concept was pretty good as it was interesting to see the early Hunger Games and the origins of President Snow (though the carrying out of this concept was very bad); the story contruction was terrible as first act drags so much that its boring and the third act is completely out of place as it felt like they forgot to make Snow the bad guy (the second act is pretty good as its just The Hunger Games and plays to the strengths of the franchise); storytelling/flow between sequences was bad as every scene just felt forced and nothing felt like it flowed between each other (and this is especially seen in the final act as the movie has to make up for making Snow be the good guy when hes supposed to be the bad guy; character writing was very bad (Snow is terribly written as they put so much emphasis on sympathiszing him and making him be the good guy that they run out of time in making him be the bad guy and rush/force this part of the character in the end, Lucy Gray Baird is not written either as you really don't cate about her as her singing just gets really annoying towards the end), Pretty Bad Screenplay (The dialogue did not flow and was kinda forced; the tension build was good and carried out well in The Hunger Games act; the symbolism was very shallow as it does not do a good job in building Snow's journey for power; the foreshadowing was none-existent as the movie forces the ending because they forgot to make Snow the bad guy in the first two acts), Good Score (Carries different motifs from the original franchise), Good Cinematography (Helped show how grand the capital was and helped build the world (especially in The Hunger Games)), Good Sound (Helped in the action scenes), Good Editing, Good Visual Effects (Helped make the movie feel like it was a part of the franchise and did not feel over-the-top in any way), Good Production Design (Helped with building the world), Plot Structure was the biggest issue for the movie as 2 out of the three acts were pointless (the first act builds Snow to be a good guy and really drags, the second act is pretty good as it is just The Hunger Games, and the third act is just so forced as it clearly shows that they forgot to make Snow the bad guys so they rush to give him moments that show how he's not a good person); The movie could've been split into two movies to help with runtime (with the entire third act being spun off to show how bad of a person Snow is as there are some moments in the second act that could allude to him being a bad guy, something a second movie could take and build on), Pacing was slow in the first and third act (especially in the third) but pretty good in the second act as the fast pace helped build tension in The Hunger Games, Climax was so underwhelming it was more laughable than entertaining, Tone was very similar to other Hunger Games movies.

title: Average acting
text: Rachel Zeigler, whilst pretty and with a great voice can't act to save her politically correct non-dwarves. Her accent and dialect changed more times during this movie than I can remember. It seemed as though they had her on the casting couch and didn't really know what to do with her. Can she sing? Cool, lets do that.And why did Snow turn into Eminem halfway through?That was just weird - one minute he's waking up to being a human being and becoming likeable, and then BAM, off came his hair and may I have your attention please. Will the real Slim Shady please stand up.Very odd movie - good to get the backstory but it's not a patch on the actual Hunger Games movies, which is a shame.

title: HOW DID THIS BEAT THE HUNGER GAMES
text: I have never written reviews on movies ever, but I downloaded this app solely because this movie was one of the best cinematically masterpieces I've ever seen in my life. Whoever directed this deserves millions of dollars and should be awarded all the rewards possible. I am very critical about movies, and I cannot believe that this topped the Hunger Games which was my favorite movie in the past. I will say I did not read the book before hand, and I'm only looking at the movie with a cinematic viewpoint. I am beyond impressed, and I am so excited for more movies of this Director in the future. WOW.

title: Winter is coming.
text: I missed the start of this because for some reason the cinema didn't play any trailers, so I felt like I was playing catch up with the characters and their dynamics for a little while (I came in on the scene in which the mentors are told whom they're going to be mentoring, so I can't have missed that much). When the film was over, I worked out I must have only missed seven minutes, so I guess that most of the audience was playing catch up along with me (that can't be Lucy Gray's literal introduction, can it?). Basically what I'm saying is that a lot of the context I assumed I missed because I was late is actually just missing from the piece full stop, and it's something that plagues the entirety of the picture. Where 'The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1 (2014)' and 'The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2 (2015)' ought to have been split into a single movie with a runtime not dissimilar from that of this film, 'The Hunger Games: The Ballad Of Songbirds & Snakes (2023)' (that's one too many "The"s, by the way) really ought to have been split into two separate movies with runtimes similar to those films. So much of this is far too rushed for its own good, and - although the flick hits the ground running and leaves little room for boredom, at least initially - this is ultimately the main flaw of the feature. There are plenty of genuinely interesting ideas at play here, with the picture following a character who comes to realise that his own self-interest might just take precedent over helping other people (or generally doing the right thing) when circumstances force him to choose between the two. Its grey morality is fairly refreshing, and having someone who isn't a hero be the protagonist of a wide-appeal blockbuster - particularly one based on young adult fiction - is quite ballsy. The problem is that none of its ideas get the time they need to feel fully formed. There's very little granularity to the character arcs and the most important relationships never feel genuine because they aren't really given all that much attention. There are solid scenes that focus on character work, but they're almost like milestones that the flick unceremoniously sprints past and are much harder to appreciate because of it. The film is at its best during the eponymous Hunger Games, as its distinct mentor-tribute relationship and Capitol-based perspective set it apart from the other films in its series. There's a lot of tension and suspense during this second act, and it generally keeps you on the edge of your seat. The pacy first part also features some compelling, if all too brief, set-up for this segment, establishing a more rudimentary rule set for the barbaric situation and having the lead make headway in transforming it into the entertainment-as-punishment we recognise from the other films in the franchise. It's all rather entertaining, even if it does leave you feeling a bit breathless. After the games, though, the feature slams on the brakes and slows to a crawl. The pacing almost entirely resets, and what follows is both too long to be an epilogue and too short to be its own thing. Again, it introduces some thoroughly intriguing ideas and it does have some really engaging moments, but it just doesn't have time to do anything with its ideas and ultimately ends with a bit of a whimper. That's not to say the ending is especially bad, but it does leave you thinking "that's it?" (despite the fact that it's technically quite well-rounded). The tragedy of the plot doesn't really come through as well as it ought to, and the ending doesn't have the intimacy in character behind it to justify its comparatively tiny scope. The formal successes of every technical department go under the radar, too, because of the underwhelming way in which the narrative is faithfully yet insufficiently adapted from the source material (which I haven't read). The writing really is the only thing holding this back, as it's a well-made effort with solid performances and some really entertaining sequences. It is enjoyable and some of it is surprisingly intellectually stimulating, but it could have been so much better with just a few small yet significant tweaks.P. S. It's kind of weird how it's essentially a musical, but I don't mind that.

title: Good movie but it hurts
text: I went into this movie knowing what was basically going to happen. Obviously it was going to match up with the other four hunger games movies where snow is the bad guy. But I haven't read the book, and I did not expect the level of betrayal that happens in this story. It was absolutely wrecking, and I felt it so deeply. I was in shock leaving the theater. It also seemed slightly gorier than the other movies. Overall though, it was very well done and the portrayals by the actors are top notch. I would recommend watching this movie, just be prepared to be shocked if you haven't read the book and bring some tissues.

title: Sour prequel
text:
Incredibly disappointing, and here's why:
The other Hunger Games movies were emotional rollercoasters, whereas this movie left me bored and little invested. I was really not looking forward to feeling "nothing".

title: Excellent Movie and Addition to the Hunger Games Franchise
text: Great acting and a thought provoking movie. In line with the themes of the Hunger Games Franchise. It is a great addition because it shows you the other side, it shows how a real person could turn into something you hate. The point isn't to sympathize the point is to understand.The movie sets up many situations where the main character could make a right or wrong decision. Sometimes he does the former and sometimes the latter. Sometimes he's selfish and sometimes selfless. Sometimes a situation forces him to make a decision he doesn't want to make, sometimes he makes a decision or action where he is not required to make one.A very smart movie that sits very comfortably in the grey (as opposed to black and white) complications that people confront in their lives.

title: Good fun, but not without issues.
text: This story focuses on the initial years of the Hunger Games. It is basic- a large room, some cellars and a few cameras to capture so the action. Not the slick flick we are used to. It brings out tidy intros to the later films, the Mockingjays, the Jabberjays and the latter are used as a pivotal point in the film.Snow is shown as a faltering teen, making his way into the world, fallen from greatness and eager to hide his lack of wealth in the Capitol. His golden ticket is described as the runt (although this hardly rings true compared to the others). Regardless, out she shines- Zeglar and her songbird voice. Introducing songs used in the earlier films. But she be a country and western gal.. ye haw! Bizarre.Ok. This film has numerous faults. But overall, it has a good story. The earlier films were.. kids kill in an arena. This at least had some substance. Could have been so much better though.Blyth and especially Viola Davis shine. Zeglar.. meh. The ending was actually excellent. A set up for future films, but sadly I suspect these will never see the light of day.

title: A Big Letdown
text: I LOVE the Hunger Games Franchise..until this new movie. The actor who played Snow did a fantastic job, but the actress who played Lucy Grey was not a good actress. She had many opportunities to connect with the audience, but everything she said felt scripted. She never drew me into the movie. This movie is supposed to explain the Hunger Games, but had I not seen the first 3 movies, I would have been lost. In the end, this movie did not "feel" like a part of the Hunger Games. In reality, this movie actually felt like a musical. I was so disappointed that it completely missed the mark. I had high hopes!

title: Suffers from the cast and expected expectations
text: The budget has obviously been slimmed down, a prequel is usually more squeezed out than mouth-watering, charismatic newcomers don't grow on trees. Bad omens. Can the Panem rehash still shine? Only in part. The main obstacles are a rather pale Snow and his unpleasant tribute. Blyth, I may be wrong and probably contradict some people, but nothing great is growing here. What isn't can perhaps still become, but I couldn't feel the later Snow at any point. But perhaps this was the aim of the film, who knows what will happen in the event of a sequel. The ending at least shows the beginnings of a direction. Zegler, on the other hand, as a "self-confident" young Latina woman, will certainly be booked a little further, as she has been before, continue to exert herself, continue to annoy, continue to warble, until these, in a negative sense, conspicuous appearances hopefully wear off quickly, or she continues to tie a rope in her private life. We understand that she can sing, but that doesn't mean that every film has to be made into a musical for this nobody. It's impossible for these two characters to fit together, no chemistry. One "was always trying", the other focussed on being an egotistical self-promoter.The Capitol backdrops are greasy CGI mess, reminded me of the Fantastic Beasts eye cancer, the natural part in the District fits visually. The production wants to be big, but a few pathetic sequences are not the key to the epic, but real substance. The director may be the same as in previous instalments, but a chef can only be as good as his ingredients. In the second part of the running time, the film takes a calmer approach and works much better for me, which saved the viewing for me. It's not a mainstream romp, which is what people seem to think cinema is today, but content. What is fundamentally appealing is the story. I don't want to get too carried away, but Shakespearean material is always something that speaks of life, timeless, people, their ups and downs. It doesn't matter whether it's Hamlet, Star Wars or Hunger Games.

title: A film that manages to be good, but could have gone further with a better structured script in its final act.
text: "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" is a good film that, as a prequel, managed to interest me in its story without having first seen the other films or read the "The Hunger Games" novels. The production is of a spectacular level, the script divided into three acts is effective, the first is dramatic and manages to generate sympathy with the main characters, the second act has good action scenes and manages to have good tension that makes you worry about the characters, but the third and last act is weak, slow but has well-directed dramatic moments. The performances are good, highlighting Rachel Zegler who also shows off her voice in several songs, and Viola Davis brings to life a unique character. The cinematography is not excellent but it does its job. The music composed for the film is its greatest success, highlighting the dramatic, action and suspense scenes. A film that manages to be good, but could have gone further with a better structured script in its final act.

title: Good movie adaption, not as good as the novel by a longshot
text: It wasn't bad, but not half as good as the novel. Many things are left out, other things are portrayed differently. Considering that adapting such a complex story is really difficult, I think they did quite a good job. Pacing was too fast obviously, which isn't surprising, a running time of 158 minutes just isn't enough to cover the 500+ pages the right way. I really liked Peter Dinklage as Highbottom, he did a brilliant job imo. The portrayal of Snow and Lucy Gray's love story seemed rush and unfitting.Yes, Rachel Zegler might not be the most likeable person, but I think it's stupid to review this movie based solely on how much you dislike Zegler. I highly recommend everyone to read the novel, doesn't matter if you enjoyed the movie or not.

title: The Power-Hungry Villain of Panem Has An Interesting Backstory
text: Laughing until we pass out. Similar to "Harry Potter," the book series whose popularity in Hollywood allowed for the creation of this franchise, the big-screen adaptations made several mistakes before finding success with a single filmmaker, who is now back to helm a prequel that remarkably expands the canon while adhering to its basic ideas."The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" strikes a balance between political commentary at a level appropriate for young viewers while also honoring blood sport and young love, as only Collins can. It feels like a logical continuation of the narrative. Her message is more about identifying how institutions use entertainment to divert attention from and control the masses than it is about opposing fascism. Collins does, however, allow a soulful folk singer-the title's figurative songbird-to act as the voice of resistance even inside that critique.Rachel Zegler, the star of "West Side Story," pays grudging homage to Lucy Gray Baird. She is a hybrid of Jennifer Lawrence's selfless hero Katniss Everdeen from the original films, Victor Hugo's enthralling Gypsy Esmeralda, and a pop icon like Taylor Swift who unites people. Her songs are the high point of a gloomy thriller that is overly drawn out by thirty minutes and becomes incredibly confusing towards the end. However, Hollywood has long since concluded that people enjoy their blockbusters obese, and "Ballad" is just the most recent example of over-delivering.There's just one character in "Ballad" that viewers will recognize immediately: Coriolanus Snow, the future dictator (played by Donald Sutherland), who is now an underdog cadet. This implies that, similar to "Cruella," "Wicked," and "Maleficent," the main character in the movie is a villain who was once youthful, desperate, and... attractive.

title: A Ballad Of Incomplete Telling, But Complete Visuals and Sound Editing
text:
LIKES:The Singing:
-This movie has a little more song and dance to it than past installments, a key quality to this film and one of the characters.-I was pleased with the quality of the songs, the raw emotion and execution by Zegler and fulfilling the desperation of Lucy Gray's world.-Some are ballads that hold so much emotion hit me hard with the way she sold it, her voice deep, full of hurt, and that striving to live.-While others feel more festive, enlightening, and holding a bit more of the joy that this series needs.-Whatever reason, the execution of the songs holds the dramatic personality I expected her to have and to me that was a solid character choice for the film.The Music:
-Moving away from the songs, Ballad's music is a promotional prowess of Hollywood's sound work.-The orchestral work holds so much majesty to it, ominous percussions, strings that give a haunting energy, and a destructive presence that matches the ferocity of the very world.-It's partnered well with the shots, engaging with sound effects to unleash the full punch they were going for, adding ambience to the film and making it shine.The Acting:
-Strong work by the cast, the movie thrives well in the choices for much of the class of actors, they accomplished much with whom they chose for this act.-Davis is dastardly wicked in this movie, taking her anger from roles and refining it into a sinister discomfort, threatening gestures, and a menacing mean streak that fits well for a primary antagonist. Several of her exchanges give you theatrical chills, and her wicked looking nonverbal communication, is just as cold and callous.-Blyth as Snow was a great choice. Presenting like Snow, but still holding his identity, I found his portrayal on point, poised, calculating, and yet vulnerable, it's all there in the way of his demeanor and the way he delivers those lines. Like a true snake, the deception that rides with his every word is shockingly good for me.-Politics aside, Zegler accomplished a lot with Lucy's portrayal. Fiery, passionate, a flair for song, compassionate, and cunning were all in her presence. Sometimes she goes a tad overboard with the accent or the emotion, but her chemistry is fantastic and her presentation solid in the way she stands up to the odds.-Such great interactions between them all, such believable characters that made me fall into the investment of their stories once again.The Cinematography:
-Brilliantly finding the angles, this movie holds so much masterful crafting of that Hunger Games energy as the 10 games begins.-Shadowed filters and pressing shots give the sparse and depressing world an even grander perspective, hope leaking out in the manner that Collins' writes for crushing the hope.-The menacing glares and uncertainty shine in the eyes, the viscousness in the capital kids sneers, and just how much the shadow of impending doom settled over every inch of Panem's misery.-Even the action scenes hold some perspective that captures the feeling of the games, each contestant getting some dynamic shot that only further tweaks the suspense Collins was building towards.The Action:
-It's not the most action packed games of the bunch, nor is it the most suspenseful, but this ballad contains much more details to the games' fight scenes than the book did.-True, it didn't meet the vivid picture I painted, but the scenes are vicious, hold some well laid out action shots, and gives the sinister nature of the arena the touch it needed.-I liked the sword fighting, the destruction, and the strategy, helping add a touch more of the classic feel of Hunger Games that this book did not hold for me.-Throw in the reactions to the mentors and it helps add that unique feel when their candidate fell to the destructive ploys of the Capital.-Nevertheless, the second act was one of my favorite aspects of the movie, and the film being able to help explain the chaos of the games.The World Crafting
-Hollywood's budget and artists have made the fictional world come to life, with the same touch of genius the first movies held.-A fantastic use of real life with CGI, the movie builds colossal arenas that hold terror, craft cities and classrooms of regal status, and nightmarish labs that hold the darkest aspects of the games.-The forests, the mills, the halls, and more are all beautifully integrated, helping balance the majesty with the elite to the simplicity of the pain.-And the costumes only further help sell the status of the contestants, each one holding a characteristic or qualm that only further plays the part and helps add to the world.-Above all, this is the thing I liked the most, and what really pulled all the likes together to make this movie feel like a theater dive, including shows in 3-D.DISLIKES:
More Action:
-I know, this book isn't quite as the action/adventure as the previous ones, but the liberties could have been taken to adds a little more sustenance to this part.-A little strategy, some new beasts, maybe not quite the slaughter at the start? Not sure what could have been done to further make this shine, but the third act could have still used some fluffing with action to help further.-Puritans should still be fine with the portrayals, but... for fans like me, some liberties would have been welcomed.A few too many songs
-They were glazed over during the book, but in this film, the songs are sort of the stars of the show to show off Zegler's skills.-They are fun, they add cultural touches, but some of the songs went excessive and could have been cut for other important scenes if I'm being honest
-Another marginally low dislike, but one I agree with the reviewers could have been tweaked to not get out of hand.The Amount Of Story Cut
-The biggest dislike so far, the movie cuts a lot of what makes the Ballad the book it is.-Several key scenes I remember from the book are gone, some very important to the interactions and shaping of Snow, lost to edits that again made no sense.-The loss of integrating with her group, of getting to have more time with his best friend and shaping the political talks that tests their relationship... also gone and that was sad given how fast the movie progressed through some big points.-The cuts are noticeable, the edits smooth, but not perfect, and in some way the movie again feels rushed more than I thought it would.-And for many, the lack of internal dialogue, what Ballad thrives on, is gone, and with it much of the heart of the book and what describes Snow's transition to the man we will know.-How he thinks? The internal struggles? His burning love? It's all in those internal moments, what Collins' writing relies heavily on in most of the books I have read.-Yet, to do that in a movie is tough, and though they accomplish this so well, they still lost a lot of things that fans will notice and potentially miss dearly given the history of this series.-This was the biggest loss, and without the other liberties to help fill the gap, or dialogue to help replace those moments, the movie still lacks something that I would have liked to see in this movie adaptation.The VERDICT:
The Ballad is strong in so many facets for the theater visit and the buildup the marketing has done for this movie. It's a beautifully designed world, with Lionsgate focusing so much attention on the details of the landscape, the feel of the games, and the immersion into the world of Panem's earlier years. There is so much emotion, acting, songs, and camerawork bringing Collins' descriptions out, and doing their best to unleash the fury of the snake and the beauty of the songbird without getting too lost into the emotion. Action moments get some added details, songs help get the characters the rebellious streaks, and some of the moments are so much better than the words in the book. And yet, the movie feels incomplete as if it could not figure out the ideal marriage of new changes an cuts from the books. This book's reliance on the internal nature of the characters has been faded in this movie, as internal thought is quite limited in movies without dialogue or artistic focus. And though they capture some of this magic... it still misses much of what I remember from my reading, key moments that are gone for the sake of time and other liberties. Rather than filling them with meaningful and efficient scenes, we got more singing, but hey, the movie wasn't five hours so I can't be too upset. I agree, this movie feels that it needed two parts to do everything, but again, I think this movie still has enough bite and gusto to warrant a theater visit this holiday season, just so long as you lower your standard for a pure adaptation.My scores are:Action/Adventure/Drama: 7.5
Movie Overall: 6.5.

title: The party of pointless films continues
text: This film is the definition of a split personality. It's called Hunger Games but you only see something like that in it's first half hour, since the filmmakers had the bright idea to escalate the film in it's first act, putting the first act as the second act and then the third act as the second. Are you confused? Well, look at them! The result is that you think the movie is ending but it eventually takes a "break" and resumes in about five minutes. I am addressing to you Hollywood movie makers: beginning?, middle?, end?, world building?, exposition?, protagonist testing?, twist?, climax? Don't they remind you of anything? The movie ends and you don't know what you've seen, you are confused. Where is the catharsis? Who is good and who is bad in this movie? I didn't know whose side to take and when the viewer doesn't know whose side to take he's lost.But yes the movie has some positives (thankfully). The soundtrack, cgi and color grading are very good but it's such a shame that these were wasted in a festival of bad script and direction. It's hard to believe that Francis Lawrence has directed this film. Oh and if you're going to turn it into a musical halfway through you'd better tell us from the start.It's unbelievable and sad what is happening in modern Hollywood. They're just trying to make money based on strong and beloved franchises by changing them and throwing in minimal work. The only instances of them coming up with anything worthwhile yet are those of the known greats in the game like Martin Scorsese, Christopher Nolan, Ridley Scott, Cameron, Villeneuve and Tom Cruise.

title: met my expectations
text: Anyone who has read the book will be disappointed in some places, but will quickly get over it because it was done in great detail. A really good, entertaining Panem movie that met my expectations. I don't understand the criticism that there is too much wholesomeness, because it's exactly the same in the book. But it's probably not read much anymore. So I really enjoyed the movie and love the soundtrack so much. I really hope, one of the cast will be nominated for one of the movie awards. Viola Davis did an amazing job, she was insane! But I think Rachel will be the next Disney Superstar, so we will see.

title: It was good, really it was.
text: I haven't read the book this is based on. I have however watched the previous movies and have read the original trilogy. I didn't think I would like it but I did...really. Snow was the last character I really wanted an origin story for but it works.The acting was good to great (better than the Katniss movies). I liked that the relationships from the characters seemed earned. The singing didn't bother me and the singing was much more enjoyable than the forced performance of Jennifer Lawrence. I liked the actual Hunger Games that seemed like an actual survival game that hasn't been seen since the first movie. The movie looked great in IMAX.I recommend it!

title: Ballad of a lost franchise
text: I really wanted to like this movie, I rewatched all the originals right before and it only made this movie look so much paler in comparison. The actual "Hunger Game" in the movie at its most basic state in the timeline was entertaining while it lasted and the lead playing a young Snow along with Viola Davis chewing the scenery as a maniacal villain are the highlights, but too many musical numbers (there was all of one instance of singing in the original series) along with the stiff acting of the female lead and the tired length, made this seem like a Hunger Games if it was made by Disney. A bit too cheesy and long in the tooth, and a disappointment when held in regards of what came before.

title: The books will always be better
text:
Just like the rest of the Hunger Games movies, the movie is fine. It's watchable, you don't feel like you've wasted your time. You get some dopamine from some of the action, or music, or moments. But movies shouldn't aim to just be fine. They need to be great. Every movie should strive to be a masterpiece. This is not a masterpiece.The book was. The book did something other series couldn't do - it showed that reboots could work, that they can be as good as the originals. With the movie, this isn't nearly as impressive, as the original movies weren't the best. So all Songbirds and Snakes had to do was make sure it wasn't worse than the first movie (which it managed to do).As a Hunger Games movie, it is an 8. It adapts the book well (with a few fails preventing it from reaching a 9, and a lot of underexplored / incorrectly explored themes preventing it from reaching a 10).As a movie, especially if you haven't read the books and are only basing your knowledge on the previous movies, this is a 6. Poor writing decisions (specifically related to the movie, not the book), drag this down for the average watcher that won't be so lenient with the decisions made.The acting was mostly good. I was cautious before watching the movie (all book-readers are anxious for their characters to be cast correctly), but I was happy with the choices made. What became a problem was the way the director required them to act. First, Lucy Gray. In the book she was presented as a little bit insane, with some tricks up her sleeve (think of Foxface from the first Hunger Games). Here, she was just presented as a typical "badass", with some moments of non-badassery sprinkled in to try and balance her out, so to say. It didn't work, and just made me fail to really believe she was a genuine person.As for themes, this movie missed out on some marks simply because it didn't give us Snow's internal monologue, which is what made Songbirds and Snakes so great. The book didn't straight up tell us Snow was cunning, but through his thought process you can see that he is. It's a subtle thing that makes Snow a much more interesting character. In the movie, these subtle undertones are missed and towards the end you just get the impression Snow is a bad guy just because he's misguided or indoctrinated. There's also a lot of thought processes left out that would help colour the other characters a bit more. Generally, the other kids from Snow's school are sidelined instead of really being highlighted as rivals. You don't feel any danger from the fact that the other schoolkids are competing against Snow. Due to Snow's thoughts being left out, the problems I mentioned before with Lucy's character are amplified. In the book, the first thing Snow thinks when he sees Lucy is that she might be mentally unstable, and that she reminds him of a circus performer. This was a really interesting moment in the book - how can Snow, a dignified posh boy hope to control a poor girl who doesn't fit into social norms and doesn't care to? - but it was mostly lost in the movie.Perhaps the most important writing change for me, was the plot-twist at the end. I think, for the rest of my life, I will remember the scene from the book when Snow realises something is wrong. It came out of nowhere and hit like a train, and was one of the most tense moments I've ever read in a book. What made it so special was that you knew something had to go wrong at some point, like a Romeo and Juliet where (due to the characters present or not present in the original stories), you knew who would survive and who wouldn't. But you didn't know when it was going to happen and how. Here, in the movie, they don't even make an attempt to disguise what's coming. In fact, they try SEVERAL TIMES to tell the watcher that something is about to happen, and when it does, we're supposed to act like it's a surprise??? Ridiculous. It wasn't completely ruined, but it was unnecessarily spoiled just to... what? Why? Because the director thought the audience would be too stupid to realise what's happening?Special effects were never a strong suit of the HG series, but here they were more passable. I'm specifically referring to the design of the Capitol, which looked atrocious in the originals.The music was bad. There were some nice parts, but mostly it was just filler music.And finally, the editing. I thought the movie did a great job of attempting to get everything from the book into movie form, and that's worth some praise - I hate when movies cut out portions of the book. Unfortunately though, instead of embracing this and making the movie as long as it needs to be, they try and cut quickly between scenes to shave off a few minutes. And I mean, quickly. You barely have time to process anything. Oh, someone just died? Something sad just happened and now we need to focus on the characters' reactions? No, we immediately cut to the next scene and forget about that. It was quite unnatural.Overall 6/10
8/10 for a Hunger Games fan.

title: Dare I say better than the book?!
text: I was pleasantly surprised with The Hunger Games: A Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes, in that it was a perfectly paced film, which balanced particularly dark action and thought-provoking themes very well. In addition, it set up the first The Hunger Games perfectly, something I felt the book was a little unclear on. I was worried that Lucy Gray's constant singing, as is in the book, would take over the film, but it was perfectly placed and necessary. All in all, a really entertaining watch for Hunger Games fans with some fantastic foreshadowing scenes and quotes that were far from cheesy. This felt like Suzanne Collins wrote the script, unlike in the Mockingjay Part 1 & 2 - a film definitely worth your time.

title: Snow's Early Days
text: Well, here we go again, another spin on the Panem wheel of fortune (or should I say misfortune?). "The Hunger Games: Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" is a prequel that takes us back to the days when young Coriolanus Snow, yes, THAT President Snow, was just a lad with a head full of dreams and a name that screams 'destined for a career in villainy'. This movie is like that one guest at a party who tells interesting stories but tends to drag on a bit too long.Francis Lawrence does a decent job of setting the scene in a dystopian, war-ravaged Panem. The story itself is a blend of teenage angst, political intrigue, and the usual Hunger Games brutality. Think "Game of Thrones" meets "High School Musical", minus the singing basketball players. Speaking of singing, the casting of Rachel Zegler as Lucy Gray Baird, a character with Southern roots, was an eyebrow-raiser. However, Zegler belts out country tunes with such grace and emotion, it's almost like the role was written with her voice in mind. Her performance is a definite highlight, proving that talent transcends geographical origins.As for the plot, it's an intriguing peek into the early days of the Hunger Games. We get a sense of how the event evolved from a brutal punishment into a twisted form of entertainment. Coriolanus' journey from a wannabe hero to a budding villain is fascinating, though the movie tends to lose its grip in the midst of all the subplots. It's like trying to keep track of who's who in a very dramatic, very lethal high school reunion.Overall, "Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" is a watchable addition to the Hunger Games saga. It's not going to knock your socks off, but it won't bore you to tears either. It's like that solid B student who could've been an A, if only they'd put in a bit more effort. Worth a watch if you're into the whole dystopian thing or just want to see Rachel Zegler steal the show.

title: The second best Hunger Games film, right behind Catching Fire.
text: Stellar performances from everyone in this film. Tom Blyth really does a great performance as a young Snow and as the main character of this movie. I was not sure if I would be interested in a Snow origin story however the writers and Tom Blyth convinced me otherwise. While every actor holds their own it is no shock that Viola Davis is a standout as the evil doctor and might be my favorite performance of the entire movie.There is not much if anything I can critique about this film. Many having seemingly disliked Rachel Zegler's performance as the main female protagonist, but as someone who was not expecting much from this film I will say that she did very well. Not sure if they're expecting another Katniss but she is not that nor was she suppose to be. I will say that the biggest problem for me is the length of the film especially in the 3rd act. Various scenes could've been shortened particularly the singing scenes. It is definitely worth a watch in theaters it is a strong 7.5-8/10.

title: A Great But Not Long Enough Origin Story.
text: I had a very good time with this movie. It explored the brutal horror of the hunger games perhaps better than any of the previous films in the franchise. It (arguably) had better characters than any of the other hunger games films. Perhaps the biggest flaw was the length of the film. It wasn't long enough. It could (and probably should) have been three hours or made into a two parter. It would have given it more space to breathe and develop more stakes. For example, the main character is very poor which is his motivation to win the "Plinth Prize." But it is only suggested once or twice within the first ten minutes of the film. If they had a longer runtime then they could have elevated the plot in a few ways. But nonetheless, quite a good time and my second favorite movie in the franchise.

title: Three stars for the good look of Snow. Nothing else.
text: The Lucy Gray character is so thin... one second she's singing like it's Broadway, one second she's talking empty words about life, one second she's being emotional for no reason. Also, that best friend of Snow? There is not much logic behind his moves except just trying to be dramatic.In terms of the hunger game itself, WAYYY TOO WEAK! I know they are trying to show that Snow made hunger game the way they are in 1 and 2. But man it was weak back then! In my opinion they've written Lucy to be too good. Can you run just a little faster?!It's a long movie and I can barely seat through. To sum it up, way worse than 1 & 2.

title: Fantastic adaptation
text: The entire Hunger Games franchise has been an excellent example of how movies and books can complement each other when made well, and I was completely satisfied with how the Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes managed it. Despite the elimination of several scenes, and some modifications to the Games as far as when and how certain tributes died, the film was overall true to the plot and themes of the book. I found several scenes in the book confusing, especially towards the end, and seeing the character portrayals in the film helped those scenes click a lot better. I loved the casting of Rachel Zegler. The music was one of the things I was most excited about seeing adapted into film, and the songs in the film were did not disappoint. So much better than the awkward reading of the songs in the audiobook I listened to! Tom Blythe made a very believable Coriolanus Snow, and the actor for Lucky Flickerman NAILED it. Overall, a movie (and music) I will definitely be coming back to!

title: Younger Games
text: I somehow was able to avoid every single trailer for this movie. I had never read the book, but I did rewatch the 4 previous Hunger Games Movies before watching this one. So, going into a Hunger Games prequel, there were certain things I was wanting to see. I thought seeing the war between the Districts and the Capitol would be interesting or seeing the pitch meeting for the first Hunger Games, how and why did they come up with that. But that is not the film we got here. This starts at the 10th Hunger Games and is more or less the origin story of President Snow. I won't compare this movie to my imagination of what it could have been, I just want people to know what they're getting into.To the film's credit, this is a villain centered prequel film that actually makes the main character the villain. Unlike films like "Maleficent" or "Cruella", Coriolanus Snow in this film actually does act villainous, and I could totally believe he is the same person we see in the other Hunger Games Movies. As a prequel goes, it also doesn't try too hard to call back to the previous films. There is no talk of a chosen one prophecy of someone rising up to defeat the Capitol. There is one call back that it is a bit forced, but other than that the movie stands on its own merits.This movie also has a good edge to it. It feels more adult than a "YA Novel" movie, and this helps the film maintain suspense for its characters and the audience.Now on the negative side, the titular Hunger Game is not as compelling as previous entries. Part of that is due to the fact that the Capitol is still figuring out the format. But another has to do with the fact that we don't know anything about the other contestants, they are basically just cannon fodder. The other movies didn't have much, but they still had enough to make us remember when one was killed. This movie has a couple of moments where they announce someone died, and I had no idea who they were talking about.What about the one contestant we do get to know, Lucy Gray? When this character was first introduced, I was excited, she looked like someone who might be more morally...gray. Someone who would do more sinister things than Katniss in the previous entries. But as the movie progresses, she becomes less and less interesting, basically becoming a discount Katniss but without any emotional connection. Katniss at least had her sister to fight for, and although not great, I was more invested in Katniss's romantic subplot than I was with Lucy's.This film also has no business being nearly 2hrs. 40 mins. As the film approaches the 3rd act, it starts to be a bit directionless. Characters make foolish decisions and things stagger to an end.To end with some positives, the acting performances by all involved were really good. Viola Davis as a sort of Dr. Frankenstein is appropriately sinister. Peter Dinklage is great as always. Jason Schwartzman is delightful as the host. And I can really believe Tom Blyth as Coriolanus Snow.The film is still better than most prequels of its kind. The film just chooses to focus on the wrong things and ends up feeling overly long and convoluted. I think there are still interesting things the series could do in the Hunger Games universe; this just doesn't fully tap into that.It may be overstuffed, but I could hunger for some more in the future.

title: Wasted two and half hours of my life
text: "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" attempts to explore the origins of a notorious villain, President Snow, but ultimately falls short in its execution. While the concept of delving into the past of such a complex character is intriguing, the narrative feels sluggish and fails to deliver the depth and intensity expected from the Hunger Games universe.The portrayal of a young Coriolanus Snow lacks the compelling depth needed to justify his transformation into the iconic antagonist of the original trilogy. The pacing struggles to maintain engagement, with stretches of the story feeling drawn out and disconnected. Additionally, the dynamic between Coriolanus and Lucy Gray Baird, the tribute he mentors, lacks the emotional resonance required to truly invest the audience in their relationship. Rachel Zeigler acting sucks as well.Moreover, the exploration of the early Hunger Games lacks the gripping tension and moral complexity that made the original trilogy so captivating. Instead, it feels more like a diluted version, missing the edge-of-your-seat excitement and the thought-provoking commentary on society and power dynamics.Overall, "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" fails to live up to the standards set by the previous Hunger Games installments, offering a lackluster portrayal of a compelling villain's origins and missing the mark in terms of both storytelling and character development.

title: I really liked it.
text:
Bruce Bickley8:42 PM (0 minutes ago)to me
The hunger gamesI only saw all the other movies once in theaters and never read the books so while not coming in fresh I was only guessing on who Snow was in the other movies.Have to admit there was something about the simple-ness of the film that caught me.Not too filled with elaborateness and I loved the violence of all of it.10 years after the original hunger games and i think 25 years before the original trilogy, we get a look at the point in history in which the spectacle we got to see in the first three (or was it four?) started to come into fashion.I personally thought it was done well.

title: "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes: Where Snow Always Lands on Top"
text: In "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes," director Francis Lawrence expertly navigates the intricate prequel to the Hunger Games saga, delving into the origins of the iconic villain, Coriolanus Snow. Set 64 years prior to the events of the original film, the narrative unfolds in the nascent stages of Panem's descent into dystopia. Lawrence's keen direction brings forth a vivid sense of place, offering a captivating glimpse into the Capitol's retribution against the districts for their uprisings.Tom Blyth's portrayal of the young Snow is nothing short of star-making. From a privileged youth to a calculated manipulator, Blyth's performance unfolds with grand gestures and subtle revelations. The script, crafted by Michael Lesslie and Michael Arndt, masterfully traces Snow's ascent to power through calculated decisions rather than sheer strength, lending a chilling subtlety to this supervillain origin story.The film introduces Lucy Gray Baird, portrayed with charismatic brilliance by Rachel Zegler. Her melodic method of protest and dynamic chemistry with Blyth's Snow create a compelling narrative tension. Viola Davis shines as the sadistically chic Dr. Volumnia Gaul, while Jason Schwartzman's Lucky Flickerman provides delightful commentary on our attention-hungry times.Peter Dinklage's grounded portrayal of Casca Highbottom adds a necessary touch of wisdom in the midst of the film's wild events. As the story unfolds, the third chapter takes a bold departure, both in terms of location and emotional tone, providing exquisite tension between Snow and Lucy Gray. The cinematography by Jo Willems enhances this shift, creating a lush and dangerous vibe in a pastoral forest setting."The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" proves to be a suspenseful prequel, skillfully exploring the complex dynamics of power, trust, and survival. With a runtime of 157 minutes, the film delivers a captivating narrative that adds depth to the Hunger Games universe.#SongbirdsAndSnakesSaga.

title: Most reviews are untrue
text: So the only reason i am writing this review is because most reviews here are BS !It was true to the book the songs where perfect if you're smart enough to understand the lyrics , and thr acting was verry good aswel . I know its a hype to hate stuff without decent reasons for the last few years but its getting ridiculous even with great movies.This movie does a perfect job of showing us how, Snow became the hatefull man we know him as i even sympathize with him a little bit .It also shows us how the capitol got tricked in liking the anual hunger games and making it more of a show then just killing.On top of that there are alot of easter eggs/ refferences to the movies we already have , so watch the movie and dont listen to the BS negative reviews.

title: Wow that cinematography!
text: Okay, if you like a movie that LOOKS cool and unique, this is your movie. I remember seeing the trailer and thinking this movie just visually had something to it, and I noticed it quite early on. Almost the entire movie is shot from a low angle, with a greater depth of field and what almost felt like a 0.5 wide lens, making every location feel grand. The story was captivating and surprisingly much more violent than the original hunger games, but the violence was not over used by any means. The actor playing Snow deserves praise, he was really great.The only downside was the main actress' lame Southern accent and impromptu singing, could've done without both lol.

title: Bad reviews are misguided
text: I saw the ballad of songbirds and snakes this weekend, and haven't stopped thinking about it since. It's a great movie with a complex alternate reality that the characters live in. The acting was great, the songs were catchy, and it was interesting to see a prequel that touched on the evolution of the games that led to the beloved Hunger Games series. I think that for a franchise like this people go in with extremely high expectations or perceptions of what the movie will be and if it doesn't perfectly align, they're left frustrated. That's the tone I feel in a lot of these reviews. Don't discount this movie before going and seeing it, it was one of my favorite hunger games yet.

title: The best mediocre movie this week
text: Like other reviews here, I agree that too much was shoved into this 3 hour movie.The movie is set up initially where Snow is an orphan attempting to do right by his cousin while also not following in his deceased fathers footsteps. His fathers back story isn't explained until the final minutes of the film & his cousin has all of 5 minutes of screen time, making both feel like after thoughts by the end of the first act.In act two, there are attempts to establish two "villain's". The creator of the Hunger Games, and the head Game Master. Both fall flat, pulling the attention in three different directions. Act two does a half way decent job of letting Snow be a villainous protagonist. He spends much of the act attempting to manipulate the games in order to have his tribute win. The end of the act finishes with the end of that years hunger games. It would have been the best ending for this movie.For reasons..... There is a third act to this film. In the third act Snow suddenly has an extreme, unexplained, emotional swing. It left me wondering what I had missed, since the hook to this movie is explaining Snow's back story. He goes from "Change is possible" to unhinged in the blink of an eye.The real saving grace to this movie is Rachel Zegler's voice. The songs do get a little repetitive and are often misplaced in the scene. However, the pain and sorrow cut through in her voice giving them an authentic feel.

title: Intriguing enough to watch from start to finish, but not good
text: I started the book but did not get far. And now after watching the movie I realize that I would have liked it probably even less if I had read the entire book. Probably the biggest problem is that none of the main characters seem likable or realistic enough in the world for me to root for them or have the emotional down-spiral of the characters to be a good tragic drama.There is sort of this 1950s steampunk aesthetic that also made no sense to me given that this is supposed to take place in our distance future rather than the somewhat recent past. How/why would TVs in the future start to become anything like TV screens from the 50s? Are they also going to reinvent laserdiscs?The way the hunger games unfolds makes it feel completely absurd that the winner would win even with all of the cheating. Also the 2 big dramatic scenes after the games just seems confusing. Especially intermixed with some of the other scenes around them. Maybe he works better with all of the perspectives and time that an author is given in a book. But it certainly didn't make a lot of sense to me.Stumbling across the guns later in the film seemed way too coincidental too. And the motivations of the main characters was so inconsistent from one moment to the next near the end that he started to seem bipolar and phycho. I don't think they sufficiently developed his character so one could understand why/how he would work so hard for power and control. The beginning had him challenged that power and control so much that it was a wonder why he would even want any power and control over a society that he just barely seemed to care about.All in all. It's a mess, but interesting to try to follow because it seems to be such a mess.The actors seemed alright. The music was good. The cinematography was fine. But the story and characters didn't seem well developed to me. And I was frequently wondering why these characters and this timeline was being presented given that it didn't seem to answer many questions compare to all the questions and problems it raised.

title: Pretty faithful adaptation! Snow lands on top
text: Despite the many negative reviews on this site, I absolutely loved this movie. It is the most faithful movie adaptation out of the entire Hunger Games series. Like the other movies of course it is missing some interactions and smaller scenes, so people who read the book will of course have more context. I've seen quite a few people saying that they didn't connect with the main characters besides maybe Sejanus and that was the point! In the book Snow might have been slightly more sympathetic but his thoughts usually give away his true intentions so I'd say the movie did a good job of balancing him out since we could not read his thoughts. The slight changes made did not affect the overall story and large plot points were left unchanged. They did a great job considering it was not split into two parts and while it can feel a little bit rushed it really does follow the same timeline as the book. Loved every minute of this movie and would recommend it to all Hunger Games fans.

title: The Sound of Snow Rising
text: I like it. My expectation for a movie has never been lower after my sanity was bombarded by Captain Marvel and Five Nights at Freddy's, but I must say I'm pleasantly surprised by The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes. The use of vibrant colors, the realistic (as opposed to visibly CGIed) scenic layouts, and the elaborate, coherent storyline adapted from Susan Collins' amazing textual foundation. Seeing the in-constructing Capital and the Hunger Game in its early stage creates great contrast with the overly affluent city and the meticulous game designs in the original tetralogy.
