Moreover, the plot is just so much better than Marvel's AI-produced ones: there's plenty of clever foreshadowing devices, a balance between fights and dialogues, and 2 movies of volume in 1, although I understand why Lionsgate didn't separate the game itself and Snow's journey into two films in fear of revising the failure of Mockingjay part one. However, I do feel like the second half or part three of the film has its problems in terms of pacing, including Sejanus' sudden lack of judgment, Snow's hurried embrace of his villain arc, and Lucy's reduction in part. Such a prolonged narrative works for a novel, but certainly not a movie.A compliment to the cast, who definitely go beyond their standard performances and portray quite memorable characters. Despite surrounded by controversy, Rachel Zegler really can sing the unbridled Covey verses and act a mysterious songbird. Tom Blyth is bold choice for the renowned character and his depiction of Snow's change in character isn't that convincing in the third part, but overall he is above decent. There's also a lot of rewarding easter eggs for those who know the original saga, like The Hanging Tree, Tigris' fate, supply drops, and why Snow hates "Katniss."I like the film, but please do not make a sequel to the prequel.

title: Character development & acting
text: Stale character development coupled with unauthentic facial expressions and acting make this movie flop. The first 10 minutes of the movie didn't have a strong hook and left viewers uninterested. The acting from the freshmen cast was not believable or compelling. I felt no connection to any of the characters, and felt that the character development could have been better. Ziegler's performance was not up to par and they weren't able to convey a story in a genuine manner. This movie lacked balance in art, action, and attraction. I had higher hopes for this film because I loved the original trilogy.

title: Not too impressed, I kept checking my phone in the theater.
text: This movie goes on a bit too long and I feel like if you're not really into the Hunger Games series (like I never was as much as avid fans) then you're not going to care about this movie and it's not going to keep you wanting more. There are definitely some intense scenes and some good acting that made me pay attention a couple of times but I can pinpoint another major problem going on here. The main character of Lucy comes across as way too helpless/defenseless in too many scenes and relies way too much on luck or someone to save her to get her out of danger. She is less resourceful and strong than Katniss Everdeen was and it shows. I thought Hollywood cared about feminism?? This was not a good example.

title: Hits and misses, but hits prevail
text: I went to the movie having low expectations and was pleasantly surprised it wasn't even bad. The story has holes in some places, but it catches up in other with complexity. The design and acting are good.Not a movie to become a classic, but likely you won't feel it's a waste of time either.The story is all around Snow (played by Tom Blyth) and his path to success at all costs. It was a complex role and Tom performed great. He carries the whole movie on himself, and the character passing a whole roller-coaster of events and an afterthought of him remains even after you end the movie.The other actors had been unltimately outshined. E.g. Dr. Gaul and Sejanus were played by good actors, but the roles were too bland, it's not on them. Or the actors had simply way too short screen time (Tigris). The only exception was Jason Schwartzman who had played an eccentric showman, but not as absurd as in the original trilogies.I am a split about evaluating Rachel Zegler playing Lucy Gray. Usually the characters/actors can show that there is one face they show to the public and another when in private (e.g. Jennifer Lawrence in the original Trilogy). That builds up trust to the viewer. But Lucy Gray was always the same person for whom pretending costs nothing. She carries the same "poker face" and demeanor all the time (except it is cheery-naive look). Lucy had no less and often more obvious psychpathic traits than Snow's character, especially when it comes to the lack of remorse and manipulations. And it just doesn't fit to the character so young and put into an extreme stress. So either Rachel played an extremely skilled psychopath or she had slacked and didn't bother to provide depths to the character. I don't know, honestly.It's interesting that the Hunger Game itself is a plot-mover, but not what the movie is about. The game battle itself is bloody and just like in the original, has huge and dumb plotholes, but one must give a slide here. Luckily, it's not the main plot thing.Anyway, an interesting shift of the perspective, and I find it to be a great move from Suzanne Collins and a fitting expansion of the franchise.

title: Amazing return to one of my favourite worlds
text: The hunger games are by far my favourite YA series. Incredibly brutal and grim, yet full of such hope and optimism for the future. Always so well written, and with an incredible cast. Also luckily, very faithful adaptations too. This one is no exception. Very close to the book, and thematically quite different to the 4 sequels. Far darker in tone, and absolutely lacking the hope or optimism. This is the rise of a truly impressive villain. It is fascinating to see the progress of Snow, his origin story as the most formidable villain I've seen on the screen in a long time. Incredibly cast, with a breathtaking performance but thankfully not a character they decided to humanize. Just because someone has humanity, doesn't make them a saint. Really enjoyable film, so glad I got to experience this world again.

title: Long, yet short
text: I have never seen a show that is this long, and yet this short. Events jump by too fast for any backstory to make sense. This movie jumps from one well detailed scene to the next, passing so quickly the events happening don't make sense.This should have been a two parter, instead it was just disappointing. I love the idea of the plot and it had such potential, it is such a shame that all that potential was wasted.The worst part of the show starts about half way through. We don't see any backstory, if we could have seen events going on over time, stuff he had to witness, stuff he did then his actions would make sense, but we don't get that. There is just too much missing for this movie to be good.Its an awesome idea, and I really wish they had made it into 2 parts, but this finished product was just so disappointing to watch.

title: Love this film
text: I really enjoyed the movie, I love the actor for Snow, and also Lucy Grey her singing is so good. I liked that there were a lot of side characters in the arena and out of it, and you could see all of their very different personalities, and how not every character is purely good or purely bad. Definitely makes you feel a lot of emotions in the final scene, but I hadn't read this book prequel, and I've only seen the other hunger games films so it was completely a surprise to me, but a good surprise I liked how it ended in a way better then I was expecting. I love the soundtrack so much, and I like that we get to learn more about the world of Panem and see more of the Capitol.

title: An appreciated Installment on the History of a Franchise
text: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is the perfect example of taking a pre-existing franchise and expanding its world and lore in a fresh and modern way.As someone who enjoyed the original Hunger Games trilogy(?) and always wanted to know more about the past Games and why the nation of Panam is the way it is in the original films, I think this movie did a lot to answer those questions.Although the story may seem a tad rushed due to its time skips, I believe this movie was paced very well and did not have to be divided into multiple parts. I believe the movie accomplished what it set out to do by answering who President Snow is, why he is the cruel dictator we see in the original films, and how he came to be in power.I find that those complaining about the story of the movie are simply too caught up in nostalgia to take this movie as a modern installment of The Hunger Games that is not set to be just another story for those who were Reeped.I applaud the director, writers, actors, and anyone else who helped create this movie for taking a chance and making a movie that is somewhat similar to the trilogy but also artistically different plot-wise.Overall this movie was great in my opinion and at the bare minimum, a fun watch.Very Recommended Watch.

title: "Hunger Games Spinoff Hits Sour Note: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes Struggles to Find Its Plot Amidst Confusing Musical Interludes"
text: "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes left me feeling like I was stuck in a bizarre dystopian version of American Idol. The story wanders around like it's on a quest for purpose, centering vaguely on two characters who seem as lost as I was trying to follow the plot. And then there's Rachel Zegler, popping up like a musical fairy godmother every 5 minutes. I half-expected her to break into 'Hunger Games: The Musical' , anyone?The film's attempt to weave a compelling narrative feels more like attempting to solve a Rubik's Cube blindfolded - confusing and with no clear resolution in sight. The decision to turn it into a pseudo-musical only adds to the bewilderment, leaving me wondering if I accidentally stumbled into a Capitol-sponsored talent show.Rachel Zegler's constant musical interludes make you question if she has a secret contract to ensure a song every 300 seconds. It's like the filmmakers discovered a 'Sing for Survival' clause in the Hunger Games rulebook. I can't decide if it's a desperate attempt to inject life into the story or an unintentional audition tape for 'America's Got Talent.'The storyline is as elusive, full of plot holes. It's like they dropped a bag of breadcrumbs in the woods, and we're left wandering in circles, trying to make sense of the narrative maze. The movie's plot is more twisted than the Capitol's fashion choices, leaving me with a sense of confusion.In the end, The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes feels like a failed attempt to remix a dystopian classic. It's not a symphony of storytelling; it's a cacophony of confusion with a side of unwanted musical numbers. If the Hunger Games were a competition for viewer endurance, this movie would win hands down. May the odds be ever in your favor if you decide to give it a watch - you might need it."

title: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes does right what the first four Hunger Games films did wrong
text: I wasn't a big fan of the Hunger Games movies. Downbeat and sometimes downright sad movies can be quite good sometimes, but they have to have good drama and action to make up for the negative emotion. A movie with positive emotion (such as a comedy), doesn't always need the drama and action, as we are watching the movie to relax and have a good time. But no one wants to see a movie that's just sad, which to me is what the first four Hunger games movies were. One thing I did wonder while watching the movies was Snow's past, and how he got where he was. This was only hinted at in the movies, but when I learned there was a movie dedicated to this question, I rushed to the theatre to go see it.We meet Snow at age 17, in a sci-fi dystopian world, where he is a student vying for a scholarship to get into the university, but in order to get said scholarship, which would set him on the pathway to success, he must mentor one of the tributes in the hunger games, an annual tournament in which teens from across the country fight to the death, with only one surviving. He soon finds out there is more to his tribute than meets the eye. The plot goes in amazing directions, but I'm not gonna give away any spoilers.I loved this movie. We can all relate to young Snow trying to make his way into the world, even if we don't agree with his ethics. This movie is almost like a Scorsese gangster drama, except it feels like it was made by talented teens and set in the future. It hits all the right storytelling beats, and succeeds where the original movies fail. It's hard to believe that this movie has the same director as some of the other Hunger Games movies, as this movie, in my opinion, is by far the best Hunger Games movie. I really appreciate the scale in the cinematography, with some amazing shots in the film with gorgeous lighting. I highly recommend this movie, even if you've never seen a Hunger Games movie, as this movie doesn't get much wrong.

title: Entertaining at least
text:
7/10 is right on the money in my opinion. It's an entertaining movie and is close to the novel, which is nice.A little about me first. I have read all (4) novels and seen all the movies based on them. I consider Catching Fire to be my favorite, followed by the original movie. I watch mostly movies from the 30s-50s (Holy crap, this movie had a lot of color!)The good:
The bad:

title: Weak
text: Weak story line and awfuly slow burn.There does not appear to be and structure to the movie, the story line jumps and clearly the writers are just hoping the previous movies popularity is going to sell tickets and bring people to watch this.The acting is barely on par with B movie and this has been so openly advertised as something it is not!Do not waste your time, go watch the original movies and appreciate good acting, writing and directing along with the excellent casting... who are all these unknown actors? Is it too hard or costly to get someone worthwhile to star in a movie in the 22st century!

title: It was alright
text: I liked the beginning and middle of the movie. It had a lot of good acting and the characters were fun at the start, but the ending was really unsatisfying. The character motivation got really confusing at the end and I had no idea why Snow turned evil. It just sort of happened for no reason and it was really sudden. But the middle with Snow being clever and trying to outsmart everyone was pretty fun. Music was also nice. I liked that the film had great visuals too. But the whole conclusion was honestly disappointing to me and I really wanted to see more of Snow's rise, but it just sort of ended instead.

title: Should have been 2 movies
text: I read the book first and was very excited for the movie!Unfortunately the movie was slow going, characters didn't spark, too much of the character undertones from the book went missing, lacking the excitement, etc.Found myself uncomfortable and checking my watch constantly.The story was true to the book, but it lacked the engagement of the other Hunger Games films.Actors were terrific, scenes were on point, but it dragged on far too long.I also feel that if you hadn't read the book a lot of the story line would not make sense.Definitely a watch at home movie so you can stop for a rest!

title: Well done and diferente view to an already existing world
text: This movie makes a new look to the world of the hunger games. The original movies were the same all over again, but this one was something fresh to watch and discover more about the origin of the main villain of the saga.The actors' work is excellent and helps us to have empathy even for the "worst" characters.The movie is made from three parts, two of which are were very easy to watch, but the third, and the final one may seem a little bit heavy because of the length of the whole movie or because of the slow development of the story.To sum up, I like this movie and my friends did too. In my personal opinion. This is better than the other ones because it's not repeating the same hunger games action/survival story.

title: such a beautiful movie
text: It was such a pleasure for me to watch this movie. It has plenty of scenes that full of excitement and thrilling which i enjoyed a lot! But I'm supposed to say that ending was not as i excepted it to be. All the things that lead to story to its final score packed up in the last (I suppose) 30 mins. Such a great example of love is a trick lol.Acting: I didn't recognize any apparent bad acting. (10/10)Music: lovely and relaxing... (10/10)Final: it all happened a little too fast and unexpected because of the story progression. (7/10)Visual effects: (9/10)Story: as I previously mentioned the final was pretty fast for me but other that it was ok. (8/10)Total: 8/10.

title: You can see what's coming...
text: I didn't believe we needed another installment of this franchise. Nevertheless I was intrigued where this would be going. If they wanted to start a new chapter for a trilogy, it definitely needed a great script... and this is where it was lacking.Yes all actors are giving it's (almost) best, the action is there,... but the first 2/3th of the movie, it's all about the games. We've seen it. Kill and survive.The last third of the movie just flips it all around, and where it could've gone right and more intriguing. But, the lack of good writing, dialogue and bad pacing delivers us a very confused ending to the movie.Again... try to suck us into the story and getting interested in a further franchise, but this was a total fail. If another movie comes, I'll wait till it's on a streaming platform.

title: Rachel Zegler is insufferable
text: I was not a huge fan of the original trilogy. I'd rate this slightly below the others, but not too much.It's the curse of sequels and prequels I suppose, and with that in mind it actually wasn't too bad. Most of the cast does a decent job - With the big names (& small person) carrying most of the weight.Rachel Zegler, however, has ruined all movies she will ever play in.One cannot unsee the arrogant, snide and nasty person she revealed herself to be. It's embedded into everything she does now.She has massive reputational damage, along with Disney.It will take a long time and lots of effort to undo.

title: See it for the script and committed execution
text: It's a savage, 1984 dystopian satire, on class inequality. Much of this comes from the unfamiliar and grand 1984 urban-scapes filmed in Poland and Germany.From another angle, it plays more like like a horror film; you wait for each young kid to be killed to find out how. It's dark, not a young adult action flick like the original Hunger Games trilogy or the first Mazerunner movie. Would have done better at box-office released in October for Halloween?Best acting is by an unrecognizable Viola Davis (The Woman King). She's a mad scientist supper-villain--yet, not over-done. If Donald Sutherland was 10/10 crazy, she takes "unhinged" to 11. Impressive. She commits to showing the ugliest and unpleasant aspect of dissociated economic elites.Using title cards, the movie is divided into three acts. The end of the second act is the highpoint of the film. DON'T MISS IT! Brilliant and amazing filmmaking! Afterwards, I was half ready for the credits to roll. Yet it goes on for another 45 minutes to show us how young Snow became old Snow in the trilogy.The King's Man (2021) had a similar problem. The film peaked at the end of the first act. For Hollywood blockbusters, both The King's Man and this film are original and narratively unorthodox. I believe the average male movie ticket buyer often perceives "original" movies as "problematic." The Creator (2023) also had originality audiences did not appreciate.Joss Whedon's scripting maxim still applies, to be big hits, a movie has to announce its genre to audiences; and then, "stay within its lane," be creative with the tropes available to work with. Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves (2023) took Joss's advice to good effect.

title: Worth the watch
text: I haven't read the book but I found this to be an adequate origin story for Snow. There was decent character development and the story all in all didn't have any huge flaws (maybe some questionable moments but nothing I couldn't ignore), HOWEVER I struggled with Rachel Zegler in this film, her acting felt unnatural and forced as if she's trying too hard. Might be me being harsh which I fully accept but she was 90% of my issues with the movie. Tom Blythe on the other hand I felt delivered a believable character and really made the role his own, this was the same with pretty much all of the other characters. All in all definitely a movie I would recommend people to watch but not anything ground breaking which is perfectly fine.

title: I liked the book, but the movie should have been two films
text:
I had started the book for sometime on kindle, then when it was announced it would become a movie production, I thought finish the book first, but other worldly commitments tookover, so read it in tandem while watching a streamer of the movie.... pausing occasionally on both, can't do that in the Cinema.....
A bit condensed the movie imho, could have done better with two parts like the Mockingjay series, action by the main characters, Viola Davis totally over the top manic gamemaster and amusing, Peter Dinklage played himself as usual a bit too droll and diminutive portrayal to the original character ,Rachel Zegler great singer of course, but a little tame compared to the book character who is a lot more reactionary and manipulative. Visually the screenplay, and the games arena seemed a tad skimped, could have been a pastiche of Nazi germany in the late thirties,futuristic train models and stockyards, but a poor rendition,and graphics in scale and size. The critters,jabbajacks, snakes etc made up for the lack of quality settings.Of course the previous history, and games origin, rebellion and organisation of the Districts was glossed over as the filmakers must have assumed that they were making a fan follower movie.As for Cornelious Snow rising up to be corrupted by the politics of power in Panem, the personality a bit watered down in the movie.The compere was the only Actor who got close to Stanley Tucci's original.

title: Very Good Character Study.
text: I was blown away with how well this was done because the trailer made it look like garbage. I've read the original trilogy and seen the films, and I always hated Snow, who wouldn't. It's easy to hate Snow here, BUT Tom Blyth does a phenomenal job, this movie rises or falls on him and he carries it, if this isn't a star making turn for him, I dunno what would be. I despised Snow in the original trilogy, he's obviously only presented as the evil dictator he is, but he's very keen and intelligent, even though you hate him. Here, although I felt repulsion towards Snow at times, I was rooting for him to choose good, we know the inevitable end, but again Blyth does such a phenomenal job of conveying the characters inner dilemmas; we see the constant push and pull off his wanting to do good, but also his selfish ambition, and the desire to walk in his father's footsteps. He does have guilt, but not enough to turn him around, we see this many times as the movie goes on.I felt the transition of him from morally specious to evil was mostly believable, again, because of Tom Blyth's powerhouse performance. I definitely had sympathy for him and I understood where he was coming from. I also felt the transition Snow made at the end felt a tad rushed, but this was a character on a knifes edge, teetering between what's right and selfish ambition. This is, for me a very welcome change in modern mainstream films. Instead of a boring action film, we get a philosophical character driven film, it's very refreshing, and I'm glad this was 160 minutes, not 2 movies, that would have bored People to tears.The rest of the cast is decent, Viola Davis is horrifying, but she never overplays it, Jason Schwartzman does a solid job as Flickerman, Peter Dinklage is solid as always, however, Rachel Ziegler is not a very good actress, she has little emotional depth, but her singing, wow, I knew she had to have been trained, and I was right. I saw her in Westside Story, but she wasn't nearly as good there, in fact I left that movie halfway through because I was bored, I hated what they did to Maria, they ruined her character and the singing was mostly bland. She does a very good job here with the songs, her singing here, however, is some of the best singing I've heard in some time, I'm a little perplexed why she's not a singer after watching this. I suppose material is the issue, if you're not a songwriter, you have to find good material, which is tough.I liked the story, though Id like to have seen a bit more of Tigris, she was a good character and she truly cared about her cousin and hated seeing what he was becoming. I enjoyed seeing the capital in it's early days before it became a complete hedonistic hellhole. I really liked the setting of the primitive games and how they initially treated tributes, it was interesting, and I liked seeing how Snow played a direct hand in what the hunger games later become. Those were the more exciting parts, once it got to the final part, Peacekeeping, it definitely slows down, but it still held my interest, and it took some surprising turns.Overall, worthwhile if you have a good attention span and don't mind movies about evil people.

title: Solid Hunger Games, Tom Blyth & Rachel Zegler carry the torch.
text: Just like almost everyone I love the Hunger games both books and movies. I recently rewatched beforehand and they still holds up and I totally agree with director the 3rd Mockingjay should have been one film instead of split into two. If it was one it could have been easily remembered as one of best trilogies.I'm not huge fan of humanising the villains as we saw with Loki in Disney who killed thousands of people in Newyork and then becomes this funny caricature of a villain/Hero in later movies. So, I never read this book but here I would say Tom Blyth's screen presence and emotional turmoil sold this story to me. You can feel in his eyes how good & evil both live simultaneously inside us and you let one win over the other.Rachel Zegler was amazing as she not only speaks in southern accent but sings too. She never fights in the whole movie not once as she rightly said that "Lucy Gray is a performer forced to fight and Katniss is a fighter forced to perform.". Her character is very from Katniss and she uses her singing as weapon which you never see in films.The problem just like most viewers is the 3rd Act, as it slows down and then slightly rushed towards the end. I still immensely enjoyed the movie, and can't wait to see what Tom Blyth and Rachel Zegler (besides Snow White as I'm over CGI fest remakes) do next.

title: A worthy prequel to the series.
text: More of a political thriller than an action adventure, the story follows the creator of the new Hunger Games in three distinct parts. Good use of imagery and foreshadowing as it reuses the main themes from the original stories but with a fresh view. The story is good if a bit simplified and obvious at times, but it was enjoyable throughout due to the great acting from the main cast, the cracking country ballads and the use of contrast from the grand to the dilapidated in the scenery and settings. The Games themselves weren't as shocking or thrilling as they could have been, but were still entertaining to watch and the run-down nature of the arena fitted well within the post-war recovery setting.

title: It's ok, but a far cry from the original films.
text: First off, I haven't read the book. So I've nothing to be disappointed about in its adaptation.This is an "ok" film, which suffers from comparison to its predecessors. What it does well, is an interesting portrayal of Snow's journey and descent into the man we see in the originals. Unfortunately, the lead female will suffer from an inevitable and unfavourable comparison to Jennifer Lawrence. It feels like she was cast solely for her singing ability which is impressive, but unfortunately her acting skills lag far behind. Perhaps it's the writing, and the book character is the same, but there is nothing endearing about her.Maybe there will be more content, maybe not. I'd possibly be interested in seeing an earlier story depicting the war, but probably not more from these characters.

title: Avid reader
text: Personally, I thought I would really enjoy this movie, because I love the previous installments somewhat, even though they didn't go by the book but I just couldn't look past using Rachel Zegler as an actress in this movie it doesn't give the same feel as the book does when reading the book you miss Lucy Gray but when she wasn't on the screen, I was OK with it. Honestly, that is a big factor of the book that is missing. The love for the character. Personally, I really feel as Rachel's current controversies and backlash going on in the world. She should step back for a moment. She needs to think on her choice of words and understand where the fans are coming from. We are the ones that consume, so shouldn't that be a factor.

title: An Intelligent and Layered Story
text: Intelligent, Layered Story. Engaging and full of interesting ideas that feel fresh against the original films and their themes. Visually stunning cinematic moments with scenes of intense shocking brutality. The connection to the future is apparent but the overall design and atmosphere is generally different. The multiple singing scenes make sense with the storytelling. The acting is overall very well done for all characters, especially Coriolanus, and Dr Gaul. Lucy Gray embodies her role, though more exaggerated at moments in comparison to the rest of the casts more subtle acting style, but that may also lend to the character she is portraying. The tone shift in Act III, is jarring following the end of Act II, but necessary to witness Snow's descent into evil. The movie ends on a high note, leaving some open ended questions that can be analyzed through the evolution of snow in the original films setting the table for his position to rise to power. The core premise brings new meaning to, "it's the things we love most that destroy us" Creating a dynamic parallel to the original trilogy that stands alone as its own independent story.

title: Brutal
text: Brutally long and uninspiring movie. The lead character is unbearable to watch. Her accent is something like an O'l southern accent mixed with a really poor Irish accent. Her facial expressions, and unnecessary singing made me ask myself several times how much longer is this movie. The worst part is I bought it instead of renting it.I enjoyed all of the other hunger games movies, the acting was better, the characters had better chemistry, the storyline flowed better. I don't know if they are going to make more movies to follow this one. However if they do I hope they get a new cast and director.

title: Basic human nature described
text: At first glance I saw it all that despite it prequel this sequel has a heavy hit on the success of the hunger games and how beautiful it was to finally see who snow turned out to be, if I had to guess the message in the bottle, it was that nobody really knows who they really are until they are backed to a corner with the wall against them, in this case it all trails back to how you fend for yourself and yourself only no short comings just you against the big wild world, i examined the mindset of the protagonist for such an outstanding performance it was all in his nature, trust, love and pain control these and the world is yours for the taking snow taught me that much.

title: Believe it or Not, The Best Hunger Games Movie Yet
text: I didn't give myself over to Songbirds & Snakes immediately. The movie certainly had my attention and I think the opening was very strong in establishing Coriolanus as a complicated protagonist and setting him down his path to both his triumph and later his destruction. It took me a while to warm up to Lucy Gray, she was too feisty and too finely geared to make her likeable. But her willingness to trust Snow instead of just being whiny and mistrustful and her not too squeaky clean sense of morality wore me down. Her character picks up steam after the games are done and by the end, I was rooting for her. My biggest problem with the original series was how selfish and petulant Katniss could be and Songbirds & Snakes flips the formula by asking us to root for the villain. One of my friends suggested a House of Cards style show just showing Snow's rise to power and S&S showed the potential and promise that kind of project.I hadn't seen either Tom Blyth previously but to follow Donald Sutherland in this role couldn't have been easy. I was quite impressed with his commanding presence and how well he captured Snow's charm and conversely his ruthlessness. He definitely brought some humanity to the character and he conveys slow descent well. Rachel has a ton of energy as Lucy Gray and she's good at being vulnerable in the beginning and being coy & mysterious near the end. Viola Davis, Peter Dinklage and Jason Schwartzman are the heavy hitters in the supporting cast and I enjoyed them all. Viola comes on strong at the start (could the obviously evil character turn out to be evil?) but her performance fits and Dr. Gaul transforms into a formidable enemy by the end.I also want to congratulate this movie for putting more of a focus on the animosity between the Capitol and the Districts. There's a lot more anger and venom between the two sides and the bitterness adds to the stakes. They also do a good job of showing how disorganized the games could be in their beginning cycles. This version of the Hunger Games is much less glamorous, the tributes are barely suitable, the mentors are only in it for themselves and the citizens of the Capitol barely care. It adds to the bleakness of the festivities and how they would eventual fuel another rebellion which is important in where the story will eventually finish with the Katniss saga.I did have some problems with this movie, but they were mostly minor. Songbirds & Snakes relies on some plot contrivances and the film can't help but being a little precious when it's winking at elements from the original trilogy. This is something that isn't unique to Songbirds & Snakes but wouldn't it be nice if it could have been avoided? But the easiest and most obvious problem is that S&S feels a little overproduced. It's been pruned and tweaked for maximum power several times over and it robs it of some of it's spontaneity. I still really enjoyed it but I couldn't help but feel like I was being manipulated a little bit.I really didn't expect much going into this movie. I saw the original trilogy and read the books but I considered The Hunger Games finished and I moved on. I was blown away by how intricately packed and well made this prequel was. Judging by the other user reviews, I might in the minority but Songbirds & Snakes builds on the mythology while staying true to the spirit, the film shapes Coriolanus Snow into a layered and engaging character/villain and reignites the fire for this universe. I'm somewhere between an 8.5-9/10 but I'd wholly recommend this and unless you're extremely attached to the original trilogy, I'd be surprised if you walk away from the theatre without something to discuss or a new appreciation for this franchise. To Suzanne Collins, Francis Lawrence and the creative team, Bravo!

title: Good
text: A decent watch but a bit to long.We get the backstory of President Snow and how he came to be a sponsor of District 12's Lucy Gray. He is tasked with being her sponsor as the final challenge to win a scholarship to college in the capital. Dr Gaul is the game maker played by Viola Davis and is menacing, her last go to save the games as people hadn't been watching, turning a game into a spectacle. Lucy leaves an impression on Snow, one to make him sacrifice it all, the 10th annual Hunger games commences.A decent watch, the movie is split into 3 parts, the opening, the games, the close and the first two were about 20 minutes too long and I think that could have helped the movie but in saying that is was extremely faithful to the book.The games itself not so great, little attachment for me to the characters like previous movies so I didn't actually care what happened to them, some poor CGI moments.The movie is trying to do a little too much symbolic work rather than being an original take.I did like the whole snow story which is the main thing and my absolute favourite was Flickerman, he is the perfect host to the games and he is my favourite of the movie.Look overall it is good, I liked a lot more than I didn't, a tad too long and too much music, good character building and great side characters, some questions unanswered which would have been nice, who knows, if it makes a load of money we may get those answers , 7/10.

title: A grim dark drama
text: Snow is falling and in doing so The 10th annual Hunger Games is fought, in his rise, a girl will sing and the evil that is President Snow will rise. He does start of the villain but will be the villain. It's a prequel that gets it right. In this drama that is so amazing and sad that I was so invested in this story and world again. It's book to screen in a amazing way and I loved it. Rachel Zegler as Lucy Gray was so amazing and I did not hate the accent. Like in the book it has parts and the parts match the names of the part names in the book witch I loved. It's really goodIt's The Ballad of songbirds and snakes.

title: Although knowing all the atrocities that will still be committed by Snow, now we deeply know the nature of this character and the Hunger Games itself
text: Before Katniss Everdeen, her revolution, and the Thirteenth District's participation, there was President Snow, or more precisely, Coriolanus Snow. "The Ballad of Songbirds and Serpents" tells the story of the dictator of Panem before he rose to power. Years earlier, Coriolanus Snow (Tom Blyth) resided in the capital, born into the imposing Snow house, which faces challenges both in popularity and financially. He is preparing for his opportunity to shine as a mentor at the Games. The fate of your family depends on the small possibility of guiding the victorious tribute. He has been assigned the task of mentoring District 12 tribute girl Lucy Gray Baid (Rachel Zegler). Now, their destinies are intertwined.The author of the books Suzane Collins and the screenwriters Michael Lesslie and Michael Arndt are careful to establish this in every way they can in the chapters that precede the tenth edition of the Hunger Games and the first to count on mentors chosen from among the most promising young people in the Capital, among they Snow, of course, to guide their respective Tributes throughout the fight for their lives. The protagonist may not be exactly a complete villain at the beginning, but he already carries with him all the characteristics that make it clear how much he simply sucks, with the author really taking the risk of building a character with whom her readers probably won't identify. After all, to say that someone identifies with Coriolanus or the values he espouses is a problematic admission. But that's why I ended up liking Cantiga. No just doing the obvious and no sugarcoating the pill. What we see is a young man who is deeply envious of his schoolmate Sejanus Plinth, whose very wealthy family comes from District 2, the equivalent of the "new rich" compared to the "traditional rich", even though Sejanus turns out to be honest. And sensitive, considering Coriolanus as a true friend. Snow is also manipulative, using his beauty and friendliness to get what he wants and to hide his family's poverty - he lives in a luxurious but run-down apartment, with no money to eat properly, with his paternal grandmother and his cousin Tigris, who provides for the family - a secret that no one else knows, except Dean Casca Highbottom, addicted to morphine, credited with creating the Hunger Games and enemy of the Snow family.Even when it places him as the protagonist, "The Ballad of Songbirds and Serpents" makes it clear that we are dealing with a person with a controversial nature, capable of anything to achieve his goals. In this sense, Tom Blyth does an excellent job. Known for smaller productions such as "Benediction (2021)" and "The Golden Age (2022)", the actor truthfully delivers all of Snow's moments, from when he feels his pride hurt when he is reminded of the family's financial failure, to when he arrives to the height of confidence when he achieved (almost) everything he wanted at the end of production (it's no spoiler to say that he lives, after all, the character has a future that fans know well). On the other side, we have Lucy Gray Baird, a tribute from District 12 who tries to survive in the midst of a cruel world. Rachel Zegler also delivers a good performance, in contrast to Blyth's: as we see the story from his point of view, Lucy Gray is always shown as an enigmatic character, of whom we know little and can be suspicious at all times. Of course, a large part of this is due to young Snow's paranoid look, but the film gets it right in conveying this feeling in such a believable way.Here, the screenwriters start from a "canvas" already painted with dark and sad colors and use Snow's mentorship in the Hunger Games to then deepen these reprehensible characteristics (a euphemism, of course) of the character. The tribute he receives to "take care of" is Lucy Gray Baird, originally from a nomadic music group that, during the war, was forced to settle in District 12, and the young woman, since her summons, already reveals herself to be different, be it because of the multicolored dress she wears, or because of the snake she hides in her costume to defend herself. Of course, the reader must expect the classic attraction between mentor and tribute, but even with that the author works trying to avoid mere clichés tired of this type of approach, keeping Snow resolute in his extreme selfishness that only allows him to do things that directly benefit him. Or indirectly.The tenth edition of the Hunger Games itself becomes an "origin story" in a way, as there is an abyss of differences between what Collins describes in the trilogy that takes place 64 years later and Cantiga's version, which avoids mere repetitions of deadly competition. Here, the Hunger Games are much closer to the gladiatorial fights of Ancient Rome, with the tributes simply being thrown into a simple stadium, with some weapons, so that, in the end, only one is alive. There is no special technology used and the organization of the games does not even interfere or influence their progress. Mentoring, of course, is the first sign of change, but it is still weak and far from the media carnival of decades later, so Collins tries to "insert" known elements here and there, some originating from Snow himself and his desire to showing someone out of the ordinary (which he in fact is), such as betting on tributes, so that it is perfectly possible to make a mental bridge between one version and another. At the beginning of the film, we have a simple human zoo and the stage for the deadly competition is more reminiscent of the Coliseum than the sci-fi forest of the first time we discovered the games. The idea of the story is to show us the transition of the competition to something closer to the reality show that we saw later, coinciding with the rise of Snow and his suggestions that shaped the modern version of the competition, something that begins to take shape here with the retro presentation. Futuristic design by Lucky Flickerman (Jason Schwartzman), donations from the public, drones and the proximity of participants. This, however, limits the film's own sense of scale, which is more gladiatorial than pure spectacle, more crude than innovative, something that has incited criticism from the audience about the film's lack of entertainment, but it is to be understood that director Francis Lawrence - returning with another good job of world building and character development in the franchise - and the production had less scope to work on this side of the story due to the premise itself.The games are less exciting this time, especially because Lucy's survival plot is subsidiary to Snow's arc, making the narrative a little more distant from the competition, which is the franchise's greatest visual and impactful attraction. But it is worth mentioning that the production could have been more creative in terms of action and in the construction of the game participants, who are less charismatic and devoid of the personality we saw in the players of other films. Even the layers about the revolution are left aside, gaining representation here and there amidst the obviousness of the text, with the film trying to create a musical characteristic with Lucy that, for many, did not work in Zegler's forcedly theatrical interpretation and in the displaced composition that those moments come. It's also strange how the Games end halfway through the film, making the final act feel more like an epilogue than a climax. The narrative drags between a watered-down romance between Snow and Lucy, and more generic representations about revolution, even though the protagonist's good (a)moral turn happens precisely as a result of this narrative line. Maybe the film works better as a character study than a blockbuster action epic, right? The production certainly could have better balanced the different facets of Collins' prequel, as the Katniss film series does so well, but it lacked drama, vulnerability, personality and scope for the origin story to be close to the Girl on Fire's journey.At almost 2h40, the film becomes tiring, especially after the plot that actually shows what the tenth edition of the Hunger Games was like. This characteristic is also felt in the book. With 571 pages, the publication chooses not to end at the climax, but rather to show another layer of Snow, which clashes with the rest, although it is important for the construction of the character. Even though it cut a lot of things from the original story, something common in any adaptation, the film cannot overcome this characteristic and it is quite possible that many fans will end the session somewhat tired. Despite this, it is also possible to end the session with a feeling that "The Ballad of Songbirds and Serpents" is a story that needed to be told. Although it is bittersweet to reach the end knowing all the atrocities that will still be committed by Snow, there is a feeling that, now, we deeply know the nature of this character and the origin of the Hunger Games itself, as it was shown in the main franchise. Not pleasant, but completely necessary. Both the book and this film adaptation do not succumb to the obviousness of this premise. The Coriolanus Snow of 64 years in the future echoes well in the Coriolanus Snow of 18 years and Suzanne Collins uses her narrative verve to expand the dystopian universe she has created so well. It is by no means a necessary book, but among the many unnecessary books out there in its category, this is one of the most interesting.

title: Almost a masterpiece
text: To start off I have not read the ballad of songbirds and snakes book, but I have read the other hunger game books and watched those films. I have to say I thought this was better. A controversial take but I will stick with it. The acting is brilliant, the story has me thinking about morals and the choreography is well done. The film does not disappoint and is one of the best I have seen in a while. It does have its disadvantages such as how I can never decide if the film is too long or too short and there are several loose ends that I don't think will ever get wrapped up. Either way it's still a film worth watching and I would recommend anyone who can spare 2-3 hours to watch this film. Now I need to go read the book.

title: Mediocre at best
text: The movies script could be a bit more polished and the cutting should have been more heavy. It feels more like a musical than a movie. Rachel Zegler (Lucy Gray) is so unlikeable in this movie that she should have been recast. Tom Blyth (Coriolanus Snow) gets dragged behind her and he feels a bit off. We sort of get why president Snow turns up to be like he is but.... Then the ever lasting song starts. It breaks the mood more than adds to it! NO chemistry between the two either. Peter Dinklage is a cut and paste from game of thrones but in a more boring way. Shame. He is sutch a good actor. The rest of the cast feels more like filler than adding to anything. I do think you should see the movie, but save your money and wait untill it's on a streaming service or a cheap rental.

title: Pleasant Surprise
text: Though the whole movie moved fast and each part was shortened,it really had an intriguing plot so good riddance to the writersThe cast Esmeble delivered well,the only problem the movie had was it didn't give the characters the time to display different types of emotions to do what they didConsidering the fact that it was originally supposed to be a 2 part movie,time as well as costs made it into a single movie,the colour grading fit the narrative,the early rebels as well as the why President Snow became the way he did, despite not being given a chance for his character to fully become the man he did.Really enjoyble film,reach the conclusions your own and don't let any film critic tell you a movie is bad,they can never be objective.

title: Perfection in every sense of the word.
text: It was perfect. The feelings of disgust, anger, sadness, they all washed over me at the same time in the movie as in the book. They nailed every character, every line, every emotion. There was a period while reading I put down the book out of pure anger at the circumstances, and in the exact same moment, I felt the urge to leave the theater. Despite knowing how it ended, I spent the entire movie rooting for characters and experiencing it as if I'd never read the book. It left me just as unsettled, just as memorized, just as addicted as I had been when I put down my copy of the book for the first time.

title: Truely a Mixed Bag
text: Having read The Ballard of Songbirds and Snakes a long time ago, I remember that it was nowhere near as good as the OG hunger games trilogy.And the movie seems to echo that.I was disappointed to see Snow painted an utter antagonist. Yes, he killed his friend and his moral compass is very askew, but isn't he preserving his and Lucy-Gray's life? Isn't he doing it out of love? There is good in him, up until his last breath. But why does the movie force us to think of him as a mad killing machine in the third act? Speaking of the third act, it is extremely awkwardly paced near the end.I'm sorry to say but Lucy-Gray is nowhere as likeable as Katniss, where she detracts from Snow's storyline. Rachel Zegler's performance is so overpowering to the point where it feels adds disbelief to the plot, and elevates it to an emotional level that is nowhere near realistic, while Jennifer Lawerence's performance is grounded and natural, which amplifies emotions with the audience far better.There is too much singing in this movie. I get it, Rachel Zegler can sing, but that is no excuse to turn this movie into a musical. What makes it worse is that the songs are so stylistically sung that it clearly doesn't fit in with the scene's emotional tone, or that it is blatantly obvious it was recorded in a studio.Also, it is extremely hard to like any of the characters in this movie. Their backgrounds are glossed over. There was no real interaction from Lucy Gray prior to her reaping. It wasn't like the Katniss/Prim dynamic. Plus, the awkward camera angles and the POV of the games from Snow felt like there a massive lack of stakes.Positives, well it was good to spend a few hours in Panem again. The nostalgia was good, and so were the references to the original films, although they were completely unnecessary. That being said, I think I'll watch the original hunger games trilogy again to actually feel something more surreal.

title: «Enjoy the Show!»
text: In times of ever more totalitarian regimes in the real world and omnipresent war news from all over the world, the fictional, deliberately media-critical «Hunger Games» prequel comes just in time: a singing Rachel Zegler and blonde Tom Blyth play excellent roles, Jason Schwartzman (as TV-presenter Lucky Flickerman), Viola Davis (with a piercing gaze) and «Game of Thrones»-star Peter Dinklage are nice additions. The plot is lengthy and epically long (2.5 hours), but once again the décor, the backdrops and the change of location towards the end of the film are fascinating. Original quote: «Enjoy the show!»

title: A Good Movie That Unfortunately Suffer From Pacing Problems, Some Of The Writing, And Too Long Duration
text: I found The Ballad Of Songbirds & Snakes as a waste of a good movie, literally, this movie could've been great IF the pacing was faster, some of the writing done better, and it's not 2 in a half hour long, wish they could just trimmed down the duration of the film, because the rest of the movie was actually pretty good, the best thing and the big W for the movie was all the performances, it's a very well acted movie throughout the film, the special effects was great, the song and the score was great, and the story for the most part was pretty interesting, and it's very unfortunate that the pacing was way too slow from the beginning and it's 157 minutes long, knowing that, i already get tired and pretty boring while i still try to get to the story because i also still realizing what happen in the screen was actually not bad, it wasn't amazing and it did not make me excited but it's not bad, another thing i don't like is now that we all know how Snow became this evil person, i just don't satisfied with the reason behind it, i actually find it pretty lame, i'm not like "i get it now how he become this evil person", the movie have three parts in it, while the first two felt like one movie, the last part felt like completely different movie and the weakest part of the film although towards the end it gets pretty interesting, so overall The Hunger Games: The Ballad Of Songbirds & Snakes is actually a good movie that unfortunately suffer from pacing problems, some of the writing, and too long duration.

title: An absolutely phenomenal film holy moly
text: This movie is a prequel and still, in my opinion was the best out of the franchise. The casting was absolutely perfect, the wardrobe was beautiful, the plot kept you entertained, and the songs were absolutely lovely Rachel killed them. I can't usually sit through long films but this one kept me amazed, it had me jumping out of my seat and clapping or screaming. That hype feeling men get during football, that was what I felt. To add to everything, snow was such an attractive man, he had all of us women gasping for air. The movie was sectioned into three different parts that went in depth on parts to the story line. If I could rate this higher than 10 I would. Best movie of this year by far.

title: Most disappointing piece of Mid
text: Might be the most mid film to ever exist...If you're expecting Rachel Zegler (Lucy Gray) or The Hunger Games themselves, then you're 100% going to be disappointed. Rachel has about 10 minutes screen time and the Hunger Games only last a few minutes and we don't see much at all.This is a President Snow Prequel, and nothing else.It felt way more like a mini-series which got slapped onto the big screen for the sake of it. Nothing about this felt like an actual film.What a disappointment.For the time Rachel does have on screen, she is great. Viola Davis is fantastic as well, and Jason Schwartzman is fantastically cast.

title: Swing and a miss!!!!
text: As someone who has read the book multiple times, this is an awful adaption of an incredibly well written book. The entire movie is rushed to the point where it should have been split into two. Important characters are barely involved or completely cut out. How do you show Clemencia get bitten by the snakes then nothing of her afterwards????! No Pluribus Bell, Satiria or interactions with the Plinths... Viola Davis is a remarkable job with what she was given, but come on!!! No Hippity hoppity, not once? So much of the fear of her character comes from her craziness and it was missing.There was absolutely no chemistry between Snow and Lucy Gray. Their relationship is completely left out of the movie and that is due to the rush through of the story. Rachel Ziegler was a terrible choice for this role. She may be able to sing, but cannot act at all. Her entire portrayal of Lucy Gray was off and disappointing.The book it full of character development for Coriolanus Snow that isn't depicted in the film. You don't see the struggle he has within himself, let alone the final blow to his goodness by loosing the trust and love of Lucy Gray. This change is what makes Snow who he is later in life and why, I believe, he hates Katniss. There are many similarities between these two women and Katniss reminds him of a past weakness and betrayal. This is shown by subtle foreshadowing. Unfortunately we don't see these changes of character in the movie and that is the entire point of the book. To find out why Snow became an evil and spineless person without feeling.So many important moments were left off or changed that it was frustrating and took every ounce of self control not to walk out of the theater. Poorly done...One last thing! Great job Rachel Zegler, you succeeded in ruining another movie just by the charm of your horrible acting, singing, facial expressions and explicit talent to not learn any skill required to succeed as an actress. Amazing casting for Snow, that guy nailed the role, but holy moly what a utter pile dog-sheet this movie was because of Rachel Zegler. Don't even get me started on the singing. Its unreal how this unfunny personality is getting such major roles whereas super talented talent out there never sees the light of the day. Rachel Zegler is an absolute talentless person and should not be given roles as significant as this one.

title: Loved it!
text: I thought it was an excellent adaptation of the book. I was quite worried it wouldn't have the same character and unique touch that the original films had, but i have to say that everyone involved absolutely outdid themselves. They deserve their flowers. The performances were just so incredible and this movie brought so much more to the table. A very good prequel to a very well loved franchise.An especially wonderful part of the movie was the music- They managed to capture the liveliness and spunk of Appalachian- folk music quite well and i loved watching all of the musical scenes (of which there were quite a few!) Rachel Zegler is a really special performer.

title: Low expectations. Still negatively surprised.
text:
I guess this is just what Hollywood has come to. I always expect more, but no. The audience still get treated for what we are to them; cold cash.It's hard to say where this movie went wrong, because not much went right, really.The movie is set in the amazing dystopian universe created by Suzanne Collins, that the first 2 Hunger Games movies could, to a fairly high degree, do justice.Unfortunately, this movie does everything but. The storyline is scattered all over the place, none of the characters are remotely interesting and the writing is just... oh man. Stop singing!!!The only two good things to say about this movie, are:
1. The production value is high (kudos to the people trying to do their job, even when the state they work in is way below their standard).2. Some of the actors do a good job, considering the scripts they've been given. Tom Blyth and Viola Davis are the two main names here.Unfortunately, the singing Rachel is also in the movie, so you kind of forget that some of the actors actually try to do a good job.Needless to say, I won't be wishing for any snow this winter.

title: About 30 minutes longer than it needed to be
text: My overall impressions are, it was good and the story was intriguing and the characters were mostly interesting, some of them were bland. But 2 hours and 40 minutes was just too long. I haven't read the book, but I am a fan of the original trilogy, so for me, there were just too many long drawn out scenes too many cuts of characters staring off into the distance, and it was a bit overdramatic at times. Some of the characters didn't have good chemistry. But I did like the music in the movie, I know some people didn't.The main "villain" of the story was just ok, and much of the on screen performances, came off as awkward. It felt weird to be thrown in to the story where we were It's the 10th annual hunger games and they don't really explain a whole lot. I just want to see what happened during the first hunger games.

title: THE RISE OF A TYRANT
text: How do you create a tyrant? Well let's see, you begin by dismantling him and bring him up in a nation and a world full of venomous snakes (so to speak), and then you take that man, and you begin to unravel him. Nothing says blood and more blood than the fact that you cannot get it out, it leaves a nasty scar, and it stains too, not just on clothes, but your cold, cold heart.There is no wander Suzanne Collins wanted to revisit Panem, she wanted to tell the story of how one kid became a ruthless dictator and the why and how behind it. Now I refuse to sit here and tell the story, no I will let you be the judge and character of that. This prequel will not only be the greatest in this series, but I will say Francis Lawrence has done it yet again.Nothing screams blockbuster, then this one. This move has defied all odds or as the tagline for the series says, "may the odds be ever in your favor." The odds are that you will not survive the arena. The entire cast was just phenomenal and the storyline leading up to the first movie left a lot of holes filled in. This cast including the talented and most gorgeous one of all.... Ms. Viola Davis, she can be sinister and yes, I have seen it, but not this sinister. To the newcomer Tom Blyth, congratulations dude, you just made Donald Sutherland very proud.To the beautiful Rachel Zegler, I said this for West Side Story, and I will say it again, seductively incredible - I cannot begin to tell you how incredible you were. To the rest of the cast Peter Dinklage, Hunter Schaefer - awesome.Thank you, Suzanne, for bringing us back to Panem, we have lost it over the last 9 years since Mockingjay, Part 2 - thank you, thank you.This movie was in a word sinister and wonderful rise to the threat of Panem through the eyes of Coriolanus Snow.

title: The Best From the Series!
text: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is the prequel to The Hunger Games, were they show us the first original beginnings of the games. Everything was less technological and looked more like a Gladiator arena, and here I could really feel that they were fighting to survive, the connection between the tributes was really strong, and they made that danger feeling much stronger in here, then in the original movies. It was also about the story of President Snow, how he started as a young man that had plans for a bright future, but ended with an evil path, with rage and madness. His story, and how his rage was evolving, was showed greatly, with complete understanding. The movie itself, did have dominating pros, but could have fixed some things. The pros, first of all, was amazing storytelling. They distributed the story in three parts, each chapter about a specific topic. I liked the prequel best from the franchise because it was richer story. In the originals, they focused mostly on one topic, but here, they included more of everything. Story, feelings and character development. President Snow as a character was amazingly performed by Tom Blyth, as a lost boy of perfection and squareness. Rachel Zegler as the songbird, Lucy Gray Bird, was the movies mystery. She was like an incomplete book, and made her more an interesting character. Rachel Zegler took her role, and personally, she is a very good singer, she is very pretty, but her acting is decent. Her acting could be better, her expressions could look more realistic. Her songs were good, though, they were mostly about the society and people of district twelve, and gave me a bigger understanding of their culture. The first Hunger Games was ok, but it always missed a puzzle. It didn't really explain the nature of the country, society and culture, something they did in this part, and made it finally a complete picture. Good scenography, editing and action sequences. The Hunger Games fights were very entertaining, very barbaric, and some of the kills were pretty well made, with good dramatical scenes and so. They could focus a little bit on the dialogues, more originality, even though it was good enough. The beginning with an impressive intro ended with a good, dramatical outro, and closed the movie complete. To conclude, this is the best Hunger Games so far, and I hope maybe some day the story will continue in a similar way as this one.

title: Why all the movies have to be so long now?!
text: Another film victim of length mixed with pace. It's ultimately the big complaint I have. Sometimes it becomes slow and eternal. A few editing touches and the film was among the best of its year. However, technically it's good. The photography is an attractive set of contrasts and realistic colors within a retrofuturistic world. The stumbling block that photography has is the choice of lenses. It wants to fit too much into the frame, which distorts the edges of the frames a lot, making it look a little uncomfortable to watch.The performances are generally good. Nothing to highlight and nothing to reproach.The jewel of the film in my opinion is the production design. A post-war world that is in active reconstruction thanks to technology is portrayed with great effectiveness. The exterior locations are beautiful and very well used.With this new story of the saga, the desire to see a new magical world of Harry Potter, for example, is rekindled. I have faith in that new WB project. (It's totally a different dish, but I wanted to comment it anyway).

title: Rushed and disconnected
text: They didn't allow time for suspense in so many moments, the whole thing felt rushed like it should have been two films. I appreciate it's a long film but that's because they were trying to do too much all in one film. Some of the actors were over the top and theatrical rather than displaying substance which was surprising considering the big names in this movie. Some big names in this film yet they disappointed us as they really felt to of lacked depth. I've seen them in films where they have been truly astounding yet they fell flat here. I can't help but wonder if it's because of how rushed this was, you didn't have time to become invested in any of the characters. The previous hunger games reallly felt powerful and hit a nerve, this felt showy and lacking in depth. On a positive note I liked the singing and the female lead, I just wish they given her more time to provide suspense in many moments instead of rushing through. The scene with the snakes was fantastic.

title: A pretty damm good film.
text: I have never read the books before and it has been many years since I watched the movies. But I really enjoyed this film. Racheal Zeglar is awesome. I really enjoyed her performance. As well as the dude who played young snow. The movie feels like two movies but for some reason, it didn't feel bloated. It actually flowed really nicely. The third act was cery unexpected and took a very different tone in storytelling. I found it a little shocking if I am being honest. But I liked it alot. The first act 8s exactly what you think the film is going to be and the 2nd and 3rd act are pretty interesring with how different it is. But I enjoyed it. The one problem I had was that I would have liked more expansion into the plot points in thr third act. I could tell the screenwriters cut alot of that middle act out, even though I didn't reas the books. ButnI will give the film 8/10. Very good film. Must watch.😁

title: Overall good, but still left unsatisfied
text: First let me just say kudos to the movie for sticking to the book. I especially liked the way they portrayed the games and the ending, however some parts of the movie left rushed.Now let's talk about the character portrayal. We saw some really good performance from Viola Davis, Dinklage and the actor who played Sejanus was exceptionally good! However, our dear President Snow failed to evoke the intricate emotions we felt when reading the book. In my opinion, the actor who played him wasn't able to showcase the complicated emotions Snow goes through in the book. As for our songbird, Lucy Gray, I didn't see her in the movie at all. The actress who played Lucy Gray was very very pretty and she has a great voice, but her performance on this was abysmal. Her accent was awful and confusing, and her acting felt so insincere. I connected so well with the book Lucy Gray but on screen, I didn't feel the same with her. Her singing was great, but even still, I wished they had made it feel more like a real person singing instead of a musical performance from a pop star. Even the Hanging Tree song - when Jennifer Lawrence sung in the movies I felt chills on the back of my neck. It was so raw and evokes the emotions you felt in the book. In this new movie, it was sung on a higher note and it just didn't feel the same.Also, I was confused about some of the dialogues on the movie. It left like 2023 language was being used and towards the ending you get the feeling that you're watching a 2023 movie instead of a movie set on a dystopian era at a dystopian place called Panem. Compared to the original series, this movie did not transport me to a different world. Perhaps, I'm nitpicking too much...Overall, this movie was a mixed bag of emotions. Though peppered with commendable moments/performance, the movie failed to whisk me away to the world of Panem and didn't leave me dejected and longing for more like the book did.

title: A mixed bag
text: Prequels. AKA tying one arm behind your back.Whatever the writers try and do, we know who Coriolanus Snow becomes, and we are always looking for the signs of what leads him down his future path.Unfortunately the moments that show Snow's future path are a bit too subtle. If you didn't know what was going to happen, a lot of them come across as him being a bit tense and over-reacting.The other main issue the film inherits from the book (which I haven't read but my children have) is the three-part structure. The film ends up telling two quite distinct stories: one is an early example of the Hunger Games; the other is about Snow's military career. This pads the film out to a saddle-sore 2h40m. They should have chosen one of the stories and got it done within 2 hours.Performances are a mixed bag. Rachel Zegler's accent was a mistake, and the fact that she has a song for every plot development can be jarring, but it suits the odd atmosphere that pervades Panem. It helps that she is a very good singer.Tom Blyth is a bit flat as Snow. He doesn't have a fraction of the charisma that Donald Sutherland brought to the role.Viola Davis' Dr. Volumnia Gaul goes too far over the top, with oversized rubber gloves and a whole range of unsettling facial expressions.However Peter Dinklage and Jason Schwartzman are both excellent, with Dinklage capturing world-weary contempt for his students, and Schwartzman bringing much needed laughs to the weatherman-cum-death-match-host "Lucky" Flickerman.The supporting cast are mostly disposable, even Snow's best friend Sejanus is barely developed, and he spends a lot of time on screen. This film doesn't have the depth of characters of the original trilogy.But despite these criticisms, it is a (mostly) enjoyable film. The costumes and set design are great (even though there is heavy use of CGI in the backdrops), there are a few moments of tension, and the story manages to tick along. The best sequences by far are the Hunger Games contest and the final scenes.A fair effort on a story that was always going to be a struggle to tell.

title: Runied bye the female lead.
text: I don't know why this girl or young lady was cast. Having JL as the main female lead in the last one. In my opinion she RZ can't hold a candle to her previous female counter part. She is so mono tone and her facial expressions are very lacking. She just was not near ready for this type of role. Her past roles she could get by just being somewhat pretty and that's about it. I think the movie industry has never recovered since covid. And trying to reboot everything isn't helping. PD and VD do an amazing job. The main male character does well. However the two have zero chemistry it's like AH acting next to JD.

title: I did not at all expect to even like this film but I LOVED it!
text: Films that epitomize the essence of movie-making often begin with a compelling story. "The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" is no exception, boasting an outstanding narrative alongside remarkable acting, producing, and cinematography that immerse you in its world. Although the film starts somewhat slowly, this cleverly serves as a plot device to foster empathy with the main characters, allowing us to see reflections of our own choices and dilemmas on the screen. Have you ever sacrificed something you love for a necessity? Have you made decisions that altered the course of your life? This movie explores these questions and more over its engaging two and a half hours. It reminds me of films like "Titanic," which don't just transport you away from your life but place you in another's shoes, prompting you to contemplate your own reactions in similar situations. For those who appreciate the preceding works, this film is a solid choice, paying a subtly ingenious tribute to its predecessors. It is replete with plot twists that cleverly subvert expectations. Special mention must go to the young actress McKenzie Lansing, who portrays a villainous character with a pitchfork. Though her role is brief, it is intensely visceral and memorable. In conclusion, this film truly encapsulates the author's vision for an engaging sequel.

title: "THE HUNGER GAMES: THE BALLAD OF SONGBIRDS AND SNAKES" REVIEW
text:
Directed by Francis Lawrence. A runtime of two hours and thirty-seven minutes. With a PG-13 rating."Coriolanus Snow" played by Tom Blyth lives with his "Grandma 'am" played by Fionnula Flanagan and his older cousin "Tigris" played by Hunter Schafer. "Snow" father helped create the "Hunger Games" with his best friend at the time "Dean Casca Highbottom" played by Peter Dinklage."Snow" and his family should be living a life of luxury instead their faking it until they make it. That financial strain will be over once he gets named top of his class. But that's all about to change when "Dean Casca Highbottom" changes the rules. Making all students have to get and mentor a tribute in the tenth annual "Hunger Games"."Snow" gets paired with district twelve "Lucy Gray Baird" played by Rachel Ziegler. "Dr. Volumnia Gaul" played by Viola Davis oversees the "Hunger Games". Not only is she twisted and smart but she's taking a liking to "Snow"."Snow" will have to improvise the best he can. His family is depending on him, "Lucy Gray Baird" life is depending on him along with his potential future or lack thereof. All while prominent people are watching his every move. Let's not forget this is also during a highly tense time when the districts are always plotting for revenge. We all know how it ends in the long run but find out what led "Snow" to become the man we all know and despise."The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" was a decent prequel. It showed a more in-depth look at "Snow" while seeing some familiar faces from the previous films. "Snow" wasn't all bad which was surprising, he was still conniving though.I expected more singing just from the title alone but all the singing that took place made sense. I loved Viola Davis's character she was odd and kind of spooky.If you're into this franchise you will love this film. If you didn't care for this franchise then it's more of the same. I was never the biggest "Hunger Games" fan. But I did enjoy some of the films and the creativity of certain scenes. I liked them better than this film.It was a little long and after what I thought was a pivotal conclusion, there was still a good chunk of the film left. It felt like there should have been a period instead it was a comma. It made sense and tied into the actual end somewhat. I still felt they could have edited down some more because it just left me asking more questions than anything.They left it open to have more films which I expect them to do. For someone that's not a huge fan of the franchise I still think it was a decent film. I give it three mor fires 🔥🔥🔥.#CosmoandtheMovieWithin
#CosmoMovieBlog
#CosmoLanier
#TheHungerGamesTheBalladofSongbirdsandSnakes.

title: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes (2023) Delivers the basics, but does not evolve
text: If there's one popular franchise that I can't seem to like, it's the Hunger Games franchise. None of the films gave me something wonderful and so special that it left such an impression on me. This new release doesn't deviate much from that. It is again a very weak film that fails to develop a story in a captivating way. This actually occurs during the middle of the film, where most of the action scenes take place. The film as a whole always seems to drag on, but part 2 is much better than the rest precisely because it escapes this tiring pace that doesn't go anywhere. Part 3 is where it gets even more tiring. The film always seems to be coming to an end, but it never ends. The beginning and middle seem not to be connected with the end. It feels like you're watching two movies and it ends up being even more unbearable. There are many problems in the development of the story as a whole, especially those of some important characters. It's a mediocre film that doesn't deviate from the franchise's standards. It's not the worst, it's not the best. It is a film that becomes forgettable.

title: A perfect adaptation from the book
text: As someone who read the book, I thought the movie was very similar and I really enjoyed the it. I think that most of the people that are having problems with the music, the pacing, and connecting to the characters didn't read the book. The book had the same pacing and the music was very important. Rachel Zegler is an amazing singer especially since she sang everything live. Tom blyth did a great job as Coriolanus. I loved the seeing everything come to life in the movie. The sets and scenery looked amazing. I think that this was a really good adaptation of the book. I also think that people expected it to be more like the Jennifer Lawrence movies, but this was its own movie and it did really well on its own.

title: Not just a winner, a spectacle
text: I came u to thus movie thinking it may be bad but I had high hopes. And boy were my hopes blown away. The score, the story, the production value, the acting, I was in awe. Every moment in this film is foing something something to help move it along. The pacing is really good considering this is almost 3 hours long. I don't even want to the work each character's costume took. Lucy Gray's was especially beautiful. Adding along to Lucy Gray, Rachel Zieher plays her wonderfully.
