She seemed a bit annoying at first but I soon loved her. Plus her voice is absolutely perfect. That was one of my favorite parts of this movie,the song are all amazing. I also loves the bittersweet and believable romance between Snow and Lucy Gray. It was perfect in every way. I don't think there is really anything big I can critique about this movie. Tom Byth plays ever emotion of snow perfectly, I couldn't take my eyes on off him either hehe. If you are a fan of the hunger games, go see this right now. It definitely lives up to the past ones and is the 2nd best one.

title: Expected More.
text: Wasn't captivated by the story to be honest. It looked great and some of the acting surpassed the previous movies. The whole singing element was a bit convoluted and I'm not sure it fits the narrative we are used too. Additionally I found it to be much of the same stuff over again. Tribalism in the arena. Characters you love to dislike and very similar Lord of the flies mentality. The back story of Corialanus Snow is something that I was quite keen to understand. But I found the origin story to be unfitting to such a heinous individual. I found it difficult to relate the two versions of him and on occasion forgot that it was a movie about him altogether. Overall it just lacked something. Too similar to the originals and nothing fresh and vibrant. 6.

title: Bored out of my mind. Annoying, unimaginative, just bad.
text: At a little after two hours (out of 2 hours and 37 minutes of run time), I couldn't stand it anymore and with no end in sight, I left the theater before I fell into a coma. The 10th Hunger Games was the shortest, least interesting and unchallenging of all. I don't think the actual "game" even lasted 20 minutes. Gone was all the CGI, the different effects and terrains and all the out-of-nowhere things to challenge the players in addition to the tributes trying to kill each other. I found Rachel Zegler's character, Lucy Gray, annoying at every turn, shallow, not particularly clever, with no real depth or even a back story. I wish they'd just have focused almost entirely on the character of Coriolanus Snow, the mentor, who was very interesting and checked off all the personality points that Lucy Gray didn't. I tried to wait to see how his story played out, but even that wasn't worth waiting for. But, ladies and gentlemen, the first Hunger Games Musical! Zegler can barely get through a scene without bursting into song and her W. Virginia twang in both song and speech is over-the-top fake and gets closer and closer to nails on a chalkboard as the movie goes on. If they left out all the singing, the movie could have probably been a half hour shorter. I love Peter Dinklage, but he looked about as bored as I did. In short, if you're going in there looking for signs or similarities to all the other "Hunger Games", skip this because you won't find it. Save yourself the money and time.

title: Annoying manipulative techniques
text: When I see a movie or show with constant music playing under the dialogue, it tells me the creators really don't care about the story. Not only is this inaccessible for those of us with hearing and/or sensory issues, it degrades the work of your writers. Please stop this practice. Let the actors do their jobs to tell the story and set the mood. Music has become too prevalent in film as it is.Also, many of the scenes are lit too darkly to see what's going on. I could not see the entire opening sequence. This is another manipulative technique that degrades the set design and acting. It's also inaccessible for those with vision issues.Aside from the inaccessible and annoying techniques, there is no character development other than a few minutes of dialogue that summarizing Lucy Gray's life story in an unsatisfying way.

title: Awful acting from Zegler
text: Awful acting from Zegler, i gave her a chance but the movie is like a musical and the depth of the characters is left down trying to make her character more likable and boost her acting career but under the character mask the true nature of her awful personality is seen in through her facial expresions and her eyes. There is non acting talent and love for acting this is pure chase of fame and money !!!In general the movie could be done in more depth slower pase and possibly to make it two parts. Better cast with people full with natural talant and love for acting. There are a lot of young actresses which could do the job better!!

title: It's a Strong Movie, but I Should Probably Read the Book
text: An origin story for the main villain of the Hunger Game series - he falls in love with a tribute, and has a hard time dealing with it.I have not read the this book, so I really went into this movie blind. (I have read the Hunger Games). I can't really comment on how it compares to the book, but I can say that I think it is the strongest Hunger Games movie as a cinematic experience. The acting is quite good, the cinematography and action are beautifully rendered, and the characters were interesting to watch. I think my only compliant is with Snow himself. Without an internal dialogue that would otherwise be present in a book, his motivations feel muddled.I could maybe rate this movie a bit higher, but really I just found it good, but not necessarily great. Most teen and adult audiences will enjoy it.

title: Have you ever gone to an H.G. flick, only to have a concert break out?
text: This is the feeling many viewers of THE BALLAD OF SONGBIRDS & SNAKES are left with by this film. People are demanding more snakes, and fewer songbirds. Previews for this picture suggested that it would feature a plot comprised of wall-to-wall snakes, so it's disappointing that most of its venom is reserved until a long--if not excruciating--two hours have elapsed. Meanwhile, viewers are completely underwhelmed by a main character learning to play the guitar, as she tramps from crowd to crowd warbling her Joan Baez imitations. No one ever said that starving ladies make for the best opera soloists or are likely to achieve any Grammy Awards. I do not think that Karen won very many.

title: The Hanging Tree
text: I have never read this book or any of the books in the series. I've watched all the film and enjoyed them even as their quality was diminishing towards the end. The film puts your right in with the characters and as a result attempts to make you feel something for the characters.With a longer runtime I can say that I was never board or hoping it was wrapping up. They keep the pace set right for how much is covered. The build up to the games, the games themselves, and the aftermath all feel definitive. The one area this movie suffers is its final 15min or so. It an attempt to keep this film under 3hrs the ending feels rushed which somewhat undermines the story and it's core characters.I can look past this for the most part because everything else before hand is so great. It's been a while since I've seen the original films but this one stands out to me. I walked away from this feeling more satisfied than I did with Mockingjay Part 1 and maybe even Part 2. Don't hold me to that though. It's been a while!

title: A good but maybe slightly over-hyped film
text: I must admit that despite enjoying this film overall, I was left slightly underwhelmed.Starting with the positives, the overarching story is strong and it's so fun to return to Panem. The whole universe holds a lot of nostalgia for me and anyone who grew up on The Hunger Games series will get a serious kick out of this film. It enriches the world that we know from the previous films and fleshes out some vital developments and characters that prove pivotal later on. It also feels quite epic in scope and does everything you could want a prequel to do.The performances are also strong. The supporting cast is out of this world, with colourful characters presented by Viola Davis, Peter Dinklage, Jason Schwartzman. Rachel Zegler is terrific in the role of District 12 tribute Lucy Gray Baird, creating a thoroughly compelling character. Tom Blythe in the role of Coriolanus Snow is intriguing. His performance is really solid, but the character does sometimes feel a little off.This is where some of the negatives start to creep in. Framing Snow as the lead character just didn't work for me. I'm all for expanding the lore of a villain, but this just didn't really get deep enough for me. Despite the good performance I just never bought into this angle.I do also think that, despite being strong overall, the story felt a little bit too segmented. The distinct parts of the film created a bit too much distance from the others and interrupted some of the flow. That's not to say the film was too long at all, it just didn't always flow that well.It also felt to me that too much of the film felt a little bit too corny, which mostly came across in the dialogue. Considering this is a major studio film it also it seemed weirdly low budget at times.Ultimately though I did enjoy this film and it is a good instalment into the Hunger Games mythology. Perhaps I have just grown out of the target audience which might explain some of my criticisms I don't know. I still had fun though, I just maybe expected to be a little more bowled over, especially given the hype this film is receiving.

title: ⭐ The Excellent Story of the Rise of Coriolanus Snow and What a Brilliant Production! It was Gorgeous ✨
text: Just Got out of a Hunger Games Dolby Cinema Screening.Everything was so Well Made.Elements of the Film -1. 💛 Firstly I loved the fact that the 2nd Act is the End of the Games and the 3rd Act is the Extended "After the fact" Part. I loved the feel that this Layout gave the overall film.2a. 👌 Then we have 5 Top Notch Performances by Tom Blyth, Rachel Zegler, Viola Davis, Peter Dinklage and Josh Andres Rivera as Sejanus Plith.2b. 🤐 Look I am by no means a Rachel Zegler Stan at all, her Sheer Ability in her Acting and Accent were Very Good and at times, her Singing Ability is Quite Something.3. The Screenplay was Great, again with the Excellent acting and Dialogue, and pretty much this is the Beginning of Coriolanus Snow and certain things he went through and did.4. 🎥 The Cinematography was Something to Behold, there were so many Eye Popping Shots. I had to Adjust my eyes multiple Times to take in what I was witnessing. 👀 👌5. (One of my Favourite Scenes) Near the End when Coriolanus picks the Gun up and says "No more loose Ends" Lucy Gray - "Besides me" Coriolanus - "You wouldn't Tell anyone?" Lucy Gray - "Course Not". And then the Look 😶. I Loved that Scene.6. 🗽 The Very Ending with Coriolanus Snow finally coming into his own and will become the Future Gamemaker.7. 🔊 (Bonus) The Sound Design was very good, particularly, the Birds when people are hung. The sound of the Ceiling Speakers and Side Speakers were travelling all around the Auditorium.Overall, Excellent Story, Performances and Stunning Production.

title: A solid entry in the Hunger Games franchise.
text: First thing's first, this film is a jumpscare musical and I can't believe we got two of them this year. That being said, after the shock wore off, I actually didn't mind the songs and they were pretty good for the most part. Props to the production designers for this film, they did an amazing job. Our two main leads are dynamic, with good chemistry. All in all, the entire cast was fantastic, ranging from Viola Davis, to Peter Dinklage. Jason Schwartzman is having a great year, all three of his roles were tremendous, Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse, Asteroid City and now this film. My main gripe with this film is the pacing and structure. That's because the first act is replaced with the third act, the second with the first and the third with the second. Basically, the climax happens during the first 45 minutes, and after that, the story loses its focus and becomes way too uninteresting and boring. But that is all backed up by great visuals and a moving score.

title: We were very disappointed
text: We felt cheated. Love the book's author, loved the entire original Hunger Games books and movies, and my husband and I really looked forward to this movie. As dark as the original stories were, they were bright and colorful compared to this movie. The world in Snow's youth seemed even more dangerous and uglier than when Katniss came into the story, which made me wonder why were supposed to be so worried about her. The acting wasn't very good, the screenplay was awful, and the sense of doom and ugliness made me want to take a shower when we got home. Frankly, we wouldn't encourage anyone to see it. I wish we'd gotten our money back.

title: A Well Done Book To Movie Adaption!
text: The Ballad of Songbirds And Snakes is a solid movie, it's an adaptation of the book of the same name and does a lovely job of following the source material. The storyline as one might guess follows the books, which is the 10th annual hunger games and the point at which they really turn the hunger games into a show, a spectacle with rewards for the victors. As already said the movie follows the books pretty closely so in terms of story all I can say is well done there. They had the source material and they followed it. The only negative I have is them skipping some important parts especially for those like me who've read the book and wonder where the heck did that scene go, I know the movie is already quite long but another 15m and they could have included all the missing 30s to 1m scenes that were not included in the movie but where quite significant in the books. Like for example Corio's adoption by Sejanus's father at the end among many others.The cast is pretty solid overall. We have the beautiful Rachel Zegler playing our heroine Lucy Gray and I think she does a pretty admirable job in her role. She does a good job at singing all the songs Lucy Gray does in the books and she manages to get Lucy's personality down quite well as well which is nice to see. The only complaint I have is her character not being quite right which is not even her fault it's just the difficulties of trying to move her character from paper to screen.Tom Blyth plays Coriolanus Snow and brings him to life on screen. He perfectly portrays Snow's character and personality and most of his nuances as well on the big screen. Lovely casting decision there and I for one really enjoyed his performance.The supporting cast consisting off but not limited to Hunter Schafer as Tigris, Peter Dinklage as Professor Highbottom and Jason Schwartzman as Lucretius "Lucky" Flickerman all do amazing jobs in their respective roles. The only casting I'm unhappy with is Viola Davis as they race swapped her character, That is also the reason the movie loses a star from me. That being said she still does a great job as head game maker and gives us a memorable performance.The VFX and SFX are great, I didn't notice any issues there and the music from Lucy Gray and the Covey makes for sweet listening.Overall a solid film and more importantly a good prequel to the Hunger Games movies and books we all know and love. A well deserved 7/10 from me with my only wish now being a book and then movie made on Haymitch's games in full, Finnick's, Johanna's etc.

title: Good for hunger games fan, average for non-fans.
text: The hunger games; ballad of songbirds & snakes is a desent movie to watch if your a true hunger games fan. However, if you did not watch the first hunger games movies it could be a little bit more boring.In this hunger games, number 11 i believe, you see the beginning of the rise of president Snow. But thats not what this movie suprised me. It is the detail of how to bring back a old version of the hungers games which still could entertain the audience!If the special effects and ''ground area'' must be seen as low quality, the story line should be extra strong. There is little doubt that the cast succeeded in this approach. Clearly this has an impact on the true hunger game fans.That being said.. the actors also gave a pretty decent show away. The only thing what i felt was rushed is the ending. Is President Snow that heartbreaked in the older hungers by a relationship that is less then a year old... i cant really imagine it.. I hope later on there will be a part two with a bigger betray.All by all; a 7 out of 10.

title: Created lots more questions than it answered
text: After Coriolanus Snow's father, one of the founders of the Hunger Games, is killed, the family struggles to stay afloat in the Capital. On the verge of winning a coveted prize, Coriolanus's life is about to change for the better, except the powers that be decide to change the rules of the game. Now, he must mentor his tribute in the 7th annual Hunger Games, except he is given a petite girl who is unlikely to survive. As he navigates the game and tries to win the prize, he questions the morality of all parties involved.The prequel to the hit book and movie series, this movie is the origin story of President Snow, the cruel ruler of Panem. The film does add some depth to the story of the original trilogy but also creates many questions. The movie could be shortened, some cringy parts removed, and the narrative more concise. The film has some fun easter eggs and references that will excite fans. Still, it does an excellent job of entertaining overall and is worth a watch, especially for fans of the series.

title: Never trust a guy in his slim shady era.
text: Tom Blyth is so fine and he played snow so well like if he wasn't a murderous maniac id be so lost why lucy left him ngl, homeboy was left alone for 5 minutes and shot up the sky so that's cute. How much id pay to see Josh Hutcherson and Sam Clafflin in this movie with him id be foaming at the mouth i would watch this movie on repeat like. Rachel is such a good actor i love her sm i thought id hate her after the whole snow white stuff, but she's a great actor. Im trying to fill the rest of this space so yall can know about my tom blyth/josh hutcherson/ Sam clafflin obsession so yea ladadadadada okay im good now bye guys.

title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
text: I couldn't help wondering if Francis Lawrence had just asked for that "Tom fella..." "You know..." The casting director didn't realise he meant that "Tom fella" from "Harry Potter" and got Tom Blyth instead. There's an uncanny resemblance with the blonde floppy hair and the rather linear facial expressions. Indeed, despite a promising (if frustrating) shower scene at the top of the film, Blyth ("Coryo") is really what drags this otherwise quite decent action adventure film down. Rachel Zegler, on the other hand, is full of enthusiasm as her "Lucy Gray" character is selected to fight for District 12 in the "Hunger Games". Meantime, "Dean Highbottom" (the infrequently used Peter Dinklage) has come up with a way to spike the dwindling television ratings. He has decided to allocate one of his top students to mentor each of the captives. Yep - "Coryo" is put with "Lucy Gray". A bit of sabotage changes the nature of the game and gradually our hero starts to wonder if he is on the right side - especially when he becomes a little too emotionally involved with his protégé and attracts the enmity of his own erstwhile mentor. Luckily, the whole scenario is being overseen by the hammily menacing "Volumnia Gaul" (Viola Davis) who is clearly having a ball with industrial scale make up and a barrel of genetically modified snakes. The last twenty minutes smacks a little too much of sequel building, but this film has plenty of action and intrigue, loads of back-stabbing and just a little moralising. Zegler delivers a few folky style ballads confidently and generally does a lively enough job keeping it quite a bit better than I was expecting. It needs a cinema, though - the grand scale effects and photography work best that way. On the television it will probably just come across as a bit derivative.

title: Snow's Dark side is truly the best side of him.
text: "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" is a prequel to the movie that launched the franchise, focusing on the origins of Panem's authoritarian leader Coriolanus Snow. The film is split into three chapters, delivering a trifecta of overwrought, overacted, and overlong. The adaptation of Suzanne Collins' novel explores the Hunger Games' origins and Snow's descent into the dark side. However, the new Snow, played by British actor Tom Blyth, is a bland construct, joining other privileged young Capitol residents as mentors to the youths chosen to compete and die as tributes. Snow is tasked with capturing Lucy Gray Baird, a talented actress from District 12. Snow is captivated by her talent and plans to help her survive the competition. However, he must navigate the eagle-eyed masterminds, Casca Highbottom (Peter Dinklage) and Volumnia Gaul (Viola Davis), who resembles Cruella de Vil in her appearance and line delivery. Lucy's success will be crucial in the film's success. "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" is a thrilling prequel based on Suzanne Collins' 2020 novel, focusing on Coriolanus Snow's rise to power. The film showcases Tom Blyth's transformation from a moneyed pretty boy to a clear-eyed manipulator, showcasing Snow's transformation from a destined greatness to a manipulator intent on crafting his fate. The film's gripping performances, including Donald Sutherland's portrayal of Snow, make it a captivating watch. Dr. Volumnia Gaul emphasizes the importance of creating memorable spectacles, with Viola Davis playing a chic, sadistic character with the right amount of camp, and costume designer Trish Summerville's striking creations benefiting her. Snow's dark side is revealed in "The Peacekeeper," a bold departure from previous chapters. The film moves from the austere Capitol to a pastoral forest setting, creating a romantic and dangerous atmosphere. The 157-minute film slows and quiets down, allowing for tension between two people who trust each other. Lucy Gray's folksy charm is used effectively, and the energy in the film is balanced by the lush, romantic, and dangerous atmosphere. "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" is a suspenseful prequel to Coriolanus's long-standing belief that snow always lands on top.

title: Why Was This Bomb Detonated?
text: There is no saving grace to this movie.The movie is insufferably long, running well, well, over two hours.The story is a bore. Really. Tedious and tiresome.The directing is just abysmally horrible.And then there are the actors. Holy crow, you won't care one bit about them. And the worst of the worst is the girl who plays Lucy Grey. She cannot act her way out of a paper bag. It is of no wonder Disney cancelled Snow "White. She's horrible.And speaking of horrible, adding insult to injury, we are forced to listen to her sing the most dismally boring tunes literally every 15 minutes.My head was going to explode. She has a horrible voice too with poor pitch and a vibrato that will make your ear drums twitch.I truly wonder who thought this movie was a good idea.

title: The education of Coriolanus Snow
text: It's a prequel to the earlier "Hunger Games" movies, set briefly two years after the revolution before the creation of the districts in Panem, and then focusing on the 10th Hunger Games event when Snow is about 19. Essentially, the prequel shows us the evolution of Coriolanus Snow (Tom Blyth) as he becomes the person portrayed much later as Coriolanus Snow by Donald Sutherland.The Hunger Games are much more primitive, but teenager Snow provides input to the shape of the Games that have been suffering from lack of attention. The persons running the games are Dr. Volumnia Gaul (Viola Davis) and Casca Highbottem (Peter Dinklage). Snow and his best friend, Sejanus Plinth (Josh Andrés Rivera), mentor two tribunes fighting in the Hunger Games. Snow is guiding a young woman from the 12th District, a very accomplished singer, Lucy Gray Baird (Rachel Zegler).The film follows Snow's efforts to help Lucy Gray, the Hunger Games themselves, and the consequences for Snow after he is caught cheating to help Lucy Gray. Snow becomes a Peacekeeper in District 12 as punishment, where he is joined by Sejanus and finds Lucy Gray. Snow's viewpoints shift during this period.This "Hunger Games" prequel makes the most sense if viewers have read or seen the originals. By itself, it seems a less flamboyant rehash of the earlier films. It is interesting to see what factors shaped the enigmatic Coriolanus Snow, played by Donald Sutherland. Blyth and Zegler have good chemistry. Dinklage is compelling, as always. Davis' character is over the top.If you liked the earlier Hunger Games movies, you'll enjoy this one. If not, give it a pass.

title: Easiest 1/10 ever given
text: Book to movie adaptations have a habit of cutting out character development and worldbuilding, which is to be expected due to time constraints. This wouldn't necessarily be a problem if they hadn't decided to completely erase some of the MAIN characters. The few people mentioned by name in the movie were rewritten to the point that it makes their characters seem like entirely different people. In the books, Coriolanus Snow is a sociopath who is downright evil and worships his father, who is basically American Hitler. In the movies, he comes off as sympathetic. The directors rewrote lines, added lines, added scenes, deleted scenes, and threw stuff around until they made a jumbled-up mess of the original. It's like the director and writers read the plot points on SparkNotes instead actually reading the book. Out of all the movies I've seen, this one was one of the biggest letdowns. There are so many fans who have waited so long for this movie. Money is not the problem. And neither is time, considering people have waited this many years already. Either Suzanne Collins did not have the ability to offer much input for this movie or she did not care to correct them. Because this movie is a hot mess. Spectacularly terrible adaptation.

title: great
text: Nice movie...The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds" masterfully resurrects the dystopian universe crafted by Suzanne Collins. The film explores the complexities of power, rebellion, and sacrifice with poignant storytelling. Jennifer Lawrence's reprisal of Katniss Everdeen is as compelling as ever, embodying the character's strength and vulnerability. The movie delves deeper into the Capitol's machinations, unraveling a web of political intrigue that adds layers to the narrative. The cinematography captures the stark contrast between the opulence of the Capitol and the struggles in the districts, creating a visually immersive experience. The supporting cast delivers stellar performances, breathing life into familiar and new characters alike. While the pacing may feel deliberate at times, it ultimately serves to build tension and suspense. "The Ballad of Songbirds" is a gripping addition to the franchise, blending action, drama, and social commentary to create a captivating cinematic journey.

title: Better than the originals. Still not great.
text: The first movies felt like a lesser version of Battle Royale. No real substance, just something slightly fresh and too predictable.This felt better. Some actual world building, deeper characters, and actual great character performances.A little tighter story telling and it could have been an 8 or a 9. Instead, it felt like for everything the movie wanted to say, they added 10 minutes to the runtime.I find it a real shame that runtimes keep longer, because somehow we have lost the ability to say something in a more impactful and succinct way.That's really my biggest gripe. And maybe the contract for Zegler was a little too generous on the time spent singing.

title: Best of the Hunger Games movied
text: I just got back from watching this movie, I liked it very much. Tom Blyth did and awesome job portraying Snow. The movie stars of slow, getting to now the timeline we are in and the characters and than the plot starts picking up speed and we are in the Hunger Games again. I was a bit hesitant about this being a prequel of the original franshise movies but this absolutely did not disappoint. I hope this could be a start of a new streak of movies in the Hunger Games franshise. If you are a fan or not you will definitely like this movie. 2 hours and a half flew by.I give this movie an 8 out of 10.

title: READ THE BOOK
text: Pleaseeee read the book and watch the previous movies or else you will be confused, I went to see it with one of my parents but because there was no explanation in the beginning it left them confused on who is who the good news I had the chance to read the book and seen the previous movies so I was able to explain it. One more issue is the spilt parts.Despite this the movie was good and I enjoyed it I think all the actors did an amazing job and the songs were good too, would i recommend it to other people yes I would, only if they seen the original hunger games Movies or read the books. So go see it.

title: Characters lacking depth, pacing totally off
text: The characters of importance to the story all lack depth and proper motivation for their actions. The pacing seems way too quick to establish any sort of connection.I don't think this movie deserves to be titled "The Hunger Games". It doesn't come close to the story telling of the original franchise. Besides, the CGI used in this movie occasionally gives vibes of a low budget production (smoke, fire, ...).Personally, I wouldn't recommend the movie. It joins the ranks of productions like "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them", a pathetic attempt at reviving a franchise which already died happily.

title: GOOD COMEBACK FOR THE GAMES...!
text: A new entry in the franchise is now a prequel (taking place 10 years after the first Hunger Games) as we follow the rise of President Snow (essayed by Donald Sutherland in the first series) as a young man, Tom Blyth, who has seen the worse of the war alongside his sister, Euphoria's Hunter Schafer, but now live in the bustling metropolis of Panem awaiting news if he's won the coveted Plinth prize which his family desperately needs since their finances are on the wane. To add more stress, the new Hunger Games are upon them & the ratings are down so the game makers, Oscar winner Viola Davis & Peter Dinklage, will introduce to this new tourney having the contestants interact directly w/their mentors w/Blyth partnered w/Rachel Zegler (already tagged as someone to watch since when her name's announced she flings a snake in a rival's blouse & sings in defiance to her nomination). What follows is another battle royal (sorry since the Hunger Games were always pegged as American copies of that notorious Japanese classic) w/most of the gameplay located to one environment as we wait to see if Zegler will pull off a win. Francis Lawrence wisely returns back to the fold after directing 3 previous entries already & his knowledge of the material works well enough to mount something familiar which still manages to rankle some genuine tension & disgust at the extreme politics seen on screen (maybe something The Phantom Menace wanted to do?) w/the performances fine & flinty which makes me wonder if there's enough fire in Suzanne Collins' belly to put out more installments to be filmed.

title: Better than I expected
text: I watched the movie like a week ago and to be honest, it was much better than I expected. The new characters were really good, the plot was fun. Of course the other 4 movies are much better in my opinion, but that's definitely a strong entry. There are few little things I didn't like. I didn't like that this new girl turned the movie into a musical (and I noticed it was basically the same song just with different lyrics every time) and I also didn't like how the ending felt kind of rush, but I guess they're going to make a second movie so they wanted to make it like an open ending. But that's all I didn't like actually. Everything else I really enjoyed. I will be honest, I didn't know it had a prequel book from 2020 so I can't really say if the movie followed the book 100%, but other than that, the dialogue was good, the acting, the plot, and my god Viola Davis is one hell of an actor, she's just amazing. I definitely recommend the movie. It's one of the best ones this year in my opinion.

title: Rachel Zegler acts very very poorly!! Really bad movie, Jennifer Lawrence is so much better.
text: The film has little depth and strange things happen out of nowhere without any context. Thus, Snow betrays his friend out of nowhere. And Lucy Gray suddenly flees from Snow without it becoming clear why exactly. Lucy also acts VERY poorly. She is only concerned with being beautiful and charming in the film, you hardly see any emotion, pain or fear. She is just pretty, that's it. You don't believe her, she is not authentic. She seems to be competing in the Voice instead of the Hunger Games. Singing like she is a singer on stage. Instead of being afraid or emotional. Too bad, because her role is important. Jennifer Lawrence was so much better and more believable!!! Snow acted well, and Viola Davis was also excellent as an actress. But it wasn't clear to me why Snow ended up being evil. This is not well developed in the film. All by all, it was a bad movie, and the other parts were so much better. I really can't believe all the positive reviews.

title: Good but felt too long
text: DISCLAIMER: This review is coming from someone who hasn't read the books yet.Big fan of the original series, especially, the first 2 entries. Mainly, I loved the first 2 cause of the actual 'hunger games' part. This one served a different flavor to it since it happened years prior. They weren't that "tech-forward" yet.That said, it was great. UNTIL AFTER THE GAMES.For me, it felt too long. My interest stopped after some scenes post-hunger games. I felt like they could've left those in the possible sequel. The ending also strongly validated this since there were still a lot of questions left.

title: General review, It was enjoyable if u like the franchise 67/100 🃏
text: At the beginning I start quite well I can say it went straight into the hunger fight, the performances were fine, it continued paradoxically by giving some touches to the previous ones, in general it's pretty good and I hope the sequel yes it's up I can say in terms of direction it was good, nice plot, in general I like survival movies, this project can easily become a series (irrelevant), the seven is worth it, although my rating would be 6.7, the ending is a bit surprising, in my opinion it could to become more shoulder and limit a little the love story, hunger games and we expect even more.

title: Awesome
text:
More time...
Once you notice how they feel the need to say « Lucy Gray » all the time, you won't be able to unhear it, it's painful. Lucy Gray this, Lucy Gray that... Viola Davis is excellent, atmosphere and setting are ok, but all in all it feels like you're watching 3 different movies in one, scenario is - again - the main issue. Main actor lacks charisma and just isn't good enough to be a lead. The singing is really annoying, I don't care if it's like that in the book, they could have integrated it in a much better way. The guitar thing at the tribute presentation... is it X-Factor? And I really wanted to like this movie...

title: A solid 7/10
text: This is the "prequel" to the Hunger games series. Set 64 years before the events of the first film, its plot follows the events that lead a young Coriolanus Snow on the path to becoming the tyrannical leader of Panem, including his relationship with the Hunger Games District 12 tribute Lucy Gray Baird during the 10th Hunger Games. It stars Tom Blyth ("Billy the Kid") as Snow and Rachel Zegler ("West Side Story") as Lucy Gray Baird. I found it to be very entertaining and the performances of the stars are good. And the action scenes should satisfy fans of violent carnage. Also stars Jason Schwartzman as the unctuous but funny Lucretius "Lucky" Flickerman. Only issue I have is Tom Blyth supposedly being a young Donald Sutherland (President Snow in the main series) - it is hard to imagine the handsome Blyth turning into Sutherland! Maybe it is the evil things he does messes up his face! Anyway, I recommend this one as a 7/10.

title: not worth going to the cinema. Just wait for the stream
text: What a horrible movie. I expected the hunger games and some singing like the iconic song but this was something else and not in a good way.It seemed more like a movie about a country singer, which is fine but don't call it the hunger games. The characters were weakly developed and the story was miserable. It was hard to empathize with anyone in the movie and honestly quite boring.They could've taken the time to develop the characters but instead wasted all the time on lengthy singing. I get that singing is essential but there's simply too much of it for a movie like the hunger games.Not a movie to watch in the cinema. Just wait for it to stream.

title: Am I a sucker for a tragic story
text: I liked almost everything about that movie. And originally I was determined not to watch it, since I am tired of sequels, but the reviews were so good, that decided to give it a try and I am not at all disappointed.The characters are very believable and the acting is really great. I am very impressed by Lucy and Tom's acting. More him, since his character has many more complex feelings that he does manage not to overpay, hers is more straightforward, but she is apparently singing herself, that is impressive, girl with many talents.The pacing is strange, since the games finished in the middle of the movie, but that is ultimately not bad, as keeps the interest growing.One of the few sequels that are right there with the first in the series.

title: I don't think I was the target audience
text: Let me start by saying a couple things: I think a lot of people will like this movie. I read the original Hunger Games trilogy and loved every second and then saw the movies as soon as I could. I enjoyed them, but was slightly underwhelmed, so I never got around to reading the source material for this one. I decided to go into this movie blind, and I feel like I missed a ton not having read the book. I understand that it was supposed to be the story of Snow and his background, but I felt like it missed the opportunity to display his internal madness (which apparently was a central part of the book through the internal monologue). To me, it felt like he just went crazy because of a girl, and that felt lame. I'll probably need to watch it again to see if I can glean more from it, but that inherently is a problem, which is why I have it ranked where I do. Certainly worth the watch, but just didn't move the needle for me.6.1/10.

title: Boring - Convaluted - Boring - Nonsensical - Meaningless - Boring
text: Not even sure why this movie was made. Made my brain numb. Plot was all over the place. Characters you could care nothing about. Seemed like a show piece for Rachel Zegler to sing horrible songs. Everyone is a bad guy, until they aren't, then they are, then they are all plotting together to basically get to the next scene. Writing: Gawd aweful and presented with no emotion. You're supposed to "care" about the contestants, but you really don't. I really struggled to find any point to this movie. The writers must have just thrown the script up in the air and put it back together as they picked them off the floor. Movie has no "bite" to it. Supposed (I think) to show everyone means something by playing the Games only to not really play the games. Instead just avoid any attempt to win the games, that apparently, nobody is watching. Such a mess of a film.

title: I understand any mixed views it was solid
text: Pretty good for what it is, I'd say Rachel Zeglar is one of the best aspects she's a great fresh actress! I kinda wanted to see sooner glad I got to see regardless I enjoyed a fair amount; I watched the other films months ago which are great especially the 2nd one. There's some stale acting in this I agree with the person that mentioned about the development in series although the story was great and pretty entertaining the bulk of it I don't know about the 7.2 rating to me it's more of a 6.4 at best. As much there's a few flaws it's got plenty of charm and seemed very accurate to the source novel so that's excellent!

title: The fire will spark and the songbirds will sing and the snake will rise
text: The story of Cornelia snow before the hunger games happened a few years later before katniss and all the others were born . The story of how the hunger games started really blew me away of how people from all districts fighted learned to work together. Snow I knew something was about to change him . He wanted to help Lucy win the game by helping her win the hunger games . But after he caused chaos and fear in district 12 I realized snow was starting to become a new kind of man . When the snake bite him and the venom went through his vains he started to form a new kind of form . The snake was his symbol of the hunger games . And Lucy who he was in love with was not ready to love the snake . The songbird and mocking Jay will rise up to snow in the later saga and katniss lead the hunger games by showing everyone that snow was the real president of the hunger games and Lucy who was out in the wilderness or in other districts saw how dangerous snow was after the first hunger games.

title: Missed Potential
text: First of all, the movie is not bad. The setting is great and actually I'd say more convincing than the other movies because it's not as polished and therefore has more depth. For the most part the characters are also quite convincing, although I think the character development towards the end falls a bit flat and thus the movie misses out on its potential to really display Snow's transition in all detail.I'd still recommend watching it, as the music performed by Zegler is really entertaining and fitting and, for me, really portrayed the working-class lifestyle of district 12 with it's blue collar industry and industrial bars.

title: You don't find many movies like this
text: Okay first I think it's best to say that I have only watched the original hunger games and that was years back. I heard that this snow guy is a bit villainous in other movies and that this movie is kind of his backstory.The movie is set into three parts, part 1 and 2 were amazing but I do have to say part 3 did drag on for a little.I think this movie displays greatly how people can turn corrupt through traumatic events. We see this innocent and helpful man trying his best to not only win an award but genuinely try to help his tribute. At the start you are rooting for snow and by the end you almost kind of hate him due to how events changed him.The relationship plot of this movie is great. It's a rollercoaster. It starts off kind of awkward then it gets great and then you kind of predict and know how it will end which is a rivalry.As for the actual hunger games itself, it was pretty good. Considering it was a prequel they dealt with the deaths quite well. It also displays the consequences of cheating and how it can change people for the worse.The host of the hunger games was pretty comedic and I found myself laughing quite a bit. I liked the diversity of the tributes and it displays that literally anyone can die.Maybe I rated it higher than other because I haven't seen the other hunger games but I think this movie was a masterpiece and has you follow this innocent hard working guy that turns into demented being that racks up around 4 deaths.

title: My wife made me see it and it wasn't that bad!
text: I normally wouldn't have watched this on my own but my wife wanted to see this movie. I thought the previous movies were fine so, why not, right?Broken into 3 parts, the story follows the bad guy, Snow, from the original movies. The story is supposed to be his rise and fall, but it never quite commits to that whole part of his arc until the last third of the movie when the writers remember this movie is a character study.I wish they only had two "Parts". The three "Parts" didn't follow the typical three act story structure which ended up making the pacing and story feel disjointed. In fact, I forgot there was a part 3 remaining because the big climax happens at the end of part 2 so I was ready to leave the theatre when "PART 3" was displayed on the screen.Part 3 takes place in an entirely different area with only 3 of the characters from the first 2 parts. It dealt with the aftermath of the previous two parts and this is where it finally got interesting. Suddenly charters were changing, forwarding their own goals, and cautious around people they once trusted. I genuinely would have enjoyed an entire movie based on the 3rd act alone.I'd be remiss if I didn't mention the cringe. There's some melodrama. I wasn't the target audience so take it with a grain of salt, but when the female lead is introduced, she sings at the top of her lungs at the reaping ceremony. You later find out she's a performer, but being introduced to her like this had me literally looking away from the screen in second hand embarrassment. She also sings at the top of her lungs during the climax of the movie during the hunger games which felt a little cheesy.In act 3 they also start referencing the previous movies A LOT out of nowhere. Within 10 minutes they start randomly singing the "Are you, are you" song from the previous movies, they look in the sky randomly and say "look, Mocking Jays!" And then pick up a random root and go "this root is called Katnis!" - it was bad. Stop that.Overall though, I had a good time and if you liked the previous movies and read the books, you'll probably enjoy this movie too!

title: Too much singing ?
text: I read a review of this before I went to see it and it began with the line 'too much singing' I thought - what an odd thing to write - then I went to see it and guess what ? Too much singing - thought it was gonna be a musical once she sang up at the reaping - so disappointing - cheapens the film - also - film never seem to be able to chart the ruse from young person to murderous dictator well at all - the Annakin Conundrum almost - Snow is just too inconsistent - angry one scene And full of compassion in the next one - I don't buy the journey to the Snow we know from the films or the books - let down.

title: No room for love
text: A dystopian romantic tragedy born in a genius mind. Hunger games is euphemistic and satirical of the horrible divides of human society. Story poetically exaggerates and aggravates thoughts on snow's journey. A perilous trek of survival that turns to a venomous obsession driving the song bird away. Snow's character is presented to us as a man who makes a choice to become an enemy of himself. A story with a great script that was supplemented with perfect performances by the cast. Lovely music for the song birds and great sound effects. Great visial effects picturing the wonder of capital. A great addition to the series that must not be missed.

title: The Hunger games: way too long, like its title
text: The Hunger Games return and I'm not sure whySure, I was exited as any to return to this universe and have some fun. While I'm not the biggest fan of the original movies, I still see them as very entertaining. The problem here is the lack of focus and missing some really easy focus points. This movie is really easy to save by simply focusing on one of the storylines more, but it derails itself by being more or less 2 movies in one, and I would have preferred this to be split so we really got a situation where we could dive deep into the world and it's characters instead of a surface level look.Coriolanus Snow is a young man training to become leader of the capital. He and his fellow classmates are assigned to make the 10th Hunger Game more interesting by making the contestants famous before fighting.The biggest issues with the movie to me is the aforementioned lack of focus. The movie is very easy to fixed by focusing on some of its elements more, since they are actually interesting. Making a movie about the first fame Hunger Game is such a good idea. What went right and wrong, how would they turn the people and the ideas, and some of these elements are here, but are never in the forefront. The same could be said about the journey of Snow. He has to turn into something, but that journey is not clear or well-made. The first half of the movie his barely in focus, and by the end, the journey he makes in the second half doesn't match the first. It's a mes. Even the romance aspect is rushed. The movie wanted to do too many things at once, and the result makes a movie that is barely about the things it's about.The characters also lack depth and story to really make us care and root for them. Snow's character is poorly explained, since everybody goes along with his idea, even people in power! Why? He's a kid! The lack of emotions and attachments really got to me, and it bored me.Because the movie becomes boring. It got to a point where I simply didn't care anymore. It goes from one thing and derails into its own sequel, and without the focus it feels uneventful, and it becomes too long, split this movie into 2 with more focus, and you have 2 decent movies.There are some good performances and shots though and some really gripping scenes, some involving guns, some with mockingbirds, it's interesting that the movie feels this well-made while the script doesn't, I think the grandness despaired for me. The Hunger Games isn't big yet, and it can be felt. It seems more boring and lifeless, and that's the point, the problem is that we, the audience, also fell that.I also need to question the Katniss moment from the first Hunger Games. It bothers me that she started a rebellion when she did. In this movie, there is even a Katniss type character doing a similar event to hers. Why didn't that start a riot? Who knows.While some of the performances are good, the dialogue is terrible and the actors don't have a lot to work with, sadly. It makes them look bad, but it's easy to distinguish that it's not the actor but their material.This movie with a way too long title is a mess. I really wanted to like it and while there are elements I did like, the story told just simply didn't grip me at all. It was a boring and too long experience, and the problem for me is that I can see the easy fixes, which means the team missed it somehow.

title: Entertaining
text: When the book The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes was published, I liked it a lot more than I expected (having been apprehensive of it being about the villain of the preceding trilogy rather than any of the other characters' backstories).Needless to say that I was proven wrong and waited for the movie adaptation with baited breath!All in all I think they stayed very true to the source material, especially considering the very limited timeframe a single movie provides.This of course meant that a lot of side characters got the shaft and some nuance was lost (especially relating to the finer points of Coriolanus's inner monologue), but I think they still hit all the emotional beats from the book.Being this time-constricted and still crammed full of plot that needed handling, certain key moments had less time to breathe than I would have liked, but I guess that's always the gripe of book fans with movie adaptations. This could've easily been a two-parter.My favourite casting choices were Lucy, Gaul, Highbottom and Sejanus. Coriolanus was acted well, but I kept thinking how he was too tall and old looking, and I didn't like how fake the blonde curls looked when his hair was still long.The costuming was great I thought, and I loved the academy uniforms with the skirts over trousers.

title: This movie is really interesting. 😀
text:
In my opinion the movie is interesting, all the actors have played an amazing role in the movie and also the star caste is also good,
If you ask me about the story line then I would tell you that the movie is containing a great story,
The movie "The Hunger Games" has a complete fullness of drama. The movie is adventurous and also a science fiction movie,
but the thriller part is also amazing, So it would be worth it to spend time on this kind of movie.Movie also has a emotional part and contains a good action and you will never get bored while watching the movie.Although the movie is a heart winning movie and takes you to his world.

title: Yes, worth seeing.
text: Yes, worth seeing this movie.Liked the telling of the history of Snow. I still don't like him even though I see now why he's the way he is.Liked seeing Viola Davis even though I did not like the character Dr. Volumnia Gaul. She is pure crazy evil.All the actors played their parts well. The songs were good. The story flowed well and was well written. I liked the length of the movie, because it was over 2 hours.Overall they did a good job on the movie and left some crumbs for the fans to wonder if there will be another movie. Hope they make another one. I want to see one where the evil Dr. Volumnia Gaul is killed in the hunger games.

title: If u love the novels, u will like it!
text: Firstly, I can understand there are a lot of people thinks this adaptation is unnecesary, even the book.For me, as a person who read it as a teenager (the first books) and more like an adult the last which is based the movie, is necesary because the message of all the saga is not a stupid love story, is a critic to our society, is the reflect of human actions took it to an extreme.Ballad of songbirds and snakes is the story of how assume the control over a place being cruel, but from the beginning, from the birth of cruel punishment created to oppress the society and forcing it to contribute to make richer the richest.Apart from all of this, is a good adaptation, the directive team decided to suppres some details i would have liked to see...but a movie is just a circle from the rectangular book...

title: Just watched the new hunger games prequel
text: I am a huge fan of the hunger games franchise they are some of my favourite movies ever made so I was eager to watch this and I can say it mostly delivers. Now I have never read any of the books so this story was all new to me. I loved seeing snow's journey and how he changes into the man he is in the other films. Rachel Zeglar while not my favourite actress out there by any means was surprisingly alright, the only part I didn't like about her was the singing some scenes it can come of really cringe and boring. Now the movie does feel like it's two films in one so the run time can drag on a little.

title: It's the things we love most that destroy us.
text: It's like the Panam people made a movie and only rich people played all the characters. Bad casting, bad acting, and I'm normally a fan of Viola. The story wasn't believable and the character development was non existent. Cliches from the fist movies were over commercialized. And the hunger game fights itself was boring. I was a fan of the first movies, and even though they were never oscar worthy, they were entertaining. I loved Katniss so much I even named my Cat , Katniss. Maybe include people from other districts (3rd world countries) when making such movies, to add depth to the story. The characters lack soul, and even the one that shouldn't have a soul was one-dimentional. It had so much potential. It's a good story that was not givin cinematic justice. I feel sorry for the writer of the book. But my partner liked the movie, so maybe it's just me.

title: Melody and Menace: Navigating the Prequel's Labyrinth
text: "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" emerges as an intriguing prequel within the famed dystopian series, weaving a tale that seems primarily aimed at a younger demographic. While the film endeavors to engage a diverse viewership, its foray into musical sequences presents a double-edged sword. The narrative, rich with potential for emotional depth and thematic complexity, might have benefited from a more restrained approach to its musical elements. Arguably, a singular, impactful musical scene could have sufficed to convey the depth of emotion intended, without potentially overshadowing the storyline's broader themes and pace.The movie shines in its technical and aesthetic aspects. The costumes and makeup are meticulously crafted, enhancing the visual storytelling and helping to immerse viewers in the world of Panem once more. The action sequences are well-executed, striking a balance between spectacle and the story's darker themes.Performance-wise, the cast largely delivers. Viola Davis stands out in her portrayal of Dr. Volumnia Gaul, bringing a delightful complexity to her character that captivates the audience. Tom Blyth, as a young Coriolanus Snow, provides a nuanced and compelling look into the psyche of a character destined to become one of literature's most notorious villains. His evolution from a character driven by greed and ego to the monstrous figure we recognize in the subsequent films is both convincing and chillingly portrayed, underscoring the talent of the young actor.The film does not shy away from exploring themes of occupation, reprisal, and the darker facets of human nature, making it relevant and thought-provoking. Through a sinister and despairing lens, it scrutinizes the mechanics of power and control, resonating with viewers familiar with the franchise's critique of authoritarianism and societal inequities.While "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" undoubtedly has its charm and moments of brilliance, its appeal might be somewhat narrowed by its targeted demographic and creative choices. Nonetheless, it remains a worthwhile addition to "The Hunger Games" saga, offering both entertainment and a platform for deeper reflection on the themes that have made the series a cornerstone of young adult literature and cinema.

title: What a great movie! Finally got that feeling and emotion in it, I was waiting for.
text: Welcome, to the 10th annual... review of a ballad of songbirds and snakesA great adaptation. That I love and will hold deer from now forward.I first found the book accidentally, bot knowing there was another chapter to the hunger games out and even that had come out recently. Took it without a thought and loved it.It has its cons, like not having delved deeper into the Snow's woridview and his never stopping thoughts, maybe like seconds to every sequence would've been nice. And a bit more into Lucy Gray's character, interacting little bit more with the world.And still I think the film is amazing, because I still loved it even with these, though small, noticable details, even when comparing to the book's depiction. Amazing take from the book. Francis Lawrence did as always, with few exceptions in that always. The cast too, great performance with a few meticulous edges. For some characters you don't need something more to them, because there is something that is central in the plot and it must stay there not get distracted. They work even that way.The atmosphere was like I imagined when reading, if not then next to that what imagined. Some details and looks and deets were left behind, but first. That's how it is, when they have to make it shorter, which for me longer would've been even better, but that's me and second. Not leave the more important actions out. The important is to make the whole world as it was created and to make it work in people's eyes. I'd say it works, there is thrill, there is suspense, but you have to listen and watch with your whole body and instincts, because every way of talking of a character and some of their moves, show how they are, how they work and what are they, also what they think they are or others are. It's how a character is being acquainted to.So if you want some tension, some good character exploration from the characters themselves, some suspense in the actions forward and a movie with chapters, exploring its story's different stages and development - plus if you want well delivered book adaptation of the same name, then go and watch it, unless you don't like songs in movies - characters that are singers (therefore they sing, because it's what they usually do - not all the time, of course, it's not a musical) , unless you tend to hate adaptation, although try it, but stop judging just because you expected not to be annoyed that much, well you may see if want to go or not, watch the trailers!Thank you for that adaptation and may the odds be ever...

title: The pursuit of perfection is even worse
text: Generally speaking, for classic works that have come out, co-making sequels is the choice of most investors, but the risks are: first, surpassing the previous work. Second, 10,000 people spurned, obviously, this Hunger Games has achieved the second effect, first of all, the rhythm is the biggest failure, the three-hour duration is not the label and necessity of blockbusters, and many blockbusters are long because of the complex story structure., that's why there will be a large duration, obviously the director made a fatal mistake, the overall rhythm is a mess, and secondly, the actors' performances are a mess, is there no actor in the United States? Don't insult the audience's aesthetics and IQ with the audience's feelings for the previous work, if the director can watch the first Hunger Games himself, you are watching this one, and you will know what it means to insult the audience!

title: THE HYPE OF THIS FILM IS KINDA...QUESTIONABLE
text: I had expected more 😭 for all the hype i'd seen on the internet, i had expected it to be epic with deeper hidden meanings.The plot is decent enough compared to the other adaptations of the series. I especially like the costumes as they were more elegant and fashionable compares to those from the previous movies (some can be considered artistic from my pov).I know the main focus of the film is about the young president snow, but the the love line of the two main characters was depicted so briefly that it failed to arouse in me the emotion that i think i was supposed to experience.All that aside, PRESIDENT SNOW IS GORGEOUS. I JUST LOVEEE SEEING HIM IN HIS UNIFORM SM 😭😭😭😭 red suits him perfectly well, and also the curls 😭 the fact that i giggled whenever he appeared on the screen with that uniform on makes me feel even more guilty lol.

title: Disgusting movie, absolutely waste of time
text: Where to begin. It felt like torture, nothing makes sense, because nothing has any meaning of any sort. The scenes, the cinematography and the dialogue feel like a 10 year old made the script and put it together overnight. The actors tried their best, but its not their fault the movie is absolute garbage. It was sad to see Peter Dinklage's talent get wasted on this movie. I think the worst part of the movie is how slow and un-interesting everything was.There was so much potential, and after 11 years from the original 2012 movie, this is absolutely pathetic sequel or prequel.Don't recommend to watch even if your life depends on it.

title: Enjoyable Movie
text: Disclaimer: I've not read the book, so this is based purely on the movie.I really liked this movie. I felt it was a fun prequel that added context to an already rich world.Tom was brilliant. This was my first experience with him as an actor, and it was a great first taste. Definitely has me curious to see more of his work!I felt the number of easter eggs and references was good. Not so much it felt overwhelming or pandering, which is something I feel other franchises do.I do feel the pacing was off. A fair portion of the movie was dedicated to the games. The bit after felt rushed, which was unfortunate because I felt this is where the bulk of the story was.I also wasn't a huge fan of Lucy's singing. It wasn't bad. It just wasn't as amazing as everyone was making it seem.Overall, very good. If you enjoyed the first four Hunger Games movies, I think you'll enjoy this.

title: One of the best
text: It is an engaging film that skillfully weaves tether suspense and drama. The plot unfolds with unexpected twists, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats. The strong performances and atmospheric cinematography contribute to the overall tension, making it a worthwhile watch for fans of the genre.What sets a apart is the strength of its performances. The cast delivers compelling portrayals, bringing depth to their characters and enhancing the emotional resonance of the story. The chemistry among the actors adds an authentic layer to the film, drawing viewers into the characters' dilemmas and conflicts.

title: Better than expected, worse than it could have been
text: I blame it on Lucy Gray, a character so annoyingly righteous and vigorously rebellious that it was very difficult to connect to anything she touched. Fixing just this character would have made this film close to greatness, because almost everything else was good. The casting, the acting, the sets, the story.Tom Blyth was great, Viola David too. Most other characters were filler, but they were cast well and did their job. As opposed to the original trilogy of films, this felt more grounded, more mature. It wasn't perfect, but I enjoyed the film.There were three parts of the movie, the third felt the most rushed and frankly I would have probably liked the film more if it were not part of it. It would have also brought it to a normal length; I hate these modern three hours productions. If you can't tell your story in 2 hours, that's a problem. The story was intriguing, documenting in a tense and oppressive way the rise of a villain, I think one of the most entertaining types of tales out there, but the rushed third part muddled that a bit.I can't believe I am saying this, but this deserved a split into two films. As such, you are left with a bitter aftertaste, like someone took something that you felt had coming from you. Enough to turn one into a villain.

title: Decent
text: Although I never read the books, I eventually grew to like the original films. It's hard not to compare them to this one. To be honest, this film isn't quite as good. I didn't find myself too emotionally invested with the characters. Visually, the film was good and it kept my attention. I guess it was nice to see the Hunger Games world from a different perspective, but I felt a little disappointed by it. It was the one film in 2023 that I was super curious about. I'm currently rewatching the original films and they're a lot more enjoyable. Everything from the cast, the plot and the actors and actresses.

title: Extremely faithful adaptation of the novel
text: People are complaining about the amount of music in the movie. Evidently they didn't read the book. It's incredibly refreshing to see a Hollywood film actually stick to the source material. This film is very well done but could have been a little bit longer the third act is a little rushed. They did a nice job creating retro aspects of the original trilogy's costuming and the overall tone. You are introduced to characters that become major players in the original story as well as new characters that weren't featured in the original movies. This film was perfectly cast, and all of the performances are solid, go see it.

title: Long-winded mess
text: The Hunger Games storyline in the movie struggled with ratings and views, almost similar to the movie's reception itself in the real world. What a long-winded mess that didn't make sense. I looked at my Apple Watch in the cinema a few times thinking when will the movie end. The motivation behind certain characters are not very convincing or not properly elaborated, although the movie itself seemed to have gone on forever. Acting is sub-par, perhaps could have improved with better casting. There was too much singing in the movie that just didn't fit. I was expecting some emotions to be stirred but I felt flat and disappointed after. Overall it was a major let down from the Hunger Games series, especially for fans of previous three installments.

title: Lucy Gray & Turning Snow
text: First thing first : Do not listen to reviews that's either A - have not read the book aka think this is a typical hunger games film or B - didn't expect "more story less action" in a movie with a 2hr 37min runtime...you can't win with these people.Now, let me say the #1 thing this movie did for me was make me feel. The acting & performances were all around spectacular. This was my introduction to Rachel and she was LOVELY. Tom Blyth.had moments in this film that sucked you right out of your seat and put you beside him. Supporting cast kills it, I mean people Viola Davis "the" award queen is in this movie she's amazing.

title: Well....it has to come, didn't it?
text: I really cannot say that I remember any of the "Hunger Games" movies, so i came without any expectations. It was like a clean slate for me, because it was not so anticipated, from my side; so just start watch and whatever will be...will be. Hardly remember Panem and the main characters from the Trilogy, but i remembered president snow as A Character (that was played by Donald Sutherland).Can't say that I remembered him as one of the biggest villains that the cinema has ever seen, so it was not very clear why do we get this movie, that President Snow is his main protagonist / antagonist. Unwillingly, I've started almost three hours of watching and finished the experience pretty satisfied. It was a good movie, with great acting performances and stood by its own, while telling a story with subtext. Don't think I remember it, as i haven't remembered its siblings, but it was pretty solid.The characters were pretty freaky. Peter Dinklage was Dean Casca Highbottom and for the few times he came in the frame he was excellent as usual. Viola Davis as Dr. Volumnia Gaul was nuts. Not easy to swallow this pill and I am sure she was to be less grotesque, or maybe not, but she accomplished the mission, as for her acting skills and impact on the movie.Both actors in the leading roles were fine and especially young Tom Blyth, that took the chance to make a name for himself. Cant say that he was too interesting or I was too interested to see his transformation, but he made it pretty well - the movie didn't and while pacing slowly into the next and third chapter of the movie, suddenly Francis Lawrence started running.The director has told a story about the hunger games and the privileged young people that were chosen to be mentors and how snow was part of the competition, but when he needed to flip into evil, the process was too short and too quick in relation to the progress of the film's pace.As part of my personal conclusions of the several days watching of this movie - it seems that it doesn't have a lot of right of existence, as part of a cinematic universe. Take the fact that the last chapter (which was divided into two movies) doesn't grant the permission to make another one and yet... a prequel was born...cause, money...you know.It's a good old 6.5 and probably will be forgotten until next reboot or whatever movie they will invent.

title: A good prequel
text: I didn't have that much expectations from this prequel as the original movie series was an average experience for me.The movie starts off well, had some ups and downs and ends off well. The story was good and connects properly with the original series, the screenplay was little bit uneven, the direction was good and the performances were great (you can connect with the characters and can understand their motivation). This prequel explained the politics (which is one of the main elements of this franchise) better than the original series.Overall, you should give this movie a watch if you have watched the original series.

title: DOESNT DISAPPOINT.
text: I can safely say that The Hunger Games has risen again, and this adaptation does not disappoint one bit. It was a very well done story, I like that they did it in parts to represent the phases that he goes through. As a fan of The Hunger Games you can identify each of the references to the original saga without feeling tired of it. "The Hunger Games: Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" is a unique and recommended cinematic experience. For fans of the saga, it offers an intriguing insight into the origins of an iconic character, while for new viewers, it is a chance to immerse themselves in a world where the complexity of the characters is intertwined with entertainment.

title: A decent prequel
text: I enjoyed the original trilogy, that were very good adaptations of the source novels. With this being an entirely new story I approached with some trepidation not having read the novel and was pleasantly surprised. I saw on the credits that Suzanne Collins was on board as Executive Producer and it shows, as we get a story much in keeping with the look and feel of the originals.Without wishing to give away the plot suffice to say that the actual hunger games play a lesser part in the story. Instead we concentrate on a young morally ambiguous Snow, played excellently by Tom Blyth. Viola Davis is excellent as the chief game maker, with a good supporting turn from Peter Dinklage. Although I would have liked a bit more of his character. It is a good origin story that stands on its own two feet and allows for a further story to be told before we get to the original and on this showing I would welcome it if the producers are inclined to go for it.I want to make special mention of Rachel Zegler. At the time of writing she seems to be getting a lot of hate online. I don't know why, and I'm not inclined to bother looking into it. What I will say is that this is the first time I have seen her in anything and she is also very good as Lucy Gray. Lucy is not a Katniss clone so don't expect a fierce warrior as portrayed by Jennifer Lawrence. Lucy is a musician, much more vulnerable and placid in the hunger games arena. However, she is important in the development of the Snow we come to see in the original trilogy. Lucy as a musician gives Rachel the opportunity to belt out some songs and wow can she sing, what a voice.This isn't going to go down as a classic movies, but neither did any of the originals. It is a very very good movie though and well worth the price of admission.

title: A Worthy Adaptation
text: I think most fans of the book will like it! I enjoyed it. Whoever did the casting did a great job as the actors cast really fit their roles well. Particularly, Tom Blyth as Snow - fantastic performance. Rachel Zegler as Gray did an excellent job as well. Both Viola Davis (super creepy as Gaul) & Peter Dinklage (very believable as Highbottom) were great, as usual.The grandiosity & lavishness of the Capitol on the big screen contrasted with the ruin & squalor of District 12 was impactful. The pacing was good - action scenes but also a very character driven story. Taking us along for this cinematic ride makes it easy for viewers to see how the younger Snow becomes the man he is when we meet him in The Hunger Games book 1.

title: 6.5 Fun Dreadful Ride
text: I'm a bit conflicted about this one.Prior to watching this i watched all of the hunger games films. If i had not done this, i would have found this movie intolerable. The only reason i was invested was because of the fresh smell of Katniss Everdeen hanging above me. Without the prior films this movie doesnt hold up in terms of engagement. This being said, because of my fresh rewatch i was pretty invested in this story and actually found it really interesting and well construted. This film has great production value, great cinematography and an alright cast.Alright cast... alright. Some of the performers were... not alright. In fact they were quite... bad *cough* Rachel Zegler *cough* The poor writing was no help to her case.I found the film score to be incredibly weak as well. James Newton Howard had a great opprotunity with a hunger games revival to make something awesome. It was not awesome.I Left the theater feeling unsatisfied and BAD. This film leaves you feeling bad. Some good things going for this film, but some downsides as well.

title: Sucked
text: Sorry but the other 4 movies were wayyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy better. I fell asleep in the movie theater and was disappointed I didn't watch this online. Honestly it was boring and didn't keep me interested, although I tried hard. The other 4 movies had more essence, a better storyline, more attention to detail and a better understanding of the outlines of the games. The Spanish actress who played the girl who sang country music was not good. Her singing was the only thing that appealed. Viola Davis was just ok as the previous Elizabeth Banks. Not good enough. The Snow guy looked like Ryan Gosling, but overall this movies was not in any comparison of the previous. I hope they don't make a sequel, it's just doing harm.

title: Coriolanus' Origin Story
text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & SnakesThis prequel provides an origin story for the villain, Coriolanus Snow. As a prequel, this does a wonderful job of setting up characters later seen in the movie franchise, but if viewed as a standalone it falters to shine on its own.The trailer promised a wondrous spectacle but probably due to its drawn-out screen time some sequences lack spunk, especially after The Games are concluded. It's also perplexing that with its extended screen time, a lot of character motivations are glossed over, and the final act is rushed through. The Hunger Games was mostly uninteresting and this can be tied to how we're given less time to invest in the characters, and also in how quickly the games take place.The infusion of the songs is done splendidly and Rachel Zegler's voice pierces through in those scenes.Tom Blythe gives a rousing performance as Coriolanus Snow and Rachel Zegler delivers as Lucy Gray even though she sometimes leans towards theatrics. Viola Davis and Peter Dinklage are this movie's shining light, stealing the scenes they appear in, and it's a crime they didn't get more screen time.In conclusion, this prequel blazes from the hanging tree with good performances and setpieces but is doused by its script and screen time.6/10.

title: MUST SEE OF 2023!
text:
5 ⭐s
I was completely sucked into this film - the story, and the characters were so easy to love and hate that I felt completely transported into Panem and watching Snow evolve as a young man through this film was both stupendous and heartwrenching. The obvious desire for power over humanity becomes glaring when you see how a man's ambition can supersede his very heartsong and Lucy Grey is the perfect heroine to test the valiance of such a man.When you see how easy it is for the madness of war and the degradation of a society controlled by totalitarians who seek only to control populaces using tactics that divide and conquer, it's easy to find the similarities with modernity and how swiftly the descent into madness and gradually becoming the essence of 'evil,' occurs. I highly recommend this film for all people who enjoy seeing the nature of humanity when tested by the ultimate atrocities and how love conquers only when we allow it to.

title: Better than the book!
text: I found the book a bit tedious but at the time I knew if they made a movie I would like it better. And I did!I loved this movie. It was dark and mysterious, and very different from the trilogy.
