You kind of root for Snow, but then, you know who he is so you aren't sure what parts of his character to trust.The movie shows the early Hunger Games, which are primitive and lacking in viewership (no surprise). The main character, Coriolanus Snow, and his classmates are given assignments to mentor the tributes (children) and come up with ideas for the Games.The movie is in 3 parts. I really liked that they made the film long enough to give the different themes time to sink in. I thought it was the perfect length. I suppose the singing could have been a little more engaging because some of the songs were slow but I thought the style fit the period/feel really well.It makes me wish that Collins would write another book in the ~60 years between this and the trilogy, so we can see more of how the Games developed.There's a lot of detail to miss on a first watch. Must see again!!

title: absolute joke of a movie
text: One of the worse movies i have ever seen and ive seen some bad ones. This seems to be a terrible trend with reboots of a successful franchise, simply put the name in the title and any old garbage in the scrtpt and hope it will sell. This fails on every aspect from acting to directing to cinematography. Rachel zegler is badly miscast and really lame, at least jennifer lawrence was believable as a badass but zegler just dosnt cut it. Its about time holywood stopped piggybacking off successful franchises and started to come up with more original concepts before irreparable damage is done to the movie industry.

title: Absolutely Brilliant
text: I go to the movies about 10 times a month. Since 2020, you are lucky if you get one or two good movies a year. Everything else is political diatribe that no one is interested in. Especially Disney, how the great have fallen. This movie, however, was a gem. No politics, just entertainment and damn was it good. Tom Blyth smoked every scene, what an amazing actor. Paired with Rachel Zegler...wow...just drop droppingly good. Those rating the movie with poor ratings because it was different than the book are ridiculous. Of course it's different than the book, it's based on a screen play. Most likely Francis Lawrence never even read the books, as most directors don't. It's a movie, it's a great movie and I would highly suggest seeing this one on the big screen. Enjoy that holiday popcorn!!!

title: Rachel Zegler's Hunger Games Is Worse Than The Marvels
text: As a dedicated fan of dystopian narratives, it pains me to say that the much-anticipated recent Hunger Games adaptation is nothing short of a letdown. Despite high expectations, the film fails to capture the essence of Suzanne Collins' gripping trilogy, leaving audiences yearning for the intensity and emotional depth that defined the source material.From the moment the opening credits begin, it becomes painfully evident that Rachel Zegler's Hunger Games is marred by a sea of cringe-worthy performances that even the most forgiving viewer will struggle to overlook. The cast, including Zegler herself, delivers a collective display of wooden acting that undermines the gravity of the dystopian world they're supposed to inhabit.

title: A true adaptation of a Killer Novel
text: The Hunger Games Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is a win. From the start, it is a story full of surprises, twists and turns. Jumpscares riddle the first half and left me trying to remember the novel and what comes next in the second. I was wildly enthralled and captivated by the fast-paced plot unfolding. This was done in an exciting and engaging way for the audience. Other directors should pay attention to this film as an example on how to adapt book to film. I plan on seeing again asap and can't wait to do so! Fantastic casting, acting from the cast- especially Tom Blythe, and incredible tributes (haha) to our girl on fire. You will laugh, cry and cheer!

title: Don't believe any reviews including this one. There's NO WAY this is a one star movie
text: Please don't take my word or anyone's words in here. Go see it for yourself.I'm surprised by so many haters out there bringing the movie down. My only guess is it's not because of the movie, but for something else. I don't know the main young actors at all prior to this movie and have zero expectations coming in. But I was blown away by this movie. All of my friends who went with me loved it too.The music is hauntingly beautiful. The cast is stellar. And the story really drew me in and made 2.5hrs passed by quickly. There is a lot of parallels to the real world conflicts we are experiencing. That does stir up painful emotions in me. I wouldn't want to do this all the time. BUT I would definitely make an exception for this movie and even go watch it again.

title: Movie of the year without a doubt!
text: I got to experience, for the first time, how book readers feel when they watch a film based on a book and a I have to say I was thrilled. One of the things I enjoyed the most about the film is that we got to see a bit of Lucy's point of view, whereas in the book we only got Snow's point of view.While reading, all I could think of was how it was going to look in the movie and I have to say this movie gave me the chills, Rachel Zegler and Viola Davis stole the show, but overall the cast did an outstanding job.This movie was simply a masterpiece and although I know that this story is "complete", as a fan I can only hope for more books and movies, as long as they make sense and are not done just for the sake's of it.

title: This could be an Oscar level movie with so many wasted premises
text: You can find a review on this everywhere else I will skip to what I felt could have been so interesting and was missed out on.This story has always had deep themes around class warfare, dystopian government, mankind's ability to separate people and make Others Inhuman and able to be treated as cattle. So I think one big missed opportunity is with the plot around the Mentor Program and Corio Snow. Something that has always stuck with me are the servant master relationships we hear about during the American Slavery period. Famously, Thomas Jefferson had a very romantic time with one of his slaves. There should have been more about Lucy Gray, what does she really feel, does she feel grateful? Do they really fall in love or is she playing him? Yes there is that in the beginning but the movie never has the guts to say, these people are in a deep love for each other even though its a sick relationship with an extreme power imbalance. Perhaps they could show her having the power over a foolish Snow. She gets him to rig the games for her and yet has a soft spot for him by the end. Snow could be scandalized by being shown addicted to his "lesser human" girlfriend and therefore his cheating allegations and exile would impact him because he would be deeply grieving feeling that he would never see Lucy again. Lots of ways they could go with this.Also there is just not enough done with the 1960s TV premise. What if this was the first Games in Color? People in The Capital would see the red blood of kids for the first time, would that make a difference on how Panem sees the kids? So many characters could bring you a deep feeling through their eyes of seeing all this awful trauma.How Snow relates to the people on District 12 how it made him change The Hunger Games in how he did how it made him see the people of Panem as human beings and yet how he rationalized seeing himself as worthy of dominating and controlling them at the end, is stuff that can take the viewers on a ride of terror and imagination.The premise, theme, storyline and dialogues of this movie in the right hands are Oscar winning. Too bad they failed on most execution. Another movie that could be life changing wasted in the Hollywood machine. At least it was watchable and had some cool world building so 5/10.

title: Seems to be kind of provocation...
text: The movie notably centers on Rachel Zegler, who appears to excel in every aspect. She portrays the most kindness, despite becoming from occupied district, winning without resorting to combat and effortlessly dodging crossbow bolts, she takes care of friend and even shares Snow's food with Snow... She sings the best and she can do it strong and proud even snakes seem to kill her in the moment.Regrettably, the first two acts lack bright sides, offering only mediocre or subpar elements. Mediocre music - bad plot; mediocre dialogs - bad characters; mediocre locations - bad jokes.The third act, while an improvement, feels somewhat disconnected from the rest of the movie. In the end, the events that unfold don't even matter, because the clue is that Snow was always playing hardball.Anyway I can blind the eye to this nonsens and plot pointlessness and still rate it 3 starts, primarily due to the notable improvement in the third act..

title: I Don't Get the "Not Needed" Reviews
text: I guess that I don't understand the reviews complaining that the movie was "not needed." What movie is ever needed? A movie should be judged for its intrinsic qualities, not by the need that it supposedly fills or lacks, and for me the movie was definitely a welcome surprise.To be honest, Rachel Zegler is so irritating in interviews that I was expecting to hate the movie because of her, alone, but given the singing requirements for the part, I can see why she was chosen and that she was probably a good fit for the role. She didn't run away with the spotlight, but she held it, which is all that the supporting role required. (The main character is not Gray; it's Snow.)I thought that the world building was sound. You'd expect a movie set 64 years before "The Hunger Games" to depict a less advanced society, and the movie does a good job of unwinding the level of technological development of Panem. There are no elaborate game arenas. There are no game pods. There are no high-speed trains. As you expect for a society recovering from a devastating war, life is hard even in parts of the capital. There seems to be a much smaller gap between the capital and district 12. Of course, district 12 is poor, but the people aren't portrayed as near starvation as in the original. They've been living under the tyrannical regime of the capital for only a short time, and the capital and districts haven't yet settled into the dreadful equilibrium shown in the original movies. The residents of district 12 have a nightlife and some basic freedom compared to the residents of district 12 in "The Hunger Games." All of this could be expected from a society finding a new modus vivendi.I never gave much thought to the development of the world of "The Hunger Games"---I just took for granted that the peace of the movie was imposed and let the story develop on the stated foundation---but the movie answers basic questions that could be fairly asked of the original. Were the people of the capital just morally or ethically inferior to the leaders of our world? (Are they just less hypocritical?) How were the Hunger Games received? How bad was the war? In something of a surprise, the movie portrays the Hunger Games as of low popularity because on some level, they offend the moral sensibilities of the people of the capital as well as the defeated people of the districts, and the starting point of the plot of the movie is an assignment for the characters, students in a school and leadership academy with a wide range of opinions of the games, to devise ways to increase the popularity of the games before the games are simply permanently canceled by Panem's president. The movie builds toward a philosophical explanation for the purpose of the games, to perpetuate the status quo by reminding everyone of their respective roles in the world: in the world view supported by the games, the world is divided into victors and vanquished and is stable as long as everyone remembers their places.The original movies and books didn't really try to provide much of a justification for the games beyond Snow's account of hope in his conversation with Crane, and the speech didn't really explain the development of the games because the perspective represents a view of the games as an entrenched institution and not the kind of view that could have been used to promote the games to an ambivalent capital public. The movie offers interesting, new perspectives on the purpose of the games, a perspective that could have unconsciously driven at least the promotion of the games if not their unconscious embrace by the public, as well as giving a bit more depth to Snow, who is torn between the higher ideals of Tigress and some of his classmates and his personal fears, something like his own, internal hunger games.In short, the movie was a lot of things, but it wasn't unneeded. It's definitely worth watching.In more general terms, I found the acting and effects to range from competent to excellent. In fact, the characters come across as much less caricatured and much more nuanced than the characters of the original movies.

title: Misses what made the book so interesting
text: I recently read the book in anticipation for the adaptation, and came out enjoying the origin story of coriolanus snow, enjoying the twist and turns and getting to know the mindset that drove him to become President Snow from the original trilogy, but all of that seem to be missing in the movieThe performances are quiete fine, instead its the lack of focus in the interesting parts from the book thats missing. We dont see the the intricit thoughts and motivations that drive Mr. Snow to become the character we know.What we end up with is a Young Adult cliche relationship that feels forced and disconnected from the book, where you were left questioning his motivations and perspective.The movie misses what made the book so interesting and instead leans toward a main stream Holywood love story.

title: Needed this to be 6 hours long
text: Honestly, I think this needed to be two movies, not one. I wish Lucy Grays and Snow's relationship was developed a lot more and the complexities and intricacies of it was explored. Like, she leaves him so suddenly (which I understand the symbolism and motive behind) but we get no warning as an audience and it takes away from the whole villains-are-slowly-forged-from-circumstance message of the book/movie. If we were to gradually see Snow become worse and worse (which we do, but again it's these really rough jolts and jumps) the ending and his ultimate fate as the dictator later on would have been made so much more impactful and meaning-full. We don't get to see his fondness turn into liking turn into love turn into obsession for Lucy Gray, so we're left so confused as to why in the freak he is so balls to the walls ready to cheat, bribe, murder and commit treason for her? In the book, he sees her as so enigmatic and charming and that draws him to her at the start, but her helplessness and her dependence on him in the games is what makes him start to crave the power he feels when he's in control of her life, and if that was shown, the audience would understand the ending so much better. However, it was good; the set design was so realistic and convincing, the costumes were really accurate to the book yet still creative and fun, the acting was very entertaining and believable and Rachel Zegler does a stupidly fantastic job with her singing and Appalachian accent. It's a spectacular movie, I just wish there was more.

title: What a shame
text: A lot of potential, who doesn't want to see a villain origin story? The problem is this is an incredibly boring villain origin story. Do we blame the book? I read it and it's not great so that's part of the problem...Despite the book's failings I think so much could have been done with the movie, characters better fleshed out, maybe a way to know Snow's inner dialogue would have helped. Anyways Hunger Games fans like myself will watch the movie and probably like it. I gave it a five for the actors who did the best with what they had and a nicely done dystopian world. There's too many misses to mention, but nonsensical plot lines, poor costuming, and lack of real chemistry between the lead characters are top of my list. Like many others have said: I would have much rather seen a Haymitch back story. Maybe that's next!

title: Follows the book quite well
text: I read the book, I loved it, and the film was honestly just how I imagined it! Although, this way I knew what was coming, what was going on, etc. I feel that yes, there were details, not thoroughly explained, included, which I never really like, as it makes movies feel lashed together.The film was very long, as they tried to put everything from the book in it. I liked the characters, I do think the casting was spot on, everyones portrayal felt like the characters in the book, the sets too! They made the music come to life in a great way also!The problem with it is actually whats the best in it...how muvh they tried to stick to the book. I liked the book and I like how it come to life in front of my eyes. However, I do know that ~300 pages worth of story greatly explained in a book cannot be put into a film completely as it is. I'm glad they didn't change much, maybe they should have concentrated on a few bigger things and expand them (character development, etc) or explain the smaller things a bit better, maybe just leave out if it's too much detail.The ending was like this in the book!! It's meant to be confusing! The whole story for that matter. That's why it's a fresh angle. And for criticizing the singing and why it's in there...I cannot even begin.

title: Pointless and boring
text: This movie did not need to be made. Every review here explains why. My biggest issue was that the two leads had zero chemistry. They felt like strangers for the entirety of the movie. Zegler's character was incredibly flat and one dimensional, like a shell of a person. The actor who played Snow was better, but couldn't carry the film.Overall it was a weak storyline that felt like it didn't know why it kept going on. I checked my watch many times throughout the movie.I think the best part was the songs. They were enjoyable and helped me forget about the boring characters for a minute or two. Zegler is a great singer.The movie felt like a cheap version of the original hunger games series, which felt real, raw, and emotional.

title: You've seen the end, now this is the beginning
text: What if you somehow know someone will do something horrible in the future? A dictator leading a cruel fascist state. There's that science fiction trope of if you could meet him as a young child what could you do...kill him, or teach him to be good instead of following the path to evil? In the sequels we saw the villainous old man and here we see the young frightened child and young adult living in dilapidated quarters clinging to former family glory. You have sympathy for him and if he chooses he could have love, freedom...or power. But not all of the above. Not having read the book this was a series of surprises which kept me guessing and hoping for the characters to overcome all odds. Well worth watching.

title: Performer in a hunt
text:
The story follows the young Coriolanus Snow, who would later become the ruthless president of Panem that we meet in "The Hunger Games".As a young man, Snow is a mentor in the tenth annual Hunger Games, assigned to mentor a tribute from District 12 named Lucy Gray Baird.The novel explores Snow's early life, his ambition, and his descent into darkness as he navigates the complex and corrupt world of the Hunger Games.___Katniss and Lucy Gray are very, very different.The Hunger Games is about what happens when you place a hunter in a performance.The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is about what happens when you place a performer in a hunt.___
IT WAS PERFECT
ALL THE CAST KILLED IT.I AM GOING TO WATCH IT AGAIN.

title: Amazingly faithful movie
text: This movie was incredibly faithful to the book. It did cut a few scenes out but I could see the purpose in that. All the actors portrayed their characters perfectly. My only downside is that we didn't get more out of Coriolanus's relations with his friend.Incredibly good movie and would recommend any Hunger Games fan should watch it. If you want a slightly better viewing experience, read the book first. SO much more detail in it.I especially loved Peter Dinklage as Dean Highbottom. He played the role with so much passion and I loved it.It can be a little confusing for people who haven't read the books, but still would watch it.9/10.

title: Empty, lazy
text: Having enjoyed the book so much, I was excited to watch the film. But the screen adaptation was lazily done and had to rush through what was a well-written story to squeeze itself into a film.The character of Corialanus was completely lost on screen and became an empty, 2D version of what he should have been. He became en empty villain character- no complexity, no human element whatsoever.The Hunger Games has an important place in literature and film because it speaks a message to young people about fairness, power and kindness to others but this message was on completely lost in a stupidly rapid, thin narrative.A bit embarrassing tbh.

title: Pleasantly Surprised
text: First thing I should mention is that I didn't know this was based on a book that came out after the third installment Mockingjay. Since I did not know it was based on a book I was worried it would be just some tacked on prequel afterthought to the franchise and would hold the same problems as the Star Wars prequels character development, the X-men prequels, and other failed prequels. I have to admit I was captivated.The more the movie went on the more captivating the characters become. The atmosphere is really intense. They did not make the mistakes of a likable young Anakin Skywalker who suddenly jolts to the dark side. Without spoiling the movie all I can say is that if you go in awaiting a spectacle and wondering "how does Snow become the dangerous and powerful man we know" you will not be disappointed. The characters and their developments are touching, intense, and scary at parts.This movie was so much more intriguing than I thought it could be, and I'm still enthralled with how intense the character interactions were.

title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes Sings and Slithers
text: Hey, Streamers! As holiday and awards seasons approach, the theaters will be overflowing with new releases. We've been seeing the trailer for The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes for months now. It is a prequel to The Hunger Games movies that starred Jennifer Lawrence. Now, we get to see how the world that Katniss revolutionized came to be. Here's whether this prequel proves its worth.The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes takes place 64 years prior to the action of the original The Hunger Games movie just before the 10th Hunger Games is about to begin. Our main character is Coriolanus Snow (Tom Blyth), a bright, ambitious young man determined to win a cash prize that will help him restore his family's stature in the Capitol. Snow becomes one of the first set of mentors for the 24 tributes for the 10th Hunger Games. Snow also comes up with a plan to revitalize the Games and provides counsel to the head game maker, Dr. Volumnia Gaul (Viola Davis). Meanwhile, Snow is assigned the feisty tribute for District 12 Lucy Gray Baird (Rachel Zegler). Lucy Gray has a magnetic personality and a beautiful singing voice. Snow uses his ingenuity to help Lucy Gray try to survive the Games. Singing, snakes, and child-murdering hijinks ensue.The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes like its title is too long and a bit convoluted. At 2 hours 27 minutes, this movie really could have used a trim. In fact, while the story is told in 3 chapters, it is pretty distinctly 2 movies. There is about an hour and 15 minutes that feels out of place. Despite that, this movie is never boring. There is so much going on that your attention will be held for the entire runtime.The cast will hold your attention. Even though I don't think she is that good an actress, Rachel Zegler makes you care about Lucy Gray. Moreover, she is beautiful singer. She gets to do a lot of it in this movie. The songs aren't great, but her voice is beyond. Tom Blyth does a good job as Snow as well, but it is the supporting cast that overshadows the two leads. Viola Davis is doing the absolute most in this movie and I am here for it. She relishes every moment of screen time and when she is not on screen, you will be thinking about her. Davis is perfect here. Jason Schwartzman and Peter Dinklage also get to ham it up and add some spice to this movie. I could have used more of both. The production design and visual effects utilized throughout help to build the world of Panem. This dystopian era is portrayed very vividly. It is a feast for the eyes.Ultimately, The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is a very entertaining movie. Even though it is too long, it is able to keep your attention with moving songs, a virtuoso performance by Viola Davis and great production values. You'll get your money's worth if you choose to go to the theater. Grab a big box a popcorn and return to the world of Panem.

title: Unearned violence sandwich on boring bread
text: The first hour of this movie is dreadfully boring. I actually fell asleep in the theater for the first time in my life, and that's what compelled me to write this. I understand the importance of singing to the story, but it doesn't match the tone of the movie AT ALL. We're just bursting out into song like it's a 2010 Disney channel movie. I feel like I got whiplash every time she started singing because of how wrong it is for the tone of this film. Additionally, I felt embarrassed for the actors during several of the dramatic scenes leading up to the games. And then you get to the actual games...I don't know that I've ever seen a film with such an unearned display of violence. It's genuinely brutal. I normally applaud a film that has the balls to kill a kid. It's usually unexpected, and when done well, it creates incredible tension. In this movie, you're expecting kids to die, which somehow just adds to how distasteful the actual violence is. It's completely unearned. We've had random singing, terrible dramatic acting, scenes that feel like TikTok fan fiction, and everyone in the capital is twirling their moustache like a Bond villain. Whether the writers like it or not, this movie is WAY too campy to allow for this kind of brutal violence and social metaphor.I don't even really want to get into the last 45 minutes, or whatever it was. The main guy acts like a sociopath the entire film, and we know who he becomes, so I don't feel I'm spoiling anything by saying that he continues to be a sociopath, and everyone acts accordingly. And it's boring, and confusing. So its boring until it's violent, and then it's boring again, with a little bit of pointless confusion sprinkled on top.

title: The Best Of The 5 Hunger Games Movies
text: I just saw this in theaters and I was a big fan of the Hunger Games so I knew I had to go see this. It is a prequel to the Hunger Games Katniss was involved in and it talks about how President Snow became the president of the 13 districts. To me the best part of the whole movie was Lucy Gray, played by Rachel Zegler. There has been a lot of controversy about Rachel, but I must say that girl can act and sing and was in fact, perfect for this role. Her version of The Hanging Tree was amazing as well as all the other songs she sang in that movie. The guy who played Snow was really good too and when you watch this, it makes a lot of sense why he ended up being the way he was in the first 4 movies. Without a doubt, story wise and action wise, I would say this is the best Hunger Games movie like almost everyone else is saying. I give The Ballad Of Songbirds And Snakes a 9 out of 10. So worth watching if you are a Hunger Games fan.

title: The movie is so fantastic
text: The movie is soo good and the characters in movie done excellent job and they entertain us full time.overall movie is soo good.everyone done good job.If you have read the hunger games, I highly recommend watching this dystopian themed movie exploring the genres of love/hate, government dictatorship and adventure. This masterpiece of a book has been made into the most spectacular movie ( in my opinion ) ever made. The characters, all perfectly cast and played amazingly and exactly how I imagined them to look like, every single one. The first one sets the background for the franchise of the hunger games movies and does it extremely well. District 12 and the Capitol were completely well made. Especially if you compare the two, the Capitol so bright, lively and modern while district 12 is so run down and old.I absolutely love the Capitol citizens outfits! Truly astonishing and exactly how I imagined capitol fashion to look like when described in the books ( bright and colourful )

title: I'd be happy to expand on your review:
text: I'd be happy to expand on your review:"I am compelled to express my profound disappointment with 'The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes' (2023). Unfortunately, it proved to be a subpar cinematic experience for me. One of the major letdowns lies in the portrayal of action sequences, which, in my view, failed to captivate and fell short of delivering the excitement one would expect from a film of this genre.Moreover, the movie's problem-solving elements left much to be desired, earning it a resounding 0/10 in this department. The narrative seemed to lack the depth and ingenuity necessary to engage the audience on an intellectual level. As a viewer, I found myself yearning for a more compelling and intricate storyline, but sadly, 'The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes' fell short of meeting these expectations.While I understand that opinions on films can vary, I felt compelled to share my perspective on what I consider to be a lackluster cinematic endeavor. It is my hope that future installments in the Hunger Games series, if any, will manage to recapture the essence and thrill that made the earlier films so memorable."

title: Great, but too short to do it justice
text: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is an awesome but imperfect companion to the original series that left me wanting more. I went into the film having read and seen the original Hunger Games series many times as a teen and adult, and I especially love the fictional world of Panem.I think people got lost because the film is trying to condense a massive novel with rich worldbuilding and relationships into a 3-hour format which outright omits many stories. When Mockingjay released, many fans were disappointed with the slow pace of the films; but rewatching the series back-to-back shows how perfect that development was. With so much plot to cover and so little time to do it, some of Ballad's performances felt rushed, especially when it comes to representing internal dialogue that was described at length in the novel. Therefore, I'm not making any statements about the performances. That's your task! Go watch it!I left the film wanting more from the world, characters, and differences between the historical periods it takes place in. The Ballad thoughtfully reframes our perception of the other films and the characters within it, but only if you keep an eye out for it. There's still plenty of mystery that propels the story. There are many profound moments when you go into Ballad without reading the novel first, as you connect the dots between the main series and see how they came to fruition. This is clear in the deep worldbuilding of Suzanne Collins and the production design throughout the film and series. American, Roman, and post-Soviet architecture fuse together to illustrate decay and oppression globally and throughout history. Together, these reinforce the central theme of the film (in contrast with the original series) that we are all capable of committing violence, delving into the moral dilemmas which influence us. While the original series takes on a clear moral tone, the exploration of individual and societal morality in Ballad makes it a particularly timely piece. If you miss out on that, I implore you to think about it.The production design, while living comfortably within established Hollywood styles, is wonderful. If you have an eye for set, location, costume, and lighting- there are plenty of inspired details. CG is minimal and rightly so. I only noticed it once, and that lends to the tasteful fusion of historical and contemporary style that gives The Hunger Games the grit we are used to. Perhaps with a longer running time, we'd see more of the locations that make the series so distinct like the Seam, daily life in the Capitol, and districts 1>11. Ballad still lacks some of the ruggedness it needs, starring characters with perfect makeup in a literal human zoo, and fresh-faced folks on the brink of bankruptcy- that definitely took me out of it.I think the goal of a PG rating was ill-advised, especially as the real horror comes from the story's psychological elements which would leave a young person impacted anyway. Despite that, the composition and direction use our own imagination to make the most of that PG rating, presenting death theatrically, but not unbelievably.Oh, and the pacing isn't slow. Like, at all. Sure, it's not the overly-fast-paced media we've become so accustomed to, but it's filled with action and even the slow scenes take place in well-designed locations to keep your mind busy.Overall, I just wish the studio gave more screen time to this delightfully crafted piece, perhaps splitting it into parts. Definitely a must-watch for any fan of the Hunger Games.

title: don't go just watch the first orijinal film
text: Personally, I can say as a Hunger Games fan that it's a complete disaster. Normally, it's a perfect series with both a strong plot and an original old film, but this new film is both empty and long. Moreover, the atmosphere is so different that it seems a lot has changed in 65 years (compared to the original film). There's no similarity in the setting, and I find the setting quite dull; it's a major mistake.Characters: The actors weren't bad at their jobs, but they weren't good either. Definitely, the acting in the first film was much better. I can say that the actors were a bit inexperienced, and especially, they couldn't convey fear. There were no scared expressions on their faces; it was as if they were playing a little charming game.And finally, thanks to them for ruining the perfection and indispensability of the film.

title: I don't understand the hate
text: I would understand if all of the bad reviews were coming from those who read the book because this is what usually happens when people's imagination is different from how it was portrayed in the movie. But so many 1-5 stars... is it the same quality as Twilight or what?I enjoyed the movie and found it refreshing since it's not purely about love or the games themselves but rather about Snow and his character extremes. It is not overly dramatic to say that he is who he is because of betrayal or love issues... not at all. He was who he was since day 1, the most cruel person is the one who pretends not to be. I would gladly watch a sequel.

title: Cheap Rom-Com set in Panem
text: Okay hear me out, I am a hardcore hunger games fan. I love the gritty, pure and raw four movies, especially the first two.This movie feels more like a cheap rom-com that happens to be set in Panem. Zegler is an insufferable pick-me girl that sings like the popular girl at your high school play. I know it says ballad in the title but that does not justify the commercial musical songs that are thrown in there to distract from plotholes.Blythe gets way too much screen time and nevertheless the character development from nice guy to evil Snow falls down from the sky like a dead mockingbird.It's a painful watch that made audience sitting around me cringe at their kissing scenes, because it all seems forced and chemistry is lacking.And why did the make up department decide to give Zegler a YouTuber 2014 Glam Up ? A girl from District 12, come you all can do better.This is nowhere near the previous movies. The extras did well though, a better performance than most actors.

title: its amazingly bad
text: I just came home from the cinema with my dad, and i am still annoyed at how bad the movie was. The dialogue was so confusing, and the characters made no sense. Every scene something didn't make quite sense. Wether it was a characters reaction, or his motives. And it doesn't help that the main character is so stupid to look at. It seemed like they tried to make him look complex all the time or cynical, but he just ended up being really unrelatable. But probably the thing that annoyed me the most was the chapter thing. Why did they make it in to three chapters, when the "chapters" just blend into eachother. Maybe the gap between chapter 2 and 3 made sense, because that he was transferred. But the chapter 3 screen was so short, that it didn't seem as if, we were going to a new chapter of the story. Because the new chapter just started so quickly. The movie also tried so much to be a kind of masterpiece, but that didn't work either.

title: Character Development when one knows the ending
text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and SnakesWhat drives a person? Is it emotion? Is it calculation? I ponder these questions often especially when turned inward. I am a social, yet solitary, individual, that can be multifaceted in what drives me. This dichotomy is helpful for me because I can see things from an outsider's point of view, and from being among others.What is that point of that paragraph? Where is the movie review? Why are you still reading? Something drives you. In this film, I, like most people, wanted to see the early development of the character from the previous films. I volunteered as tribute and got my ticket for opening night. But, with all of my reviews, I went for more than the "oh so that's how it happened!" moment. Would I understand the complexities, or would it be simple?I was delighted to find it very complex. Without spoiling, stimuli will always have a factor in a person's choice. But when that choice does not go as intended, it can be natural for a back pedal to lead toward another choice. A person's desire to keep pivoting to save face can lead to the most unfortunate consequences. People... tell the truth. The story can still be told without being an episode of Three's Company where everything was based on misunderstandings. (I'm dating myself here).The title is very apt and ironic, but I'll let you interpret it as you see fit. All those words have literal, metaphorical, and symbolic depictions. It was fun re-arranging my perspective. I promised no spoilers but my perspective did end at a very specific conclusion that I wasn't entirely pleased with.So, I ask again what drives a person? Watch and find out.I enjoyed this film, and do recommend it, for both escapism and the over analyzing I love to do. Just ask my friends! :)

title: It wasn't as good as the old ones.
text: It had so many things in. Yes it's a flashback film,it contained metaphors. But these were a bit complicated to understand. If you cannot carch the details in the sentences you cannot understand it. Also there wa so many things happening. I think the idea had too many thing in it. It was giving the vibe :Lets add this,oh! This too. We can't skip this, let's add this too! There were so many thing. It could be done as part 1 and part 2. Since there's so many things happening, it became boring and boring. And the ending was(for me) very missing and a bit silly and unnecessary. It could be much better. For me the performance of the film was equal with the Thor-Love and Thunder.

title: Awful acting and no storyline
text: I wanted to like this movie but it is easily one of the worst I have ever seen. It plods along at a snails pace, and nothing ever happens.The acting is shocking even in it's best moments, you would think it's a cast of child actors with how hammy and fake their reactions are. The lead woman is just shockingly bad, almost like she is loading emotions when needed and you can see the loading times. Her random bursting into auto tuned song was so weird too. It never made sense, she just randomly sings and for some reason that saves the day every time.The leading male does an ok job but again not enough to say it's good enough.And eesh the story is just nothing at all. It's a movie where start to finish, absolutely nothing happens or has impact other than the 3 heavily focused maguffins which might as well have big neon signs pointing at them that they will shortly be used to move the glacial plot forwards.This feels like they googled a few key words from the originals and just crowbarred them into this abysmal movie. You can happily live your life as a hunger games fan having never seen this tripe.

title: Somehow better than the book.
text: When I read the book I thought that it was sloppy and very unlike the writing style of her other books. As I watched the film I realised why the book was written, it was written to be a film. In my opinion the film fully captured the insanity of Snow and the supposed innocence of Lucy Gray. Snow's descent into evil is made clear near the end of the film, making it more intriguing and also saddening, whereas in the book his evil personality was obvious from the beginning. I thought the film was very well cast and directed. I thought that the music might make it seem like a musical but it so well placed throughout the film that it only helped the plot instead of displacing it.

title: Cold, cold, cold actors,
text: The actors are so cold and lifeless. District 12 is way more lively than it should be, and they are dressed way too well after the games.Lucie Gray actress is acting like a cold robot. On paper she's doing really well, but she's missing emotion and soul when acting. Also, what's going on with her jaw, is she on cocaine?The pacing is too fast and the game was unrealistic, nobody could have survived that. They barely show District 12 and we're supposed to care for them?Recent american cinema is missing the mark on so many movies big time. It's time they stop recycling actors in all their movies.Not a movie I would recomment, 4/10, below average.The only good thing about this movie is the set design.

title: Very good movie.
text: From captivating storytelling to stellar performances, the hunger game is a cinematic masterpiece that effortlessly weaves together elements of drama, suspense, and emotion. The visual brilliance and attention to detail bring each scene to life, creating an immersive experience for the audience. The exceptional cast delivers performances that resonate, leaving a lasting impact. The thought-provoking narrative, coupled with a brilliant soundtrack, elevates the hunger games to a level of cinematic excellence. It's a must-watch for anyone who appreciates the art of filmmaking.Must watch movie of 2023.

title: Excellent Movie
text: The Hunger Games is the rare movie that succeeds on almost every level,where each character,scene,costume to make a film worth repeated viewing snacks are scary,but the joy is intoxicating, the male lead is superb and felame lead she done a fabulous job, the problems she faces wii have you in stitches,the more interesting part is technical aspects of the movie,everyone will pay attention to things like cinematography,lighting,and sound quality,hero heroine performance and their acting levels were peak they both done excellent job and old lady she done a amazing performance must watch movie go.

title: Soars, sings, and has a venomous bite
text: 64 years prior to the original we see what Panem was like in the early days of its fascist rule a mere 10 years after the civil war ended.Lucy Gray is a friendly, sweet travelling performer... with a distinct edge beneath. Rachel Zegler's singing and acting are excellent, though do take a few minutes to get used to, and certainly I get why some say that there are too many musical interludes here. I acknowledge that some of the things she's said show that she's not the best feminist yet - let's please keep in mind, she's 22 years old. I would definitely say she's well on her way. Give her some time to have more life experience and reflect on these things more, and I'm sure she'll get there.It has been 8 years since we last got an entry in this film series. Some would say that the moment has passed. And that this does not have enough new material to justify making it. That it smacks of corporate greed. In my opinion, this was the exact perfect time to make another one. Allow me to explain why.This is the first of these to be made after the PG-13 rating was pushed so far that it could properly allow for coming extremely close to showing the bloody violence that the subject matter requires. While this is not as intense as certain parts of the Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 3, it is very obvious that it came out after that one, rather than shortly after the first one. The action and tension are the most visceral yet, and each death hits you like a sledgehammer. They're also the most clear and well-staged, easy to follow with one very effective long take.Some of the central issues that this franchise provides social commentary on have become worse and/or visible to a general audience. Regular people are forced to work ridiculously hard for less than a living wage, while the rich live a sheltered existence - it's very telling that several major characters in this feel no fear of actual danger, but instead consider their potential embarrassment to be a fate far worse than the certain death of 23 teenagers that had no way to avoid becoming Tributes.The youngest generations find themselves in a world where they have to be constantly camera ready, and the gig economy provides what little they have to live on. They either grow up too quickly or seemingly not at all, while their elders, those with significant power, who have created the current terrible conditions, judge them harshly, sitting in their ivory towers, insisting that it couldn't be any other way. 18-year-old Coriolanus Snow is influenced by several people in his life who try to encourage him to go in specific directions, and the potential for the future that he and his peers at least hypothetically hold is underlined; to either create a better society, or destroy all hope of it for generations to come - to let nationalists completely eliminate civil rights of anyone they deem lesser, or to wrestle back control.Those reporting on deadly conflicts may not actually care, or feel they have any skin in the game, and might treat it with little sensitivity, provide no context and simply try to get great ratings. There was never a long period of this movie that did not make me reflect on incredibly sad recent news stories. I understand that this is a negative for many, and I 100% respect those who disagree with the following; I don't go to movies to turn off my brain and be completely distracted from tough reality. I go for something that will help me process it better. And this absolutely delivered that.I recommend this to anyone who believes they can handle it - you'll know a few minutes in. 8/10.

title: This is so good and amazing....
text: AMAZING!! As a fan of the entire Hunger Games franchise (I watched all movies and read every book) I can say without a doubt that this movie was amazing! It connects perfectly to what we see 64 years later with Katniss. I loved this movie so much. I just finished the book the day I saw the movie and was so excited. It definitely lived up to my expectations and did the book justice. Yes there was a lot missing from the book but who can except to have everything copied verbatim (it's already a 2.40 hour movie!) they had all the parts that were necessary and made it so people who haven't read the book understood what was happening. I thought the cast was amazing and such well chosen, loved the representation.

title: Lacked depth and emotions
text: I watched Catching Fire right after seeing the newest Hunger Games movie and it made me realise what I was missing in it. The emotions. The OG cast gave stellar performances, eveybody was cast perfectly and conveyed what their characters were going through. The Ballad felt somewhat empty. None of the characters were compelling enough. I found Lucy Gray to be too perfect, her relationship with Snow was rushed and lacked depth. The supporting performances were also mediocre, nowhere near as good as Haymitch, Effie or even tributes like Rue. In a minute of watching Catching Fire I felt more emotions than in the whole Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes. It's unfortunate since that's where the strength of this movie should have lied. It is obvious that the games themselves aren't that entertaining to the audience anymore after watching the trilogy. Therefore, Ballad had a lot of potential for character development and conveying the story, the relationships between characters and the chemistry between them in the end...just wasn't there.

title: Don't listen to anyone, just enjoy it
text: When the book came out I wasn't interested, but with the first trailer I was HYPED and immeditely read it. This was a highly anticipated movie of the year for me, and my dudes, it delivered!Go see it as it is intended. There's singing yes, but it's not a musical.The acting is amazing, Tom is great as a young Snow.There's a lot of worldbuilding, as we get to see how the games evolved, we get to see a war torn Panem. I think this is a great villian origin story.I couldn't name anything big they left out. They really made the book justice. You can't expect them to line by line. Don't nitpick.It was worth the hype! Can't wait to see it again.

title: Worst movie from the series
text: The new Hunger Games movie took a surprising turn, deviating from its action-packed roots to become more of a musical, which was quite unexpected. The focus on a handful of songs over a prolonged duration made it feel disjointed and detracted from the core theme of the Hunger Games. Instead of delving into the gritty, survivalist aspects that the series is known for, the film centers almost entirely on two characters, whose storylines overshadow the broader narrative of the Hunger Games. This shift in focus and genre may disappoint fans who were anticipating the high-stakes action and intense drama typical of the Hunger Games saga.

title: Absolutely amazing movie
text: This is one of the best movies I have seen in a long time. I've seen all of the hunger games movies and read all of the books and in my opinion the first 2 movies are the best out of the first 4, but this one is now tied at first place. It's a Rollercoaster of emotions, it made me happy, excited, nervous, anxious, sad, (I could've cried) and most of all impressed. The casting is amazing, the actors were all great and there are so many more references to the original movies than I thought there would be. Overall I give this movie a 10/10 because it really was just the complete package, and I had low expectations for the movie then it just blew my expectations out of the water.

title: Beating a Dead Horse for Over 2.5 Hours.
text: I just don't feel like it did anything to meaningfully justify its own existence. It's well-made, that's for certain, and the actors are trying extremely hard to believe in the world the filmmakers have put them in. But it just smells so...Hollywood. DOA. It's like looking at a corpse of a Hunger Games movie. Clearly, it's going to make a zillion dollars, especially internationally (I saw it in a semi-packed theater in Madrid). It's almost like what Disney is doing to Marvel -- inventing pre- and back-stories that actually don't need to exist because they add nothing to the canon, nor do they change the way you see the other movies. No additive comprehension. The Games themselves were much, much too short, and they solved the problem of the games themselves in a deus ex machina way that was deeply unsatisfying. I'm super impressed with Rachel Zegler, because she clearly is a talented musician who learned probably 10 different songs for this movie...but in the end, the whole thing feels like a borderline musical meant to appease an imagined audience consisting mostly of teenagers. In other words? Weirdly gimmicky. I found the whole thing boring, and kind of stale. Give it a pass. You'll be fine.

title: Awesome picture
text: When I first started reading The Hunger Games books I was shocked at how much Suzanne Collins was able to keep the book and all the characters in the book to continuously grow and become more and more interesting to read. Katniss everdeen started out as this quiet, archy loving girl until one day when all of that changed. My mind switched from "This is a good book," to "I need to finish this book." I grew more attached to the book because I could really connect with the characters and know how they are feeling. The characters had so many unique personality traits that made each one of the characters different which is what I liked most about it. Some people might call a character they don't like "dry" "boring" or even "plain". I could never describe a character in this book in any of those word but that is just a small part of why The Hunger Games is so good!

title: Hunger Games: The Musical!
text: I tried to watch this film. I was a fan of both the original series books and films. I haven't read the book this latest film was based on, and after watching the film (as much as I could stand), I likely won't bother.What the previous books and films did well (for the most part) was convince you a world where society was so broken that people would watch children slaughter each other on tv was possible. They built a universe with a history, characters, and circumstances that made sense, despite their extreme nature.But this film did none of that. We're introduced to characters, the protagonists, who immediately seem absurd. It was like they were trying to channel Harry Potter in a world that was never about magic, but instead about human evolution under extreme forces.One of the protagonists starts randomly singing while in Renaissance Faire cosplay within the first 20 minutes. People in the audience sing back-up. Why?! It was sentimental, saccharin and just silly. We don't even know these characters yet, but should buy that they're singing sending the protagonist off to die?I tried to continue watching, but none of the actors even seem to be in the same room as each other. Their interactions are unbelievable; Rachel clearly does not understand the tone of these stories and seems like she's been involuntarily transported from a Broadway stage. I didn't make it past the tv introductions of tribute and mentor scene, not even 30 minutes in. I can't stand terrible films, and this one just wasn't worth my time.

title: Better than I expected!
text: Yes, the movie is long (like most these days), but it wasn't boring even for one minute!I felt with Snow as he tried to navigate the world of Panem. It is a movie about his turmoil, how he got corrupted.I don't get the hate against Rachel Ziegler. She might not be the best actress on earth, but she did really well. And her singing was amazing!I'm sure that more women than men like this movie, because it's with singing and a love story etc. But this movie was definitely better than I expected! When the movie ended, I even thought that I liked It more than the old movies. If I could 7,5 I would. 7 wouldn't be fair and 8 is a bit high. But 7 just doesn't show how much I enjoyed this movie.

title: A fantastic film adaptation!
text: I'm always nervous to see a book turned into a movie. There's always something that's lost in translation, I was especially nervous on this one as it focused a lot on Snow's internal dialog. However, they managed to pull it off wonderfully! The casting was great and both Tom Blyth and Rachel Zegler were fantastic. Blyth was able to capture Snow's conniving and paranoia. Each act was poignant and focused on the different issues within Panem, while having the same over arcing theme of the cost of war. I was focused on the movie the whole time and never felt there was a slow or pointless scene. I really really enjoyed this movie!

title: Tom Blyth steals the show
text: One of the big highlights for 2023 is the return of The Hunger Games to the cinema with a prequel. Set several decades before, we learn how Anekin become Dart... okay wrong movie... but the same basics happens here. And the rising Hollywood star Tom Byth delivers a very convincing interpretation of young Coriolanus Snow. However, you cannot say the same for the female lead role in Rachel Zegler who portrayed a country western signing version of Lucy Gray. The unconvincing character portrayal failed to deliver any convincing chemistry that the story require. And there is question around the lack of technological advancement outside of laboratory. Nevertheless, most of the movie is a good story. It is not as epic as the Hunger Games movies in the past, but an adaption of a novel that serves its purpose well.

title: Snow Lands on Top
text: A great film overall! The acting across the board is fantastic with Tom Blythe stealing the show. The music, cinematography, sets, storyline were all superb. The only flaws in my opinion were the romance between Coriolanus and Lucy left a lot to be desired, the pacing was a little weird in the 3rd act, and Rachel Zegler really seemed to struggle acting when she wasn't singing (which luckily she was singing a lot). Having read the book, part 3 had weird pacing in the book as well so not too much discredit to the film, and Rachel Zeglers poor ability to act was covered up mainly by Tom Blythe as well as all the other fantastic supporting actors. I was truly enthralled the entire time and it made me excited to see a movie in the theaters for the first time in what's felt like forever. Highly recommend it to anyone.

title: Phenomenal Book to Movie Adaptation
text: It has been YEARS since I've seen a movie actually stick to the plot of the book that it is based off of. Readers will be so very pleased with this prequel. It truly stays so true to Suzanne Collin's vision! I felt the rise and fall of Coriolanus Snow just as I did while reading the book from his POV. Tom Blyth and Rachel Zegler bring their respective characters to life in the best ways possible. Kudos to Rachel for her innocent portrayal of Lucy Gray and her beautiful singing voice. And Tom- your portrayal of Coriolanus is absolutely phenomenal. Just like in the book, I wanted to root for your character despite knowing what you become later in life.GO SEE THIS MOVIE!!!

title: Disappointing and failed attempt at a Hunger Games film
text: I have watched all the other Hunger Games films and this was nowhere near as good as them. Hunger Games 1-4 are some of my favorite movies and I was so excited when I saw that a new one was coming out. This movie had way too much unnecessary and descriptive violence. It was almost like this was a musical because Lucy Gray sang about 6 times. This movie would have gotten a 4 star review if it had ended 45 minutes earlier than it did. One of the only good things about this movie were the actors. The acting was good. There was sooo much killing that was completely random and unnecessary. The Hunger Games arena was too small so the fighting was very close up and gruesome. I would not recommend this movie.

title: MUST WATCH
text: SO GOOD!!! Snow's character development was shown exceptionally well, demonstrating his rise to power and the lack of remorse he has in him. The songs were beautiful reflecting district 12 and the storyiline. Lucy gray was portrayed amazingly, her voice her acting and her outfits really created the character that was shown in the book. My family was in awe of the movie and it was a constant conversation starter. It sets up the hunger games movies well, showing how the games were formed and the way it was set out. Sejanus was played well, showing the compassion that humans should have and the hatred towards the games. I 100% recommend this film to everyone. Some violence, i wasn't fazed by it, but younger audiences might be.

title: Better then expected.
text: The characters are quite well placed, so you get a good feeling of what and where they come from, both social layer and attitude towards the Capitol/hunger games control system, and what their general view on life is.Although there are small hints and eastereggs of the original trilogi, they havnt placed a Kitnis-like character, and Snow gets his own stand alone story, and at the same time, by the end of this movie, you can feel that this young Snow really fits well on how the old Snow in the original trilogi.Well done, only a few places where you think they had to add new things to a world we fell familier with, and still got a good story with good character arcs and a clearly told story.

title: Anybody blaming anything but the writing is in denial.
text: The major beats of the book plot play out more or less exactly as written here in the movie. It falls flat because the author decided this story required "adult pathos" to justify its existence, and, most unfortunately, writes that pathos like a 12 year old making their first big foray into Wattpad. Other than a few vaguely satisfying beats in the (very short) Games sequence, there's nothing here but incredibly amateurish melodrama, and that's all true-to-text.All the best parts of the political intrigue and action/adventure that make the first trilogy so engaging are completely absent, or present only as cameo-style, utterly embarrassing call-backs to those 10-year-old stories that actually interested you. The romance was the worst part of the original series, but here you're begging for it because if it's not the current on-screen focus then you're probably watching a bizarre musical theater kid wet dream where Everybody Has To Stop And Be Impressed By Your Heartfelt Singing That Happens To Be Precisely Suited To The Collective Emotional Moment And Isn't That So Cool. There are literally five or six EXTENDED musical sequences that serve absolutely no plot function, but are wielded by the author like plot points nonetheless, because she's got nothing else to offer while moving the story forward.This flick may not actually be 525,600 minutes long but you could sure fool me by the end. Hard pass.

title: Excellent movie
text: Wow!!! I have been looking forward to this since the book came out, hoping it would be turned into a movie! They truly knew what to keep in the movie, what to adapt and what to leave in the book. Absolutely fantastic! I'm so happy and I loved every second of it. The actors did an amazing portrayal of the characters and the movie had great pacing and flow. This movie was by no means perfect, but it was really good. I would have thought it was a perfect 10 if the action was better paced. It was nothing on her part. Definitely not as good as Catching Fire (the peak of the series to me), but better than both of the Mockingjays! Give it a shot without a bias of this young women in your mind and you just might find yourself enjoying it.

title: Cheap Musical Movie, has nothing to do with the original hunger games
text: Just finished watching the new Hunger Games movie, and I have mixed feelings about it. It felt a bit disappointing, to be honest. The movie leans heavily on shallow acting and a fairly simplistic musical style that might find an audience among certain viewers, but for me, it didn't quite click. Spending three hours on it left me wanting more. I was expecting a deeper level of storytelling and quality, especially considering the high bar set by previous installments in the series. While it might resonate with those seeking more straightforward entertainment, it lacked the intricate storytelling and character depth that made the earlier movies so compelling. It's not that it's terrible, but it didn't live up to the series' legacy for me.

title: Loved Rachel (and her voice!)
text: As a hunger games fan I really didn't expect a lot from this movie. Didn't even know it was a thing until 2 weeks ago. But now that I watched it, I have to admit that the movie fits so well to the Hunger Games universe. Really gives you a good idea of Snow and his character. I loved the actor playing as snow but also Rachel! She did a great job and has such a stunning voice. Crazy! Fit well to the Hunger Games singing vibe from the past ones.Only thing that felt off is the length of the actual Hunger Games. It could have been a little longer or more intense because it feels like they had to save on time since they wanted show everything else. But again, all in all, definitely worth to watch!!

title: WOWWWW! SO WORTH THE WAIT!
text: As a true Hunger Games fan who has read the book and seen all the older movies 12 times through each, I was soooo excited when I saw this movie was coming out! For 2 years I had waited on this movie as a huge event coming in the future, and here comes November 17th as I was way to excited for this! Let me just say....... This MOVIE WAS DEFINITELY WORTH THE WAIT! It was SOOOOOOOOO good! I loved everything about the actors, props and sets, storyline, and MUSIC! The music is super good in this film as well! I will have to say that the cool in this film is 10x as worse as the old ones! This movie puts you in the actual games and doesn't disguise any moment of the what happens, but I truly love the aspect and reality of it! I recommend this movie highly for those who are OG Hunger Games Fans because this deals so much with back stories and why things happen in the original trilogy! I hate that this movie is only in theatres though because I want to rewatch it 12 times like the other movies! AMAZING MOVIE, SO SUSPENFUL, SO MYSTERIOUS, AND SO WORTH THE WAIT!

title: Poorly cast
text: Absolutely the weakest instalment in the series and mostly that's down to Rachel Zegler's rigid staring-into-the-mid-distance acting and incessant singing. The story is ok, I mean it's Snow's origin story mixed in with what seems to be unremarkable filler. There are some good moments, few and far between, I was feeling pretty bored half way in and was hoping it would end, but no, it goes on... and on. Overall the dialogue is pretty rigid and unnatural, the plot is a bit of a mess, the acting is pretty bad from most - Rachel Zeglar especially cannot act. It might have been passable if they'd replaced her with someone who didn't do a Zoey Deschanel staring gurn all the damn time. Poor and missable, if you have over two hours of spare time my advice is watch something else.

title: An hour to long, and...
text: Yeh, I finally lived to that moment when I did not didn't care about the cast.Luch Gray, who, for some reason of always addressed by her full name even in the intimate scenes, is meant to be this... tender flower, with a tiny bit of teeth and thorns, but still a kind soul, nice girl in a bad spot, awakening kindness in heart of Snow... problem is, she's played by the same... girl, who's been going around telling about what a bs it is - girls in need of saving, and how she hates Snow White story, and how she's all powerful and all. And overall built a solid reputation of a b***h. Result - the entire movie of her "being weak and tender" I've been expecting the backstabbing, and not convinced by her act.It would be a solid 6 if not for her. But would be still to long and to boring.

title: NOT WATCHABLE
text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" falls short of the high expectations set by its predecessors. Despite its attempt to delve into the origin story of President Snow, the film struggles to captivate audiences. The pacing is uneven, with long stretches of exposition that lack the gripping tension characteristic of the franchise.The choice to center the narrative around a young Snow feels misguided. While exploring the evolution of a villain can be intriguing, the execution here feels forced and fails to humanize the character. Donald Sutherland's charismatic portrayal in the earlier films is sorely missed, leaving a void that the new lead fails to fill convincingly.The film's production design is commendable, successfully recreating the dystopian world of Panem. However, the visual elements alone cannot compensate for the weak character development and a lackluster script. The absence of a strong female protagonist akin to Katniss Everdeen is particularly noticeable, depriving the story of the resilience and depth that defined the previous installments.Furthermore, the film's attempt to provide social commentary on privilege and power lacks subtlety, coming across as heavy-handed and didactic. The subtleties that made the original trilogy thought-provoking are sacrificed for a more straightforward narrative, diminishing the intellectual engagement that characterized earlier films.Despite a few redeeming moments, "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" ultimately fails to capture the essence of its predecessors. Fans of the franchise may find it disappointing, as it struggles to live up to the legacy established by the original trilogy. While the film has its merits, it pales in comparison to the thought-provoking and emotionally resonant storytelling that made "The Hunger Games" a cultural phenomenon.

title: Very enjoyable and fun to watch movie
text: I haven't read the Hunger Games books, but I did enjoy the movies, so this is a review from this perspective. I went into this optimistically excited to see Snow's rise and fall with power. I wasn't disappointed as the performances were captivating and engaging throughout. I enjoyed the story and the precedent for the Katniss and future Hunger Games. Definitely worth watching!People who red the book for this say it is a little fast paced and should have been made into multiple movies. However, from the stand point of not reading the books, it felt well paced and made you feel for the characters.Sure it can be annoying when a film adaptation isn't a direct mimic to the books, but this was a great movie and doesn't deserve some of the bad reviews that are being given.

title: Shouldn't be able to rate without reading the book
text: The movie was a WONDERFUL adaptation of the book! It has been years since I listened to the audiobook, but tonight, when I saw the arena entrance, tv stations, Snow's outfit and more, it all came back to me. Things looked EXACTLY like they were described in the book. The ending was definitely a little blurry. I thought the end quote was "snow lands on top", but that is not the last thing we hear in the movie.There are some aspects of the movie left for the viewer to ponder what the outcome was, which isn't my favorite thing in a movie.Overall, just wonderfully done. This movie truly did the book justice, and the singing was above expectations as well!

title: Well.. just no... Teenage movie at best
text: I'm writing this review only because Jason Schwartzman deserves to be mentioned. In his role he is just brilliant, so thanks for at least his performance.The casting for Snow was also not bad, but the rest of the actors can be forgotten. Above all, we couldn't stand the calling of 'Lucy Gray' after what felt like the 100th time.We're generally not big fans of singing in movies, but these songs were placed so tactlessly that it felt like imitating a Disney film. The only suspenseful part is in the last section of the movie - precisely when it ends.! It seems like the whole movie is made for teenagers. Overexplained and repetitive scenes dominate. We're glad we didn't watch the film in the cinema.

title: Hunger games
text:
Time...
Once you notice how they feel the need to say « Lucy Gray » all the time, you won't be able to unhear it, it's painful. Lucy Gray this, Lucy Gray that... Viola Davis is excellent, atmosphere and setting are ok, but all in all it feels like you're watching 3 different movies in one, scenario is - again - the main issue. Main actor lacks charisma and just isn't good enough to be a lead. The singing is really annoying, I don't care if it's like that in the book, they could have integrated it in a much better way. The guitar thing at the tribute presentation...#excellent #wow #doprocks good.

title: Change Isn't Always Positive!
text: My God ! I think it was a year since they released the trailer of the movie and I was waiting for it with great enthusiasm.The narration of the story and the soundtrack were good, but I am not sure about the choice of actors.The ending was very incomprehensible, if it doesn't continue, it will make watching this movie really worthless.It was not really clear what happened to the girl and what really happened that Snow was transformed like that; Apart from this, as much as this movie raised questions in my mind, I don't think it answered that much!!!I miss the previous episodes! For a moment, a smile appeared on my face.

title: AMAZING ADAPTION
text: I love book to movie adaptions but this was like nothing I've ever seen before. So many scenes felt like they came right out of my imagination and it was so incredible to see them on stage.The entire cast did amazing and really brought the story to life. This was my first introduction to Rachel Zegler and Tom Blyth so I didn't know what to expect, but now that I've seen them I can't imagine anyone else playing Lucy Gray and Snow. They brought so much emotion and heart and really brought these characters to life.It's definitely a different vibe from the original series but it has the same depth and heart. It's a truly beautiful story that brings a whole new perspective to the original series. Writing, directing, acting; everything was perfect. It was a really wonderful experience.

title: Better than the Sequels 8/10
text: This movie was better than the original prequels. It had great visuals and was more mature than the sequels. It was a great casting, and the storyline flowed throughout the movie. At first, I thought the music was a bit cheesy, but it kept the film together. The music and singing were excellent.It wasn't long or short; they did an excellent job with this prequel. Usually, prequels are worse than sequels, but I could enjoy and be invested in this one. The main characters were great, and there was a depth of emotion in the film. Hopefully, they will continue with this prequel lineup; there's more story to tell here...

title: Movie Fan Opinion - Did Not Read the Books
text:
This movie was just not good.Pros:
+ Great casting for Snow.+ Great way of "showing" the evolution of the Games.+ Shows why the Capital was angry at the Districts.Cons:

title: Disappointing
text: I had high hopes for this movie but it just didn't seem to ever get to any notable point. I think a whole lot more was spent on the computer graphics than on paying some good writers to script this film. None of the characters were well developed. But I will say that for a singing audition this film worked and that's about all. It was disjunctured for the most part often making absolutely no sense whatsoever many times. Plus the whole premise for the plot was never clearly defined. Additionally, there were some major fopauxs with some of the CG. Watch the vat of snakes turn opaque black when it is lifted by the crane. I watched the film but I didn't enjoy the film. They could have and should have done better.

title: Stop comparing to the original THG
text:
Please - keep in mind it's a movie on its OWN. Watch it as if you never seen the hunger games universe. In THAT way..,
👏🏼 Bravo. They stayed to the book wonderfully! Especially considering how MUCH they LEFT OUT of the PRIOR movies - This one did NOT fault!!!If I could literally clap for this cast I would BOW TO THEM!!! I'm sorry that I disagree with people - I have my OWN opinion of course....I absolutely LOVED it. Viola Davis (chefs kiss) as ALWAYS... but to be introduced to such an array of new talent (to me) was super cool too!This movie held its own and among a lot of other good movies that came out around the same time too!Definitely worth watching.... Or if you're like me and love the books as much.. good enough to watch over and over again 😂

title: Worst Hunger Games movie of the saga.
text: I love the franchise and I'm always taking pleasure of watching it again from time to time.But this one, one time was way enough! It was even hard staying until the end.Most boring movie I've seen this year so far. No rythm, plot and dialogues are poor. Not to mention acting which is the worst of all of it.@RachelZegler is like an empty shell. No charisma at all.She can sing for sure but that's actually it. No more, no less. Acting is definitely not her strong suit. She has always that same expression on her face and it makes the movie even more.Such a disappointment for a good franchise.

Literally one of the best movies I've seen in a long time. I can't describe how much I love it. It's so accurate to the book and they did so well in picking out the important parts of the book to display. The chemistry of the actors and their performance is amazing. Tom Blyth is a force to be reckoned with! The cast and crew did the films and books the absolute best homage they could. I almost wish we could have a whole trilogy just on Snow's origin, but this one by itself does the job perfectly!!! All I can say is thank you from the bottom of my heart. You gave teenage me such a thrill at the theater. Seriously, thank you.

title: Disney karaoke games
text:
I loved the original hunger games films. This one felt at times like a Disney live action musical which felt wrong in so many ways (and not in a so wrong it felt right kind of way). The Lucy Gray character was all wrong and breaking into song far too many times and so "professionally" it just killed off any tone or atmosphere the movie was trying to develop. And for someone who had been through what she had been through she was surprisingly happy and upbeat. The other actors were fine and "Snow" was very good, although after watching this prequel, it really didn't feel like a story that needed to be told.Lacked the depth, the emotional connection, the characters, the spectacle,
the writing, the pacing and the darkness of the originals. Not a completely terrible movie, just very poor when compared to the original hunger games movies.

title: A difference to films these days
text: Set 3 years before the first hunger games, this film shows how the Capitol was being maniplulated to start liking and watching the hunger games.This movie, was a great adaption to the film series (even though this film is a prequel), one of the best since Catching Fire. Rachel Zegler is and incredible singer and an amazing actress. The songs that are sung by her are very important to the story, each song contains an important part of the film.Tom Blyth also adapts the role really well and is also an incredible actor. His interpretation to this role is amazing.This film, unlike other movies of 2023 has incredible character development and has an amazing plot and soundtrack. The visuals are gorgeous and has an incredible cast who adapt their role very enjoyably.Overall, I believe that this film is incredible and definitely deserves a watch if you can handle a 3 hour movie.
