Also, pay very good attention to the movie because every little detail is important.

title: Good movie with better book
text: It isn'tan exceptional masterpiece, but i don't regret watcing it in cinema. I'd say you have to read the book first, it will definetly make yout experience with this movie better.The Characters are pretty good on point, I personally liked the interpretation of the covey the most. But I have to say the people looked a bit AI generated in the first half of the movie, but maybe thats just me.I don't think the movie is too long, as many other have said here, I didn't get bored while watching it. If you're a Hunger Games Fan: Watch It, its worth it. And if you won't read the book under any circumstances, just see the movie, it's better than nothing.

title: Nothing like the book
text: This movie was so disappointing. It was nothing like the Book and had so many holes in the plot line. It felt so rushed. I can't stand Rachel Ziegler as lucy gray. She's just so harsh and stiff with the mannerisms and it feels very forced in the acting. I really didn't enjoy the singing in the movie either. I wish they touched more on Coriolanus and Sejanus' relationship. I didn't like the casting and felt the cast didnt fit the roles in the book. I wish it was more true to the book. The characters just felt empty and like nothing was behind them. I did however really like Tom bylth as Coriolanus he was the perfect snow.

title: Most reviews missing the point.
text: Most of the bad reviews here are missing the point: this movie is not meant to be an explanation of the history of the games, or an addition to the original story, or all the other things they're saying. It's meant to be the story of president Snow and how he became what he is. It's his personal de-evolution into the evil person we meet in the original trilogy, and it's much more psychological than the other movies/books. That's intentional.I thought it was very well done. It deviates from the book a little, but only in ways that make adaptation possible. I thought they demonstrated Snow's downward spiral very well, and the climactic moments at the end-actually better than the book did, in that respect.Two thumbs up from me.

title: Snow always lands on top (No Spoilers)
text: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes not only exceeds expectations, but it develops the complexity of a young Coriolanus Snow.Forced to be the mentor of a young female tribute from District 12, a teenaged Snow faces a battle between his personal aspirations and his loyalty to close friends.While this prequel relies on call (forwards?) backs to the original Hunger Games Series, this doesn't create a cheap feel to the movie. Future President Snow is explained in depth and developed into a sympathetic figure throughout this film. This movie also convoluted Snow's behavior in the original series, creating confusions and questioning the characters motives moving forward.Absolutely worth the watch for any fan of the Hunger Games Series.

title: A Solid 8 - Engaging, Full, and well told
text: My overall experience was highly enjoyable for several reasons. Firstly, the movie stood out to me for its commitment to telling a full and intricate story, paying attention to numerous small details that added depth and richness to the narrative.One of the standout performances for me was Tom Blyth's portrayal of Snow. I found his depiction fascinating, as he navigated the delicate balance between being a jerk and a good guy. For those of us knowing the story of the original Hunger Games movies, this installment allows us to understand the roots of his character's attitudes when he is older. Blyth's performance added layers to the character, making him more complex and intriguing, and is one of the rare events where we might feel sympathy and loss for one who at first may have seemed unredeemable.While I appreciated Rachel Zegler's portrayal, especially if the books have emphasis on Lucy Gray's singing, I wasn't as enamored as some other reviewers seem to be. Zegler's back-woods accent, while almost authentic, occasionally felt a bit distracting. Nevertheless, her performance contributed to the overall narrative, and she represented the character well.The movie's pacing was a notable strength. It struck a fine balance, being calm enough to allow for the exploration of the complexity of Snow's development. The deliberate pacing also gave room for a few humorous moments, some well-executed action sequences, and, of course, engaging Hunger Games action.We watched the film as a family and remarkably, none of us ever felt distracted or bored, proving the film's ability to maintain interest throughout. This is a rare quality in a longer film, and it speaks to the movie's ability to captivate a diverse audience.In summary, 'The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes' is, in my opinion, one of the best movies of the year so far. It was crafted with care, evident in the attention to detail and the well-developed storyline. The performances, especially Tom Blyth's, added depth to the characters, making the movie a compelling and thoroughly enjoyable.My go-to way of judging a movie is how we feel walking out after it's over, talking over the high and low points. All of us had only good comments for The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes, and we all agreed it's certainly one of the movies to see this season.

title: Terrible
text: I was completely uninterested in the film because of the terrible performance and the uninteresting plot. The movie seemed to go on forever, and I found myself fidgeting with my phone multiple times since I was bored with all the dull scenes.Much as in the literature, the characters speak in a similar manner. The acting is top-notch. The scenes are paced appropriately. Still, you don't care about a single plot point since the film is so dull.In comparison to the previous Hunger Games films, this one was terrible. My excitement at the announcement of a new Hunger Games film was palpable because I adored the first four films in the series. There was just too much graphic and pointless violence in this film.

title: Not worth it to see in Cinema
text: The film is visually very good and beautifully made. The film in itself is not bad but it is far too tightly screwed together it could use more immersion in the development of various characters. Even though the action is packed, it is still long drawn out and you can't help but look at your phone to see what time it is when you are sitting in the cinema. Tom Blyth plays the role of Snow fantastic, but I can't say this about Rachel Zegler, she makes the film seem like a musical, she generally just doesn't fit into the film as Lucy Gray, she lacks this "bad ass" thing that Katniss/Lawrence had. Overall, the film is nice to watch if you need something to ser when you're bored, but I can't recommend watching it in the cinema, it's not worth it.

title: Don't expect a masterpiece
text: I rated this an 8 because I knew what to expect. Not the best acting, not the best storyline, but a solid world building prequel to a good series. Could've done with a bit less singing. Acting was good in most parts but some "iffy" parts here and there. Fun action for sure, and some fun Easter eggs referencing the original trilogy. I personally never read the prequel, but am definitely inclined to do so now. Overall very entertaining and engaging if you're a fan of the series. Definitely wouldn't mind another installment in the time between this and the first hunger games movie. Good movie. Worth the watch.

title: Eye catching movie
text: The movie will be a spectacular watch for the viewers. Each scene creates a spine chilling movement and its very difficult to predict the next scene. From the characters to the costumes, from the story to the script is everything worth watching. The trailer clearly shows that it would pave a great impact in the theatres and netizens will be waiting to watch it in OTT. The actors renewed their roled and mostly they lived in those characters. The kind of effects they used are simply superb and unique. The director simply used his own way of critiquing and came up with wonderful skills. All the actors did their best in their own ways. Excellent photography, amazing editing and multiple enlightening enabled this movie to reach the records in the box office.

title: film for teenagers, musical comedy, or parody? What's certain is that it's a complete failure.
text: The film is slow and boring, the story makes no sense, it's full of clichés (teenagers in cages exhibited at the zoo, ridiculous) and wokism (men in skirt uniforms, participant with Down syndrome who brings nothing to the story).The worst being the acting, the heroine (R Zegler) plays horribly bad, it's exasperating, the young hero is hardly better and even Viola Davis and Peter Dinklage overact and are very bad.The action scenes are poorly filmed, the special effects are bad, there is no tension, it's very flat and rather boringObviously the film is a complete failure, don't waste your time and move on.

title: Didn't See in the Theater..Wish I had
text: I did not get to see this movie in the theater so I had to wait for it to be streamed. Let's just say I have watched it 3 times. I loved it. I now will get the book to add to the enjoyment. Viola was scary. Tom and Rachel were excellent. I am sorry it appears so many people seemed to dislike it but too many want to be critics and don't let the movie speak to them as it was designed. I am now a Tom Blythe fan. I had no trouble with the music as it played a big part in this movie (songbirds) so if it was viewed and too much, that would be the viewer's loss. I will own this one since I have the original 3. Actually this and Catching Fire are my favorites now.

title: MASTERPIECE
text: Did the book justice, phenomenal acting, incredible soundtrack, literally amazing. I could not have asked for a better movie adaptation, gave us hunger games fans what we wanted and gave Snows character so much more depth. Tom Blyth and Rachel Ziegler played the leads perfectly, could not imagine anyone else as Snow and Lucy Gray. I can not fathom how anyone could dislike this movie genuinely. Having read the book as soon as it was originally released, I was so hyped for this movie and it lived up to my expectations. The movie was quite lengthy but it needed to be to cover all that happens in the book; it could be said that it felt rushed however I think the pacing matched the vibe and atmosphere of what was happening in the book, it was all life and death situations which naturally would feel fast paced.

title: What could have been.
text: Man,While not a huge fan of the series, I foind the originals decent and enjoyable.To be honest I was enjoying myself thru the first two acts. Despite some truly stupid plot choices.But really just made this move a 0 was the third act. Literally nothing made me care or made sense in the 3rd act. They tried to fit 10+ hours of character development into 15 minutes. This was 10x worse then the last season of game of thrones.Like literally delete the 3rd act and thid goes from a 1 star to a 7 star movie.The producers took some crazy wild drugs and said, "make people feel sorry, but also make him evil in the last 10 minutes,"Seriosly, I live in Wisconsin and could have wrote a script 1000x better then these west coast wannabes.

title: Made for fanatics, but don't deliver
text: Another movie in the same storyline as the first two. But in contrast, it failed to deliver the same interest. A producer trying to prolong the interest and liking of the first two movies. But that is about as far as it goes. No " Games of Thrones" here, just simple viewing for 5 to 15 year olds. Plays of years before the others, but the theme is exactly the same. Silly TV characters, unnessary violence, assisted by studio scemantics of explosions. Acting sub-standard, and just plainly made for youngsters, which is OK I guess. Will there be a fouth movie? Well, money counts, doesn't it. Overall assessment....lucky to get a 2/10.

title: A solid entry in the Hunger Game Series
text: The Hunger Games: The Ballas of Songbirds and Snakes was much better then what the previews show. Going into this I had set my expectations low based off of what I read going into and seeing the previews. I was totally off wrong on this one. This is a Prequel to the original Hunger Game films and tells the story of a young Snow who ends up becoming President of Panem. This movie is probably the darkest in the movie series with very brutal kills for a PG-13 rating. I would also say the film does a great job of showing how Snow goes from being good at first to the crazy President of Panem that we all know. The only thing that this movie doesn't do well is with pacing. The movie was very overlong at 2 hours and 30 minutes. There could have been some scenes that were cut or at least trimmed down. I really thought our young Snow played by Tom Blyth did a really good job. Also our character Lucy Grey played by Rachel Zegler was amazing. All in all this was a very solid film and I really enjoyed it. The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes gets a very good 8 stars out of 10.

title: Meh... nothing special, probably wait until it's free on Netflix
text: Very poor acting, way too much signing, felt like a Disney musical for me. I was watching Rachel Zegler play her own self there, I could see her thinking of her lines and stage positioning, completely broke the magic of the movie. The plot is quite predictable. I'd say if you really want to waste your time watching this, wait until is free on a streaming channel somewhere. Hard to believe this is ranked 7.2 here on IMDB. I used to swear by those rankings, wouldn't watch anything below 6.5, now I have my doubts... 7.2 used to be a good movie. This is not even a 5 IMO. The previous Hunger Games movies were way better, This feels like a cheap knock off.

title: A CINEMATIC MASTERPIECE!! better than original!!! And Tom blyth😘
text: First off Tom Blyth😘 and Rachel Zegler did an OUTSTANDING job. They have so much chemistry and are both phenomenal actors. This movie is not what you would expect. I honestly think I love it more than the original hunger games (not think I know) I'm not someone who likes to rewatch anything but as soon as I finished this movie I wanted to watch it all over again it was that good! The love story was so cutesttttt I loved it even though I knew from the start it couldn't ever work out because knowing the original hunger games movies snow isn't ever good nor does he have a love interest but I still needed it to work out. But this movie Kept me invested the entire time I was never bored! Ending pretty much drove me mad but in like almost a good way where I was so invested in it that I had to know what happened you'll see what I'm talking about. "Can't catch me now" is so good and literally relates to the movie like exactly. The BEST soundtrack I've seen in a movie so real sounding and I love Rachel Zegler's voice it's so pretty! AHHH IM OBSESSED WITH EVERYTHING ABOUT THIS SHOW!! THIS IS LITERALLY BEST MOVIE IVE SEEN IN A WHILE IVE SEEN IT 4 TIMES IN ONE WEEK!!! IF YOUR READING THIS AND YOU HAVEN'T WATCHED IT, PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE GO WATCH ITTTT it's literally incredible don't miss out!!

title: Made Me Want to Rewatch The Originals
text: The prequel has a very different vibe to it from the original trilogy, but I went into the movie expecting that because this is an origin story FOR A VILLIAN. We all know, and loathe, Snow from the trilogy, yet we start this movie with a reasonably likeable person. I'm surprised at the folks who feel the ending was rushed - maybe a bit, but I felt that the movie did a decent job of showing someone who was torn between wanting two different things, showed glimpses of a dark side, and ultimately, others see him for who he truly is before he realizes it. I did feel that this movie helped explain how he reacts to Katniss and what happens in the original trilogy, which was my understanding of the movie's purpose.

title: Lucy Gray everywhere
text:
I think I've heard "Lucy Gray" for thousands times during the movie.Second part of the movie it's complete mess. There are no motivation, dialogues or at least logic.When I was watching first two parts - I really thought i like it. But then third one has started...
One of the problem - Snow hasn't changed during the whole movie. As he was egocentric, ready to lie for a purpose - as he is in the end, despite the script trying to hide it - doesn't work at all.Lucy Gray: not so bad as a character. The only thing I didn't like - in the very beginning where she accidentally started to sing - complete disaster, nobody believed that character really can behave like this.

title: Hunger games: the epitome of evil
text: Where do I start? Movies and their characters rarely gives me icks where I feel disgusted seeing them. Dr. Gaul and Casca gave me the icks whenever they pop on screen, especially Dr. Gaul. I love this movie so much, this movie makes you realize that not everyone, aka Snow, never just turn out evil. There is a reason for it.Don't get me wrong, there is no justification in Snows behavior of why he acted the way he acted when he takes over as president. However, I understand why he turned out that way. One just simply should not do people that way and what happened to him involving Lucy was wrong and what Lucy did to him was wrong.I sympathize with the situation that Snow went through with Lucy but I don't sympathize with him at all. Again, no reason to be acting like that. Yes, Snow got his heart broken and was done wrong by Lucy. Totally understand his anger. So what? Move on! There is more fish in the sea then on earth. Snow should have found someone else to fall in love with. No reason for him to be holding onto old crush, his 1st love all the way into his old age (80+) and then 60+ yrs later go after a woman from district 12 who reminds him of Lucy.As far as Lucy goes, she also was no angel herself. Her and Snow was not all the way trustworthy. Lucy was a snake in her own right. I felt she used him to win. Was her love for him even real? I don't think so. Other then that, such an amazing film that I can watch over and over again.

title: Incredible!
text: Absolutely fantastic! Captivating, cinematic & beautiful. Fast paced with action at every scene. I had no time to take a breath during the whole film! I saw it at a Dolby Atmos theater. The music was loud & stunning. Showed Lucy Grays emotions perfectly. I read the book & it was pretty spot on, more than I thought. I'm glad they dismissed making the film into two parts. It was paced so well you didn't know it was around three hours long. My favorite was the ending. It was so well done. The book was definitely more violent & bloody though. But that would have obviously changed the rating to R. All in all. The film was great! I will be seeing it again and purchasing it for home. I hope there is a prequel #2.

title: Loved every second of it...
text: There was a time when Hollywood made some great YA novel based dystopian action films like The Maze Runner, Divergent and The Hunger Games series itself, so its too good to see another one of them in recent time.. I don't remember anything about THG series its been years since I watch those movies but i loved every second day this prequel story.. It had an amazing cast, some good cinematography, highly tense and thrilling moments and a gripping story which will keep you engaged from start to finish.. What I love about dystopian stories is the subversion of rules we have today now in real world.. The term dystopian itself means in terms of fiction is 'a society running by some elites of the world in near future where normal rules of humanity don't even apply' as you can see even in this movie elites don't even see contestant as humans but rather as a means of exploitaion for their own entertainment.. They were thrown into an arena where they have to kill each to survive. There are some heavy dialouges in this movie which will make you realize that in the face of death humans lost their humanity and morals in a blink of an eye.. Overall I enjoyed this film it is one of the best of 2023 and maybe now I'll revisit THG series very soon in near future... We need more films based on Young Adult novels these days..

title: The Long Boring Saga Games
text: I'm not even going to bother giving spoilers, there are already too many here... I just need to say that this film doesn't deserve the hype, nor the ticket money... I think it's poorly thought out and I don't think that's what it was were asking - at least some fans of the saga.A mess, with a somewhat forced message.There are many technical and casting points that could have been suppressed, but I think the biggest problem - I think - was the rush to make something and release it quickly for the world to "consume".Quickly and well, there is no one.This may serve as a lesson for future attempts.I just regret the lost time.

title: I thought the first ones were ok but...
text: And before you hunger game gatekeepers come at me, never read the books but I do fully intend to. Don't get me wrong, the first ones were good for what they were. This one on the other hand, which I already have the book ready to go, I was against watching it because of the Rachel Zegler fiasco. I'm glad I swallowed my pride because the performances from all the actors were captivating. I've never seen Tom before and he really was something to watch. Rachel is new to the industry and young, I think she'll learn from all of this, but the girl is talented. I can't tell you how obsessed with Lucy Gray I have become. I couldn't turn away from the movie. There's action, love, and music. And by the end of the movie, I was just absolutely heartbroken for both Coryo and Lucy Gray. Please don't listen to the horrible reviews and watch it with an open mind.

title: feel like a movie made by a 12 year old
text:
Even though I accepted the unreasonable decisions made by the main characters (like we all have to do in action movies), it kept coming all movie long till the point you feel like vomiting... and then several times there's a plot twist, suddenly romance, suddenly terrorism, suddenly a fight, but no follow through, the story just jumps from here to there and back... and partially because of that the movie is way too long... I really wanted to leave the cinema, and would have if I hadn't come for once with my daughters.Once half way you start hoping: "ah finally the last plot twist, now the movie can stop... " and then a new story starts, totally new, out of the blue, little to do with what happened before, they could have gone in 50 directions, and just picked one, for fun of spending money on making movies or so? What a waste of my time and money...
The main actress even sings up to 3 or 5 times the same song, you'd think it has become a musical, but no no, that was just another plot twist.After a while your only hope is to see some nice fighting scenes, but even there the movie disappoints...
I try to find one positive aspect... well, maybe the fashion, the clothes... I appreciated it, or at least considered it "interesting"...

title: Beyond the Games
text: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes Promises a Gripping Tale of Ambition and Redemption.The trailer opens with a haunting rendition of the Hunger Games anthem, setting the stage for a dark and suspenseful prequel.It is visually stunning, with lavish costumes and sets that bring the opulent Capitol and the bleak districts to life. The Games themselves look even more brutal and terrifying than ever before. But it's the performances that really give me chills.I can't wait to see how their story unfolds. The Hunger Games are about to get a whole lot more interesting.So, if you're looking for a movie that's both visually stunning and emotionally resonant, The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is definitely worth checking out.The Games are a brutal spectacle, masterfully directed by Francis Lawrence. The Capitol's decadence contrasts starkly with the districts' bleakness. But it's the performances that really resonate.

title: Just watch the movie - you won't be bored
text: I have never read the original books, nor am i a huge fan of the series. But if you wanna watch a movie for a pure ENTERTAINMENT then go and do this right now. This film never made me bored, the story is very well structured and easy to understand, the acting is, although not amazing, but great enough to feel the emotions of the characters, especially in Snow's case, you can see him becoming more and more obsessed with ambition.Yes, it's true that one can find it difficult to attach to the characters, as none of them is particularly likable, but, after all, this is HUNGER GAMES, they are only there to get your attention, to entertain you, so that you could forget them after the show is done, and wait with excitement for the next one.To put it short, this is a great 'villain origin' film. Stop overthinking and just watch.

title: Lacklustre
text: There's more substance in a vacuum than in this movie. The writers are clearly unmotivated and decrepit. Their work stinks, and the director put the final nail in the coffin.This is the sort of movie one would expect from one's teenage son after gifting him his first camcorder and clapperboard combo. Little Jimmy went off to play with his friends and came back with this rubbish.The actors should seek alternative employment, and the producers should just move to Florida and forget all about life. As for the audio people, they seem a lost cause entirely. The audio quality of this movie was terrible. Don't studios that invest millions of dollars in movies check for basics such as the sound quality?This is another movie that puts me off new movies. I'm just going to watch old black and white flicks for a while, and I'll check back on the new stuff after the bad memory of this rot has faded a bit, and in the hope that Hollywood has past its dead years and has started making movies worth watching again. What a horrible experience.

title: The worst one
text: I did really enjoy all the other movies, I was invested in those characters, I cared about what happened to them and I was intrigued to see what happened next.But this film, wow, from the get go I could not get into it, what's with the random awful singing etc?! The story is really boring and I'm not remotely interested in it, I'm only still watching it as the wife seems to be liking it.I can't believe how long the film is and at no point have I really been remotely intrigued as to what's going to unfold. I don't think any of the acting is particularly bad but it's just a terrible storyline.

title: It is a good watchable movie
text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad Of Songbirds & Snakes is the perfect masterpiece haunting origin tale showing the downfall of president snow. What a masterful job at taking the book and adapting it to the screen. The cinematography is excellent. Tom Blyth is a star and rachel zegler embodies Lucy Gray.What an experience, the whole theater was at the border of their seats, quiet, just admiring the movie. The story, the acting, the music, the references, EVERYTHING was just perfect.So many things and people came together to make this movie suck us right back into the world of Panem, and it really felt like we never left!! It was a gorgeous movie with gorgeous performances and settings and costumes and music by Olivia Rodrigo and such.

title: Hate or Love it Movie
text: It's not a bad or boring movie. I will be honest i've never read the books but in my opinion this movie was better than the original movies. It was long because it's not a theater movie,it's a streaming movie and i guess this way they could make the movie close to story of books. And we could see the character as a human with flaws not a cliche selfish evil character. But i also should say that i think they mainly prepared the second half of the movie and it was completely different and better movie. Watch, enjoy and dont listen the people who never like a movie.(And put your phone down while watching a movie)

title: Much better than expected!
text: I expected yet another weak prequel of a successful trilogy to squeeze more money from it. I entered the cinema with low expectations (maybe this was the trick) and was surprised.Characters, story, visuals, songs, all much better than expected. Especially the two main characters and their development are convincing. Maybe you should know and expect that this is mainly about the development of Snow. Without spoiling I can say that he makes his first steps from a somehow likeable or at least comprehensible character to, well to someone less likeable.If you liked the catching fire, etc., you will like it. My recommendation is to watch it after you refreshed your memory with the existing movies. Without knowing and liking them, it might be hard.

title: Read the book!
text: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes was a very good book, however, the film falls flat. Despite the 2 hours and 37 minute run time the story is rushed and relationships/plotlines were not developed.The romance between Snow and Lucy was developed slowly yet deeply in the book and their relationship made sense. In the film you have to use your imagination (go figure) to see how the two could have fallen for each other in such a short period of time. There was absolutely no chemistry between the actors in the film and their casting was terrible.In the book, Lucy is extremely likeable and Snow's motives are developed with much more depth. In the film, Lucy is underwhelming at best and not likeable more often than not.The voice actor whom sings in the audiobook does wonderful renditions of the songs in the film, which leads the films versions to be very disappointing.Sejanus was annoying in the book but was a likeable character, in the film Sejanus is just annoying.The casting/acting were terrible in this film. I half expected to find out that this was the director's first film and that the casting director was an intern.Lastly, Maude Ivory was a truly missed opportunity. Maude Ivory in the book was so cute and likeable yet in the film she is just someone onscreen.

title: It's a good movie
text: I read the book. The movie did a good job adapting the main points of the book without sacrificing context. Don't compare katniss to Lucy gray. They're totally different. This is the story of Coriolanus Snow, the others just helped shaped him up. Give it a chance. It's a good movie.Personally I didn't find the movie dragging at all. The pacing is really good. I'm so glad there's not much cheesy moments, the movie doesn't need it. I don't like Rachel Zegler but she did the job. Tom Blyth is perfect for the role. Francis Lawrence did a good job directing. Nothing fancy or amazing but the story line superb.

title: Very Good!
text: I was not sure what to expect when seeing this 'Hunger Games' prequel, but I really enjoyed it! The idea of seeing how the main antagonist from the previous films rises to power is so intriguing.Rachel Zegler gave an amazing performance and she has a phenomenal singing voice. The film would have lost a lot of charm if her performance and character was not present. The costume design was fantastic as well, as you really get an eerily dystopian distinction between the rich and the oppressed citizens.I thought the CGI was a little shaky at points. The titular snakes needed either more practical effects or just tweaking how they looked in certain lighting.Through other online reviews, I have heard that they left some important details or features from the book. So, it may not be an entirely faithful adaptation but it is definitely worth a watch in my opinion!

title: Eminem as Stan could not save this movie
text: Shocked they got Eminem to go back in time and play Stan. Jk but a hunk of junk this movie wasWhy so much singing? Zeigler is a terrible actress or at least a movie actress. WAY TOO THEATRICAL! She's yelling or singing every line. The male lead is actually solid and hope he can save the series but she's got to go.So derivative of its origins I can't begin to explain. Basically the same cast of characters bastardized to be lesser versions of the original. I'm not saying the hunger games is Citizen Cane but it had its charms. This movie gets high praise and ultimately what likely led me to be disappointed.Not the worst movie but 30 minutes too long and not sure it has the momentum to carry the load of a full series.

title: The Hunger Games prequel that deserved to be made.
text: I think it's hard to appreciate how The Hunger Games movies did a decent job of adapting the source material for the big screen while not evolving into a behemoth of a franchise. That Suzanne Collins made it clear that there was only the three books, and she didn't want to do anything else until she was ready was a welcome change from an entertainment industry that likes to squeeze as much money out of popular things as fast as possible. With this in mind, I can applaud The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes (2023) for being respectful of the original trilogy while also trying to expand the narrative in prequel form.While not a completely necessary prequel, it was still interesting to see how early versions of the Hunger Games were run. Of course, our knowledge of how they eventually evolve into something worse is only staved off by seeing just how Coriolanus Snow (Tom Blyth) "lives long enough to become the villain." Having not read this book yet, the over 2.5-hour length of this movie felt a bit much a times as they tried to cram everything into it.Still, through an ironic twist of fate, movies about the Hunger Games are still entertaining for the same reasons the Hunger Games are entertaining. These characters are bizarre, but interesting. Rachel Zegler was the best choice for the role of Lucy Gray, which should come as no surprise for anyone who saw West Side Story (2021). Even the famous actors (like Viola Davis, Peter Dinklage, and Jason Schwartzman) add the gravitas needed to make The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes not just another prequel cash grab.The Hunger Games prequel that deserved to be made, I give The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes 4.0 stars out of 5.

title: Incredibly boring
text: I felt quite relieved when this movie was finally over. It's incredibly boring. If it makes one thing sure: It shows the amazing level of acting Jennifer Lawrence had in the former films because nothing comes quite like this in this prequel. She is strongly missed! Some of the dialogues were really bad and also the way women are portraied in this movie is a shame. Rachel Zeglers acting skills did not convince me at all. Maybe one plus for the music, in my opinion it was quite fitting. Overall I did not see any need to stretch this over more than two and a half hours. I won't watch it again and cannot recommend it at all.

title: (No Spoilers) An Ugly but Beautiful Face to the Hunger Games Franchise
text: I will start this off by saying I wasn't much a fan of the previous Hunger Games movies. I wasn't *not* a fan, because I did like it, but after the second installment I kind of checked out of the whole thing. Then I saw this. I even mistook the trailer for a sequel to the new D&D movie, because that's just how different it was from the others. Understandably, this may upset many people who loved prior Hunger Games movies because this one could really be it's own thing with how completely divergent it is from the originals. However, I think that's what makes it so great. Don't get me wrong, I despise it when a movie, especially a reboot (which I somewhat consider this, like a prequel-boot), strays so far from the original that it's basically not even related anymore, but for this movie it's done so beautifully. Especially for newer audiences who maybe did not watch the original Hunger Games. Maybe I'm going too far with the following comment, but would some agree that for someone who has not watched the previous movies that it would be a very nice introduction to the franchise?In summary, the movie itself is an amazing one, but a problem that I did not have, but many may is that it does seem moreso like it's own movie than anything, but for those who are willing to take that risk, you really won't be disappointed.

title: Close to ideal
text: At first I thought that two and a half hours was a long time for the movie. But after watching the movie, I was attracted by the sequence of events and how Snow was a good person and what influenced him and made him a different person. I enjoyed it very much.The sound of the beginning of the Hunger Games was poignant after such a long period of time since the end of the film series. For someone who had not read the book, the story was wonderful and explained many things about Snow's character in the previous four parts.I was wondering what this movie could add to the story... but it was perfect... I didn't like the ending, but certainly this is the perfect ending for Snow's character.

title: Mixed emotions. Overall bad decision.
text: Went to see this movie with my wife, and one of our best friends. The movie was well designed, and casted. Acting was 10/10. However, the plot was horrible. This was not "villain origin" this was "writer wrote a perfect love story and decided he wanted the main character to be evil out of NO-WHERE". I still don't understand the ending at all. Snow didn't seem to lose his mind. He just seemed to be turned into a being of pure evil in the last 10-15 minutes of this USELESS 2.5 HOUR MOVIE. I wish I had not wasted the time on it. It gave no meaning to the story line. I'm not sure what the intention, or goal was- with the creation of this movie. Thoroughly disappointed.

title: Awsome Movie
text: Good Direction and VFX. I enjoyed that a lot and i really recommned it to the movie lovers its very good time pass movie. Go to the theatre and enjoy the spacticular experience of The Hunger Games.Direction is just super like its previous parts and the performances of the actor are tremendous as well.I went to watch this movie with friends and we all enjoyed it so much. Very Good work of all the crew, director and actor whoever attached to this movie.The locations are also very nice and was looking so smooth and real.So folk do not wait for anything just hit the theatre.Thank you all.

title: A thrilling prelude to a dystopian saga
text: The stories of survival, rebellion, and the unbreakable human spirit found in The Hunger Games series have made it a towering monument in the field of dystopian fiction. Now, with The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes, we're transported back in time, decades before the events that shaped Katniss Everdeen's life, to witness the rise of a young man destined to become Panem's most feared figure - President Coriolanus Snow. As the 10th annual Hunger Games approaches, 18-year-old Coriolanus, a charismatic yet ambitious student from the privileged District 2, finds his life taking an unexpected turn when he's assigned to mentor Lucy Gray Baird, a tribute from the impoverished District 12. With the Capitol revelling in the spectacle of the Games, Coriolanus is determined to make a name for himself by guiding Lucy to victory.However, Lucy proves to be no ordinary tribute. Her rebellious spirit and captivating singing voice challenge Coriolanus's preconceived notions of District 12 and the very nature of the Hunger Games themselves. As the two navigate the treacherous arena, a complex and unexpected bond develops between them, forcing Coriolanus to confront his own prejudices and the harsh realities of Panem's oppressive society.The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes masterfully captures the essence of The Hunger Games universe, delving into the dark origins of the Games and the moral complexities that lie at their core. Director Francis Lawrence delivers a visually stunning and action-packed spectacle, while screenwriters Michael Arndt and Michael Lesslie weave a compelling narrative that explores themes of power, loyalty, and the human capacity for both cruelty and compassion.Tom Blyth shines in the role of Coriolanus Snow, effectively portraying the character's transformation from a self-serving young man to a ruthless leader. His portrayal is nuanced and layered, revealing the cracks in Coriolanus's carefully constructed façade as he grapples with his growing empathy for Lucy Gray.Rachel Zegler delivers a captivating performance as Lucy Gray, infusing the character with a blend of vulnerability, resilience, and a touch of defiance. Her singing is a potent symbol of resistance in the face of the oppressive regime; it is both beautiful and haunting. The supporting cast is equally impressive, with Ayomide Adegun and Hunter Schafer delivering memorable performances as gamemakers Sejanus Pliny and Tigris Snow, respectively.The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is a visually stunning film, with cinematographer Mark Gordon capturing the grandeur of the Capitol and the brutality of the Games arena. James Newton Howard's score for the movie perfectly complements the narrative by adding layers of suspense and emotion. The film's editing is crisp and effective, seamlessly weaving together the various storylines and maintaining a brisk pace throughout. The dialogue is sharp and witty, capturing the essence of the characters' personalities and the political machinations of Panem.Offering a new take on the dystopian world and its inhabitants, The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is an exciting and thought-provoking prequel to The Hunger Games saga. It's a film that will keep you on the edge of your seat, leaving you pondering the complexities of human nature and the dangers of unchecked power. It successfully expands the dystopian world of The Hunger Games. With its strong performances, stunning visuals, and thought-provoking themes, it's a must-see for fans of the franchise and newcomers alike.

title: Two side of stories we certainly need
text: Brilliant!! This movie explain the background of snow before he become the president and end up as katniss nemesis. It explore comparative perspective on how capitol think of district people and vice versa. You need a certain wit to understand the plot. It's focus on snow as the main. Bring you to understand the emotional aspect that snow experience as well as his choice that led him to be born as a tyrant ruler of the capitol.Don't expect this a that hunger games 2012 this is not focus on the competition but the games itself. People who doesn't understand will tell you it's boring. No it's not! They watch wrong movie, for them they just need to watch film like lala land.Edit: I'm going through the review and I found people that read the book praise the movie, there's also many who read the book feeling dissatisfied. Though I don't read this particular book, I've read enough book and seen enough adaptation to say that this is a worthy adaptation. You can't expect movie to have the same degree of quality as the novel, that won't happen. This is my perspective that don't read the book and surely the movie is great!

title: I love it
text: I never watched first 3 Hunger Games because I was not interested in this kind of story. But I went to watch this one since my daughter was reading the books and kept telling me how much she enjoyed the book. I prepared a blanket with me so I could take a nap in the movie theater. But I watched it from the beginning to the end. And I didn't want to leave the theater until everyone was gone. I really liked it. I ended up watching the first 4 movies of the Hunger Games at home with my daughter on that weekend. But I still liked The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes the most. I liked the story and the characters in this movie. President Snow was very charming in this movie.

title: Fantastic Movie
text: The film's story, based on the author Suzanne Collins' source material, pursues the humanising angle of exploring a younger and less hardened Snow as an empathetic figure - it's sort of like his Anakin Skywalker phase, pre-Vader.The film's story, based on the author Suzanne Collins' source material, pursues the humanising angle of exploring a younger and less hardened Snow as an empathetic figure - it's sort of like his Anakin Skywalker phase, pre-Vader.The film's story, based on the author Suzanne Collins' source material, pursues the humanising angle of exploring a younger and less hardened Snow as an empathetic figure - it's sort of like his Anakin Skywalker phase, pre-Vader.

title: Had potential but poorely executed...
text: This movie has so much to go for, nice set designs, fairly good actors, but probably ruined by poor writing. Screenplay was corny and at times just cringeworthy. Motivations of the main characters were not convincing and downright not logical to begin with. The arena for the hunger games and action sequences was random and not satisfying. They tried their effort in building and depicting a dystopian world but it just wasnt it, it lacked depth and some soul. The vibe of this hunger game installment reminded me in the beginning alot of squid game. Squid game is a perfectly good example how a Battle Royale movie should be directed. But unfortunately after the disappointment of this Hunger Games I wont be looking forward to another one.

title: Snow always lands on the top!
text: Coriolanus Snow is chosen to be a mentor to a tribute at the 10th annual Hunger Games. He is mesmerized by District 12's Lucy Gray and her singing. Coriolanus wants to achieve back his family's lost glory and he wants to do it through Lucy Gray. He along with his best friend Sejanus are sympathetic towards the tributes and wants to do the right thing, amidst the rebel's constant attacks. What truly happens post the Hunger Games, the impact it has on Coriolanus and his friendship forms rest of the story.This was indeed a lengthy film and unlike the earlier trilogy, this doesn't feature the Hunger Games for that long. Probably, that is what got me a bit restless as the drama took a whole 2 parts to settle in. It is only in the part 3 where I was able to invest properly as the story focused on Coriolanus, Sejanus and Lucy Gray. What the film did succeed in getting the dystopian world setting despite the Hunger Games segment not being that intense. This still manages to set up the story for the sequels to take over and there is enough mystery intact to stay interested.

title: Awesome movie
text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad Of Songbirds & Snakes is the perfect masterpiece haunting origin tale showing the downfall of president snow. What a masterful job at taking the book and adapting it to the screen. The cinematography is excellent. Tom Blyth is a star and rachel zegler embodies Lucy Gray.What an experience, the whole theater was at the border of their seats, quiet, just admiring the movie. The story, the acting, the music, the references, EVERYTHING was just perfect.First and foremost, I have to compliment my girl Rachel Zegler. Her acting as Lucy Gray literally felt like she ripped her straight off of the paper. She was the most perfect Lucy Gray and I don't think anyone else could have done her as much justice as Rachel did. Even more than Rachel's acting, is her INCREDIBLE singing.

title: Hunger Games left me Hungry
text: Film felt ungrounded and there was no sense of universe or tone being created the way the previous Hunger Games films had done, including the characters. It seemed that the main character broke out into song at every opportunity and the movie lacked some grit. We weren't ever introduced to who the characters were, which left us with no one to root for.Moments that were meant to be heartfelt sometimes fell flat, leaving us a bit uncomfortable. No clear sense of urgency or stakes to a majority of the movie, other than Viola Davis and Snow's Friend. I understand what was the vision but it wasn't clearly or artistically communicated.

title: Despite the length, it's an attention holder
text: I don't have much experience with the Hunger Games. I have seen the first movie only once or twice. Haven't read the books or seen any of the sequels. I only really went because I was offered a ticket and the premise of the series was mildly interesting to me. I heard how long it was when we showed up to the theater. I thought there was no way my attention was going to be held on this movie for that long. My movie tastes are really not dystopian films. I am a diehard horror fan, my favorite sub genre being torture. Horror is what I live on, and it's hard for a movie without intense gore and scares to hold my interest for even a regular movie length, let alone a long one. I have no idea how it did it, but I was fixed on the screen the entire movie. Interested and invested. There were some sickening scenes, none of which were visually too gory, but the undertones and set up made them impactful all the same. There was some darker humor in there that made me absolutely cackle, however bad I felt for laughing at it. I really, really don't know how they did it but they held the attention of a torture movie fan for over 2 hours with a PG-13 movie.

title: A fantastic addition to the Hunger Game series
text: I loved Hunger Games since I was a teenager so the new movie was like a miracle for me. No matter what other people say I think that the chosen cast is perfect for this movie. All of the actors managed to portray the true character of the main characters and managed to portray the scary reality of the great country Panem. The whole movie I was not able to tear my eyes away from the screen as not only the visual picture was mesmerising but also the soundtracks created for the movie sang by Rachel are fantastic. The choice to add more music to this movie is a great move as music is integral part of the plot that carries a deep meaning. So overall I would definitely recommend watching this movie!

title: Don't have expectations
text: I love the hunger games movies and never read the books. I did not really like this movie. It's an origin story of one of the characters, and it wasn't even that entertaining. It had so much potential, but was executed poorly. Not worth watching unless you particularly care for HG series. There's no action or thrill. It has it moments, but they're brief and rushed. Its all drama and character development. Typically I'm one to say a movie is better than most people say it is (I even liked the live action avatar Airbender movies after growing up on the cartoon!!) So that must say something about this movie.

title: Feed The "Hunger"
text: Suzanne Collins' Hunger Games series of books, set in an extremely Dystopian place called Panem in which participants from various districts in varying states of poverty are forced to fight to the death, are likely second only to J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter series in terms of popularity among teens and young adults. The first three books, "The Hunger Games", "Catching Fire", and "Mockingjay", were published in consecutive years, 2008. 2009, and 2010, and were subsequently made into massive box office hit movies, the first in 2012; "Catching Fire" in 2013"; and "Mockingjay" made into two films, Part 1 in 2014, and Part 2 in 2015. Each of those films starred Jennifer Lawrence as Katniss Everdeen, a girl from District 12 (located in the Appalachian region). In 2020, Collins released a prequel, "The Ballad Of Songbirds And Snakes", that was set some six and a half decades before the events of the first three novels. And in 2023, that book too got made into a massive opus of a movie.Although Lawrence's character of Katniss Everdeen is absent here, THE BALLAD OF SONGBIRDS AND SNAKES does get into the meat and bones of how one character, Coriolanus Snow (played in the three films before this one by Donald Sutherland) came to be what he became in the main trilogy. As played by Tom Blyth, Snow is assigned to be a mentor to a District 12 contestant named Lucy Gray Baird (Rachel Zegler), an itinerant mountain girl and folk music singer, to help her win the tenth edition of the Hunger Games. This sets him up to be closely monitored by the Games' prime mastermind, Dr. Volumnia Gaul (played with rather vicious relish by Viola Davis), and the games' creator Dean Casca Hightbottom (Peter Dinklage). Zegler manages to win the Hunger Games, but many complications between her and Blyth ensue afterwards, as do his relationships with, among others, rival Sejanus Plith (Josh Andres Rivera).As directed by Francis Lawrence, who helmed CATCHING FIRE and both MOCKINGJAY films, THE BALLAD OF SONGBIRDS AND SNAKES, aside from being Dystopian in ways that I think would have been hard for even Aldous Huxley or George Orwell to imagine, is quite hair-raising in terms of its action sequences, occasionally imperiling the credibility of its PG-13 rating. It is also quite a long movie at almost two hours and forty minutes, though that length is offset by the action sequences, and the breaks into Appalachian folk music that Zegler's character indulges in, and which earns her the support of the Hunger Games viewing audience. Zegler, whose role as Maria in director Steven Spielberg's beautiful 2021 reworking of WEST SIDE STORY is one for the ages, does a very good turn as Lucy Gray Baird, with her folk-singing voice being very much reminiscent of Mother Maybelle Carter, Joan Baez, and Linda Ronstadt; and although this role isn't quite on the level of what she did for Spielberg, it is nowhere near the hot mess that her detractors (of which there seem to be far too many), and she really gets into the role in the District 12 "bar" sequences.THE BALLAD OF SONGBIRDS AND SNAKES, even with its weird complications, twists, and turns, earns a rating of 8 from me.

title: Painfully boring and unnecessary long!
text:
How can a movie from a great franchise like hunger games be this bad!!I mean they could just copy paste the previous ones and make a better movie than this trash.1- acting was so bad, i felt nauseous watching them. The worst was zegler and the rest would follow her on the list

title: How are villains made...? Is it the nature or nurture?
text:
How are villains made...? Is it the nature or nurture?Are they born evil, or it's the environment that shapes their psychopathy...?It's can be quite difficult to root for a character, which we as the audience already know will grow up being personification of darkness, having been innocently named Snow. And yet the intriguing aspect of well made prequel is sense of anticipation of us wanting to know how things actually began.The action of The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes takes place 64 years before the original trilogy (its trilogy even though the last part was split in to two movies) and shows the origin of Coriolanus Snow the character played in the original movies by Donald Sutherland, known as President Snow, Having antihero as your protagonist can add a feeling of moral ambiguity and yet the makers of this film make it work in to its strength rather then failure.The story of Coriolanus Snow, years before he would become the tyrannical President of Panem. He is handsome and charming, and though the Snow family has fallen on hard times, Coriolanus sees a chance for a change in his fortunes when he is chosen to be a mentor for the 10th Hunger Games only to have his elation dashed when he is assigned to mentor a girl tribute named Lucy Gray Baird from the impoverished District 12.The plot is set in the 3 chapter structure. The first 2 are rather well paced showcasing the origins of Hunger Games, how they were created being full of mostly well executed suspense and action scenes as well as character development.The 3rd and the final chapter feels a little anticlimactic and somewhat rushed...The performances are rather strong leading with multi talented, young yet charismatic Rachel Zegler, which plays the character of Lucy Gray Baird a singer chosen from district 12 as a tribute.She becomes assigned to Snow as her win guaranties his success in social ladder claim.I must say I feel sad for Zegler that she has been blacklisted in Hollywood after her silly remarks about the new version of Snow White adaptation.At age 22 she had her whole career in front of her and now going the arthouse career route might be difficult to say the least. Very talented singer in her own right, she actually sang life all the songs, which are performed in the movie. She has that endearing quality and yet also possesses some strength, which makes her very watchable. I hope the Hollywood power players will grant her a comeback after her ego find humility, as she hugged the proverbial cactus long enough...;).Tom Blyth as young Snow displays duality clearly having daddy issues,which create deep need to fulfill his ambitions no matter what costs.Viola Davis as Dr. Gaul conjures an inner witch within, opting to dive in towards theatricality over ultra realism. In supporting cast Peter Dinklage stylized on to morphine addicted Jesuits-priest teacher, brings depth in his choices.The production and costume design works very well stylized on rather analogue technology, as digitized electronics perished in war due to presumed Electro Magnetic Pulse weapons, brings the Hungar Games back to basics.The insignia of Panem looks to have Freemasonry
symbology, as the new world order post Apocalyptic reality is without religious connotations.The costumes of the elites specially male are wearing both pants and dresses symbolizing unity of sexes are all well throughout.The peace keeping units having United Nations clear inspiration are adding additional believability specially in act 3.All in all this prequel is rather entertaining, apart from somewhat misstep in pacing in act 3.When chapter 2 finished with finally of Hunger Games, which keeps the audience quite engaged, going toward character driven chapter 3 feels little anticlimactic, but specifically the fans of the original source material should be satisfied, considering that this film adaptation apparently follows the book adaptation faithfully.Recommend!

title: Embarrassing movie
text: This one was seriously poor movie. Everything is either poorly done or then very overacted, over dramatic and pompous. Starting from acting, to costumes, to special effect, writing, everything, it was either poor or mediocre. It felt like I was watching an over length episode of a lousy stream series which is cancelled after the first season due to poor view ratings. Then some extra things like musical style singing to reflect the story with dramatic fashion was totally overacting and way too overdramatic. Just an example of weird decision to add extra drama into the movie. Everything felt so out of the place.Other reviews have also mentioned that the scenes were loosely connected. I also felt it was like that. Not to mention that it was very difficult to follow what really this movie is about. The story is so confusing. I had no idea after the movie that what the districts are there fore, what is the Capitol, what are these mean looking soldiers and how they fit into the concept of Capitol, what these hungergames are really for and so on. The amount of open questions was like vast. Then the sheer amount of talking with completely meaningless dialogue. Oh my God.After the second part, the movie is split into parts by the way, I was completely lost that what the story in the movie is actually all about. Then some story lines are concluded with super lame fashion. Just suddenly something is happening just for some reason to kill the characters so that the storyline can be concluded.This kind of movie makes me really think that how the movie industry is going so wrong with big budget movies. Somehow I believe that at 80s or 90s with this budget, people at the industry would had made something way much better. In this movie, there is virtually nothing spectacular, nothing to see explicitly at the cinema. This movie is a total filler into stream service catalog what you may watch into some point at home and then just close the movie because it's so lousy. Maybe stream services are killing the cinema industry inside out. Who knows...

title: A fun take on the book
text: I'm surprised by all the average reviews here. I think many people here are comparing this movie to the hunger games, instead of judging it on its own. Yes, the hunger games and catching fire are better- they're hard to beat. But this movie still completely stands on its own.While the runtime is a bit long, the movie never feels boring. There's always something going on, and it's quite faithful to the book. I do think that original fans will likely appreciate this movie more than most. However, you don't need to be a hunger games lover to enjoy the movie. It has action, romance, a compelling plot, good characters, and heart.

title: hasn't this franchise been overdone?
text: Hollywood has become addicted to sequels and sequels and sequels. Hunger Games. Star Wars. Twilight. Harry Potter, ad nauseum.There was no good reason to make this movie, except for the money. And sure it will bring in enough money that the makes will call themselves justified.The only decent sequels came from Tolkien's LOTR. The script was good, the acting was good, the sets were good, the cinematography was good. Though Peter Jackson went overboard on the script at times but what he produced was worth watching.They should have stopped with the first film. Hunger Games was somewhat watchable, though I think Jennifer Lawrence was overrated as an actress. One movie was fine, the rest of them were merely indulgence.

title: If you are a Hunger Games fan, You'll love it!
text: Pacing: I find the film to be too fast-paced. Ironically, the film is set in a rush while the book is written at a slower pace. While the film lasts 2 hours and 37 minutes, extending it to 3 hours, similarly with Oppenheimer (2023) movie, could have allowed for a more thorough exploration. Nonetheless, the adaptation works well.Adaptation Details: I read the book and noticed that the film focuses on the most important parts of Coriolanus Snow's thoughts and other of course important details, but it leaves out some smaller details. The director did a good job handling these important parts, making a well-rounded portrayal even though certain elements were left out.Directing and Cinematography: The direction of Francis Lawrence has improved significantly, and the camerawork is outstanding with its camera shots. The visual elements of the film - its colors and camerawork - create an extremely genuine and thrilling mood and atmosphere for the movie.Intense Scenes and Storytelling: The film is filled with tense moments, which increase the audience's engagement. With themes of trust at its core, the narrative is engrossing and skillfully executed. Well done.Acting: The cast performances were impressive. Despite some online criticism, Raechel Zegler's portrayal worked well for me, especially her "anti-Katniss" character contrasting with Coriolanus Snow's similarity to Katniss. Tom Blyth as Coriolanus Snow did a gread job portraying his character. Josh Andrés Rivera's performance reminded me of Matt Damon and he did well; I also liked Lucky Flickerman's performance with his witty character that brought a blend of Effie Trinket and Cesar Flickerman's essence from the original Hunger Games films.Music and Soundtrack: The film featured lively and entertaining Covey music with bittersweet lyrics. Moreover, The James Newton Howard-composed score, which paralleled the style of Ludwig Goransson's score for the 2023 film Oppenheimer for me, was outstanding and consistent with Howard's work on the four prior Hunger Games films.Accuracy and Production: This film, in my opinion, out of all five in the Hunger Games series, most accurately captures the essence of the franchise as depicted by Francis Lawrence, like maybe about 9/10 accuracy. Hence, Suzanne Collins' as executive producer's role in this movie was evident.Overall: I was considerably impressed by The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes. I am optimistic about it. The film effectively depicts the essence of the franchise and fills the Hunger Games dystopian world, its characters, and its breathtaking music with new perspectives and topics that could be brought up to the discussion.

title: Slow Pace. Bad Dialogue. Didn't care about characters
text: This movie genuinely bored me to tears. I love The Hunger Games series so I was pretty excited to see this movie. I was aware that this film was going to be a more dialogue heavy kind of thing but it was just unbearable. The pacing was awful and it just went on for so long. I'm fine with movies on the longer side but not when you're forced to sit there and watch paint dry for 60% of the movie. I also did not care about any of the characters or their well being. I had no reason to feel emotionally attached to any of them. By all means do what you want and check it out but for me it was a huge yawn. I wanted to walk out of the theater but I sat through it all unfortunately.

title: Great
text: As a huge fan of the franchise I thought that this film was very awesome and really true to the novel also I think that it was interesting that the changes they made to the novel not only word but improve the story for the better. Also there are plenty of references to the original films and nice Nas to the future and it is very Cool but lf you never read the original novels or the novel this film is based on you can still enjoy the film and it is it own story and this film is perfect cast I highly recommend this film or the novel. And I the make a sequel or a more prequel or spin-off!!!!!!!!!

title: "The Life Of Coriolanus Snow"/"The Rise And Fall Of Coriolanus Snow"
text: I'm writing this merely because I've watched all the films (didn't touch the books) and I've read so many bad reviews of this film (which I think is completely unfair and not true) and I think I've figured out why that is and I'll try to explain.This movie takes you through the life of Coriolanus Snow. He was tied to the Hunger Games, yes (and that's the only reason they're a part of the movie), he fell in love (that's why it has a bit of that in there as well), the movie has a look into his family/friends/authority relationship, early thought process, mid thought process and his final choice. He had events happen to and around him and choices along the way to make and those made his life go in a particular direction. And I for one think that it was very interesting to see his mind and soul change gradually from one thing to another and to see his reasoning behind it and which actions had impact on it.If you watch this movie as just another part of the Hunger Games series you've already watched, you'll end up giving it a 5 and being bored and disappointed that the "games aren't the whole movie" and that "they're not as "spectacular" and "grand" as they were in other movies", that there's no "never ending, dragged out love story". But neither of those things are the sole point of this movie. The point is Coriolanus Snows' journey and how his decision changes and adapts after certain events and how it ends up being solidified and think most people missed that.This movies' most accurate description/title would be "The Life Of Coriolanus Snow" or even "The Rise And Fall Of Coriolanus Snow" (hence I wrote it in the title) and I think the movie is great, interesting and very well made and I would recommend it as a watch. Some parts could be better, sure, but overall, it's pretty good. Try it :)P. S. Most of people's complaints are that it's "long" and that it's "dragged out" but let's be real, they were just expecting/wanting another movie with 2h long arena fights and they kept waiting and waiting for that to happen and it didn't. If you are one of those, go watch Battle Royal (it's really good if you haven't and want precisely that).

title: Nonsensical!
text:
First, I want to emphasize that I have read the trilogy and watched all the movies.The books, although written, perhaps excessively, in simple language, are easy to read and provide decent entertainment, standing out like a lighthouse amid the vast sea of worthless fiction. On the other hand, the movies based on the trilogy are so powerful and energetic that they have turned Katniss into a symbol.And now, a few words about this movie:
My expectations were, rightly so, enormous-at least 7, maybe even 8 stars. After just half an hour, it became clear to me that this film is simply a waste of time-nothing substantial! Boring, slow, and overacted. Those interested in the series should watch and stick to the movies based on the trilogy, and skip this one. I definitely recommend the books as well (I haven't read this one yet, and probably won't after the movie).

title: Boring exposition, confused plot, flawed characters
text: This film has an interesting look and design. It relly feels like the past of this world where they haven't yet perfected the devious Hunger Games. But sooo much on-the-nose dialogue where characters only talk about the things they've done, in part, makes this a terrible script. And what is the story here, star-crossed lovers or rags-to-riches rise of a fascist dictator? The director doesn't know, so why should we care? Finally, if the plot is the latter, then it's really hard to care about the rise of a evil character. And Lucy Grey isn't that much better because she makes many questionable choices and not the ones she thinks are bad. Skip this film and rewatch the OG, which is almost a flawless script and film.

title: Improvement on the Mockingjay debacle
text: The money making Hunger Games machine continues to rattle along in this impressive prequel set 65 years before Katniss and Peeeeetah mope their way through the original. This is Hunger Games #10, with future President Snow assigned as mentor to a new tribute as some kind of high school graduation Dux program. The winning mentor is awarded a prized scholarship, so young Snow gets immediately to work.The tribute in question is the ludicrously gorgeous Rachel Zegler, a feisty songbird who has ensured a direct path to the Games by upsetting the Mayor's daughter. Of course Snow is utterly besotted, and must make some unpleasant choices along the way; as those familiar with Panem know, the odds are not really in your favour.Along with Zegler, Tom Blyth is a promising newcomer as Snow, but it is the senior brigade of Davis, Dinklage and Schwartzman who dominate proceedings. It isn't really difficult to top the two Mockingjay disappointments, but this is a more than worthy addition to the franchise. 8/10.

title: Better than the original movies
text: I can't believe I'm saying this, but it's actually an improvement upon the original movies. I can say I only read part of the book, not because it wasn't interesting, but due to my own personal attention span with reading in general. However, I did get the impression it was more "adult" and complex than the other book, even though I do enjoy them and appreciate both perspectives. I love a good villain origin story, and unfortunately many are not very believable. With this story, you almost forget that it's a villain origin story, because it offers more than simply that, that it feels it can stand alone well. I never got bored and loved the length of it. One of the best movies I've seen in a long time.

title: sour haters of Rachel or Hunger game fans mad of a remake.
text: The hate of the movie is valid only if the book didn't meet the actual movie, however I haven't seen a movie that actually gave me such suspense to make my heart drop. The acting was flawless, the direction was beautiful and the plot line via movie was so passionate and story telling. The message was strong, I don't want to tell any spoilers or give any details but the movie was like straight up perfect. These people just like to dig in ways to dislike it cause they're salty. It's flawless and poetic one of the best movies I've seen this decade. If not the best, also kudos to writers, they used strategy and love to win the games by mentor and tribute relationship. The truth is in my opinion it was taken better than peta and katniss. Gasp and do whatever but yall just need to cope with that and not hate the fact its true.

title: A must see if you watched the other films!
text: This was in my opinion the best of all of the Hunger Games movies. The lead actors were fantastic and did a great job overall. I read the book when it came out and very rarely have I ever said that the movie is better. In this case the movie was much better. The movie did not lag in parts as the book did. I also found the transition of Snow from being a nice guy to who he becomes later to be much better in the film. This was rushed in the book and much less believable. As for our lead actor, I would take her as the hero over Jennifer Lawrence. Not to say Jennifer Lawrence was bad because she did a great job, I just like this actor much better. Great story, great acting, cinematography was also well done and lastly the addition of the singing was excellent. Go see it!

title: It was good
text: I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. When the whole Hunger games series started I paid little attention, I think I've only watched the first installment in it's entirety, just bits and pieces of the other two but I was interested in seeing how Snow becomes what he is. Strong performances from Tom Blyth and Viola Davis. There is too little Peter Dinklage to have an opinion of his performance. Couple of standouts in other characters whose names I don't recall. The stink bomb that sucks in this movie is Rachel Zegler. Yes she was born with a beautiful singing voice (lucky) but she's not much of an actor. At best she is very paint by numbers with zero nuance or charisma. She pretty enough and can sing but I bet had they looked a little harder, they could have cast someone much, much better. Her acting is just so bland and boring. Overall good movie though...now I have to actually watch the whole series.

title: Leaves you starving for something better
text: Beyond the frankly baffling choice to make a Hunger Games prequel and position it in a time where the Games are already part of the status quo, there is a ton of wasted potential here. My lack of investment in this series can not be understated, but even I was looking forward to seeing Panem built upon - what it actually provides on that front, though, is practically null, and when you remove the context the audience is already familiar with, it completely fails to sketch a decent picture. I haven't kept it a secret that I wasn't particularly enamored with the filmmaking in those original entries, however, the way they crafted their world easily outshines any equivalent effort here. District 12 was a tactile place, where the hardships and inequality could be seen and sensed, especially when contrasted with the Capitol, which felt properly different. In Ballad (not writing that title in full), it wouldn't be remiss to assume these two places aren't fundamentally distinct. Yes, the Capitol is technologically more advanced and has the structure of a sprawling, concrete city, but you don't feel that. The outside world is never emphasized, and as such, apart from the mustache-twirling villainy of the Capitol population, it doesn't distinguish itself from the 'lower' districts. From all that you can gather here, District 12 is comprised of an industrial complex with surrounding plains, and the most we ever see of civilian life in here is a crowd at a bar having a pretty good time. This is very much a problem when you consider how the driving force in much of the characterization is the moral push-and-pull some figures from the Capitol are experiencing. According to some, there are pressing matters of inequality and injustice that need to be addressed; yet we don't see much of what those issues are supposed to entail outside of some troopers being nazis. Those troopers are in the Capitol too, and usually enforce their policies fiercely, even in that environmental - again, no palpable basis of inequality is established.The Hunger Games themselves are also, to quote Gaul here, "dull, dull, dull...". The nonsensical and often arbitrary construction of the Games in the originals always bothered me, but at the very least they made for some engaging scenarios. Here, you have to thank those rebels for messing up the battlefield, or this would've been even more uninteresting than the repetitive forest: you get some stone, some marble, and a bit of debris. Enjoy looking at that for a while. The action does help elicit something visceral out of this bland arena, utilizing some lengthier takes to assist in providing a proper sense of space during the frantic fights - but outside of these specific scenarios this is not eager to do anything of equivalent value with the camera. The sense of space is even lost in the arena itself, where, despite its simple structure, the positions of the tributes are consistently unclear. Do they just disappear, or are they wandering about in a place we've not been shown?I have no clue how well the book is written - and I wouldn't use that knowledge to judge this adaptation, anyway - but this is stuffed to the brim with story beats that come off as bafflingly unmotivated aside from their presence on the preexisting pages, dots to be connected with no need to consider how and why these junctions work (assuming they did in the book). Especially in a character study this is a major issue: if I can't grasp someone's reasoning or motivation, it's hard to understand and connect to them. It felt as if Snow was simply hopping from one side of his moral quarrel to the other, which is a shame, because I take a liking to these gray areas (in particular in this instance because the Capitol is otherwise an utterly one-dimensional antagonistic force).There are some beacons of light to be found, mainly in the practical sets and some of the performances: Davis is delightfully diabolical, Schwartzman consistently hits his comedic marks and Zegler gets plenty of opportunities to use her vocal chords (and if you get second-hand embarrassment during song in a film you're boring, by the way). The whole thing is just entertaining enough - as you might hope from a blockbuster - but not enough to distract from its glaring problems. Ultimately pointless and unsatisfying - in other words, another Hunger Games film.

title: Wonderful plot
text: "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" takes audiences back to the vividly crafted world of Panem, offering a gripping prequel that delves deep into the origins of President Snow. Set against the backdrop of a nation grappling with the aftermath of war, this film brilliantly explores the moral complexities and societal tensions that shaped the ruthless leader we came to know in the original series.Overall, "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" is a thought-provoking and immersive addition to the franchise, offering a deeper understanding of the series' enigmatic antagonist while exploring themes of privilege, morality, and the corrupting nature of power. It's a must-watch for fans eager to uncover the roots of Panem's darkest figure.

title: Awesome depiction of Snow
