text: President Snow is an amazing character in the original trilogy. This movie does an amazing job of describing the events that lead to Snow's character. We get to know why he's so hesitant with trust and careful with emotion.What needs a special mention is the sound design of this piece. I got to see it will Dolby Atmos and I must say, the subtle usage of music that is undisturbing yet powerful really proves that the sound is even more important than the visuals. I don't mean to disgrace the visuals and cinematography. The iconic Hunger games camera shake and cold-corrected color is not present in this movie, and to be honest, I'm quite glad. It is a great movie, story and cinematographically-wise.Every fan of Hunger games is basically obligated to watch it.

title: Slow, long, and stupid
text: A musical Hunger Games? Viola Davis is embarrassed by this one. She should remove her name from the credits. If this aligns to the book, then it is written to cash in on a previous innovative story. Now it's full of its own cliche's and makes one think the original story didn't age well. Maybe it could have been better with real headliner actors as the main characters vs supporting roles. Peter Dinkledge proved he couldn't carry this one despite him being the only interesting character. They should try this one again because it is either too serious or too dramatic. There are no heroes and the singing is a distraction despite being good music. It just isn't appropriate to the story.

title: Better than anticipated
text: For once in my life, I did not have a movie ruin the book. Granted I never finished reading the book. I started reading it when it first came out. However, I really enjoyed the movie. Tom Blyth, someone I was unfamiliar with, filled the part of Snow. Interesting to see the backstory of someone I despised from the original series. Rachel Zegler has a fantastic strong voice. Her in/out accent was one beef I had with the movie. If you know someone from the South, which I know many, you know what it should sound like. Would prefer Hollywood just skip it rather than hearing it come and go.Viola Davis as a villain-awesome.Great movie and would love for there to be another along this story arc to go with the Hunger Games.

title: Entertainment power pack
text: If you have read the hunger games, I highly recommend watching this dystopian themed movie exploring the genres of love/hate, government dictatorship and adventure. This masterpiece of a book has been made into the most spectacular movie ( in my opinion ) ever made. The characters, all perfectly cast and played amazingly and exactly how I imagined them to look like, every single one. The first one sets the background for the franchise of the hunger games movies and does it extremely well. District 12 and the Capitol were completely well made. Especially if you compare the two, the Capitol so bright, lively and modern while district 12 is so run down and old.I absolutely love the Capitol citizens outfits! Truly astonishing and exactly how I imagined capitol fashion to look like when described in the books ( bright and colourful )As the film progresses, the main character Katniss Everdeen's - played by Jennifer Lawrence - confidence grows, in her defiance towards the Capitol and her hatred starts brewing, we get to watch that anger grow in strength until the last movie when she kindles that anger. I promise you, once you watch this movie that has you on the edge of your seat the entire time, you will want to watch them all.

title: Not Great
text: It's hard not to compare this to the original but when I do it falls flat .I don't think Jennifer Laurence will be crying with jealousy .First off the singing .What was that all about ?It was totally unnecessary and very annoying .Speaking of annoying Rachael Zegler is very unlikable in this role .The singing and prancing around at the start of the film put me off.The story is very much all over the place and we're never sure what we are supposed to concentrating on.If you watch to see a hunger games movie you will be very disappointed.The ending makes no sense at all.I was very confused.The Snow character totally changes his personality for the final act .I was really looking forward to this movie and I was totally let down .I won't be rushing to watch the follow up .It could have been a masterpiece but what we got was a mess.I see people giving it a 10 or 9 on here which also worries me .There was a time when IMBD was the Bible of reviews .

title: Surprisingly good prequel
text: First of all: I'm not a big fan of the Hollywood legacy of milking franchises that is going on for at least 20 years now. I went to this movie without high expectations, but it suprised me. Strong leads without a big name, and especially good character development by the antagonist. A bit slow close to the end, but without losing quality. The movie has a bit of a George Orwell feel to it, with elements of gems like Equilibrium. The small nudges towards the original movies, especially in district 12 are fan pleasers and add to the story in their own way. Truely enjoyed it.Recommend watching, even for those new to the story.

title: This should have been better
text: "The Mockingjay" book has been adapted into 2 movies for no good reason and it went terrible. The producers learned a hard lesson, but now it seems like it was even too hard for them, cause "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" feels like it has adapted two books into one movie, even thought it didn't.This movie has some serious timing problems. It's definitely too long, but at the same time manages to make you feel like the second part of it is too short and should be extended. I feel like it should be separated into two movies. One about the 10th Hunger Games and the rise of Snow (this doesn't really need much more, that the first hour and a half of this movie) and another one about how he turned from an ambitious boy in love to a overambitious manipulator and tyrant (this one definitely needs more time and depth).The most frustrating thing about the new Hunger Games movie is that literally every element of it is interesting, but still none of them is really well done and fulfills its potential. The main character is interesting, writers try to make him deep, they almost succed, but then they don't have enough time to finish the job, cause the movie cannot be even longer than it actually is.In the end, I feel so much wasted potential that it makes me angry, even thought I'm not really emotionally invested in the franchise.

title: Amazing film
text:
I loved it,I think it is on par with the original Hunger Games trilogy.Initially, I was not very interested in the fact that the protagonist was Coriolanus Snow, since he was the despot and cruel President of Panem who made Katniss and Peeta and in general everyone suffer. I didn't see it possible for me to like a book about Snow in her youth, so I didn't really expect much from this book, but as it progressed, the story completely captivated me, I couldn't stop reading, everything seemed exciting and very interesting and I was very curious to know how everything was going to be resolved.It's quite strange and I must say that I was surprised by the fact that I empathized and became attached to Snow, that is, from the original trilogy we know that he became a bad person, but in this book, despite the fact that the author respected the character and did not He victimized him but showed us that duality and that questionable morality, even so you come to love him. Although it is true that Snow had a very difficult childhood and youth, full of shortcomings, that does not justify his actions, he really trusted the Capitol, he liked belonging to that society and in fact he wanted to obtain the power to control it. He was a calculator, he did everything in order to achieve his goals, in short Coriolanus Snow does not do a stitch without a thimble. However, despite all this I wanted things to go well for him, it made me happy when he achieved his goals and it made me sad when something went wrong for him.In the case of Lucy Gray, I really couldn't connect with her, I understand that acting and manipulating others was her game to be able to survive in that cruel world, but I wasn't moved or interested in what she thought or felt. In the end I didn't care what happened to him.Sejanus was a quite contradictory character, at the beginning he seemed too perfect to me and
good to be real, then he started taking some dark dyes and he no longer knew what to think with
Regarding him, he could only believe that it would end very badly.I loved Tigris, the grandmother, Ma, the classmates at the academy, even the agents
of peace, each of these characters was complex, they had their hard part but also the
emotional and sentimental. On the other hand, those of the flock did not inspire me at all, I think they do not know
developed enough to get to know them.And the ending left me speechless, I really didn't expect that or not at all, some things
were quite predictable, however I would have liked to know more about how things
They ended like that, everything happened very quickly and I was left with several doubts.

title: Hungry Games: The Awkward Karaoke Night of Hunger Lames
text: Ah, 'The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes,' a rollercoaster that's more like a kiddie ride at a local fair. Buckle up, folks - we're in for a lukewarm journey.Coriolanus Snow's transformation is like watching a caterpillar attempt ballet - ambitious but fundamentally awkward. Tom Blyth and Viola Davis give stellar performances, though it feels a bit like winning an Oscar for a school play. And that brief love story? It's the spice equivalent of saltine crackers - a bit bland.Now, the characters. Picture a group of friends you wouldn't invite to your birthday party. That's them. More background and growth? Apparently, that's too much to ask. The pacing is so off; I thought I accidentally switched to 'Hunger Games: The Slow Motion Edition.' Trim it? More like perform a cinematic exorcism.Rachel Zegler's acting is stiffer than a frozen baguette, and the singing scenes? It's like they handed out microphones at a karaoke night for tone-deaf cats. The connection to the original Hunger Games series is shakier than my Wi-Fi during a storm.'The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes' has its moments, like finding a semi-interesting receipt in your wallet - mildly intriguing, but hardly a jackpot. If they iron out these wrinkles, maybe the next chapters will be less like a kiddie ride and more like a rollercoaster with actual loops. Fingers crossed for an upgrade, but hey, miracles happen, right?

title: It is a no stat movie
text: Over acting done specially by. Rachel. It just did £300million in box office just of its name. I don't know how people can write a good review of this kind of movie. I was feeling so sleeping that I have to switch it off. And will never watch again even in my dreams.Like it's not action nor adventure nor comedy nor horror nor drama.Just peace of overacting by everyone. One movie goes good directors get over rated. Actors get over rated. And this movie show how over rated it is.Can't believe I could hardly watch first half have to just leave when she started to sing in between snakes. And other side group started shouting get her out. Such a pathetic and unnecessary seen.

title: Great movie!
text: I saw a lot of negative comments about this movie that I don't quite seem to understand. This was so much so that I had to write a review when I never have before. I saw a comment about the plot having too much context for one movie. I could see that being an issue and I would have been fine with it being a movie with 2 parts. I was so happy to see the Hunger Games franchise back and loved all the information about Panem and how the games began. Someone said they didn't connect with any of the characters. I don't think you're really supposed to as this is about the villain in the main trilogy. I love when there's a movie that explains a character and why they are the way they are. I love his character...I don't love him. I felt it was a lot more grownup than the other movies. The Hunger Games was in it's beginning stages so it wasn't as big and drawn out as the normal series. I also saw a comment saying the main character was dressed weirdly for the time period. She stated that it was her mothers dress and she wore it to feel close to her (this could've been easily made but probably took a lot of time and was probably made for a special occasion). Also, a lot of comments about the amount of singing even though she was referred to as a songbird throughout the movie. I think her singing is what drew people to her. It wasn't boring at all. I think some people just have small attention spans. I'm going to see it a second time. I loved Hunger Games as a tween and I love this as a 26 year old. The extended context and information on the series and the development of the character was great. I feel like franchises need to take notes from Suzanne Collins on how to do a good job with extending a franchise.

title: One of nyc movie.
text: You have read the hunger games, I highly recommend watching this dystopian themed movie exploring the genres of love/hate, government dictatorship and adventure. This masterpiece of a book has been made into the most spectacular movie ( in my opinion ) ever made. The characters, all perfectly cast and played amazingly and exactly how I imagined them to look like, every single one. The first one sets the background for the franchise of the hunger games movies and does it extremely well. District 12 and the Capitol were completely well made. Especially if you compare the two, the Capitol so bright, lively and modern while district 12 is so run down and old.I absolutely love the Capitol citizens outfits! Truly astonishing and exactly how I imagined capitol fashion to look like when described in the books ( bright and colourfu.

title: Honest Review from Moderate HG fan
text: Hello. I hardly ever write reviews but thought this needed one. I am a moderate fan of the original movies and never read the books. I enjoyed the first 2 movies quite a bit. The last 2 were not great with the fourth being awful.I really enjoyed this one. I would put it right behind the second one as my favorites.ProsSnow was awesome. I thought the acting was superb. This guy is going to do some great things in Hollywood. The writing for his character was top notch. Lots of things to uncover on why he became what he did. Story lines that seemed "left out" seemed intentional to show what not knowing everything can do to a person. He clearly carried the movie.Other really good performances. I forget names. Snows best friend. The Game of Thones guy, the host of the games and the game master.I really liked the retro vibe of the settings mixed with all the nature. CGI was apparent but not overwhelming.Cons or so so stuffLucy. I'm 50 50 on her. I liked the storyline but her acting was good in some areas but strange in others. A little overactedThe singing. I've read a bunch of reviews and don't understand the vitriol in the negative reviews. I didn't think the singing was too much. It was part of her character and her background. What made it so so was the facial expressions during the singing parts. See previous comment on her acting. The facial expressions and what not were wayyyy over acted or dramatic even during the slower more chilling songs.There were a couple of things in act 3 towards the end that I didn't understand which at first I was like WTF is this but after thinking more about it. I think it was part of what could drive Snow bonkers to begin with.Overall 8 of 10. I would watch another one on continuing Snows character. It's worth seeing in the theater but I wouldn't feel that I missed a visual spectacle if I had just seen it at home.Thanks for reading.

title: Badly paced, some interesting pieces.
text: I haven't read the books, liked Hunger games 1 and 2. Disliked 3a and 3b.My main complaint with the movie is the second part. It is way too long. The outcome was clear, the characters were not worked out and didn't catch my compassion. I just wanted just to skip forward the part III after 2 minutes. Part 3 was interesting, but felt rushed.I totally disliked Lucy Gray. She was an heroic singing gipsy and as such, a complete cliche. She came over as an game NPC with preprogrammed texts. Snow was more interesting, because he had conflicting motives. However, he didn't have the script or time to fully make use of them. The relationship between them seemed forced. The music was nice, but it was too present like ' Hey, remember what we're singing! Don't you forget it!'.Some good parts: I liked the visuals. The theme seemed for me 1950's Russia, and even though I wondered how they could forget lcd-screens and went back to tube-tv's, it was actually nice.I'm kind of in between 5 and 6 stars.

title: Everyone Hungers for Something.
text: I am genuinely surprised with how much I loved this film. I adored the characters, the story, the songs and so much more. The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes displayed the importance of the opportunities given and the choices we make, shape the world around us and who we become. Francis Lawerence provided a fantastic sequel based off Snow giving more depth to the future president of Panem. The cast was by far the most infectious part of the film, with everyone providing great performances, especially from our leads Tom Blyth, Rachel Zegler and Viola Davis. Tom Blyth (Coriolanus Snow) had such a powerful performance here and must say I'm excited to see where his career goes from here. Rachel Zegler (Lucy Gray Baird) sang her heart out in this roll and will say I absolutely adored her character, and the songs she sang were perfect. James Howard Newton wrote and composed a great score for this film setting the tone for every scene perfectly.Overall was very pleased with this film and easily landed as one of the best in the Hunger Games franchise.

title: What a disappointment
text: Inconsistent acting varying from melodramatic to good to inadequate.Soundtrack inconsistent varying from excellent to pathetic including ruining an excellent son (hanging tree).Story very contrived and didn't make sense in some places.The capital scenes did not meet expectations and seemed very budget dependent. The lack of technology seemed to be a film budget dependent. It was a cheap film not worthy of the Hunger Games universe.Over use of "trust me" all throughout and really very inappropriate.I am grateful that I saw this for free. I would have felt cheated if I had either bought the DVD or seen it in the theater.If this was an attempt at a reboot then it did not make sense. The backstory was very flimsy.Save time. Avoid the film.

title: A very interesting backstory of the 'villian'
text: More than 10 years ago, I sat on my comfy Ikea couch, toes digging into the furniture with anticipation. Drinks read, phone off, room dark. After listening to the iconic Metro Goldwyn mayer soundtrack, I spend the next 2 hours watching "The Hunger Games".To me, the film was fascinating. Of course, I had read the books and read all about Peeta and Katniss, two teenagers navigating their way through a district sown with distrust, poverty, and dictatorship. They lived in a gruesome reality where the future hopes of children could be easily extinguished- god forbid their name would be called out at the annual reaping.Yet, while fascinated with how a movie studio had transformed written text into a cinematic reality, I found there to be gaps. There were breadcrumbs as to why a system was in place, and why President Snow cut such a cruel figure as the leader of a system which distributed wealth unfairly and held too-tight to their warped ideal of governance over those they had defeated in a past war.Snow the man could not be seen in the original Hunger Games trilogy. I could liken him to a chess player; a man undisturbed by emotion and instead roused by both logic and a disturbing allegiance to convention.But just as every good person can become bad, every good person can become bad, in very general terms. In "A Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes", it was fascinating to see how the cruelties of both life and human nature force people to make decisions that change who they are innately. I believe this affects all characters, from Coriolanus Snow to Casca Highbottom.To those who haven't watched "A Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes", I implore you to if you are the type to enjoy both action and psychology. And I implore you if you are fascinated with the idea of the system being a propellant in human downfall- that our actions are not only attributed to us, but to our environments.In terms of casting, I believe every character was chosen well. The actor who played Coriolanus, Tom Blyth, was masterful in his use of facial expressions and body language. Rachel Zegler, who played Lucy Grey Bird, was talented vocally, in both singing so passionately and taking on a twangy Southern accent.I also really appreciate the lighting of the film. I feel like the film industry has collectively agreed, behind our backs, to stick to depressing grey lighting comparable to that of Tim Burton. However, this film used both warm and cool tones, and different levels of brightness. For merrier scenes, there were warmer, brighter colors that strengthened this happy feeling, and vice versa. The amplitude of the emotional high and lows was increased. And I think this is how a film should be made, if audiences are to be engaged.The different location were also well constructed. I liked how some structure of this film felt 'antique' compared to the modernity of "The Hunger Games" trilogy, but also that some structures in the capitol were in much better condition compared to the time Katniss inhabited. To me, this illustrated the ways in which we can be influenced by glamour and glory to feel attached to our reality, when in fact, this reality might not be sustainable.Kudos to all the people behind this movie.Nice.

title: Breathtaking
text: The Easter eggs, the songs, the storyline.. everything exceed my expectations. Truly one of the best movies I've seen in a long time. It is truly accurate to the book and it makes you have conflicting feelings about the main character, as he is known as the villain in the main series but the main character in the movie. It is outstanding how they managed to portray Snow's origin story, first feeling sympathy for him but slowly recognising the character shown in the original franchise. I must commend them for all the Easter eggs and references to the original franchise, it truly elevated the level of detailing and subtext the franchise is known for.

title: Unexpected greatness because of the songs ...
text: I went and saw this on a lark, not really being a fan of the Hunger Games films. But I knew it is a "prequel" and I figured I didn't need to be super familiar with the other films' plots. Correct on that. The big surprise was how music was worked into the plot with the singing of the main character, played by Rachel Zegler (of the newer West Side Story). Her songs, and other incidental songs in the film, are often in a modern bluegrass/roots music style. They sound excellent in the film and really draw you into a story I otherwise would have found predictable for a dystopian/sci-fi aimed at a youth audience. I stuck around for the credits. The on-screen performed music is all performed by the great Dave Cobb. Also additional incidental tracks are by Sierra Ferrell, Olivia Rodrigo, and others. The film music is great and really makes for a cool theatre experience with the images and sound. And it's always great to see Hunter Schafer's star rise further. I'd see it again, just for the music. Really well done! 👍

title: Weak. Very weak.
text: Quite a departure from the other episodes. So much so it detracted from the essence of the series. The musical overtone, the lack of a deep script, and inconsistent acting, pretty much made this a train wreck compared to the other ones. The concept was good, and this movie could have been great with casting the right leads, someone who is likable. There weren't any likeable characters. No one the audience can connect to. That was another big failure in this movie. Put that together with a rushed script with no flow and the best is 5 out of 10. And the shift in Snow's character from the beginning to the middle to the end was not played well, fragmented, and definitely not believable. And I think they must have said Lucy Gray a thousand times. We get it, we know her name.

title: AMAZING
text: Went to the cinema to watch this with my sister and it was one of the best movies I have seen for a long time. I didn't really know what to expect with this one as it was before the hunger games had started and I wasn't sure if it would work but it was well made and they linked it up really well to the other films. I've watched all of the hunger games and this is definitely up there with the best of them!! Highly recommend this to anyone.All the actors were great and it was a really interesting storyline. There were so many twists and turns and it was interesting to see how snow's character changed throughout, we didn't know what was going to happen next!

title: Welcome to boring and confused
text: We left the theater after fighting to stay awake and make sense of this movie. Really hard to follow and get excited about anything. Can I get a refund????I don't know who the REAL target audience was, but if you watched the original series of movies that were good, this one just made no sense. The depiction of a future higher class society is was annoying and ridiculous.The main actors did well and that is the only reason we stay as long as we did, but the story line and everything else was just off the charts bad. I wish Jennifer Lawrence would have been cast somehow, she really made the other movies great.

title: Don't waste your time watching it
text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" fails to ignite any spark of excitement. With a sluggish plot and uninspired performances, it pales in comparison to its predecessors. The actors deliver wooden performances, failing to evoke any emotional connection with the audience. The film's attempt at social commentary falls flat, relying instead on shallow action sequences and gratuitous violence. Visually, it lacks the grandeur and imagination of the original trilogy, feeling like a cheap imitation. Overall, it's a forgettable addition to the franchise, leaving fans longing for the depth and intensity of the earlier films.

title: Very nice movie, must watch
text:
I saw this movie today. I Recommend to watch this movie, I have not been able to stop thinking about it since... I read the original trilogy but never got around to reading the prequel but decided to just see the movie. Rachel Zegler receives hate because of a comment she made about a completely different movie (Snow White), and it's completely irrelevant to this movie. She performed more than beautifully in this role. She is a classically trained soprano, and was singing beautifully in her chest voice and with a really good twangy accent (which is more of a mezzo/alto type of singing in this case). From one classically-trained singer with a degree in music who performs for a living to everyone out there afraid to give this movie a chance because of all of this biases against this young woman- SHE IS GOOD! This girl is talented, and the hate is stupid.This movie was by no means perfect, but it was really good. I would have thought it was a perfect 10 if the action was better paced. It was nothing on her part. Definitely not as good as Catching Fire (the peak of the series to me), but better than both of the Mockingjays! Give it a shot without a bias of this young women in your mind and you just might find yourself enjoying it ;)
56 out of 94 found this helpful.

title: The storyline had such potential
text: The Hunger Games: Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes had the potential to be an epic movie, consistent with the previous four. Unfortunately, it was a tedious waste of time and money.Where to start: the torturous length (138 minutes)? The mediocre acting? The distinct lack of chemistry? The disjointed storyline? The underwhelming casting? The ho-hum script, with none of the witticisms that characterised the previous movies? The rushed, unsatisfactory ending? Rachel Zegler's inconsistent Southern accent, facial distortions/tics, and choice to portray Lucy Gray more like a jaded, 40-year-old bartender than a 16/17-year-old, poverty-stricken traveller?The opening scene was powerful, and held such promise, only to be followed by a rapid decline into banality, relieved only when the credits started to roll and the lights came up.It must be acknowledged, however, that Rachel Zegler has well-trained vocals.

title: A fine adaptation of an emotionally challenging book
text: I'm reading so many reviews of how this was boring or unnecessary. No this isn't as satisfying as the hunger games. It is a prequel about the origins of President Snow. I've read the book. I could not picture how someone could portray young Snow in the film. Tom Blyth did a shockingly great job. His portrayal was urgent and nuanced in all the right ways. So beyond what I expected. I doubt he will be nominated for this but he should. Looking forward to more of him in the future. Josh Rivera who portrayed Sejanus was incredibly moving. Rachel Zegler did justice to Lucy Gray also. I maybe would have wanted a bit more sinister and less campy Dr Gaul by viola Davis but she was still wonderful. Dinklage and Schafer too. I just felt everyone involved really worked hard to tell a tense, difficult and heartbreaking tale of the Hunger Games origins. I hope you watch and take it in for what it accomplished and not what it didn't quite get right. The book is great too. Suzanne Collins is brilliant. Well done by all.

title: Looks good but a it's an illogical disappointment
text: Let's start with the good. The kid that played Snow was ok. The movie looked quite good and, I suppose that it was quite interesting to to see the birth of the antagonist and development of the Hunger Games.Now the bad. Viola Davis was ridiculous. Why was Rachel Ziegler singing all the time? This isn't West Side Story.The ending was particularly unfulfilling. How did Snow finally achieve his power? Don't know.What happened to Lucy Grey? Don't know.Why did everyone call her by her full name all the time? Lucy Grey, Lucy Grey.....Don't know.Why not have a movie about the civil war and the first Hunger Games? Don't know.Like I said, a disappointment.

title: Impressed and Delighted
text: The narrative is intense, the characters are well-developed, and the social commentary adds depth to the story. It's a compelling blend of action and emotion that keeps readers on the edge of their seats, making it a must-see for fans of dystopian fiction and especially of Hunger Games series ! All characters Coriolanus Snow and Lucy Gray , Sejanus Plinth , Tigris Snow, Casca 'Cas' Highbottom deliver strong performances and I got enough of their history of origin and the film's visually striking depiction of a seemingly perfect world raises profound questions about the cost of utopia. I was impressed!

title: Snakes and Songbirds
text: I read the book in January after they announced the supporting cast for the movie. I finished it in 3 days, and have waited until now for it, and the wait was worth it. Rachel Zegler's performance, dramatically and vocally, was breathtaking. Tom Blyth served Donald Sutherland's original performance justice, and Viola Davis was just incredible.The plot itself followed the book in almost every way, except for a few, but the changes made added more momentum to the moving story.Highly recommend viewing this film in IMAX as I did because it fits quite well with it (but note it will be VERY LOUD.)To sum things up, incredible movie, incredible performance, walked out with many lingering curiosities, but also many questions and connections to the original trilogy answered.

title: Way better than it had any right to be
text: Way better than it had any right to be - I mean it is the prequel film to a long running YA franchise.Tense, atmospheric and brutal - keeps you hooked, especially for the first two parts. The more primitive version of the hunger games is staged brilliantly and you expertly get to see how the games became the spectacle they will eventually morph into.The third part has pacing issues and feels rushed and laggy simultaneously but the exploration into Snow's psyche makes up for that and the film really nails the ending.Overall a way more nuanced and dark YA film than we are used to with a standout performance by Tom Blyth.PS - A nod to the sombre, fitting score by James Newton Howard who keeps on hitting it out of the park.

title: Better than the original hunger games
text: I don't particularly like the original hunger games movies nor the books. I hate Peeta and the awkward romance. Katniss in the first movie&book is great, and the set up of the second games is astonishingly interesting. The third book/movies are terrible except from conversation with Snow, and Coin at the end. I don't understand how people can give this movie 1-3 stars and like the mockingjay movies.That being said, I absolutely loved the book of the Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes. It explores philosophical and moral dilemmas and worldviews, different characters representing different ideals. It barely has any romance, which I appreciate. And we get a deep dive into the villain's psyche and inner dialogue. We do not get to see this in the movie, which is a shame, but I still think it is a great adaption. It distills the essence of the book without leaving essential stuff. I would however recommend both reading the book and watching the movie, for the best experience.I was thoroughly invested through both part 1 and part 2. People who complain about this round of hunger games being boring, seem to miss the point about this being the first ever hunger game where anything actually happens. I still found it exciting. I disliked the whole of part 3 in the book, and most of it in the movie. It's just slow and frustrating. The singing sounded out of place until this part. The movie did however finish really strong, fully landing the concept, establishing Snow as a villain, showing that his good side succumbed.9/10 because I thoroughly loved the parts I didn't dislike. 7/10 if I were to be objective, because it is a solid movie.

title: A masterpiece
text: Whether you're a Hunger Games fan or you just want to get started in the Panem universe, which you can do by watching this prequel (chronologically, the first part of the story), this is a masterpiece in line with the quality of the original movies and books. Let's say they had it easy plotwise, as the writer really took her time to write another book after finishing the original trilogy and created a very special prequel to lead up to the events that the fans know. If you know who the main character is from the beginning, this is such a special journey to find out what events made him the person he is in the original trilogy (or the original 4 movies). The characters are well written, the actors make them come to life and give them a (singing) voice with mastery, the movie is both packed with emotional and intense moments. Everything is very cleverly portrayed, in a dynamic and faithful way which may not have been possible without the work of the author as this film's executive producer.I'm a big Hunger Games fan and my expectations were very high, and they were not only met, but exceeded.

title: Snow Always Lands on Top
text: Being old (bordering on decrepit) and never having been a huge fan of teen drama, even when I was a teen myself (in the 18th century), I get the nagging feeling that "The Hunger Games: The Ballad etc." was not exactly meant for me. Mind you, I love post-apocalyptic dystopian fare like any other regular chap, so I thought I'd give this film a go. But well, this is the kind of post-apo yarn where folks are always impeccably dressed with perfect hairdos and teeth, because hey, you may live in a soul-crushing totalitarian society and still care about your physique, right? This made me think of "Logan's Run" (yes, I'm old), which is a compliment I guess... kind of.I particularly enjoyed each time we see Mr. Hottie show off his impeccable torso and abs (5 times in about 2 hours and 30mn, it must have been in his contract). At that point I also decided to mindlessly enjoy the ineffable Peter Dinklage (not his torso and abs though). I felt some schadenfreude at seeing him go through the motions of a Song of Ice and F..., er, a Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes, heartily quaffing wine while philosophizing about the Snow family. Good old times... Speaking of which, what kind of name is Coriolanus Snow?? Ah well, rather than try to make sense of the Shakespearean ref I heartily enjoyed all the wordplays and witty metaphors based on snow ("Snow always lands on top"). Finally the subtle Christian imagery (he gets bitten by a snake, get it???) revealed this flick to be a deep meditation on good and evil in this fallen world of ours, human nature, and white teeth. Especially white teeth.

title: I absolutely loved this movie
text: Excellent movie, I cannot wait to see what will come afterwards. It's true what they say about it being all the things we love that destroy us most, in the end! I certainly wasn't expecting all of the plots and twists and turns in this one, a few parts even made me jump, but mostly its a voice i've never heard that made me even more excited for the next one! If you haven't seen it yet i suggest doing so, it's great! Definitely a sequence of movies that you had to have watched to be able to understand, but worth watching to understand it even more! Suggestions needed, popcorn a great friend, and lots of smiles!

title: not as good as the book, just as good as the hunger games though.
text: The book is a masterpiece of a complex story, the film is a simplified version of it. The book had a lot of great charector (maybe too much), So the movie removed some great charectors (Sejanus mom and dad beanpole, smiley, the covey.) They werent realy removed they were background charectors. Removed some scenes, (the covey) etc.Honestly the film is a 8.5. But my love of the book makes it biased. Movie is to short to be 2 movies, but too long to be one movie. A bit rushed, editing a bit wierd, story might confuse you, read the book first. Sejanus wasn't that great as a charector, not as good as sejanus in the book. GREAT ACTING and GREAT STORY.Read the book. Watch the movie.

title: So good!!!!! 10/10 must watch!!!!
text: I absolutely loved this movie. It really portrayed the characters as you would imagine in the book. And it doesn't stray to far from the plot of the book either. The actors who played in this movie did a fantastic job. Tom Blyth did an amazing job as playing Snow. I loved everyone of their characters. I would 100% recommend this movie whether you have read the books or not. I read the book a while back and when I watched the movie and all the memories came back to me about so many parts of the book. They did a great job of showing what the book was about. If you haven't read or watched this movie, please do. Thank you.

title: I thought cultural appropriation was bad...
text: I thought cultural appropriation was bad according to w.o.k.e. Culture? Isn't it what they have been saying for the past ten years? Cultural appropriation is bad; if you do it, you are nothing but a bad person, a bigot, and a racist?Yet, here in this movie, one of our protagonists Lucy Grey sings country songs in rhythm and blues voice even though she is from New Jersey, and the daughter of a father of Polish descent and a mother of Colombian descent. I believe that is the definition of cultural appropriation, am I wrong?Despite an interesting premise, the execution of that premise is amazingly poor. Apart from Zegler and her fake and inadequate accent, the acting in the movie is what makes you continue watching - if you have not stopped already after the one-hour mark. Peter Dinklage and Viola Davis do the most of the heavy lifting, but their characters are not in the center of the plot. Therefore, there is little that they can do to save the film.And the singing is the worst part of the film. Each time they start singing, it is just cringe and embarrassing.

title: Better than the original trilogy
text: This movie does no doubt embody the spirit of the original Hunger Games better than the movies did.This is not a teen movie. It is what the Hunger Games movies would have been if they weren't more focused on making money rather than keeping the spirit of the books.Watching the characters evolve in the prequel and slowly become what they will be in the movie is fantastic. And the message it sends about society, control and capitalism resonates with the way the world aroun us is and how rotten a couple people in power are.I feel with this movie the saga grew, just like the viewers did since the first movie came out.

title: EXCELLENT MOVIE
text: "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds" continues the saga of Panem with a compelling narrative that explores the origins of the Hunger Games and the complexities of power, rebellion, and sacrifice. Directed by visionary filmmaker, Sarah Director, the film successfully combines action, emotion, and political intrigue, making it a worthy addition to the franchise. Jennifer Lawrence reprises her iconic role as Katniss Everdeen, and her performance is as captivating as ever. Lawrence effortlessly portrays Katniss's evolution from a reluctant tribute to a symbol of rebellion. The emotional depth she brings to the character adds a poignant layer to the film. The supporting cast, including Josh Hutcherson as Peeta Mellark and Liam Hemsworth as Gale Hawthorne, provides strong performances that anchor the story. Newcomers to the franchise, such as rising star Isabella Archer in the role of young Coriolanus Snow, bring a fresh perspective and complexity to their characters. The film's cinematography, led by acclaimed cinematographer James Wells, captures the stark contrast between the opulence of the Capitol and the harsh realities of the districts. The visual style remains consistent with the established aesthetic of the Hunger Games universe while introducing new elements that enhance the storytelling.

title: One good scene, that's about all this movie has to offer
text: I'm just going to be direct. This was for 80% of the movie, not so good. Borderline boring i'd even say. The ONLY somewhat exciting part was the Hunger Games scenes where they fought each other and that's about it. Also, I feel like halfway in through the movie, they didn't quite know what to do with Snow's character and near the end realizing... "Wait... This guy is supposed to be evil! Let's turn him heel in the last 20 minutes after 2+ hours of seeing him as a bad guy."Honestly it was so stupid. They should've just stopped at the end of the main Hunger Games franchise and called it a day. Why they decided to capitalize off of that franchise with whatever this was, is a disgrace. Therefore, this for me is a below average Hunger Games movie.

title: A Fascinating and Thought Provoking Story!
text: This film is a remarkable adaptation of another in the Hunger Games series. Somehow you are drawn into seeing the story from Snow's perspective which allows for all sorts of interesting and unique opportunities that would not be possible with a focus on the districts like in the other films. We get to see the dawn of the Hunger Games and see what they were before the spectacle they grow to be 65 years later. The cast is absolutely impeccable and you are sucked in by the work of each of these actors bringing the multifaceted characters to life. There are also a tragic aspect for some characters, as we can see some regret for the monster of an idea that they have unleashed on the word. This film works emotionally and has you on the edge of your seats, even if you know the story!

title: why so many songs
text: The extended duration of the movie tested my patience and i was quite bored few times. The characters, especially the female protagonist, lacked depth. The musical-like vibe, despite not being a musical, felt out of place, with an excess of songs. I read one review about excessive songs, and halfway through the movie, there were three, and I thought that the reviewer was exaggerating. But I kid you not, she sang at least 13 other songs in the other half. In the final scenes, the acting of the male protagonist was quite interesting, but I didn't understand the sudden change; there was no buildup.

title: i don't care what y'all say
text: This movie was wonderful, alright. Little Lucy Gray stole the show. Snow was evil and i hated him at the end, like i should've. The portrayals by the actors and actresses were perfect, Rachel Zegler was my favorite. Viola Davis was fascinating. Whoever played Snow, played perfectly. Peter Dinklage was Peter Dinklage, which is really, really cool. A lot of people say the last act was rushed, but i don't care. I liked it. I liked every bit of this movie. I really loved Lucy Gray's songs. A lot of people are gonna say that they were too frequent, but believe, i am not one of those people. I think she should've sang more than she did.

title: Gives no insight into Snow
text: I enjoyed the original Hunger Games movies and especially since I thought President Snow was one of the most interesting characters. I didn't read any of the books, so I didn't compare the movies to them. But I hope that the book this movie is based on was better than what was presented. My major beef is that the characterization of Snow gave us zero insight into what made him what he was in the future. The acting is good, but the characters are mostly unlikeable. Things are just thrown in without any thought to cohesiveness. Yes, the actress who plays Lucy Gray can sing and the atmosphere was definitely reflective of the capital and the districts, but for the most part the story and Snow were hollow. Just average to bad entertainment.

title: Incredibly faithful to the novel, gets too much hate
text: Don't listen to the bad reviews! Watch the movie and judge for yourself.This was a surprisingly well done movie. The acting and CGI were quite good despite what some say. While I have some problems with the plot (such as the rushed and ambiguous ending), that can be traced back to the book that Collins wrote because this film was actually incredibly faithful to its novel counterpart.All of the casting choices were perfect and each actor played their character to (at least near) perfection. I would have a hard time naming a better person to play Coriolanus or Lucy Gray. But the casting for Dr. Gaul is what made my jaw drop. She's actually the most interesting character in both the book and the movie, and Viola Davis' creepy portrayal of her was absolutely top notch.This film definitely gets too much hate. It was absolutely very well done. For those who complain that it isn't like the original Hunger Games, it isn't supposed to be. This is a masterfully created prequel meant to set the pieces of the original story in place.

title: awesome movies nice characters mind blowing
text: My wife and I watched The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes (2023) in theaters last night. The hunger games are struggling to maintain viewer interest so they decide to undergo rule changes, challenging mentors to guide their tributes to success.My wife and I watched The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes (2023) in theaters last night. The hunger games are struggling to maintain viewer interest so they decide to undergo rule changes, challenging mentors to guide their tributes to success.My wife and I watched The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes (2023) in theaters last night. The hunger games are struggling to maintain viewer interest so they decide to undergo rule changes, challenging mentors to guide their tributes to success.

title: Confusing
text: I am a HUGE fan of The Hunger Games but this one is extremely confusing. Is this a Snow origin villain story? Does this explore how the games began? Or is it about something else? .. Well, it's unclear till the end and after.Hated how they made this into a musical and how the film didn't delve as deeply into Coryo's close bond with his mom as the book did. In the book, Ma Plinth is portrayed as a sweet and nurturing mother figure who practically adopts him into the family, providing him with food and support. Her role makes Coryo's betrayal of Sejanus and his eventual demise even more heartbreaking.Yes, there is something that I liked; decent/promising casting.

title: I'm not a Hunger Games fan, but this was bad and just uncomfortable to watch.
text: I'm not a Hunger Games fan, but this installment fell short for me, earning only two stars. As a newcomer to The Hunger Games movies, I found this prequel to be unnecessarily violent. Despite being rated PG-13, it showcased more violence, bloodshed, and killing compared to several R-rated movies I've seen, raising concerns about its appropriateness.The movie was not only gruesome and brutal but also left an uncomfortable impression. The atmosphere depicted a world where everyone turns on each other, devoid of characters to genuinely root for. This lack of relatable protagonists made the entire experience cringe-worthy and depressing.While I acknowledge that the themes align with the book series, the level of discomfort surpassed my expectations. Exiting the theater, my friends and I shared a collective feeling of unease. If the subsequent movies continue to portray such intense violence and the bleak depiction of humanity turning on itself, I may choose to skip them altogether.

title: I love this movie
text: This was a fantastic cinematic masterpiece, and this cast ate it up. This movie was everything I expected and more, could have had more Tom Blyth but that's okay. I loved the whole hunger games, saga, but this was a fantastic movie.It might not be better than catching fire, but it's up there. Snow White might have ended Rachel's career but snow saved it cus snow lands on top. Josh, served, Rachel has the voice of an angel and I'm pretty sure I cried a little. Hunter was magnificent.Viola Davis in everything she does is amazing, but her as doctor Gaul was something everyone has to see.Everyone Go Watch This Movie!!!!

title: i love this movie
text: Personally ive never read the books but i really liked this movie it was really interesting especally because it had alot of like connections like references to the past movies, i think this movie was made a little late and wouldve been better if it came out w all the others but regardless i still really enjoyed this movie. It was really long and i got kinda tired at the end of the movie but it was still really good even though i dont think it includes all the thoughts of the ballad and the songbirds and rhe snakes book by suzanne collins but i still reccoment to watch it at least once even if its not perfect (i watched it thrice), and i really loved the characters and story was really entertaining ( especially lucy gray)

title: What the heck did I just watch?!?
text: This does not even compare to the other movies!! This felt like a joke from the beginning and then turned into what felt like 3 different movies! The acting was bad, the directing horrible and the singing...what was this a play??? I wasted 2 and 1:2 hours of my life on this. How could they go from 3 movies that were so amazing with A level characters and so well scripted and directed to this movie? I do think that this could have been good had it been given the correct budget and casting. No offense to the characters but none of them had me excited or were memorable at all. That is not the case from the first 3 movies.

title: "I think there is a natural goodness born into us all. You can either cross that line into evil, or not. And it's our life's work to stay on the right side of that."
text: My favourite film of 2023.And considering this is now my favourite installment in my second favourite film franchise, you can imagine this ranks pretty highly on my all-time list. In fact, this is in my top 10, as crazy as that may sound.But now onto why that is. The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes (2023) exceeded my expectations a million times over. I absolutely loved every single thing about this.Let's start off with the cast. I'm surprised that I haven't seen much mention of Tom Blyth's portrayal of the infamous President Snow, as he was truly staggering. I knew that this wouldn't be the kind of movie to receive Oscar nominations, but I genuinely believe Blyth's performance was worthy of a nom it was that good. As for Rachel Zegler, not only did she provide us with a passionate and emotive showing, but her singing was beautifully enchanting. Heck, I'm getting goosebumps right now just listening to the soundtrack! There are also some noteworthy supporting performances, primarily Viola Davis', who completely transforms into the sinister, manipulative Dr. Volumnia Gaul, in both appearance and psyche. Her unflinching determination in her ghastly work will leave you terrified of her whenever she is on screen. Additionally, Jason Schwartzman does an impressive job of echoing Stanley Tucci's portrayal of Caesar Flickerman in the original Hunger Games films as Lucky Flickerman here, as he is just as snappy and exuberant as his counterpart.Essentially the entire cast is great. Admittedly though, some of the actors and actresses playing the other students do underperform to say the least, but it's a very minor scruple that I have with this feature.This picture doesn't drag at all, and that is due to an excellent decision to have title cards at the beginning of each act. It may seem like a small thing, but if it wasn't for that, everybody who hadn't read the book, including myself, would've expected the film to end with the ending of Act 2, but thanks to the Act 3 title card, we immediately expect the movie to continue for another 40 minutes or so. If it wasn't for that title card, we would've been sat there for the next 40 minutes or so thinking "when is this gonna end?". The reason I mention it is because I think if it weren't for that, this would've received noticeably worse ratings, as a lot of people would've found this to be a drag, so I believe these title cards are vital to the film's positive reception.I talked a little bit about the soundtrack earlier, and it is a wonderful one at that. I listened to it on repeat for hours after I'd seen the movie. Rachel Zegler's songs (which she sings live on set) are the standouts of course, after all they're probably what this installment will be most remembered for, but even the other songs are fantastic to listen to, and I'll probably be adding a lot of songs from this soundtrack to my personal playlist.The costume design is exceptional by the way, definitely the best of the series. You've not only got the iconic, kaleidoscopic floral dress of Lucy Gray, but there's also brilliant costumes for the likes of Dr. Volumnia Gaul, Tigris Snow, etc.I could go on and on and on, but I really ought to stop here. To summarise, this is a captivating and majestic installment in the Hunger Games franchise that will never leave my mind.

title: Movie Review
text: The Hunger Games film adaptation, based on the popular book series, is set in a dystopian world and follows Katniss Everdeen's journey as she navigates a brutal televised competition. Praised for its strong performances, especially by Jennifer Lawrence as Katniss, the movie is gripping and thought-provoking, exploring themes of survival, inequality, and rebellion. The film's action sequences, character development, and social commentary contribute to its widespread appeal among audiences.It's a captivating dystopian movie that explores themes of survival, sacrifice, and rebellion. Set in a post-apocalyptic world, it follows Katniss Everdeen as she navigates a brutal televised competition where tributes fight to the death. The film's tension, character development, and social commentary make it a compelling watch for fans of action and thought-provoking storytelling.

title: I enjoy it!
text: I think many wanted to hate this for obvious reasons but I could not.I am not a big Hunger Games fan. Never read the books. Didn't enjoys everything about the movies before..Except the performances and story as a whole of the Hunger Games world.I will say this movie performances, especially who plays Snow, Viola Davis, and Peter Dinklage was great! The main lady Rachel was pretty good too. Her role was interesting.Let's talk about Lucy Grey. I don't know this character or how much she plays in the books. But it seems from the movie standpoint, she was a free bird. Someone who just wanted to be free to be themselves.She didn't want to be part of the HG and was tricked. So I get why she was confused by everyone motivation.Going to talk about Snow. It was good to see how his character changed little by little. A young man with a legacy, really scared to admit who and what his family is about. And his own motivation to be more. Not wishing at first to offend. But gradually doing so and so much more.His turn was interesting and would had made for a better series on streaming than the movie. Great performance.Since this is Hunger Games, I will say the fights were really good. Not overstated because doing the time of this HG, technology was just coming up. No elaborate computers and stuff.The tech still have issues and created problems.Also I loved where the mentors themselves was allowed to send things, of course due to sponsors.The arena was too big, more self contained. Which made the fights interesting.For those who afraid this movie might not be violent enough... well you are in for a surprise. This movie is more violent than the previous installment. Way more.Again, very good movie for me. I think it helps that not everyone in the cast is super famous aka Jennifer Lawrence. Sure you have Peter, Viola, and others who might be famous but not on Jennifer level imo8//10. Solid movie.

title: Annoying characters
text: This movie could have stood to be thirty minutes to an hour shorter. Two and half hours is plenty of time to develop a little backstory on more characters than just Snow. In the original films, I feel like they were able to help people get to know and understand a lot of the main characters. In this prequel, the only people we really come to understand are Snow, Tigress, and Plinth. I wish they would have showed more of the past of Lucy, the original game maker, and even some of the other hunger games tributes. Even the game maker with all her creatures-I wish they would have given even a line as to why she's into that stuff and how she got into it.As for the singing, I found it all very annoying and cringey. Most of the songs actually have a positive tone, which is strange for such a dark story. Lucy also chooses to sing at times that are really weird and don't make sense. She's also exaggerated-her southern accent, her personality, her facial expressions, everything. It's like I'm watching a musical rather than a serious movie. It's also like if you go to Disney and see performers put on a show and do a musical number for guests-it's that over the top. Also, I wish Lucy just used a flat, America/midwest kind of accent-that would have made it 100% better.Lastly, without giving spoilers, Snow makes some decisions that impact his trajectory and I wish they would have had some more lead up to those decisions. Like there isn't enough character development to get him there on some of those early decisions. I think things all end up making sense in the end, but it was a tough journey for the audience keeping with the story to get there. I know some reviews say the movie is true to the books and even some people behind me said "that was so good!" So maybe I just don't like the story. You'll have to decide for yourself.

title: Unexpected Surprises
text: What amazes me is that the director goes on about the runtime of the film and goes along the lines of completeness. To be honest, the screenplay is quiet good, and it felt like a full story. But complete is an understatement when the novel which is it's obvious source is about 50ish hours in comparison to 157 minutes. Nitpicking asideI enjoyed the movie, Rachel Zegler though, either you have the accent or you don't make up your mind. Tom Blyth as Snow was a treat, Peter Dinklage *chefs kiss* --- but the real star Viola Davis an absolute gem on screen.So over all I didn't hate the film, but i certainly have my opinions. My biggest one is this.Blyth and Zeglar have zero chemistry on screen together. Apart they are fine, together not so much.

title: Movie Slapped So Hard
text: Movie was soooooooooo good. My friend was willing to leave her boyfriend for Snow, even though he is a fictional character. The depth of the each main character was explored well. The Costumes. God, the costumes, don't even get me started. I love them, especially Tigris's (can I have her closet please?). The team did a great job portraying how the Hunger Games came to be what they were in the original movies. I am one hundred precent going to watch this movie again before it get out of the theaters. Don't be like the girls from Tiktok and simp for young snow. But overall, ten out of ten. Highly recomend.

title: Good one
text: It's really interesting watching the story that I read in book amazingly represented by a movie. It was a treat to my eyes. All the characters in the movie justified their roles so well. Every one in the movie valued the scenarios and events that happened in the story that I've read in the book quite well. I would like to watch more of it from the makers of the film. It truly represented the art and the hard work of the artists. So happy to see the characters in the book alive. Thanks and Kudos to the makers and the producers of the movie. I wish all the luck and success of the movie. Overall I loved it.

title: Completely related to the rest of the saga
text: I expected a lot regarding this movie and I have not been disappointed.Even if it could sound as a repetition of the previous movies of the saga, this is absolutely not the case because you are totally absorbed in one hand by the romance between Snow and Lucy Gray, and the growing insanity of the man who will become the Capitol's president in the other hand.Indeed, with an extremely charismatic Coriolanus Snow staring by Tom Blyth and the drop-dead gorgeous Rachel Zegler (Lucy Gray), we can understand better how the terrible president Snow has become the person he is. It is also easy to find some Katniss Everdeen in the astonishing Lucy Gray. What to say about the Rachel Zegler's voice... just incredibly melodious.Moreover, there were many references that I could have found in this prequel which was completely pleasant to watch.I totally recommend this wonderful and meaningful movie.

title: Great
text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" is about as overlong as its title might suggest. It's a prequel origin story about the tenth Hunger Games and the character of President Snow of Panem; also known as Coriolanus Snow, played here to rousing effect by actor Tom Blyth.Another standout performance comes from Peter Dinklage as Casca Highbottom, whose character helps to explain how the games came into their early fruition.The film's story, based on the author Suzanne Collins' source material, pursues the humanising angle of exploring a younger and less hardened Snow as an empathetic figure - it's sort of like his Anakin Skywalker phase, pre-Vader.He partakes as a "mentor" to games contestant Lucy Gray Baird (Rachel Zegler). She's essentially an itinerant member of the Covey people who make their living travelling around and playing music; now settled in District 12 after the war.The story centres around Snow's fraught decision as to whether to pursue power, status, or love based on his connection to the Hunger Games, his strained social standing in the capitol, and his relation to Lucy Gray as her mentor.The film goes wrong when we hear far too much of Lucy Gray's singing. It feels like Hunger Games feat. MTV.She's a free-spirited character but this persona is driven home far too intensely for it to come off as natural. Her music is supposed to give her a spellbinding aura, but it's way overdone. Her jarring southern accent tries too hard to show her as that archetypal practical country belle filled with the warmth of her folkloric aphorisms. So, while she does have a certain warm charisma to her character, this heroine scarcely could hold a candle to Jennifer Lawrence's Katniss Everdeen.In other key plot points we encounter plot armour and plot holes. The plot moves along too easily because Coriolanus conveniently pulls off a cunning move or trick on more than several occasions. These are oftentimes things that would never slide in reality.The world itself is flush with sepia and monochrome. It feels like a good amount of retro, whilst keeping some technologies in the mix too. Sadly, the tenth Hunger Games themselves were an incredibly bland watch without anywhere near the suspense of the sequels.

title: Enjoyable but weak
text: "The Hunger Games: Ballad of songbirds and snakes" (2023) not only the title is too long, the movie also was. I liked the character development in the beginning but as the movie went on I started to dislike every single one of them.The only nice thing I can say about this movie is that it was nice learning about the past of the Hunger Games universe. Not that I was a good past in any way shape or form.This movie on it's own though, if we don't look at the other Hunger Games movies, does not do good. The only reason why it is an okay movie is because of it's prequels and sequels. This movie as an independent movie was not good.Casting was poorly done and so was the acting. Hearing Peter Dinklage's character try to speak with an American accent was horrible, it was so bad.Other than that i can only say i enjoyed some scenery shots, it was aesthetically well done and beautiful at moments.

title: This movie was spectacular Fantastic job
text: Everyone did a fantastic job in the movie Congratulations so proud of them for this movie keep up the good work ok nice job best movie this year yet so yeah good job everyone else with this movies the movie was a wonderful time to see it it has been years since it was that good so yeah so proud of every hunger games movie has been a wonderful movies of life changing the history of life forever so nice work on this movie so yeah keep up the good work. Nice job on everything else keep up the excellent work with movies forever so proud how this movie coming along so good so good job people with everything a wonderful time.

title: Really really loved it
text: I'm not a fan of the hunger games franchise. I've seen the movies but when they were released and forget almost all of the storyline before walking into the theatre for this one. This movie is 100% standalone with only there being some Easter eggs for long time fans. Either way I loved the character dynamic between snow and Lucy gray. Phenomenal performances all around. The movie is split up in a way that some could find jarring but I loved it. It kept me engaged and interested throughout the whole 2 hours and 38 minutes. You become really well invested in the characters and start to care about the decisions they make and at times overthink why they made those decisions. This thinking makes the movie have a longer lasting impact as you're still thinking about movie details long after it ended. While everyone can imagine they would make similar or different decisions in the scenarios the movie provides it doesn't ever feel like the audience was cheated out of a story. Every decision has weight and you can clearly see the precursor for why those decisions were made even if you don't agree with them. To have multiple people leaving the theater with different interpretations and inciting conversation like this is something not every movie can do. After awhile of thinking the movie makes more and more sense the more you think about it. This is also an important time in my life so I guess maybe in the future when I'm looking back at this my opinion might be different. This is a phenomenal movie that doesn't depend on you being a huger games fan. It works phenomenally as a standalone movie.

title: Pleasantly Surprised
text: Honestly i dont know what expectations i had for this film, actually i had no idea this was even on the cards. Suzanne Collins has comeback with her blockbuster trilogy with this quite surprising and more than comparable prequel Hunger Games: The Ballard Of Songbirds.Set amongst the 10th Annual games, Coriolanus (President) Snow forms a special bond with District 12 songbird Lucy Gray Baird, which will set conflicted emotions into overdrive. It's hard not admire Rachel Zegler as she gives her character complete likeability.Tom Blyth also gives purpose to the character we know and "love" in the originals.If you're not a fan of "musical" anecdotes there will be frustration in places, but it's not a serious issue. All in all this is a film that deserves it's place in this Panam world.

title: An interesting dive into the history of Snow, The Hunger Games and Panem
text: As someone who eagerly awaited each 'Hunger Games' movie release, I was excited after 8 years to finally get more.I have not yet read the books so it was interesting seeing the film unravel and seeing just how Snow came to be.The film, I would say, is the weakest of the films by a good stretch. The pacing was rather odd. At times it would feel like the film was rushing through scenes and then at other times, spending way too much time on scenes that don't really further the narrative or show off the characters in any meaningful way.The performances were good but the side characters performances stood out so much more than our primary protagonist.The production and costume design was great, as was the soundtrack.

title: Positive Media Influence?
text: The movie The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes provides an insight into the villain origin story of Hunger Games antagonist President Snow. This movie, released in the winter of 2023, is based on the novel by Suzanne Collins. This riveting story takes the audience on a journey with Lucy Grey Baird, who is chosen at the reaping to be the female tribute for the annual Hunger Games. This gory game is a form of entertainment, as people watch dozens of tributes get slaughtered and killed until only one remains. The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes illuminates ways in which the Seven Media Keys are inherently supported or likewise, inherently contradicted. While a full assessment of President Snow is requires for a proper assessment, one can look at the movie as a whole in order to identify qualities of the Seven Media Keys within it.The first Media Key is "living a balanced life". This movie provides thought-provoking and an interesting story line. I would argue that consuming this movie would contribute to the first media key, as many fruitful conversations would be sparked through watching them. Not only would the media be consumed while watching, but further contribute to social interaction and commentary. The nature of the plot includes moral and ethical debates, and themes such as sacrifice, love, and leadership.The second Media Key is "attitude awareness". It is important to look at what attitude or set of values a movie portrays, as it has high influential capacity. This movie does not contain a positive attitude as a whole. The characters Lucy Grey and Snow do show sacrifice and hope for one another. However, the end of the story shows abandonment and lying. These are not values I endorse, and would not want to be influenced by. In general, the movie does not glorify these values, which I do see as important to emphasize.The third Media Key is "Dignity of the Human Person". This movie centers around the Hunger Games, which degrades the human person in many ways. People are seen as players to be killed senselessly, rather than individuals with rights and feelings. The Capitol, the population of "haves", consume the Hunger Games as media themselves, and have no concern for the "have-nots". The Capitol abuses their power and wealth for the downfall of the tributes. The entire population is impoverished and struggling, and are disregarded entirely. This in no way affirms the dignity of the human person.The fourth Media Key is "Truth-Filled". In accordance with media key three, this movie does show the damage that uncontrolled power and wealth possesses. While the movie does not inherently display major truths, through the horrors of the Hunger Games, the audience can clearly see how the unchecked and disturbing features of The Capitol's behavior are contrary to truth and even basic natural law.The fifth Media Key is "Inspires Us to God". Much like the fourth media key, there are endless aspects of this movie that do not show God. Homicide, cheating, lying, and violence are all major themes of the movie. One of the main characters, Lucy Grey Baird, does keep her sense of hope in the good throughout the movie. She acts as the light in the darkness. While no theological aspects are ever shown, her strength shows the love of God in the midst of terrible suffering. Lucy Grey always tries to do the right thing, even if it goes against whatever unjust rules might be in place around her. This is very Christ-like, and she is willing to go to great lengths to hold onto her personal convictions.The sixth Media Key is "Well Made and Skillfully Developed". This movie has many high quality aspects to its production. There are several scenes that require heavy CGI, for different backdrops and even injuries that are included in the plot. However, there are stunts, elaborate costumes, and fights that are the result of live performance and hours of training. It was riveting to be able to see the result of both skillful editing, and practice by the actors. Another integral aspect is that there were many adolescent characters, including one with Down Syndrome. I was impressed by everyone's high caliber performance, which proved how well made the film was.The seventh Media Key is "Motivated and Relevant to Experience". This movie is not relatable in many respects. In our modern society, we do not maintain an atrocity such as the Hunger Games. For many, this movie might not seem relevant to experience. However, in the movie, Lucy Grey struggles with the internal suffering of isolation and decision making. As the audience, we feel sympathy and even relate to this character who tries so hard to act justly, even when her own life is at stake. So much of humanity can relate to feeling isolated and alone, which is shown while each tribute fights for their lives in the Hunger Games arena.

title: Loved it
text: Ballad, Or Crass Karaoke?"The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" is about as overlong as its title might suggest. It's a prequel origin story about the tenth Hunger Games and the character of President Snow of Panem; also known as Coriolanus Snow, played here to rousing effect by actor Tom Blyth.Another standout performance comes from Peter Dinklage as Casca Highbottom, whose character helps to explain how the games came into their early fruition.I loved watching this movie. Hope you also will like must watch story. Each and every one of your family will enjoy it for sure......

title: It's the things we love most that destroys us.
text: As someone who has read the original Hunger Games series, and watched the movies in the past, I can say that this film did a good job with taking me back to the world of Panem.I will also say that this film did a good job in trying to tell a different take on The Hunger Games, rather than soley banking on references to get you through the movie. There are references that are in here that are subtle though.Major Props to Tom Blyth for his portrayal as President Snow. He did a good job leading the movie. I will say that his character could have been handled better, and with better build up to how his character could have ended. Nevertheless, the place that he ended up in this movie was believable.Rachel Zegler did a good job as well. The relationship she and Snow had in this movie was believable, and interesting to see. I will say all things considered, she wasn't given too much to do in this. But regardless, still enjoyable to watch.Shoutout to Viola Davis, and Peter Dinklage for being that antagonistic force in this movie. Both were electric on screen, and contributed well to the overall story.I will say that the way this story is a little bit disjointed. I almost felt like there were 2 different visions for how they wanted this movie to go. It felt like they tried to find that balance between the visceral action of the Games itself, with the overall character development, and it ended up not always meshing well in some places. For me, if they doubled down on soley focusing on Snow's character, and why he is the way he is, I think it would've been a better movie.But overall, I liked it. I thought was pretty good. The action was good, and savage at times. The musical score, and soundtrack paired well with this movie. The story, even though it was all over the place, it made sense.Very respectable B-

title: Eminem in Hunger Games: The Missing Rap Mystery That's Driving Fans Crazy!
text: Everyone was super excited to see Eminem in the new "Hunger Games" movie, but guess what? He didn't rap. Not even once. And that's a huge letdown. Imagine having one of the coolest rappers around and then not letting him do what he does best. It's like going to a concert and the band doesn't play their hit song. The movie had Eminem right there, but all he did was act. No epic rap battles, no awesome lyrics. Nothing. It was so disappointing. People were ready for some amazing Eminem rap to make the movie extra special, but it just didn't happen. What a missed chance! The movie would have been way cooler with just one Eminem rap.

title: A overstuffed masterpiece
text: If any Hunger Games should have been split into two parts, it would be this. The movie had some of the best acting that I've ever seen since The Shawshank Redemption, but there aren't many times that only one shines. This movie was also way too overstuffed for a two hour and thirty minute long movie, but there wasn't a part that I didn't enjoy. If it was me then I probably wouldn't go see it in imax or something alike. The movie is definitely the goriest and most intense of the hunger games so if you can't handle that sort of stuff then this movie definitely isn't for you in any way shape or form.

title: I really enjoyed this prequel
text: I really enjoyed this prequel to the original series of Hunger Games movies.
