I liked the world building aspect, showing us where the Panem of the original movies came from and how Coriolanus Snow became who he ended up being.I will say I did find The Ballad of Songbirds And Snakes slightly too long, and some parts of the movie did feel like they dragged - almost too much in the way of exposition and scene setting.Things I loved - the aesthetic of the film, the way that the filmmakers showed this was Panem before The Hunger Games we all know from the original movie series, and gave it a kind of 1950s Americana-meets-post-war-Eastern Europe look was a great way of visualising we are seeing the past in this universe. The Panem we know in original Hunger Games is definiely futuristic but not a million miles away from our own world, so putting their past into a visual style we could relate to worked brilliantly. My theory on this is that after civilisation collapsed and those left began to build Panem relying on items and records that were left from the "old world" to develop their technologies which is why some things look like an almost pastiche of what we know from our civilisation.Anyway, moving on, I think Rachel Zegler and Tom Blyth were perfectly cast in their roles. Lucy Gray is a character you can kind of root for but she isn't entirely innocent, and the young Snow is almost likeable and you feel sympathy for him at certain points in the movie, even though we all know what he will eventually become. The musical parts with Lucy Gray singing, in some ways almost made parts of the movie feel like a musical, but actually I found it really worked, though I am aware many others hated those parts.Supporting roles were well defined, and I enjoyed the nod to the original Hunger Games movies with characters like Lucky Flickerman who clearly must me an ancestor of Caesar Flickerman. In fact perhaps he is the one the high chair is for that Lucky mentions on the phone at one point in this film!The actual Games we see in this movie are a much less slick and polished version of what we have come to know. They've only been running for 10 years, and with the Capitol rebuilding still after the Dark Days there are none of the huge and realistic arenas, themed on certain environments and climates etc. They're literally thrown into what looks like an old sports arena and have to make do with what is there. The violence is much more perhaps primative because there isn't the technology or quite as much manipulation from gamesmakers as we're used to.At nearly 3 hours this film does feel over long, but the story is interesting, its visually very striking and the soundtrack is great. Overall I really enjoyed it, though I can understand the mixed reactions of others because it isn't quite like the original movie series. I'd love to see a sequel to this prequal, though we would have to wait for another book first.

title: Beautiful adaptation
text: This movie is a great adaptation of the book, the casting, writing, music, etc. Brings you back into the world of Panem, and a great new story for new fans. I went in having low expectations and was blown away. Seeing Snow's backstory is beautiful and terrifying and a true dive into what makes a villain. There are many ways to view the ending and let's you theorize how and why Snow rose from poor citizen to president. His time throughout this story shaped him throughout his whole adulthood and brings a poetic twist to the original Hunger Games. Sympathizing with a known future villain is amazing and a great way to create and expand a villain.

title: Not what I expected, but still 🖤
text: I always thought The Hunger Games saga was one of the best book adaptations ever made, until now. I absolutely love this movie, but I strongly believe that a two-part delivery was a better option for such an intense and loooong book plot. The impossibility of telling everything that's important in 2h30m is what prevented this movie to be absolutely perfect.Still, I think it's enjoyable, moving and well, I'm simply in love with these books, so it's difficult for me not to love the movies too.I really hope that Suzanne Collins continues to move forward, telling Districts 13's whole history, may be introducing Lucy Gray or even crossing paths with Haymitch's Quarter Quell. I don't know, there's just too many possibilities.

title: Hunger Games : The Ballad of Songbirds and snake
text:
Great Movie and This movie is based on Real novel The Hunger Games by American Author
Suzzain Collins .The first three films set various box office records. The Hunger Games (2012) set records for biggest opening day and biggest opening weekend for an original IP. Catching Fire (2013) set the record for biggest opening weekend of November. Mockingjay - Part 1 (2014) had the largest opening day and weekend of 2014. The films, including Mockingjay - Part 2 (2015), were praised for their themes and Lawrence's performance. The prequel film The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes (2023), which had the lowest opening weekend of the series, was praised for its production and cast, including Blyth and Zegler's performances.

title: You won't take your eyes off the screen for a second
text:
This movie was my absolute favorite release of these recent years!I couldn't take my eyes off the screen as each scene makes you more interested in what's happening next
The movie will make you feel a mix of emotion: the cute romance between the main characters will literally make your heart flutter and the constant change of mind/side of snow will make you go through a rollercoaster of emotion as the character develop. This is obviously because the actor is doing an amazing job in interpreting his character.Props to this young and new actors, hope to see them in new releases in the near future.

title: Awesome movie
text: That's nice movei must try to watch this movie.Realy nice concept in this movie.The special effect is awesome and I really enjoy it.The younger generation is like this type of movie.I got tickets for the midnight showing of The Hunger Games movie a month ago, because I had to be there opening night and I didn't want the movie to sell out. After the action-packed movie was over, I agreed with the sold out audience of teens and adults that it was awesome.The Hunger Games is set in a depressing future. Every year two kids (a girl and a boy) from each of the 12 districts are sent to the Capitol to fight for their lives in the Hunger Games. The games are entertainment for the people who live in the Capitol. Broadcasting the fighting shows the people in the districts that the Capitol has power over them. Katniss Everdeen (played by Jennifer Lawrence in an amazing performance) volunteers to go in place of her younger sister, Primrose. Katniss is determined to survive even though she doesn't want to kill the other kids.

title: Great!
text: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is a fantastic addition to the Hunger Games franchise. I think the exploration of the early years of the games was a great thing to explore and expand upon if we were coming back to this world. This film is up there with the Catching Fire film for me. One of the better films. This story originally by Suzanne Collins is gripping and engaging. I found it interesting getting to know Snow more and where he came from and how he became who he became. The performances here were great as well. Tom Blyth, Rachel Zegler, and Viola Davis are the standouts for me. I loved their performances here. All in all, I really enjoyed this installment and would recommend it.

title: What could have been.
text: This is just another prequel movie that was made just for the sake of a prequel. The book was released in 2020 and within three years, during covid mind you, they released the movie. It was almost as if the book was written just so a movie could be made. The book is by far better than the movie as it seems is always the case. Albeit the book wasn't exceptional either.The chemistry between Blyth and Zegler feels forced, almost as if they couldn't stand to be in the same room with each other in real life. The only person that really brought anything to the table was Viola Davis. An origin story of her character, that I would watch.The entire movie feels rushed and at the same time too long. This new idea that movie need to be 3 hours long is getting old. The reason that movies like The Ten Commandments was so successful and long wasn't because the director wanted an epic movie in his repertoire, it was because the actors and the story were so good. I am just thankful that I watched this at home where I could pause and not the cinema where you just had to sit and suffer.I would have to say that this tribute did not become a victor.

title: Not a stand alone movie
text: I kept wondering about some of the character details from this prequel to the Hunger Games movies. I do think it would have been better to watch the original trilogy again before seeing this. It's like the film makers expected the audience to have every detail memorized from the first films and if you don't you may wonder what all the fuss is about. I enjoyed the acting and costumes and sets. And as a lover of American bluegrass music I really loved the music and the stomp dancing in the band scenes. It's important to remember things are more primitive in this "world" than in the movies set sixty plus years in the future from the earlier films. But since I haven't read the books or seen the original films in a decade some character development left me puzzled. Also be prepared for the sadness and despair shown here.

title: Great prequel
text: I have watched all the movies but have never read the book. This was a great film except a little slow moving to the characteristics of the characters. I liked there was no action. It focused on Lucy Gray and Corey Snow. I think they could have gone into the love story a little more. I had a lot of questions at the end. I'm want to know where Lucy went. How does this relate back to Katniss? There are plot holes. It would have been better if they referred more towards Snow's character in between the this movie and the hunger games with Katniss. It might explain why Snow has such animosity to Katniss.

title: Adherence To The YA Source Material May Make Or Break Your Enjoyment Here
text: "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" is by no means a bad movie. It is entertaining, engaging, and has flashes of brilliance. The Hunger Games prequel also is an adaptation of a young adult novel--and such theme focuses may make or break your enjoyment of it.For a very basic overview, "Songbirds & Snakes" focuses on Coriolanus Snow (Tom Blyth), the individual who will ultimately become the Donald Sutherland-played villain of the originals. Mentoring District 12's Lucy Gray (Rachel Zegler) in a very early Hunger Games iteration, Snow falls for her (or is that the other way around?) and the two form an unlikely pairing that will ultimately lead both of them in very different directions.As I mentioned, there were parts of this film that I truly did enjoy. In some ways, it is a star vehicle for Zegler, whose singing talents are truly special. Seeing such an early iteration of the Hunger Games competition is of course interesting, and there are a number of "easter eggs" for fans of the original films to smile at.However, I will argue that "Songbirds & Snakes" fails at its primary mission: to show the trajectory of Coriolanus Snow from well-meaning Panem student to the sneering Sutherland villain. The strange thing is, the film doesn't outrightly fail at this task--all (or at least most of) the steps are indeed present. But they are handled with a very YA sensibility befitting the novels they are based on. In other words, the themes and arcs of this movie are best invested by a tween, teen, or younger audience, I think. Some of the material is very much "on the nose", while at other times it comes off as a bit lacking in true follow-through of the Snow character mission other than "well, we know he's going to become the big baddie, so...".Granted, the original Hunger Games set largely has those YA approaches baked into it too, but the inclusion of Jennifer Lawrence's super-serious Katniss was a tonic (at least for me). As good as Zegler is as an entertainer, she is not in the Lawrence acting category (at least not yet).Perhaps others will not have as much of a "sophistication" problem with "Songbirds & Snakes" as I did. But other than never being bored, the flick failed to draw me into its key tenets of existence because I felt it was constantly shooting for only the approval of a much younger audience than I.

title: Wanted to love this, but...
text: I listened to the audiobook 'The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes' fairly soon before this movie came out, and I watched the movie with my husband once it did. Much to my disappointment and embarrassment, it was a huge waste of our time. I wanted to like the movie, but honestly, watching the trailer was the best part of the entire film. It just didn't hold up. The movie was far too long (could easily have just been two parts split between the time in the Capitol and the time in District 12). It wasn't very well done, not very well acted, which is a shame because I think this was the best book in the series. And Rachel Zegler...while she is stunning was not a very good Lucy. She was cheesy and boring, not compelling. I mean, personally, maybe I would have liked her more if she weren't such a little brat concerning all things Snow White, but such is life.

title: A movie that can even be said to surpass the main trilogy
text: Very good decisions were made both while writing the source material of this film and during its production.Let me start with the source material first. I hadn't read the book yet when I watched this movie. Readers say that the film is faithful to the main material almost word for word. That's why I will write everything I liked about the plot as plus points for the book.As a prequel, I loved where the story positioned itself regarding the hunger games. I loved that the anger and pain of war were still alive here, while it was an established culture and entertainment in the main trilogy. I loved that games were not a cultural acceptance, but an innovation that people still question morally. I loved that they were making games so amateurishly and simply because they were decades behind from the main story in technology and experience. I loved that Snow, as a villain, was a real character stuck between what life had thrown at him, the system, and his loved ones. For a youth literature work, I greatly appreciated both its fiction and characters.In terms of the decisions taken during the shooting of the film, I loved their aesthetic choices. Considering the futuristic atmosphere of the original series, I liked the atmosphere of the 80s and 90s America in this story, which takes place almost 70 years in the past. Casting was perhaps the biggest problem in the main trilogy. Here, the harmony of the cast with the roles was very successful.In conclusion, I think this movie is not appreciated as much as it deserves.

title: New, yet nostalgic, cinematic experience
text: Reading the novel before the movie was the perfect choice! The movie honors Collin's captivating writing.Knowing the world from the original series made the cinematic choices exciting, which speaks to the whole production team's thoughtfulness. The capitol's depiction is beyond what I pictured in my mind while reading.Davis and Blyth kept me GLUED to the screen by their acting performances and on screen appearance - props to their makeup, hair, and wardrobe team!Jason did a great Lucky in this serious movie - it is commendable to bring humor to a dystopian world!I enjoyed going to the movies with my fellow Hunger Game fan friends (even though we really missed Peeta)! It brought back great memories!

title: My favourite part of a series
text: Great actors, awesome story of a man that we know from the previous movies as a ruler with absolute power, songs and much much more. I'm not a huge fan of this series, it's just ok, something I watched and I liked, but for sure I enjoyed this movie.The hunger games as 1/3 of a movie is good enough for me, the remaining 2/3 is house of cards with people plotting and fighting for their part, which is great to watch and see who wins and who loses. The steps and hard choices especially main character has to make show him as a complex person, not only the bad guy.It also gives context on some things e.g. What hunger games are suppose to be and why there is so much show around it that we saw in previous 4 movies.

title: So Awful I Couldn't Finish it
text: I'm a huge fan of the Hunger Games franchise. All the previous films are well-directed, well-acted, awesome casting with amazing sets and costumes.But I couldn't finish this watching this trash film. I don't know how this can be the Hunger Games. The story was disjointed, seemed rushed and was confusing at times. The film makers assumed we all read the books so no need to develop the story. I never read them.Casting was horrendous. Rachel Zegler is just awful. A cardboard cut-out moved around by someone hiding behind it would have been more compelling and interesting. The forgettable actor playing Snow wasn't much better.Except for the actress who played Dr Gaul, the entire cast was forgettable. Hers was a stand out performance. She almost saved the film.

title: Off Key and Out of Tune: A Discordant Symphony
text: In the grand orchestra of cinematic ventures, there are those rare films that resonate with the harmonious blend of storytelling and spectacle, whisking audiences away on flights of fancy and fervour. Then, there's "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes," which, for lack of a more genteel expression, hits more bum notes than a drunken karaoke session at your local pub.One can't help but feel that in its desperate clamor to be heard over the cacophony of contemporary cinema, this prequel performs a juggling act akin to playing the violin whilst riding a unicycle - admirable but fundamentally flawed. Its overture promises a symphony of suspense and socio-political commentary, yet what follows is akin to an orchestra tuning its instruments ad infinitum. The melody is lost amid a discordant clamour to check every box, creating a tune that feels more like a forced medley than a harmonious composition.Directorial decisions aside, the plot - if one might be so bold to call it that - seems to have been co-composed by a committee intent on merging "The Hunger Games" with "Frozen," complete with inexplicable singing segments that leave one wondering if they've accidentally switched channels. This bewildering inclusion not only fractures the narrative but also screeches across the viewer's sensibilities with the grace of a cat sliding down a blackboard.Despite a cast that tries valiantly to inject some life into this pallid affair - with special mention to Tyrion Lannister's portrayer, who appears as out of place as a penguin in the Sahara - the film ultimately suffocates under the weight of its own vanilla ambitions. It's a cinematic endeavour that's all noise, no substance.In conclusion, "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" swings wildly for the fences but ends up striking out, delivering a performance so out of tune with its original melody that even the most ardent fans might find themselves yearning for the sweet silence of the end credits. In the grand scheme of things, it serves as a stark reminder that not all that glitters is gold, and certainly not all that sings is sweet.

title: LOVEEE
text: I LOVED THIS MOVIE. It did a great job at developing the backstory for snow and why he is the way he was in the original hunger games. I loved the suspense throughout the movie and it had great pacing. I was never bored the entire movie- there was always something interesting going on in the movie never just boring meaningless dialogue. They did a good job of incorporating different elements of the first hunger games into it.I having nothing else to say other then it was a great movie. I liked how it showed different parts of Snows life and how they affected his character.I want another movie staring young president snow part 2 💔

title: Great
text: "The Hunger Games" is an electrifying masterpiece that captivates from the first page to the last arrow shot. Drawing readers into a world brimming with political intrigue and heart-pounding action. This compelling tale sparks contemplation on societal issues, leaving an indelible mark long after the final chapter. In conclusion, Suzanne Collins' "The Hunger Games" trilogy stands as a tour de force in young adult literature. Its gripping storyline, compelling characters, and thought-provoking themes have solidified its place as a timeless classic, captivating audiences of all ages. With its seamless blend of action, social commentary, and emotional depth, this saga continues to resonate, leaving an enduring legacy that transcends the pages of its books.

title: Just stay true...
text: The formula is simple: If you've got a good source material, stay true to it and you'll do good. It ain't rocket science.It's so refreshing to see someone from Hollywood to figure this out. The source material is Collins's best installment to the book series and the movie producers were smart enough not break what was already perfect. Sure they took liberties, both small and big, especially towards the end. However, by "liberties", I mean leaving some things out and simplifying others - that's perfectly acceptable.On that note, the movie was both long and rushed at the same time - that can be considered a sign of quality. Sure, they could have split it into two movies and I wouldn't have minded (unlike in the cases of Harry Potter and Twilight) but I respect them for taking the page out Lord of the Rings 3 and keeping the movie in one piece and as long and as shortened as needed.

title: Zeigler was more cringe than I expected
text: The whole cast was mediocre at best... Except Zeigler was extra obnoxious and cringe. I can't believe after she destroyed Snow White they gave her this role. She can't act and she definitely cannot sing. Her "singing/screaming" sounds like someone torturing a large bird. But Even Dinklage was terrible in this too. His acting was too forced and boring. The movie was boring. The singing was just too hard to get through. The whole cast was mediocre at best... Except Zeigler was extra obnoxious and cringe. I can't believe after she destroyed her last role they gave her this role. I can't watch Zeigler.

title: Wanna be Disney with all the singing
text: First off, I LOVE the book and have read it several times, so there's plenty of nit picky things I could say. I think they made some good changes that did clear things up and make things better. I would like to see a director's cut, though, because a lot of what happens is rushed and puts events all in one day or weekend rather than weeks and months.Must've just been for time reasons, which makes sense.It's faithful to the story and movie-only fans wouldn't know how much feeling and character development they miss, and probably would still enjoy the movie and be satisfied knowing Snow's backstory.Lucy was a little disappointed with how stiff she was. Overall, rushed but not worst film. Just a little hollow, and unfortunately probably not a favorite.It was also felt Disney-esque will all the singing.

title: Long, boring, over the top, far-fetched, cringe and cheesy.
text: First of all, although I am not a big fan, I really enjoy the previous three movies and occasionally rewatch them. Also, I have never read any of the books.That being said, I hated this prequel, which I found too long, boring, over the top, far-fetched, cringe and cheesy.Not to mention a lot of nonsensical twists and turns and the terrible and inexplicable decisions and atitudes of many of the characters.Could hardly finish watching.I believe that most of the good/great reviews are from die hard book fans. That is the only feasible explanation I can come up with.What a waste of time.

title: Better than I thought, the book
text: First I didn't want to read the book because I was afraid the story would be unnecesary, BUT THEN I readed it, and I enjoyed it very much!The same with this movie: first I didn't want to watch it because I thought they would do a simple movie, but today I watched it and (and I'm not joking) ALMOST EVERYTHING was EXACTLY like my imagination when I was reading the book. The scenes, the clothes... was exactly like how I imagined it.I understand that the movie is fast, I mean, the movie is long but the story is told quickly. The book is so big that you would have to do a 5 hours movie in order to explain everything. But even with that, I think they did a great jobe with selecting what to put and not to put in the movie. Again, the book is really big, is difficult to do a 2 hours movie.In conclusion: of course the book is better than the movie, BUT the movie doesn't disappoint. Actually I think that the movie is more enjoyable if you read the book first, because then you understand the background and the reason why characters do certain things.As I said, the movie was an exact photo of my imagination while I was reading the book. The difference is that now I can hear the songs (they are beautiful by the way).

title: Solid Book Adaption, Incredible Actors
text: First off, HUGE SHOUTOUT to this amazing cast. The acting was top tier.As someone who LOVED the book, I thought the film did a beautiful job bringing it to life. The beginning felt a bit rushed to where someone who hasn't read the book would need to pay close attention. And losing Snow's inner monologue definitely makes it harder to catch his full transformation.But other than that, I think the story was entertaining and portrayed very well!Definitely worth the watch.Disclaimer: It's THE BALLAD of Songbirds and Snakes. There is singing. It was a little cringe in the book and is still cringy in movie. But Rachel Zeigler is a great singer!!Disclaimer 2: It's a villain origin story. Don't expect warm fuzzies.

title: Incredible faithfully
text: It's been some years since the franchise have us Mockingjay Part 2, my interest peaked at Catching Fire, but slowly diminished as it went on, I thought this looked recent from that trailer, for me though this was a bit of a damp squib, it wasn't bad, it just didn't hold my attention, a film I just couldn't get into.I had a feeling the film would struggle without Jennifer Lawrence, and it really did, I had no issues with Rachel Zegler's acting, indeed I thought the was rather good, but I couldn't attach to hers, or any of the characters, I just found them all a little anonymous, and almost impossible to empathise with.A mixed bag in terms of production, I thought some of the visuals were great, some terrific special effects, but all of that music, it just wasn't for me, I didn't quite see the appeal.Do yourself a favour, go and see Saltburn instead, an infinitely better film, I did thr double, that captivated me, this one sent me to sleep.

title: Hunger Games like you've never seen
text: To start, I think it should be stated that the movie and book are extremely similar. So hats of to the director for a great job there. However if you are looking for a similar storyline to the first 4 movies you would be disappointed. This movie is dark compared to the others, but this is to be expected as this movie is about a person who will do anything to be in power. Willing to kill anyone to become powerful. It's a great reflection of the capitol and society as a whole. So to anyone who thinks this movie was boring you obviously were not paying attention. This is an action packed movie. At every Twist and turn has a new insight into the hunger games universe. However the ending did seem a bit rushed. But the action was great and so was the story line. Overall a great movie for a difficult time in the world.

title: A thoroughly forgettable film with a terrible ending.
text: I read the original trilogy of books and enjoyed them for what they were and also enjoyed the original films in the same light...but this film felt wholly unnecessary. It was unremarkable and didn't add anything to the story. This follows the son of a general from an aristocratic family in "the capitol" as he is assigned to mentor a tribute in the current games. We meet the game maker Dr. Gaul, who is probably the most interesting character in this film...in all of her vile evilness. She is played well by Viola Davis, who made quite the vivid and unsettling character in this highly forgettable film.Not a recommendation from me...just stick to the original films.

title: The best since Catching Fire!
text: I'm higher than the hopes that you brought down...The 10th hunger games are not only a great introduction to post-war Panem and some characters we've known from previous entries of the franchise, but also a bittersweet complex love story between a capitol boy and a free spirited singer/artist from district 12.Tom Blynth is probably the best performance of the movie. Nevertheless, I need to give a shot out to Viola Davis & Rachel Zegler for impersonating believable and unique characters. Acting was definitely on point.Although third act could be more fleshed out to provide more context and develop (even further) the romance between the protagonists, the movie does a great job in creating a satisfactory character arc for Snow, whom we learned to love and hate. The transition of his character from young-adult to president of Panem is nicely executed.If you liked the original hunger games saga you will love this one. The world building and the OST are amazing, as usual in this franchise.

title: So bad that it belittles the original books and movies
text: I went into this expecting nothing and yet I was still massively disappointed.The acting is shocking, the songs are straight out of a Disney film and worst of all, it mimics bits from the original films despite the fact it's a prequel and set years before them.It's done that thing that has become commonplace recently where they've tried to humanize the villain and it's just totally unnecessary. Sometimes peoe can just be evil because they're evil. They've tried to make you feel sorry for Snow and that's just inane.This saddest part is the fact that it undermines the original books and films.I would advise avoiding this at all costs.

title: A Thought Piece
text: Though this movie was a bit too long, I enjoyed it quite a bit. I remember reading the original trilogy in my early teen years and watching the movies as they came out with palpable excitement. This time was different however, because I went in theaters this time without much knowledge of the prequel this was based on and no expectations. Long story short, this movie touched me a lot differently than the originals and I connected with the message of the films more as an adult.At the core of these movies and books is a look at humanity: the good, bad, and ugly. A fictional world that teenage me gawked at as impossibly cruel. And yet, we've had gladiator arenas and concentration camps - among countless other horrible things.I enjoy media that makes me think and this movie did its job. Originally I gawked at the long screen time, but it went along quickly save for a brief portion of the third act.There are a lot of mixed ratings for this movie, but I left the theater with a buzzing brain and a heavy heart. For the moment, I was touched and entertained which is all I ask for.

title: Does Well Expanding the Universe as Well as The Hunger Games Itself
text: The Hunger Games films are probably the only book-adaptions that exist for me to say that I've actually read the source material, though then again, I never read the book for this adaption in particular. I guess the point I'm trying to get across is that I'm pretty familiar with this franchise and genuinely enjoy its content.One thing this movie does right are its performances. I know a lot of people haven't been too fond of Rachael Zegler lately, but you still have to admit that she's a phenomenal actor. I've loved her in almost everything I've seen her in, and I really hope to see her in more stuff. While this may not be her greatest performances ever (most of it may have to do with how the writers characterized her, or adapted her (assuming they kept Lucy Gray true to the original book). I think a lot of people who haven't read the original book may go into this film expecting that Lucy Gray is the main character, and while that is mostly true this film is really Snow's story (which I'll talk about more in the next paragraph). I don't think I'm familiar with Tol Blyth as an actor, but I still think he did a good job with what he had (again, he's performing exactly how the writers envisioned him).Probably the biggest complaint I've heard about this film, especially from critics, is how this film ended. A lot of people felt it was rushed and out of character. I'm gonna try to explain it best without spoilers, but I actually didn't mind how they ended this film. Contrary to popular belief, I really don't think the ending was rushed at all. What everyone knows by now is that Snow is the main villain in the mainline Hunger Games films, so it isn't a spoiler that this is a villains origin story. We get to see the fall of a man who questioned the morality of the Hunger Games, to the rise of someone who'd choose his family's legacy over the person he loved the most. I don't think Snow was ever truly developed to become good, because Snow was never going to abandon his family legacy in the first place. It's a tragic ending, but what did you expect? This is an origin story of a villain, and I for one thought it was well done.I don't think this is the best Hunger Games adaption, but I still think it works well as an origin story, and it easily fleshes out the world of Panem even further. I love how this film shows us how corrupt the Capitol is within this universes' government, as we get to see how the Hunger Games in this time period slowly differ from its original purpose (which was still screwed up either way) and start to become a form of entertainment. We get to see this through Lucy and the other District members when they are forced out of their home and onto the battlefield. What I really like about this movie is the fact that the Hunger Games aren't the same as the one's we were familiar with in the original films, this is not only an origin story of President Snow, but for the Hunger Games itself in a sense. The Hunger Games get develop as the story progresses as if the Games are a character itself, and I think this film does this very well. This goes beyond the Districts as Snow is fleshed out within the Capitol. We get to see more of the Capitol and learn to hate it as the story progresses. It's important to flesh out the Capitol's corruption as well, as it expands what we knew about the Hunger Games from the original films.I thought this film was pretty good, definitely as good as the original films in my opinion. I still think this movie is pretty flawed, there are things that could've been explained better, and yea, maybe Snow was a little underdeveloped now that I think about it, but I think that with the runtime that they had, they did a really good job with Snow's development, which is something most people will disagree with. I think if you're a fan of the books or movies, then you'd probably love this, if not, then this movie might not be for you.

title: Lost in the looks?
text: The ballad of songbirds and snakes portrays a beautiful background to so many aspects of the game, but I think the movie although brilliantly executed and shot, it can get stuck in achieving a more standard cinematic look to today's world, and I feel like the aesthetic that we had on the original saga world way better due to its more natural look. I think the shots in the ballad of songbirds and snakes tend to look a little bit too dreamy, and a little too 'good' for its predecessors. Wich, it is not something bad, I was mesmerized in part three with all of those shots of snow in the middle of the woods. But I think in a couple of aspects, I missed the kind of cinematography it had in the original saga.

title: Awasome
text:
A gripping dystopian film that captivates audiences with its intense storyline, compelling characters, and thought-provoking themes. Jennifer Lawrence delivers a strong performance as Katniss Everdeen, navigating the challenges of a brutal televised competition. The film successfully combines action and social commentary, making it a memorable and engaging cinematic experi
"The Hunger Games," directed by Gary Ross, is an adaptation of Suzanne Collins' bestselling novel. Set in a dystopian future, the story unfolds in the nation of Panem, where the Capitol controls twelve districts by annually selecting one boy and one girl from each district to participate in a televised fight to the death known as the Hunger Games.Jennifer Lawrence shines as the protagonist, Katniss Everdeen, whose resilience and resourcefulness become central to the film. The movie effectively establishes the stark contrast between the opulent Capitol and the struggling districts, highlighting themes of inequality and oppression.The pacing is well-crafted, building tension as the characters navigate the treacherous arena. The action sequences are dynamic and complemented by the emotional struggles of the participants. The supporting cast, including Josh Hutcherson as Peeta Mellark and Woody Harrelson as Haymitch Abernathy, contributes to the film's overall strength.The cinematography captures the grim atmosphere of the districts and the spectacle of the Capitol, enhancing the viewer's immersion in the narrative. James Newton Howard's score complements the mood, heightening the emotional impact of key scenes."The Hunger Games" successfully blends elements of action, drama, and social commentary, making it a compelling film for both fans of the source material and those new to the story. It serves as a solid introduction to the larger narrative arc that continues in the subsequent films.

title: Rating for the leading man, otherwise a 7
text: I haven't read the book yet and completely plan to, so I can't speak to how this follows the book. Sets a really great atmosphere for the future Capital and how the success of the games affects it. Love the leading man, his classmates and family. Lucy sings WAY too much. WAY too much. The run time could have been cut if she just sang even ONE verse of songs instead of multiple verses. I mean, really? I didn't feel real chemistry between she and the leading man. It was pretty far through the movie when I KNEW they were love interests. (I thought maybe it was going a different direction)Also, Studios continue to cast actors that aren't age appropriate. The Hunger Games seem much less brutal when the participants that are supposed to be much younger are so obviously in their 20s. Yes, we all loved Jennifer Lawrence as Katniss, but she didn't look 16.Despite the shortcomings, the development of many characters, and their relationship with the main character was well-developed without dragging the story. I DID think they worked really hard to make Lucy TOO much of a character.

title: Awesome watch
text: Being a huge fan of the Hunger Games series, this was a very fun watch. It was a great addition to the world of the Hunger Games. Rachel was born for this role and would love to see her again in many more. The rest of the cast was fantastic as well. The film was well put together but did have its times when my focus was taken away. I loved seeing the younger versions of past characters we've met, very well executed on that part. The movie soundtrack had great choices and had a great connection to the film. Overall, the film was great and didn't seem much of a cash grab, knowing it was part of an already successful franchise.

title: One of the best movies from 2023
text: This movie is anything anyone could ask for, thrilling, funny, entertaining and more. The cast is brilliantly selected and around the board the performances were great. Viola Davis was a standout, as well as all the other main characters. The script is cleverly written with comedic lines, smart remarks and it all delivered exceptionally by the cast. The action in the movie is brilliantly shot and choreographed, and entertaining throughout. Many ideas are thrilling and exciting throughout as well, making a very good watch. The writing is also great with symbolism and an extremely clever plot. The writing does deteriorate in the third part, never the less the movie is excellent in all aspects.

title: A poor and unneeded prequel
text: I love the hunger games films and must admit when I heard there was a prequel I had my doubts and they where sadly confirmed.The movie is disjointed, slow and the characters dislikeable.The love story element is overemphasised and feels out of place in what the movie is trying to be. It full of disjointed scenes which don't flow from one to the next.I unfortunately spent most of my time fast forwarding hoping for the film to improve at some point. Sadly it didn't.Sure the actors do I fine job in their abilities and the best they could with the script, but nothing was going to save this movie and its a big thumbs down from me.

title: A pleasant surprise, much better than expected
text: I won't give any spoilers, but I'll say that the movie is divided into three major parts. First two parts are solid, maybe 7.5 on IMDB scale, but the third part is easy 9.0/9.1. Actor that plays Snow is excellent, his transition to the ruthless tyrannt is Oscar worthy. This is something that was missed in a Game of thrones transition of Denearys. That was rushed, this was top notch. Also, I read that some people complain about singing. I disagree. Songs performed have their part in a film similar and maybe there is one or two to many, but nothing serious. This movie was a surprise, I expected 7, but it is 8.3, 8.4.

title: Incredibly captivating and gap filling for a grusome, yet so interesting character
text: This movie really shows the true identity of the Snow, we know from the original movies. The intriguing part about Snow, is his unavoidable lust for power, popularity and wealth, but the first 4 movies never really showed us how he rose to power and why. Lucy Gray is a forshadowing symbol of the mockingjay (AKA Katniss) that snow learns to love, trust but most importantly, fear. So many things that we remember from the first 4 movies, originates from this timeline. Most noticeable , The hanging tree song that katniss sings, Lucy Gray wrote herslef. A movie that leaves you with many afterthoughts. Rachel Ziegler is loving and charasmatic in her role as lucy gray. She persuades the audience with her great acting and together with Tom blyth, makes two convincing lovers and have such good chemistry. Overall a loving, tragic, compelling and so interesting story about a man who we know as cruel, vile and careless, swallowed by his hereditary thirst for power and control when he has the opportunity to chose the good things in life instead.

title: What a discombobulated mess
text: As a long-time fan of the Hunger Games franchise, I approached "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" with a mix of excitement and cautious optimism. The original trilogy, both in book and film form, held a special place for me, despite a noticeable decline in quality with each successive movie. The first film, in particular, captured the raw intensity and dystopian allure of Suzanne Collins' world, setting a high bar for its sequels.Unfortunately, my anticipation quickly turned to dismay as I watched the latest installment. From the outset, "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" felt like a disjointed attempt to recapture the franchise's former glory. Even with powerhouse talent like Viola Davis in the cast, the movie struggled to find its footing. The narrative lacked a clear direction, often meandering through various subplots without ever fully committing to any of them.One of the most glaring issues was the film's pacing. The story seemed to lurch from one event to the next, never allowing the audience to fully engage with or understand the characters' motivations. This erratic pacing left many plot points unresolved, contributing to an overall sense of incoherence. In particular, the moral ambiguity of the characters felt half-baked. They would commit heinous acts only to express regret moments later, making it difficult to discern their true natures or empathize with their struggles.The performances, too, were a mixed bag. While some actors delivered compelling portrayals, others appeared lost, as if they themselves were unsure of their characters' arcs. This inconsistency further muddled the film's already fragmented narrative. At times, the actors seemed to grapple with poorly defined roles, resulting in performances that felt forced and unconvincing.Another perplexing element was the film's frequent use of musical numbers. There were numerous instances of seemingly random singing, which often felt more like filler than integral parts of the story. These segments disrupted the flow of the narrative and gave the movie an odd, almost surreal quality, akin to a teen musical rather than a dark dystopian saga.The screenplay itself did little to salvage the movie. The writing came across as lazy, with dialogue and plot developments that lacked depth and originality. The characters were often reduced to caricatures, their actions driven more by the need to advance the plot than by any genuine development or motivation. This superficial treatment of the characters and storylines resulted in a viewing experience that felt hollow and unsatisfying.Despite these flaws, I was somewhat relieved that the filmmakers chose not to split the movie into two parts. Given the disjointed nature of the narrative, the prospect.

title: Slow, boring with very few exciting moments.
text: I couldn't really get into the movie. It was slow, boring at times and very few exciting moments. Quite predictable. In my opinion the worst Hunger Games yet! Probs worth a watch for many people but for me... I'll never get the almost 3 hours of my life back.. man it was boring..the acting seemed over the top and the story line in my opinion was Ball Bag.. I suppose they couldn't keep it the same as the last hunger game movies, a change had to happen BUT, c'mon they could have made it more entertaining, more action, more violence, more of everything it didn't have. Anyway, enjoy the movie... if you can.. just don't expect anything amazing..

title: interesting examples of human nature when backed into a corner.
text: Was this movie extremely long? Yes, but it is literally called titled a BALLAD. I'm not sure why some people are baffled by that.This movie was able to convey the most thought provoking message of the book - human nature when backed into a corner. The movie made the audience feel like they were backed into that corner time and time again and how it got easier and easier to make the wrong decision. It made me analyze and ponder at what point would I decide that my success isn't worth it - at what point would I accept defeat.I'm honestly surprised with how many people are giving this movie a bad review. The movie made the audience question themselves. Very well made film.

title: A waste of money!
text: I loved the Hunger Games movie series so when this origin story movie came out I was excited to see it. I even bought it digitally thru iTunes. I wasted good money on a bad movie. It was very flat! Every single character was a cliché. The entire movie was predictable and unoriginal. None of the characters are well developed nor fleshed out. You never really learn what anyone's reason, intention, or motivation for any particular choice. None of the characters gave me a reason to become invested in the story. I could go on and on. Please do waste you time and money. Just stick to the original four movies and call it a day!

title: Originally Consistent
text: Hey Hunger Game's Fans:The movie is long to sit through. I was up 3 times for refreshments and a bathroom break. IMHO the movie moved at too slow a pace. With that said, I enjoyed the show, the actors & their characters, the storyline, and, the little things which helped explain the origins revealed in the first 3 movies (books). It's cool to see the key characters development. Also, how the original H. G. were planned and played, including how the rules developed. I still think it was too long and moved too slowly. I hope they are planning a sequel to flesh out the main characters and their relationships.If you can handle the long running time, you will like the movie.

title: Fantastic job on this movie
text: Yeah everyone did a fantastic job with the movie so proud of how it comes together the best hunger games movie all around hunger games movies have been fantastic books and movies you all did a wonderful job with the soundtrack and all of the movies keep up the good work probably with everything else ok I hope you make a new hunger games movie in 2 years time can't wait for it it has to be done well ok so I wish you all good luck with the next movie Congratulations on this movie again so proud how it was very interesting and very Spectacular so proud of it so much greatest hunger games movie this year.

title: Marvelous movie
text: This is the fiveth part of the hunger game frenchise. The movie was having a great story line and best part of the movei was the plot of story and vfx which gives life to the movie and the crewpresent this very efficiently. Each character of this movie delivered the best to justify story line and the director of the movie established a fine way to show the story to the audience and keeb bind audiance to the theater to the end.the cgi of move is done perfectly in each and every frame that it can give the plot a real and feel audiance what exactly they want deliver. Its a nice movie to watch and enjoy with friends.

title: If you're reading this, you're almost certainly in the Capitol.
text: While many focus this story on Coriolanus, the real story is about the fates of the mouthpieces for the audience (Lucy Gray, Sejanus, and Tigris), specifically Tigris.When reading the original books as a teen, I positioned myself as someone in the districts, much like Katniss. We often place ourselves in the same shoes as the protagonist. We view ourselves as the hero and separate ourselves from the villain.Reading this latest book and watching this movie in my late 20s, I realize how foolish I was when I was younger. While I pretended I was reading dystopian fiction, I've always been living in the Capitol. While I had been connecting myself as a teen most with those in the districts, it is now that I realize I should have been connecting myself more with people like Tigris. The only question is whether we realize this, and whether we have the conviction to empathize and truly bear witness to the stories of Lucy Gray, Sejanus, and Katniss and take principled action rather than passively acknowledging these stories of inequity and abuse while reaping the rewards of corrupt power.

title: 9/10 review.
text: I read the book in advance in anticipation for this film, and I recall seeing in both instances questions such as "A book/film about President Snow? Unecessary! We don't want it!!" and I think frankly that is speaking too soon. With the THG series Suzanne Collins has been a miracle worker, creating novels that are arguably among the best adapted books-to-films ever made. The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes proves itself to be no exception. The film has managed to flesh out the story to near perfection, singled out the most important events, and it will all resonate with all who are familiar with this series, who knew it by the books or only from the films.PS: The amount of people infuriated by the singing when you went to watch The BALLAD of Songbirds and Snakes ....

title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes
text: Prequel to The Hunger Games films seen through the eyes of Coriolanus Snow (Tom Blyth) who would become President Snow in the first films as played by Donald Sutherland. Expecting to win the prestigious Plinth Prize, Snow and his colleagues are told at the last minute that the prize will go to the one who best mentors the competitors (tributes) in the 10th hunger games. Split between strict adherence to the rule of law and some understanding of the rebel's cause, Snow falls for his Tribute, Lucy Gray (Rachel Zegler). However, continually supported by evil games keeper Gaul (Viola Davis) he keeps his options open when he is sent to district 12 for cheating in the games.There is a decent sense of an epic story here, with Blyth giving a good performance popping between adoration for Lucy Gray and needing to get on up. He does this very well, but the whole thing is still at 157 minutes way too long. There are some good scenes throughout including in the notorious games, but it's mostly a love story littered with political chicanery and betrayal. Much better than I was expecting, but 30 minutes too long.

title: Excellent prequel
text: From the moment Snow said he felt powerful after killing one of the tributes, that's when I knew no matter what; he was always going to turn out the way he did.I'm finding it so hard to write a review for this film as I feel so much happened there is no space to touch on everything.The film is beautiful overall, the casting was excellent. Hunter Schafer was made for Tigris.Film was a great addition to the franchise, gave us a lot of backstory that just brought the whole franchise to life. Plus it made it so clear to us why Snow hated Katniss, she is essentially Lucy Grey reincarnated.I would have loved to see more on Snow and Tigris' relationship, i understand they had their different views on the games which would have drove them apart but in this film they are almost inseparable, a complete contrast from The Mockingjay part 2.

title: Much better than all the other Hunger Games movies combined...
text: First, this review is NOT from a fan point of view. I was never a fan of the HG series, but from my point of view (never read the books either), this movie was much deeper and had a much more interesting story than the previous 4. At least this wasn't a stupid love triangle in a story about rebels vs governmental issues... At least this one wasn't a cliché.It had everything from a good story, a MUCH better cinematography, unexpected turns, and good hooks throughout the movie. It is not the best acting ever, but it is at the very least on par with the other HG movies.I would say that the part that I wasn't too sure about would be the singing, since it makes the movie a bit childish, but it is part of the story.In short, if you liked the other HG movies, but wanted a better story in the same world and ambience, definitely go see this movie.

title: Wonderful.
text:
I had very high hopes for this film. The book was great,very talented singer and has a great voice, which is put on display in this movie. However, she just isn't a great actress. The film has the good cast I have ever seen for a spin off of such a successful original series. I put great on the casting director for that. Overall, What made the original Hunger Games great was that you believed in the characters backstories, and you could get drawn into it. I really wanted to like this movie, I rewatched all the originals right before and it only made this movie look so much paler in comparison. The actual "Hunger Game" in the movie at its most basic state in the timeline was entertaining
I'm very happy and supperbb.

title: The Hunger Games The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes: Unnecessary and unbalanced
text:
PlotCoriolanus Snow mentors and develops feelings for the female District 12 tribute during the 10th Hunger Games.CastRachel Zegler and Tom Blyth lead while assisted by veterans Viola Davis, Fionnula Flanagan and in a surprisingly competent casting choice Jason Schwartzman.VerdictWhen I saw the poster and discovered we were about to get another Hunger Games movie I wasn't exactly excited, furthermore when I learned it was a cop out prequel. I deemed it another unneeded cashgrab movie and didn't rush to watch it.The missus chose it for movie night so I prepared for the lackluster, more teen angst and pretty people. Was it everything I feared? Yes and no.Our leads are competent but unengaging, the supporting cast are solid but not strong enough to carry the film, the movie though feeling like a Hunger Games has a very unbalanced tone and an abundance of unlikable characters and suffers from the glaring issue that our hero is the villain in all the other movies so we know the direction this guy is going to go.Hunger Games was already stretched too thin without a non-nonsensical prequel!RantsHow many years off death sports do you think we are? In some form or another I feel they're inevitable. A TV show where people compete for wealth in games where folks may or will be killed (Likely by each other). It's going to happen, but when? Will it be born simply of a shift in society or will it be used in a political purpose format such as overpopulation? Would you watch it? What percentage of the world would protest against it? Fascinating topic but I doubt it'll be in my lifetime.The GoodCast are passable
A few watchable moments
Jason Schwartzman and Viola Davis are great hereThe BadJust doesn't click
Inconsistent tones
Weak characters
Questionable finale.

title: Well-made Movie
text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is a worthy addition to the Hunger Games franchise. It's a well-made film with strong performances and a thought-provoking story. I was particularly impressed with Tom Blyth's performance as Coriolanus Snow. He does a great job of capturing the character's ambition, ruthlessness, and vulnerability. Rachel Zegler is also excellent as Lucy Gray Baird. She's a complex and sympathetic character, and Zegler brings her to life with charisma and intelligence. The film's visual effects are impressive, and they help to create a believable and immersive world. The film's score is also effective, and it helps to set the tone for the film.Overall, I enjoyed The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes. It's a well-made film with strong performances and a thought-provoking story. I would recommend it to fans of the Hunger Games franchise and dystopian fiction in general.

title: My first hungergames film
text: This is my first hungergame movie to watch but it was more than what i expected .The amount of enjoyment in this movie was unexpected even though it was more than 2 hours and a half , i didn't get bored while watching it .Rachel zegler was the best choice for that role she killed her part and her acting and her singing made me love her even though i was one of her haters due to snow white's situation , i think i should watch the older hunger games movies because of this .I'm mad there are so many bad reviews avout this movie and it got only %68 on rotten tomatoes which is unfair for this beautiful and wonderful movie.

title: Fantastic movie all time
text: It's been some years since the franchise have us Mockingjay Part 2, my interest peaked at Catching Fire, but slowly diminished as it went on, I thought this looked recent from that trailer, for me though this was a bit of a damp squib, it wasn't bad, it just didn't hold my attention, a film I just couldn't get into.I had a feeling the film would struggle without Jennifer Lawrence, and it really did, I had no issues with Rachel Zegler's acting, indeed I thought the was rather good, but I couldn't attach to hers, or any of the characters, I just found them all a little anonymous, and almost impossible to empathise with.A mixed bag in terms of production, I thought some of the visuals were great, some terrific special effects, but all of that music, it just wasn't for me, I didn't quite see the appeal.

title: Suzanne Collins Eats Again
text: I was skeptical at first because I had heard a lot of hype about the movie and sometimes that can overhype it. This movie was phenomenal! A little different than the book which was disappointing but overall, an incredible addition to the Hunger Games Series. It provides so much context for the world of the Hunger Games and more background into the games and who President Snow was.I do want to emphasize that we never see or hear Snows inner monologue, which is crucial to understanding his character throughout the movie. Keep that in mind when watching that he is a horrible person LMFAO. It made the movie even better when I kept that in mind.The ending was also so incredible. Hope you guys like it when you watch!

title: It opened with a finishing touch
text: Without a doubt it is the best movie, it answers the questions you ask yourself with the other movies and in this film you fall in love with everything and you question the abuse of power from another perspective and you question why you are liking it.The concept of the color and the fact that of how the capitol is represented feels pretty "old" but actually or directly talking from the current present (2023) its not far away from the movie.The arena and the guns may have been the most interesting part of the hunger games because it was boring and this movie explains why things where like that, but it also explains how things are going to be.

title: Gripping from Start to Finish!
text: 'The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes' is a cinematic triumph that captivates from start to finish. Tom Blyth's portrayal of Coriolanus Snow is nothing short of extraordinary, showcasing his talent in a role that adds depth to the Hunger Games universe.This film is a standalone masterpiece, making it a compelling watch for both seasoned fans and newcomers to the Hunger Games series. The storytelling is riveting, complemented by Blyth's outstanding performance that elevates the movie to new heights.The seamless blend of drama, action, and a darkly atmospheric tone makes it my favourite installment in the Hunger Games franchise. The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is a must-see, delivering a cinematic experience that will leave you eager for more.

title: Nice movies
text: "Unveiling an intricate dance between suspense and emotion, the movie captivates audiences with its compelling narrative and stellar performances. The plot weaves a tapestry of unexpected twists, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats. The cinematography is a visual feast, seamlessly blending breathtaking landscapes with intense close-ups. The actors deliver powerful performances, breathing life into multifaceted characters. The film's soundtrack complements the storytelling, evoking a range of emotions. While some pacing issues may linger, they are overshadowed by the film's overall impact. A thought-provoking exploration of human nature, this movie leaves a lasting impression and sparks contemplation long after the credits roll."

title: Movie review and must watched movie
text: I'm really enjoyed this movie alot.The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes' follows a young Coriolanus (Tom Blyth) who is the last hope for his failing lineage, the once-proud Snow family that has fallen from grace in a post-war Capitol. With his livelihood threatened, Snow is reluctantly assigned to mentor Lucy Gray Baird (Rachel Zegler), a tribute from the impoverished District 12. But after Lucy Gray's charm captivates the audience of Panem, Snow sees an opportunity to shift their fates. With everything he has worked for hanging in the balance, Snow unites with Lucy Gray to turn the odds in their favor. Battling his instincts for both good and evil, Snow sets out on a race against time to survive and reveal if he will ultimately become a songbird or a snake.

title: Awesome
text: It was a great adaptation, the most faithful one since Catching Fire. Rachel Zegler is a great singer and a great actress. The songs are very important to the story, every song contains an important part of the movie ESPECIALLY the one she sings laying down by the lake.People need to actually pay attention to what they're watching.It was a great adaptation, the most faithful one since Catching Fire. The songs are very important to the story, every song contains an important part of the movie ESPECIALLY the one she sings laying down by the lake.People need to actually pay attention to what they're watching.

title: Hungry for More
text: Suzanne Collins does it again and therein lies what I feel seizes most of The Hunger Games success. The rest with Liongate who consistently take the written word and resist moulding it to their better judgment, chopping and changing what is so loved by its fans.I love this prequel equally to its proceeding trilogy and merely ask for more. More of Lucy Greys adventures, more of Snow and more of the world captured and created in mimic of a fallen Roman Empire.To begin with, the casting could not have been more masterfully crafted, Snow and Lucy were played in such a way that book and screen left no void. The score and musical numbers... yes, musical numbers, were performed effortlessly and seamlessly fell into the woven tapestry of Cornelius Snows story arch.Fantastic! Bravo! A needed watch!

title: Prequel, starts three years before the first Hunger Games.
text: Even though this is a prequel it is based on a book that was written most recently. It starts "three years before the first Hunger Games" and features a young boy named Coriolanus Snow. As we know from watching the Hunger Games movies starting in 2012, this character became the harsh President Snow. It is stated that this story takes place 65 years earlier and Sutherland, who plays the elder President Snow, would have been in his mid-70s when the series of movies started.Most of the story takes place during the 10th Hunger Games, so 13 years after the first scene in the movie, young Snow is now about 18 or 20.The two main characters are played by Rachel Zegler as Lucy Gray Baird, who is chosen from District 12 as one of the tributes, to fight to the death in the Games, held in a large enclosed domed arena. Her character is a singer and Zegler, who was so good as Maria in the most recent "West Side Story" movie, sings several original songs, done in a "folk song" style. It is a nice addition to the movie.The other is British actor Tom Blyth as Coriolanus Snow. Knowing he is British I tried hard to detect flaws in his American accent but I failed, he does it extremely well. As this story starts he is innocent and optimistic, he is assigned to protect and mentor Lucy Gray, he falls in love with her in the process. However as events and situations develop he begins to make more and more questionable decisions, ends up killing a few others, showing the development of the flawed character that was eventually become President Snow.All in all an interesting and mostly entertaining installment. My wife and I wached it at home on Blu-Ray, the sound and video are superb. The movie is 2 1/2 hours long, the disc has an additional 2 1/2 hours of various "making of" features. I watched some, but not all.
